Title: Behind the Art: Why was Pablo Picasso’s ‘Les Demoiselles d’Avignon’ so controversial in its time?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitAfter hundreds of sketches and several months of painting, Picasso changed the face of the Western art world by producing Les Demoiselles d'Avignon“Others have seen what is and asked why. I have seen what could be and asked why not.”This is a famous quote by Spanish painter Pablo Picasso, who always sought to look at art through a different lens. He painted Les Demoiselles d’Avignon in 1907, not knowing it would forever change the course of the art world. The painting, which is 8 feet long and 7 feet wide, depicts five naked women created from flat, jagged planes, their faces inspired by African masks and Iberian sculpture. This masterpiece gave birth to modern art and was the precursor to the style that became known as ‘Cubism’. The painting currently hangs in the Museum of Modern Art, New York City and has an estimated worth of about $1.2 billion. What is the significance of this artwork and why was it so controversial in its time?The story behind the artBefore Picasso started working on this grand masterpiece, he was going through what art critics now call the ‘blue period’. The term refers to the period when Picasso only used the colour blue in various shades to paint anything and everything. His agent struggled to sell his paintings but Picasso refused to touch any other colour between 1901 and 1904. When he did decide to finally look at other colours on a palette, he wanted to change the face of Western art. He started working on Les Demoiselles d’Avignon and this was a signal to the world that Cubism is coming and will be here to stay. He drew the first designs for Les Demoiselles d’Avignon in the winter of 1906-1907. The earliest sketches of this painting featured two men inside the brothel — a sailor and a medical student. It took Picasso hundreds of sketches and nine months to complete the painting on the canvas.Originally titled The Brothel of Avignon, this painting refers to a street in Barcelona called Carrer d’Avinyó, which was famous for its many brothels. Picasso looked at the notion of beauty unconventionally. He chose to not showcase the beauty of a woman as traditional European paintings did. The five figures shown in the painting are prostitutes who boldly stare back at the viewer. Their faces are painted using sharp geometric shapes and they appear slightly menacing along with their disjointed body shapes. The woman on the left has an Egyptian-style dress and facial features. Picasso was highly influenced by African art and masks and thus, used that as a reference.Controversy and impactThe world was not ready for Picasso’s new masterpiece. When the artist unveiled the painting in his studio, it remained there for quite some time and it was not well-liked. Only his intimate circle of friends, artists and dealers were allowed to see it. Matisse considered the work to be a ‘bad joke’. He believed Les Demoiselles d’Avignon undermined and mocked modern art. Despite his criticism, he borrowed aspects of this painting for his famous work Bathers with a Turtle. Most of Picasso’s friends were shocked by the obscenity of the painting. Undeterred by the reaction of his peers, he exhibited the painting for the first time in 1916 at the Salon d’Antin. The public deemed it to be immoral and the title of the painting had to be changed to Les Demoiselles d’Avignon from The Brothel of Avignon.Picasso never liked this title and often referred to the painting as ‘My Brothel’. Despite the widespread anger towards the painting, some art lovers did offer to buy it, but Picasso refused. He kept the painting with him till 1924 until his friends urged him to sell it to the designer Jacques Doucet for around 25,000 francs. Picasso however, did not need to sell anything by that time. He, after all, was one of the most famous artists at the time and could easily sell anything for a much higher price. The reason why he sold the painting for a lower price to Doucet was because Doucet promised he would hang the painting in the Louvre Museum, Paris. Before dying, however, Doucet never mentioned it in his will and chose to sell the painting to private collectors. In 1937, New York City’s Museum of Modern Art bought it for $24,000.Just like any change, this painting, too, took time to warm up to art lovers across the world. The art world did not begin to embrace the painting until early in the 1920s, when Andre Breton republished the photo in an article entitled, ‘The Wild Men of Paris: Matisse, Picasso and Les Fauves.’ Picasso would have never thought many would start studying this masterpiece to learn about the development of the Cubism movement and how modern art can depict a scene in several ways. He showcases how to grab the attention of the viewers and force them to look at the woman and their intense gazes. Les Demoiselles d’Avignon is an important piece of artwork in the history of Western Art. Pablo Picasso, along with Georges Braque, greatly shifted the way art had been moving and progressing, to new and interesting forms.Picasso opened the doors for artists to explore different styles to express themselves, and this alone is the biggest gift for any artist.Next Up in Behind the Art: Why is Portrait of Dr Gachet considered one of Van Gogh’s best works? Does it hold the answer to why he died by suicide a short time after painting it?Word count: 920Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Why is The Old Guitarist one of the most haunting pieces created during Pablo Picasso's 'Blue Period'?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPakistan, Aug. 22 -- The Old Guitarist is one of the most iconic and haunting pieces of Pablo Picasso's 'Blue Period' which is enriched by surrealism and symbolism.The artist painted this masterpiece during 1903-1904, a period during which he was going through emotional turmoil and poverty. Made using oil on canvas, this painting is huge and measures 48 3/8 x 32 1/2 inches, roughly four by 2 2/3 feet. It is also notable for the ghostly presence of a mysterious image painted underneath. Currently gracing the walls of the Art Institute of Chicago, USA, it is worth more than $100,000,000. It is safe to say that The Old Guitarist is a priceless piece of art by the master of Cubism and Surrealism, but what is the real story behind the art? What is the mysterious image painted underneath?When Picasso started working on this grand masterpiece, he was going through what art critics now call the 'Blue period'. The term refers to the period when Picasso only used the colour blue in various shades as well as greys and blacks to paint anything and everything. His agent struggled to sell his paintings but he refused to touch any other colour between 1901 and 1904. The Old Guitarist was painted in 1903, just after the suicide death of Picasso's close friend Casagemas. Carles Antoni Cosme Damia Casagemas I Coll was a Spanish painter and poet who committed suicide in a Paris cafe, during a farewell dinner party he held for himself. This incident remained with Picasso for life and he dedicated several paintings to his friend. At the same time, the artist was nearly penniless and knew how it was like to be impoverished. He felt excluded from society and was sympathetic to the plight of those cast out of society such as the poor, prostitutes and the ill. Thus, Picasso chose to use the colour blue to communicate the pain and desolation that he was feeling at the time. During the 'Blue Period', he continued to feature outcasts as the subject matter of his paintings. He also included subjects that were considered exiles and recluses, such as drunkards, the homeless, and of course, individuals that were struggling to keep up with the pressures of day-to-day life.The Old Guitarist was made during the peak of Picasso's 'Blue Period' in Madrid Spain. Also known as 'The Blind Guitarist', it shows a skinny old man whose bones are visible. He can be seen latching on to his guitar despite his weak state. His skin is pale blue and his clothes are torn. His sad state is further highlighted by his blindness, the isolation, and the atmosphere which surrounds him. The man's guitar is painted using brown - a colour that represents hope in Picasso's mind. He wanted to showcase how the guitar is the only hope for survival for the man in the painting and how dependent he is on it.Although Picasso is clearly showing the world how lower-class societies suffer every day, some believe that he used the old man as the subject of his artwork to represent the isolation that most artists observe. Society often isolates artists even though it is art and culture that brings together people. This represents Picasso's criticism of society as well as the reality of human existence.During his 'Blue Period', Picasso covered sketches on canvases possibly due to poverty and not enough canvases available on hand. The Old Guitarist has intrigued researchers for a long time because of the sketches hidden behind the main figure in the painting. Recent x-rays by curators found three figures behind the guitarist's body. The three figures are a young mother with a small child kneeling by her side and an animal on the right side of the canvas; an old woman with her head bent forward. The young mother in the painting has long dark hair and a thoughtful expression. No one to date knows why he chose to not complete those sketches and instead painted The Old Guitarist. However, this is not an uncommon practice. Artists tend to change their minds about their subjects all the time and Picasso was known to paint subjects that emotionally moved him. It is speculated that he may have drawn upon George Frederic Watts's 1886 painting of Hope, which also depicts a hunched, helpless musician with a distorted angular form using a blue tone.Picasso's 'Blue Period' began with the painting Casagemas in His Coffin, which was a painting showing his friend lying in a coffin after he committed suicide. After that, he made several paintings that showed despair and sorrow, all of which are scattered around the world. The Old Guitarist, however, remains to be the most popular piece of artwork. The Art Institute of Chicago acquired the piece in 1926 in what turned out to be a pivotal moment for the artist. The Old Guitarist became Picasso's first painting to be acquired by an American museum and it was also the first Picasso painting that any museum in the world acquired for its permanent collection.?Over time, the painting has influenced several artists of all backgrounds. Paul McCartney drew from the painting when creating a chord progression. It is this progression and McCartney's accompanying melody that became his contributions to the 2015 Kanye West song "All Day"Art critics could write endless books on why The Old Guitarist is so iconic even now. However, even those who hold no knowledge of art truly appreciate this piece due to the use of melancholy colours and the bony structure of a man who is latching on to his guitar.Published by HT Digital Content Services with permission from Daily Times.Word count: 942Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Sell the Picasso - Pablo's paintings might be falling out of favour in the rich art world
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitMILLIONAIRES, billionaires and art collectors - you might soon consider it wise to remove that Picasso from your wall and refrain from bidding for the artist's work at the next auction. Although he was considered the most influential artist of the 20th century - and the top-seller, too, with his painting, Les Femmes d'Alger, selling for a record $179.4m (€163m) - dealers now say the Picasso market is about to decline. The Spaniard, who is considered the "gold standard" in modern painting, is beginning to appear out of kilter with the times.Younger artists have turned against him, according to art expert Ben Luke, and his private life has come under censure.A major exhibition in Brooklyn this June, staged by feminist Hannah Gadsby, will question Picasso's links to "misogyny and masculinity". His frequent cheating on his wives and fathering children by different women are no longer admired as excusable macho behaviour. He seduced one of his mistresses, Marie-Therese Walter, when she was 17 (he was 45) In a portrait, he placed an image of an erect penis in her left cheek.His best-known lover, Françoise Gilot, now 101 and an accomplished painter herself, has said Picasso was the ultimate male chauvinist to whom nobody ever said no. (She had two children with him, and they claimed he ignored them.) He was, she said, utterly selfish.In France, where Picasso lived (until he died in 1973, aged 91) his treatment of women would then have been excused as "tempérament d'artiste", yet the truth is that great artists, writers and musicians are not always nice people. Patricia Highsmith, the American thriller writer, was described by her own publisher as "a mean, cruel, hard, unlovable and unloving human being", she "stole rich, classy blondes" from their husbands, and then dumped them; and a vile racist. She made appalling remarks about the Holocaust. She also disliked black people, and was averse to Latinos, Koreans, Indians and Christians.And yet, Highsmith is revered as an amazing writer: her novel The Talented Mr Ripley has been filmed five times, and a new screen version with Andrew Scott, will be on Netflix later this year. And there's a cinema documentary currently screening called Loving Highsmith.Bad behaviour is not in short supply among geniuses and people of towering talent. Lucien Freud was another artist to whom it seems "no one ever said no". Although involved in a homosexual love-triangle in his twenties, he went on to father 14 acknowledged children by different lovers; it's been suggested the true number could be more than 40.Eric Gill, the sculptor, whose stunning work adorns the BBC's Broadcasting House in London - and several Oxford colleges - sexually abused his daughters and his sister. There's an ongoing debate as to whether Gill's work should be removed.In Lourdes, currently, there's also a debate as to whether the mosaics of Father Marko Rupnik should be removed from the pilgrimage site (and from churches globally). His mosaics of The Luminous Mysteries of the Rosary were added to the Basilica's facade in 2008, but he has recently been suspended from ministry because of accusations of sexually and psychologically abusing women.How to separate the man - or woman - from the work has been debated for some time. It was sometimes dubbed "The Wagner Question", when it became known that Richard Wagner was idolised by Hitler (and Wagner himself had been a poisonous anti-Semite). Should he be banned? Despite his odious views, some musicians have concluded not, while others have been adamant that he should.The debate has become more pertinent today, when the personal failings of renowned individuals are more exposed by modern media.Moreover, when it comes to misogyny, women now are less tolerant of giving a moral pass to someone like Picasso, simply because he was a great artist.And yet, Françoise Gilot herself says that sometimes a great artist must have a great ego - he has to be "100 times more selfish" than others, because he must see himself as "100 times greater".In normal life, we call that "entitlement", but the genius thinks of himself as justifiably entitled.Watch the prices in the Picasso market just the same.CREDIT: Mary KennyCAPTION: Selfish: Spanish artist Pablo Picasso has been described as the ultimate male chauvinist to whom nobody ever said no. Title: Behind the Art: What is the story behind Pablo Picasso’s Le Rêve which is worth $155 million?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitBehind the Art: Le Rêve, also known as The Dream, is one of the most expensive paintings ever sold by Pablo Picasso. What is the story behind this painting and why is it so significant?Le Rêve, also known as The Dream, is one of the most expensive paintings ever sold by Pablo Picasso. The painting was sold privately for $155 million on March 26, 2013, and is known for its contrasted colours and oversimplified outlines as it belongs to Picasso’s period of distorted depictions. Made in 1932 using oil on canvas, Picasso then 50 years old, portrayed his 22-year-old mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter. Critics have pointed out that Picasso painted an erect penis, presumably to represent his own, in the upturned face of his model, highlighting the painting’s erotic content. But what is the story behind this painting and why is it so significant?Story Behind the ArtEveryone by now is aware of the troubled relationship between Pablo Picasso and his muse Marie-Thérèse Walter but what came out of their affair were several masterpieces by the Spanish artist. Walter was almost 30 years Picasso’s junior when they first met in 1927. Before Walter became pregnant and the affair was discovered by Picasso’s wife, Olga, the artist and his muse engaged in a covert affair for more than eight years. Picasso was also having an affair with Dora Maar at the time. The artist suggested that the two of his muses compete for his love. Until the beginning of the 1940s, Walter continued to collaborate with Picasso. The painting of Marie-Thérèse that Picasso called “Le Rêve” is from the time when he painted distorted depictions of his subjects using contrasted colours and simple, clean outlines. In 1941, it was first sold for $7,000, and in 1997, at an auction hosted by Christie’s, it was purchased for $48.4 million.What does the painting represent?According to several critics, the upturned face of this portrait suggests that the artist is creating an abstract version of his penis. This kind of abstract eroticism can be seen in Georgia O’Keeffe’s and many other well-known 20th-century paintings. The Dream was finished just two weeks before Marie-Thérèse showed up in Reading. She is shown in asleep in an armchair. The colour scheme used here, which Picasso used in a lot of his work around this time, gives the impression of sensuality. The composition was completed with strong lines and soft pastel colours, which exuded a contemporary vibe. The sharp lines he uses to show her fingers and the fine detail in the background will make some people think of Henri Matisse’s Music and The Dance paintings. As the young lady sleeps, the revealing pose suggests sexuality and vulnerability. Here, Picasso faithfully depicts her renowned long blonde hair by using yellow to contrast aggressively with the darker background. Her beaded necklace, which is delicately balanced on her meditative chest, then repeats the hues of red and yellow. Perhaps this scene reveals the young woman’s hair, curved figure, and undeniable beauty, which attracted her elderly lover the most. The domestic setting of this scene should suggest comfort and privacy, a private moment between these two passionate lovers. Although many people consider this to be a cubist piece, it can be argued that it was part of his surrealist period, and the colour scheme suggests fauvism. Picasso was breaking new ground in art history at this time, necessitating new classifications because of his distinctive ideas and styles that produced art in previously unheard-of ways.Controversy and Wynn incidentNo famous painting is complete without a little bit of controversy. Controversies help garner talk about the artist and his work and help the artworks stay alive centuries later. The fact that Picasso has depicted an erect penis over the face of a woman has caused a little controversy over time. It is common for artists to include hidden messages, concepts, or designs in their paintings, and the painting’s apparent similarity encourages critics to believe that Picasso drew his penis. This could represent sex itself or the model’s possession or influence by the artist.And then there is the Wynn incident. A six-inch tear in the middle of the left side of the painting was caused by one of the previous owners striking his elbow on the canvas. Due to the owner’s name, the incident was dubbed the Wynn incident, and it also significantly decreased the value of the painting itself. Wynn had announced to a group of his friends in October 2006 that he had agreed to sell Le Rêve to Steve Cohen for $139 million and then according to sources, Wynn put his right elbow through the canvas while he was showing the painting to his friends, presumably about to reveal the now officially undisclosed previous owner. After a $90,000 repair, the painting was re-valued at $85 million, as Wynn later stated that he took the event as a warning not to sell it.However, the painting’s legacy and controversy are so great that even though the tear was patched up later, people still considered it valuable and the painting was purchased by SAC Capital’s Steven A. Cohen for $155 million, according to the New York Post on March 26, 2013.Word count: 863Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Behind the Art: Is Garçon à la pipe (Boy with a Pipe),1905 by Pablo Picasso worth $104,168,000?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPablo Picasso painted his fifth highest-selling painting Garçon à la pipe (Boy with a Pipe) when he was 24 years old in 1905. Why did Picasso choose to paint this? Is it worth $104 million?Pablo Picasso painted his fifth highest-selling painting Garçon à la pipe (Boy with a Pipe) when he was 24 years old in 1905. This masterpiece was created during his Rose Period, soon after he settled in the Montmartre section of Paris, France. This oil on canvas painting depicts a Parisian boy holding a pipe in his left hand and wearing a garland or wreath of flowers. The artwork is listed as one of the most expensive paintings, after being sold at Sotheby’s auction for $104 million on 5 May 2004 and is currently a part of a private collection. Why did Picasso choose to paint this? Is it worth $104 million?Story behind the art and the boy with a pipePicasso was not always so well known and liked during his initial years of being an artist. In 1905 at the age of 24, he was still a struggling artist who was living in poverty in a dilapidated artist building n Montmartre in Paris. He had recently moved on from his Blue Period in which he only painted using blue and green hues. He was now in a new and more optimistic phase known as his Rose period. He wanted to use more colours other than blue on the canvas and his subject for this painting was a local boy named P’tit Louis who died at a young age. Very little is known about the boy and his background. According to a variety of sources, the boy was a model in his teen years who hung around Picasso’s studio and volunteered to pose for the oil work. Picasso’s comments about the boy were that he was one of the “local types, actors, ladies, gentlemen, delinquents… He stayed there, sometimes the whole day. He watched me work. He loved that. ” It was clear that either Picasso did not want the world to know who the boy was or he did not know the boy himself. However, as an artist, he spent a lot of time deciding on the position in which he wanted to paint the boy. After much repositioning of the model, Picasso decided to go with the boy sitting down, holding a pipe. The boy is dressed in blue overalls and wears a garland of roses on his head. André Salmon, a friend of Picasso, described in 1912 how he had altered what was originally a study of life into the current artwork in a sudden flash of inspiration by adding the flowers.”One night, Picasso abandoned the company of his friends and their intellectual chit-chat. He returned to his studio, took the canvas he had abandoned a month before and crowned the figure of the little apprentice lad with roses. He had made this work a masterpiece thanks to a sublime whim.”Picasso’s rendering of “P’tit Louis” also has elements of classical art. He was inspired by the work of the French Neoclassical painter Ingres. Like Picasso’s Young Girl with a Flower Basket, which was painted in the same year, Garçon à la Pipe conveys conflicting imagery of innocence and experience. Picasso described the boy as an “evil angel”. In this painting, the boy wears a garland of roses on his head to symbolise the blood of the Eucharist, a reference to the transition from youth to maturity. Picasso also depicts the contrast between the harsh street life that Louis endured and the innocence of his youth.Criticism and impact on popular cultureThe painting was first bought by John Hay Whitney in 1950 for $30,000 and then on May 5, 2004, the painting was sold for US$104,168,000 at Sotheby’s auction in New York City. Sotheby’s did not reveal the name of the buyer though sources say that it was Guido Barilla, owner of the Barilla Group. At the time, it broke the record for the amount paid for an auctioned painting. The jaw-dropping price of the painting made several art historians question its worth. Many art critics have stated that the high sale price of Garçon à la pipe has much more to do with the artist’s name than with the merit or historical importance of the painting. According to news reports, Picasso expert Pepe Karmel, reached New York the morning after the sale and was stunned to hear about the price. He was quoted to say “that a pleasant, minor painting could command a price appropriate to a real masterwork by Picasso. This just shows how much the marketplace is divorced from the true values of art.” However, some genuinely appreciate this painting and say it celebrates images of adolescent beauty and is one of the most beautiful paintings of Picasso’s Rose Period.Whether Picasso wanted to merely practice portrait painting or change the landscape of modern art, as a 24-year-old poor artist he would have never thought his painting would sell for such a high price. The painting’s worth not only shocked art critics but also sent shock waves through the entertainment industry. Calvin Harris’ 2017 song “Slide” contains the lyrics “I might empty my bank account and buy that boy with a pipe”. Vocalist Frank Ocean explained that it is an allusion to, “a Picasso painting that sold for so much money”. It is quite evident that regardless of the historical importance and relevance of the painting, owning a Picasso painting is a status symbol of its own.Next up in Behind the Art: What is the significance of Picasso’s Dora Maar au Chat which is currently the sixth highest-selling painting by the artist?Word count: 948Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Behind the Art: Why is The Old Guitarist one of the most haunting pieces created during Pablo Picasso’s ‘Blue Period’?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitThe Old Guitarist is one of the most iconic and haunting pieces of Pablo Picasso’s ‘Blue Period’ which is enriched by surrealism and symbolism. The artist painted this masterpiece during 1903-1904, a period during which he was going through emotional turmoil and poverty. Made using oil on canvas, this painting is huge and measures 48 3/8 x 32 1/2 inches, roughly four by 2 2/3 feet. It is also notable for the ghostly presence of a mysterious image painted underneath. Currently gracing the walls of the Art Institute of Chicago, USA, it is worth more than $100,000,000. It is safe to say that The Old Guitarist is a priceless piece of art by the master of Cubism and Surrealism, but what is the real story behind the art? What is the mysterious image painted underneath?Picasso’s ‘Blue Period’ and the paintingWhen Picasso started working on this grand masterpiece, he was going through what art critics now call the ‘Blue period’. The term refers to the period when Picasso only used the colour blue in various shades as well as greys and blacks to paint anything and everything. His agent struggled to sell his paintings but he refused to touch any other colour between 1901 and 1904. The Old Guitarist was painted in 1903, just after the suicide death of Picasso’s close friend Casagemas. Carles Antoni Cosme Damià Casagemas I Coll was a Spanish painter and poet who committed suicide in a Paris cafe, during a farewell dinner party he held for himself. This incident remained with Picasso for life and he dedicated several paintings to his friend. At the same time, the artist was nearly penniless and knew how it was like to be impoverished. He felt excluded from society and was sympathetic to the plight of those cast out of society such as the poor, prostitutes, and the ill. Thus, Picasso chose to use the colour blue to communicate the pain and desolation that he was feeling at the time. During the ‘Blue Period’, he continued to feature outcasts as the subject matter of his paintings. He also included subjects that were considered exiles and recluses, such as drunkards, the homeless, and of course, individuals that were struggling to keep up with the pressures of day-to-day life.The Old Guitarist was made during the peak of Picasso’s ‘Blue Period’ in Madrid Spain. Also known as ‘The Blind Guitarist’, it shows a skinny old man whose bones are visible. He can be seen latching on to his guitar despite his weak state. His skin is pale blue and his clothes are torn. His sad state is further highlighted by his blindness, the isolation, and the atmosphere which surrounds him. The man’s guitar is painted using brown – a colour that represents hope in Picasso’s mind. He wanted to showcase how the guitar is the only hope for survival for the man in the painting and how dependent he is on it.Although Picasso is clearly showing the world how lower-class societies suffer every day, some believe that he used the old man as the subject of his artwork to represent the isolation that most artists observe. Society often isolates artists even though it is art and culture that brings together people. This represents Picasso’s criticism of society as well as the reality of human existence.Mysterious images underneath The Old GuitaristDuring his ‘Blue Period’, Picasso covered sketches on canvases possibly due to poverty and not enough canvases available on hand. The Old Guitarist has intrigued researchers for a long time because of the sketches hidden behind the main figure in the painting. Recent x-rays by curators found three figures behind the guitarist’s body. The three figures are a young mother with a small child kneeling by her side and an animal on the right side of the canvas; an old woman with her head bent forward. The young mother in the painting has long dark hair and a thoughtful expression. No one to date knows why he chose to not complete those sketches and instead painted The Old Guitarist. However, this is not an uncommon practice. Artists tend to change their minds about their subjects all the time and Picasso was known to paint subjects that emotionally moved him. It is speculated that he may have drawn upon George Frederic Watts’s 1886 painting of Hope, which also depicts a hunched, helpless musician with a distorted angular form using a blue tone.Popularity and impact on Modern CulturePicasso’s ‘Blue Period’ began with the painting Casagemas in His Coffin, which was a painting showing his friend lying in a coffin after he committed suicide. After that, he made several paintings that showed despair and sorrow, all of which are scattered around the world. The Old Guitarist, however, remains to be the most popular piece of artwork. The Art Institute of Chicago acquired the piece in 1926 in what turned out to be a pivotal moment for the artist. The Old Guitarist became Picasso’s first painting to be acquired by an American museum and it was also the first Picasso painting that any museum in the world acquired for its permanent collection. Over time, the painting has influenced several artists of all backgrounds. Paul McCartney drew from the painting when creating a chord progression. It is this progression and McCartney’s accompanying melody that became his contributions to the 2015 Kanye West song “All Day”Art critics could write endless books on why The Old Guitarist is so iconic even now. However, even those who hold no knowledge of art truly appreciate this piece due to the use of melancholy colours and the bony structure of a man who is latching on to his guitar.Next Up in Behind the Art: How did Gustav Klimt’s iconic “Kiss” spark a sexual revolution in art? Why is the painting so iconic?Word count: 968Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Si Newhouse's Collection Sells for $178 Million; Seven trophies by artists such as Willem de Kooning and Pablo Picasso sell for more than $10 million apiece at Christie's sale
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitA $25 million Pablo Picasso. A $31 million Willem de Kooning. A $35 million Francis Bacon. Anyone worried that the art market might plummet following recent bank failures and broader economic uncertainty can exhale—for now.On Thursday, Christie's kicked off New York's spring sale series with a $178 million sale of art from the estate of the late Condé Nast chairman Samuel Irving Newhouse Jr. Of the 16 pieces in the cache, seven works crossed the $10 million mark. Christie's performance suggests that collectors still feel safe splurging on art trophies vouched for by a tastemaker like Newhouse, who went by Si.Christie's knew it had a hard act to follow after last fall's historic $1.6 billion estate sale of Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen , so it sought out another name with similar collector heft and a proven record of drawing bids. Thursday marked the third time Mr. Newhouse's estate has plied pieces into sales since he died six years ago at age 89—a strategy of trickling artworks onto the marketplace rather than seeking to unload them all at once. The latest batch was expected to sell for between $142 million and $202 million.A 1947 Willem de Kooning, "Orestes," that Mr. Newhouse won for $13.2 million in 2002 resold for $31 million. It was estimated to sell for at least $25 million. Christie's bumped up its estimate for Bacon's 1969 "Self Portrait" from $20 million to $22 million ahead of the sale and sold for $35 million. The media mogul paid $8.9 million for the portrait in 2006.A trio of Jasper Johns works in the estate underperformed. The artist's 1971 "Decoy," a graphic overlay of some of his best-known motifs, sold for $10.7 million. It was estimated to sell for at least $14 million. And Johns's crosshatched abstract from 1979, "Cicada," sold for $6.8 million, under its $7 million low estimate.And then there was Picasso's rainbow-hue portrait from 1937, "L'Arlésienne (Lee Miller)," that sold for $25 million. It was expected to sell for at least $20 million.Following the Newhouse estate auction, Christie's continued with an evening sale of 20th-century art from other owners, including several landscapes from Mr. Allen's estate. The house expected the billionaire's collection of scenery to sell for $30 million. Several pieces pushed the collective total to $89 million—including Georgia O'Keeffe's 1930 "White Calico Rose," which sold for $13 million and David Hockney's 2000 garden view, "The Gate," which sold for $14.7 million.There is a backlog of estate material in this spring's sales, partially because Mr. Allen's estate took up so much room in last fall's auction catalogs. Caroline Sayan, an art adviser with advisory firm Cadell, said more estates are also expected to hit the marketplace in the coming years as a generation of postwar and baby boomer collectors die and millennials make their mark.Ms. Sayan said a steady pipeline of estates is typically a boon to auctions because such troves have often been hidden away for years—but they are landing as the marketplace is also undergoing a generational taste shift among younger buyers who want a broader canon of artists.One notable casualty was a pink Picasso portrait of his mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter that was estimated to sell for at least $20 million yet stalled and went unsold. A few years ago, collectors paid a premium for anything he painted that included the same subject matter. Another Picasso, "Still Life at the Window," which once belonged to dealer Jan Krugier, came up for bid with a $40 million estimate and sold following meager bidding for $41.8 million."Who is the next bidder and what do they want?" Ms. Sayan said. "That's what auction houses are asking now."One artist who appears to be weathering this generational reckoning: Ed Ruscha, whose 1966-1969's "Burning Gas Station" from the estate of Chicago commodities trader Alan Press and his wife, Dorothy sold for $22.3 million at Christie's on Thursday. The Ruscha was estimated to sell for $20 million.And rarity remains a perennial draw: Collectors flocked to Henri Rousseau's 1910 "Flamingos," a whimsical scene that arrived at the sale with a record-level asking price of at least $20 million—nearly five times the artist's auction high bar. A telephone bidder smashed that by ultimately winning it for $44 million.Rousseau is best known for his fantastical jungle scenes, but this piece likely got a boost in part because his works rarely come up for bid at all. Plus, this menagerie hailed from the estate of the late Payne Whitney Middleton, whose late brother John Hay Whitney once served as president of New York's Museum of Modern Art.Additional sales by Christie's, Sotheby's and Phillips scheduled for next week will offer a further gauge of the market's trajectory.Write to Kelly Crow at kelly.crow@wsj.com MORE IN ART & AUCTIONSCredit: By Kelly Crow Word count: 808Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Who's afraid of Pablo Picasso?: [SURVEYS EDITION]
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitA Life of Picasso Volume III: The Triumphant Years 1917-1932by John RichardsonCape Pounds 30, 555 pagesFT bookshop price: Pounds 24In a lifetime devoted to testing the representational values of form, Picasso famously broke the spirit of anyone close to him, just as he carved and distorted the human figure on canvas. The miracle is that he has found in John Richardson a biographer great enough to stand up to, as well as for, him.The Triumphant Years, the third of four volumes, confirms this life of Picasso as an unrivalled masterpiece among artists' biographies: definitive, insightful, non-judgmental, unprecedented in detail, wearing its learning lightly, and an enormous, gossipy pleasure to read. That is true of all of its volumes, but at the heart of this one is an especially irresistible human story: how Picasso triumphed as the leader of the modern movement through an art which engaged intensely, though very differently, with his love for two women.Richardson opens with Picasso's courtship of his chilly Russian wife, Olga, in 1917 and ends with paintings of predatory physicality from 1931-32 depicting Marie-Therese Walter, the teenager he picked up outside Galeries Lafayette, who inspired ''the most ecstatic and celebratory images of the sexual act by a great artist''.This period of Picasso's work is rich, complex and fascinating. ''La Lampe'' (1931), an iconic painting of a plaster head of Marie- Therese at the studio door in Picasso's country mansion Boisgeloup, implies, says Richardson, ''that although Olga was the chatelaine of Boisgeloup, Marie-Therese, wreathed in tendrils of philodendron, was queen of the sculpture studio''.Olga's reign has intrigued scholars just as it upset the bohemian friends who watched aghast as she decked her husband in stiff suits and held court in pristine apartments bearing no sign of easel or canvas, and attended by white-gloved butlers: ''not the slightest disorder, not a grain of dust.''Picasso had met Olga on the rebound from a wartime affair when he travelled to Rome to work for Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. Olga, a dancer, was not easily seduced. Diaghilev warned of national prudery - ''une Russe on l'epouse'' - but in Barcelona, Picasso proudly paraded Olga on the Ramblas. Their 1918 wedding was a farce to which the ballerina, crippled by an accident, hobbled on a stick; she never danced again.Richardson reckons that for Picasso, ''bourgeois impersonation was partly an act'', typifying his ''penchant for self-mockery''. ''Comedia!'' he muttered, seeing himself in the mirror at Olga's soirees.In the portraits of Olga, however, there was no mockery. Instead, they embody the return to classicism with which Picasso led the 1920s avant-garde. Their apparent volte-face from cubism left fans ''in a state of resentful confusion'' which Picasso enjoyed: the adoring Jean Cocteau stayed away long enough for Picasso to miss ''having him around to mock, outwit and torture''.Like everything in this classicising epoch, the Olga portraits speak of Picasso's engagement with his place in art history. In 1925 he sold ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon'' for a paltry FFr25,000; conventional Olga wanted the disorientating masterwork out of the house at any price, but the clincher was that the collector, Jacques Doucet, promised (falsely) to leave the work to the Louvre. The money funded Olga's lavish tastes, but her melancholy, already visible in paintings from 1919 on, deepened. Meanwhile, this phase of Picasso's art had run its course.As Picasso undid the female body all over again, unravelling the contours of his sleepy, docile young lover in ravishing contortions, Richardson argues that his demonic exploitation of Marie-Therese's bright innocence must be seen ''in the darkness of his lifelong grief at the death of his beloved younger sister, Conchita, all those years before in La Corunna'' - when he made a pact with God to abandon painting if the child were spared.The Marie-Therese paintings arch back, through Picasso's classicism and cubism, to childhood terrors and superstitions, and forward - to 1930s deconstructions culminating in ''Guernica'', and beyond.The scale - artistic, psychological, historical - of the author's achievement here is daunting; all other Picasso biographers and memoirists have been overawed into hagiography or frightened into cha-racter assassination. Richardson, a magisterial writer, brilliant critic and deliriously funny raconteur, is a unique, dazzling match for his subject.Jackie Wullschlager is the FT's chief art critic.Word count: 717Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: From the Vollard Suite by Pablo Picasso, 1934: Snapshot
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitBeneath a star-studded sky, a blind, stumbling minotaur is led by a girl carrying a dove. Behind them, two fishermen haul nets. The above etching, an aquatint, is the 97th in a series of 100 etchings commissioned in 1930 from Pablo Picasso by art dealer Ambroise Vollard, and completed over the course of seven years.Grounded in classical mythology and surrealism, the Vollard Suite features two main motifs: the sculptor in his studio and the minotaur - a monstrous creature, half-man, half-bull, that Picasso used to depict his predatory alter-ego.In this print, along with the other four last works in the series, the previously raging minotaur is powerful no more. Anguished and pitiful, it is reliant on the girl for guidance. With her classically beautiful features, she is thought to portray Picasso's muse Marie-Therese Walter, the 17-year-old who supplanted his wife in his affections in the late 1920s.Redolent of tragedy and suffering, the minotaur can also be seen as an allegory of the darkening political situation in Europe in the 1930s, with the approach of the Spanish civil war and the growth of fascism.Displayed with prints by Rembrandt and Goya that inspired Picasso, including Goya's rarely seen Bulls of Bordeaux series, the Vollard Suite is at the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College, New Hampshire, until December 20. Title: Getting intimate with Pablo Picasso: [ONT Edition]
Full Article: AbstractSombre colours dominate the show, more like Paris in late winter than the Mediterranean under a noonday sun. There are black blues, ghastly whites, ruddy browns, bold black outlines and wintry shadows - as in Portrait de [Jacqueline Picasso] au rocking-chair et au foulard noir (Jacqueline l'echarpe noire) (1954) - which seem to shrowd everything in a dark fog.The town near Mt. Sainte-Victoire in Aix-en-Provence where Picasso and Jacqueline eventually settled, seems un-Mediterranean in Picasso's cool Le Village de Vauvenargues (April 29, 1959), with its dark greens, bland yellows and sharp hills outlined in thick jolts of black.Picasso presented many of his portraits, often in her favourite pose - seated, with her arms folded around her bent knees - as presents to her, with little notes attached, such as "Pour ma femme Jacqueline le 24.2.65" or "Pour Jacqueline pour sa fte, son mari." MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. This functionality is provided solely for your convenience and is in no way intended to replace human translation. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitJacqueline Picasso (nee Roque), the second wife of Pablo Picasso, was found dead October 15 at Mougins on the French Riviera with a bullet in her head. She was 59.Picasso, who died in 1973, married her in 1961, when he was 79 years old and she was 35. She was a Paris-born divorcee and former dance teacher when she met Picasso, becoming his companion and the model for some fine portraits.Obituary in The Times (London), Oct.17, 1986Even when you're about to be buried they'll dig your reputation a little deeper."Picasso Intime La Collection de Jacqueline," is the finest small show in Paris right now, in the most congenial new space, la Pinacotheque de Paris, just off a nondescript street with the too- promising name of rue de Paradis.As its brochure admits, the Pinacotheque - in what used to be the factory/showroom for Baccarat crystal - is "derriere les Grands Boulevards." In other words it's as next to nowhere as you can get in this city.Yet with "Picasso Intime," the Pinacotheque is muscling up against the Centre Pompidou, with its newly minted Joan Mir exhibition, "1917-1934 La Naissance du monde," and the rest of the major galleries closer to the city centre, by asking questions about one of the more fractious art mysteries of the last century.Who was Jacqueline? What was she? Was she merely a canny gold digger who married Pablo Picasso for his spectacular fortune? She did eventually end up with some $48 million (U.S.), long after she ruined his apparently stable relationship with Francoise Gilot, the artist's mistress for many years.Gilot's 1965 response in her bestselling and self-serving autobiography, Life With Picasso, so infuriated the artist that he cut off all ties to Claude and Paloma, his two illegitimate children with Gilot, and erased them out of his will.The above scenario apparently was on the mind of the Times' obituary writer who reminded the reader that Jacqueline was a "Paris-born divorcee" and "former dancer," attributes clearly meant to cast shadows on her honour. Jacqueline did little to distance herself from her wicked stepmother reputation when she barred Paloma and Claude from attending their father's funeral."Picasso Intime" tells another story, too - in fact several other stories.Primarily it shows Picasso's fascination with Jacqueline, her dark eyes and high cheekbones, her Spanish features. Her looks were in synch with Picasso's creativity as he revisited his early days, his Spanish roots and the works of mentor-figure painters such as Eugene Delacroix and Diego Velazquez.Jacqueline wasn't particularly tall. But in the many portraits that act as silent sentinels as you move through the exhibition, she's shown nobly, seeming larger than life.Picasso viewed old age moodily. In 1963, Georges Braque and Jean Cocteau, colleagues from his earliest days in Paris, both died. And to a great degree it was Jacqueline who helped him keep going - something she was unable to do for herself following his death, when her drinking grew worse and worse, the demons in her head closed in and she threatened suicide.Sombre colours dominate the show, more like Paris in late winter than the Mediterranean under a noonday sun. There are black blues, ghastly whites, ruddy browns, bold black outlines and wintry shadows - as in Portrait de Jacqueline au rocking-chair et au foulard noir (Jacqueline l'echarpe noire) (1954) - which seem to shrowd everything in a dark fog.The town near Mt. Sainte-Victoire in Aix-en-Provence where Picasso and Jacqueline eventually settled, seems un-Mediterranean in Picasso's cool Le Village de Vauvenargues (April 29, 1959), with its dark greens, bland yellows and sharp hills outlined in thick jolts of black.Your only hit of sun and glamour comes ahead of the main exhibition, in a photo display of images taken in the area around Cannes, where Picasso and Jacqueline had earlier set up house before moving to Aix. These shots reveal a sun-drenched Cote d'Azur, where the happy couple play with their animals, including the artist's beloved goat Biquette; clowns around for the camera; and welcomes the rich and the famous, including matador Luis Miguel Dominguin.But it was Jacqueline's attention Pablo sought. Increasingly her role in his life was keeping away all the strangers while he worked, even if they weren't really strangers.Picasso presented many of his portraits, often in her favourite pose - seated, with her arms folded around her bent knees - as presents to her, with little notes attached, such as "Pour ma femme Jacqueline le 24.2.65" or "Pour Jacqueline pour sa fte, son mari."Also among the presents were early works, such as a young and intense Auto portrait (1917) where he shows himself sitting with his sketchpad on his knee. Clearly this gift was his way of bringing himself closer to her in terms of age.Even his later self-portraits or self-portraits in disguise - Picasso as a matador or as the 17th-century figure in Homme en habit XVII siecle au fond bleu (1967) - were his way of explaining himself to her."I paint," he said, "the way others write their autobiography."While the show lacks some of the more substantial later works such as Young Bather With Sand Shovel (1971), it nevertheless bustles with a vitality few older artists can match. Jacqueline could take some measure of credit that "late Picasso" wasn't "forgotten Picasso."So "Picasso Intime" may put a dent in Picasso's life-long reputation as a sexist misogynist who got his Hollywood-style comeuppance in Surviving Picasso, the James Ivory-directed rant where Anthony Hopkins plays the artist as pig and Natascha McElhone plays Gilot, the woman victim who came to hate him.It will be a small dent, though. If Picasso's women got burned by getting close to him, he felt equally burned in return. His first marriage to ballerina Olga Koklova became so self-destructive he imagined its brutal fury with Self-Portrait And Monster (1910). For most of the other women in his life, he was the monster.Not to Jacqueline, though. "Picasso Intime" also has work representing his many mistresses, from Fernande Olivier to Marie- Therese Walter to Dora Maar (Gilot is missing).In keeping these portraits, Jacqueline was clearly trying to cast herself above all those who had gone before by proving she could handle her husband's fascination with their bodies and, even more dangerously, their minds.As a character, Jacqueline has already made an appearance in Picasso's Women, Brian McAvera's play about the artist seen from the perspective of the women in his life, in which Jacqueline, once played by Susannah York, is mostly a pathetic figure.But "Picasso Intime" gives a different picture. In fact, I think there's a movie in this show, one that may in fact change what's become the accepted storyline of movies about artists as noble, silent sufferers - see Pollock, Vincent And Theo, Lust For Life and all the rest - a notion kept alive most recently in Peter Webber's Girl With A Pearl Earring, in which 17th-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer does the silent suffering."Picasso Intime" is about art that comes from interaction of the most personal kind. Of the two words in the title, it's the one about intimacy that's the most provocative. The show closes March 28.pgoddard @ thestar.ca IllustrationAmong the many portraits of Picasso's second wife, Jacqueline en costume turc (1955) is part of the Picasso Intime exhibition currently on at the Pinacotheque de Paris.Credit: Toronto StarWord count: 1297Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
How Pablo Picasso got his horns: EXHIBITIONS
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPicasso: Minotaurs and Matadors This show focuses on two key images, viewed across the breadth of Picasso's career, from 1889 to 1971. In Picasso's mind, steeped in Mediterranean ritual and myth, the minotaur, half-man, half-bull, and the bullfighter became virtually interchangeable embodiments of tragedy and violence. Gagosian Gallery, London W1 (020 7495 1500), until Aug 25 Chris Ofili: Weaving Magic In a free display in its Sunley Room, the National Gallery presents a tapestry designed by Chris Ofili. It is suffused with a sense of magic, myth and sensuality. The walls are prepared with a grisaille mural of voluptuous Asiatic dancers, offsetting the bright tapestry. Boy, is it gorgeous.National Gallery, London WC2 (020 7747 2885), until Aug 28 Elisabeth Frink: Transformation Frink's long-jawed male figures and primal animal forms made her the "It-girl" of Fifties and Sixties sculpture. But she's been a neglected figure since her death in 1993. Featuring a selection of bronzes and drawings, this marvellous show highlights the political dimension to Frink's work. Hauser & Wirth, Bruton (01749 814060), until May 7Credit: by Mark Hudson and Alastair SookeIllustrationCaption: Bullish: Picasso's Minotaure dans une Barque Sauvant une Femme is at London's Gagosian galleryWord count: 205Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Costco isn't giving up on Pablo Picasso.: [USA 1ST EDITION]
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitCostco isn't giving up on Pablo Picasso.The retail chain says it is looking into reports questioning the authenticity of a supposed Picasso sketch, Drawing Arles, sold for a characteristically nine-heavy priceof Dollars 39,999.99 via the Costco website last year.It has also pulled a second sketch, which was going for Dollars 145,999.99until this week. It was supposedly certified by Maya Widmaier- Picasso, the artist's daughter, who told The New York Times that both certificates were forged.But Costco's card-holding Picasso-fanciers shouldn't despair. Jim Tutweiler, the fine art dealer who was the seller of both works, is still offering a far more modestly priced limited edition etching for Dollars 1,799.99 (shipping and handling included). There's also La Petite Corrida, a plate-signed stone lithograph, for Dollars 1,459.99, and L'Age du Soleil, another stone etching. Luckily, none of the above require the Widmaier-Picasso stamp of approval.Word count: 147Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPablo Picasso was 88 when he painted this picture, quickly.What a weird old guy he was."The Man With the Golden Helmet" is not quite a self-portrait, but it's got him in it. It's got his vast ego, his ceaseless transformations, his round black-olive eyes.Like the Minotaur, the musketeer, the harlequin and the shadow, "The Man With the Golden Helmet" is a surrogate for the painter.Malaga (where Picasso was born) and La Coruna (where his father ran the art school) were ports known for the fierceness of their mariners. Here, too, is a conqueror, enriched by harsh adventures, maybe in Africa.His head is horned. His nose is hornlike, too. Picasso, when young, styled himself Yo, el rey (I, the king). Here his throne transforms itself into the prow of a conquistador's caravel.-- Paul Richard"The Man With the Golden Helmet" (1969) hangs in the Picasso Gallery of the Kreeger Museum, 2401 Foxhall Rd. NW.Word count: 177Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Another side of Pablo Picasso: [Final Edition]
Full Article: AbstractThis illuminating exhibition, hosted by the university gallery for the Gardiner Museum of Ceramic Art, includes about 80 earthenware pieces by [Pablo Picasso] dated between 1902 and 1964. These are supplemented by some of Picasso's posters for ceramics exhibitions and sketches of designs.In paintings and pottery, Picasso liked to adapt shapes and motifs from the art of other times and cultures. The exhibition highlights his debt to other potters by providing examples of historical and modern pottery that Picasso might have turned to. Photo: Photos From Picasso Estate (Paris)/ Sodrac (Montreal) 2004 / Pablo Picasso, Standing Woman, circa 1948, white earthenware, painted with slips.; Photo: Photos From Picasso Estate (Paris)/ Sodrac (Montreal) 2004 / Pablo Picasso, Bird, 1947 or 1948, white earthenware, black glaze. Right,; Photo: Photos From Picasso Estate (Paris)/ Sodrac (Montreal) 2004 / Pablo Picasso, Pitcher with Open Vase, 1954, white earthenware, painted with slips, carved, glazed. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit'When there's anything to steal," Pablo Picasso once said, "I steal." He was referring, of course, to taking inspiration from earlier and contemporary art.While Picasso (1881-1973) is famous for revolutionizing painting, his avant-gardist ceramic creations are not so well known. Picasso and Ceramics, an exhibition at the University of Toronto Art Centre, fills in the gap.This illuminating exhibition, hosted by the university gallery for the Gardiner Museum of Ceramic Art, includes about 80 earthenware pieces by Picasso dated between 1902 and 1964. These are supplemented by some of Picasso's posters for ceramics exhibitions and sketches of designs.In paintings and pottery, Picasso liked to adapt shapes and motifs from the art of other times and cultures. The exhibition highlights his debt to other potters by providing examples of historical and modern pottery that Picasso might have turned to.The human figure has always been popular with potters. Picasso, who flattened, twisted and distorted the human figure on canvas, treated his clay figures similarly.To make Standing Woman (circa 1948), Picasso pinched a compact and simplified female shape from a freshly thrown flask. Three black dots and one vertical line represent facial features on a small head atop a long neck. Her arms rest at her sides and dissolve into her wide hips and she looks as though she is wearing a black and white striped dress. But the human features are barely there, so the basic bottle shape is still evident.Tanagra in Black and Blue (1947-48) also blurs the border between human and vessel forms. A long-necked woman raises her hands to her small head. This gesture recalls Greek mourning figurines made more than 2,000 years ago in towns such as Tanagra.But while these ancient figurines were intended to be seen as human forms, Picasso's woman looks like an amphora. Her raised arms resemble handles, her long neck is the amphora's neck and her well- rounded hips are the vessel's body.Inspired by ancient potters, Picasso also pulled animal and avian bodies out of vessel shapes. Bird (1947-48) succinctly blends bird and vase. With fused feet and no head, the monochrome black-glazed bird looks like a vase with a tilted body. The body, however, resembles an egg, a subtle reminder of the bird and an echo of Constantin Brancusi's sculptures a quarter-century earlier.In Pitcher with Open Vase (1954), Picasso tries a different kind of modification. He's cut out the side of a sturdy pitcher, thereby rendering the vessel useless in an obvious way. The cutout has the shape of a vase, a kind of vase within a vase, except that the second one is nonexistent.Because Picasso never seems to lose sight of the vessel format, he thinks like a potter. But he never threw his own pots, preferring to decorate and alter pieces already made by potters at the Madoura workshop in Vallauris, in southern France.He also designed unique shapes for them to make.One bonus of this exhibition is a chance to see some vessels made by Suzanne Ramie, a highly innovative potter who owned the Madoura workshop and encouraged Picasso's love affair with ceramics.He especially liked to appropriate her pieces from the drying- board and work on them.Picasso pushed and punched clay to its creative limits but in the end, I think his contributions to painting were more startling and seminal than what he did in ceramics.ShowtimeWHAT: Picasso and CeramicsWHERE: University of Toronto Art Centre, 15 King's College Circle, TorontoWHEN: Until Jan. 23HOURS: 10 to 6 Tuesday to Sunday, 10 to 9 FridayADMISSION: $16, seniors and students $12Regina Haggo, a former professor of art history at the University of Canterbury in New Zealand, teaches at the Dundas Valley School of Art. You can contact her at dhaggo@thespec.com IllustrationPhoto: Photos From Picasso Estate (Paris)/ Sodrac (Montreal) 2004 / Pablo Picasso, Standing Woman, circa 1948, white earthenware, painted with slips.; Photo: Photos From Picasso Estate (Paris)/ Sodrac (Montreal) 2004 / Pablo Picasso, Bird, 1947 or 1948, white earthenware, black glaze. Right,; Photo: Photos From Picasso Estate (Paris)/ Sodrac (Montreal) 2004 / Pablo Picasso, Pitcher with Open Vase, 1954, white earthenware, painted with slips, carved, glazed.Credit: The Hamilton SpectatorWord count: 748Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitENGLISH composer Andrew Lloyd Webber could break art auction records when he sells one of his most valuable Picasso paintings.Experts say the portrait, Angel Fernandez de Soto, could top the 38.4 million ($A95 million) paid for another of his early masterpieces six years ago.The auction comes as ticket sales at the National Gallery of Victoria soar for the biggest Picasso exhibition seen in Australia. Nearly 4000 people have seen Love & War since it opened on Friday. NGV deputy director Tony Ellwood said people were coming from all over Victoria and interstate. "We would expect it to get more than 200,000-plus visitors. The word of mouth seems very positive and the people who are coming out are saying that it's an amazing experience," he said.The show focuses on the historic events of 1935 to 1945, a period that took in the Spanish Civil War, World War II and the tumultuous love affair between Pablo Picasso and surrealist photographer Dora Maar, who met in Paris in the winter of 1935-36.Curated by leading Picasso specialist Anne Baldassari, director of the Musee Picasso in Paris, the exhibition features more than 350 works by Picasso and Maar from public and private collections.It is another coup for the NGV, which has previously hosted The Impressionists and works from Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum. -- With TELEGRAPHPicasso: Love and War is open until October 8.Word count: 233Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Pablo Picasso up close and personal: [ONT Edition]
Full Article: AbstractSombre colours dominate the show, more like Paris in late winter than the Mediterranean under a noonday sun. There are black blues, ghastly whites, ruddy browns, bold black outlines and wintry shadows - as in Portrait de [Jacqueline Picasso] au rocking-chair et au foulard noir (Jacqueline l'echarpe noire) (1954) - which seem to shrowd everything in a dark fog.The town near Mt. Sainte-Victoire in Aix-en-Provence where Picasso and Jacqueline eventually settled, seems un-Mediterranean in Picasso's cool Le Village de Vauvenargues (April 29, 1959), with its dark greens, bland yellows and sharp hills outlined in thick jolts of black.Picasso presented many of his portraits, often in her favourite pose - seated, with her arms folded around her bent knees - as presents to her, with little notes attached, such as "Pour ma femme Jacqueline le 24.2.65" or "Pour Jacqueline pour sa fte, son mari." Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitJacqueline Picasso (nee Roque), the second wife of Pablo Picasso, was found dead October 15 at Mougins on the French Riviera with a bullet in her head. She was 59.Picasso, who died in 1973, married her in 1961, when he was 79 years old and she was 35. She was a Paris-born divorcee and former dance teacher when she met Picasso, becoming his companion and the model for some fine portraits.- Obituary in The Times (London), Oct.17, 1986Even when they're going to bury you they'll dig your reputation a little deeper."Picasso Intime La Collection de Jacqueline," is the finest small show in Paris right now, in the most congenial new space, la Pinacotheque de Paris, just off a nondescript street with the too- promising name of rue de Paradis.As its brochure admits, the Pinacotheque - in what used to be the factory/showroom for Baccarat crystal - is "derriere les Grands Boulevards." In other words it's as next to nowhere as you can get in this city.Yet with "Picasso Intime," the Pinacotheque is muscling up against the Centre Pompidou, with its newly minted Joan Mir exhibition, "1917-1934 La Naissance du monde," and the rest of the major galleries closer to the city centre, by asking questions about one of the more fractious art mysteries of the last century.Who was Jacqueline? What was she? Was she merely a canny gold digger who married Pablo Picasso for his spectacular fortune? She did eventually end up with some $48 million (U.S.), but not before she ruined his apparently stable relationship with Francoise Gilot, the artist's mistress for many years.Gilot's 1965 response in her bestselling and self-serving autobiography, Life With Picasso, so infuriated the artist that he cut off all ties to Claude and Paloma, his two illegitimate children with Gilot, and erased them out of his will.The above scenario apparently was on the mind of the Times' obituary writer who reminded the reader that Jacqueline was a "Paris-born divorcee" and "former dancer," attributes clearly meant to cast shadows on her honour. Jacqueline did little to distance herself from her wicked stepmother reputation when she barred Paloma and Claude from attending their father's funeral."Picasso Intime" tells another story, too - in fact several other stories.Primarily it shows Picasso's fascination with Jacqueline, her dark eyes and high cheekbones, her Spanish features. Her looks were in synch with Picasso's creativity as he revisited his early days, his Spanish roots and the works of mentor-figure painters such as Eugene Delacroix and Diego Velazquez.Jacqueline wasn't particularly tall. But in the many portraits that act as silent sentinels as you move through the exhibition, she's shown nobly, seeming larger than life.Picasso viewed old age moodily. In 1963, Georges Braque and Jean Cocteau, colleagues from his earliest days in Paris, both died. And to a great degree it was Jacqueline who helped him keep going - something she was unable to do for herself following his death, when her drinking grew worse and worse, the demons in her head closed in and she threatened suicide.Sombre colours dominate the show, more like Paris in late winter than the Mediterranean under a noonday sun. There are black blues, ghastly whites, ruddy browns, bold black outlines and wintry shadows - as in Portrait de Jacqueline au rocking-chair et au foulard noir (Jacqueline l'echarpe noire) (1954) - which seem to shrowd everything in a dark fog.The town near Mt. Sainte-Victoire in Aix-en-Provence where Picasso and Jacqueline eventually settled, seems un-Mediterranean in Picasso's cool Le Village de Vauvenargues (April 29, 1959), with its dark greens, bland yellows and sharp hills outlined in thick jolts of black.Your only hit of sun and glamor comes ahead of the main exhibition, in a photo display of images taken in the area around Cannes, where Picasso and Jacqueline had earlier set up house before moving to Aix. These shots reveal a sun-drenched Cote d'Azur, where the happy couple plays with its animals, including the artist's beloved goat, Biquette, clowns around for the camera and welcomes the rich and the famous, including matador Luis Miguel Dominguin.But it was Jacqueline's attention Pablo sought. Increasingly her role in his life was keeping away all the strangers while he worked, even if they weren't really strangers.Picasso presented many of his portraits, often in her favourite pose - seated, with her arms folded around her bent knees - as presents to her, with little notes attached, such as "Pour ma femme Jacqueline le 24.2.65" or "Pour Jacqueline pour sa fte, son mari."Also among the presents were early works, such as a young and intense Auto portrait (1917) where he shows himself sitting with his sketchpad on his knee. Clearly this gift was his way of bringing himself closer to her in terms of age.Even his later self-portraits or self-portraits in disguise - Picasso as a matador or as the 17th-century figure in Homme en habit XVII siecle au fond bleu (1967) - were his way of explaining himself to her."I paint," he said, "the way others write their autobiography."While the show lacks some of the more substantial later works such as Young Bather With Sand Shovel (1971), it nevertheless bustles with a vitality few older artists can match. Jacqueline could take some measure of credit that "late Picasso" wasn't "forgotten Picasso."So "Picasso Intime" may put a dent in Picasso's life-long reputation as a sexist misogynist who got his Hollywood-style comeuppance in Surviving Picasso, the James Ivory-directed rant where Anthony Hopkins plays the artist as pig and Natascha McElhone plays Gilot, the woman victim who came to hate him.It will be a small dent, though. If Picasso's women got burned by getting close to him, he felt equally burned in return. His first marriage to ballerina Olga Koklova became so self-destructive he imagined its brutal fury with Self-Portrait And Monster (1910). For most of the other women in his life, he was the monster.Not to Jacqueline, though. "Picasso Intime" also has work representing his many mistresses, from Fernande Olivier to Marie- Therese Walter to Dora Maar (Gilot is missing).In keeping these portraits, Jacqueline was clearly trying to cast herself above all those who had gone before by proving she could handle her husband's fascination with their bodies and, even more dangerously, their minds.As a character, Jacqueline has already made an appearance in Picasso's Women, Brian McAvera's play about the artist seen from the perspective of the women in his life, in which Jacqueline, once played by Susannah York, is mostly a pathetic figure.But "Picasso Intime" gives a different picture. In fact, I think there's a movie in this show, one that may in fact change what's become the accepted storyline of movies about artists as noble, silent sufferers - see Pollock, Vincent And Theo, Lust For Life and all the rest - a notion kept alive most recently in Peter Webber's Girl With A Pearl Earring, in which 17th-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer does the silent suffering."Picasso Intime" is about art that comes from interaction of the most personal kind. Of the two words in the title, it's the one about intimacy that's the most provocative. The show closes March 28.pgoddard @ thestar.ca IllustrationAmong the many portraits of Picasso's second wife, Jacqueline en costume turc (1955) is part of the Picasso Intime exhibition currently on at the Pinacotheque de Paris.Credit: Toronto StarWord count: 1299Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases.
