[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitHaving an original Pablo Picasso painting in your living room is undoubtedly a matter of pride. It may no longer be an impossible feat. Soon, Indian art connoisseurs can have a direct access to artworks by legendary modernist painters via an online art auction. The auction will bring western art for the first time in the country. The auction features works by eminent artists such as Pablo Picasso, Vincent van Gogh, Marc Chagall, Salvador Dali, Camille Pissarro, and Henri Matisse, among others. Leading the sale is van Gogh's 1885 masterpiece 'L'allee aux deux promeneurs', estimated at USD 800,000-1million. The auction also includes a selection of prints by several of the 20th century's most respected Western artists including Andy Warhol, Joan Miro, Henry Moore, and Roy Lichtenstein.In all, the Saffronart's Inaugural Auction of Impressionist and Modern Art auction includes 73 works by 35 prominent western artists with a total estimate of USD 3.3 million to 4.2 million. So how were these works sourced? "The works were sourced from private collections as well as from galleries and dealers specialising in these artists. Our experts for this sale checked the provenance and authenticity of each work before including it in the catalogue. Consignors were excited at the opportunity to offer these works in a new market with a great potential," says Nish Bhutani, COO, Saffronart.He elaborates that many collectors in India have read about and experienced international genres including modern, impressionist and contemporary Western art in museums and abroad, and increasingly through exhibitions in India as well. "The concept was to give Indian art collectors an opportunity to acquire great international works of art with which they are familiar with but did not have easy access to until now. The sale also includes a selection of ceramics by Picasso as well as sculptures by Henry Moore and Lynn Chadwick. We were conscious of the growing interest of Indian collectors in Western art in the last four to five years, and we are optimistic about this pioneering auction," adds Bhutani.When & where?The sale will take place online on February 15-16 at www.saffronart.com.Credit:Jayeeta MazumderWord count: 355Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitThat immortal Spaniard, Pablo Ruiz y Picasso (1881- 1973), is easily the most revered of all the 20th-century modernists and with good reason. His mind never rested. The most fecund and innovative artist of his time, he was constantly challenging himself - and us - in his search for new solutions. After some derivative starts and despite an occasional squint at other moderns, he was always original and worked in a great variety of mediums, some of them self- invented.Picasso was also famous because he stirred envy: he had numerous lovers and wives - most of whom are represented here - and lots of money; by drawing a banknote and signing it, he automatically turned it into gold. His Midas touch and his egocentricity were fatal to some of his children. His earthy love life was reflected in many of his drawings, whether formal or overtly erotic; a fixation on women dominates his entire oeuvre.Nothing he did was ever thrown away; just his mark made it valuable, whether it was good or merely indulgent (and occasionally even bad).Happily, there isn't anything bad in Pablo Picasso; Works through a Lifetime, a new Israel Museum show, mainly of works on paper drawn from the nearly 1,000 Picasso prints and drawings in its collection. Most of the prints were donated over the years by Georges Bloch (1901- 1984) of Zurich and this show marks the centenary of his birth; in fact it was made possible by the Bloch Foundation.Bloch, a friend of Picasso, compiled the definitive catalogue raisonne of over 2,200 Picasso prints in various intaglio, lithographic and lino-cut techniques. In 1972, after having previously given 100 prints by various modernists to Jerusalem, Bloch divided his collection into three parts and gave the Israel Museum 350 Picasso prints made between 1910 and 1968, while 350 other prints went to a public collection in Switzerland. The remaining third were sold to establish the Bloch Foundation.There are many portraits in this delightful show, mostly of wives and children, all in different modes, a few referring obliquely to artists Picasso admired and drew upon as a point of departure, like Velazquez.The earliest work is tiny oil from 1902 of a village corrida, nicely brought off but with no indication of the genius soon to emerge. There are few oils in the show, most of them on the theme of bathers and bathing from the recently acquired Lejwa bequest; Lady by the Shore, a standing nude, is as much drawn as painted, with a wonderfully controlled brush contour defining an invented but believable anatomy. A great work, it is a bit overwhelmed by its undeniably handsome frame. Illustration7 photos; Caption: Pablo Picasso: Francoise, lithograph, 1950. Pablo Picasso: Face (Marie-Therese Walther?) Litho, 1928. Pablo Picasso: The Diving Board, oil on canvas, 1956 (bequeathed by Madeleine Chalette Lejwa to American Friends of the Israel Museum). Pablo Picasso: Lady by the shore, oils, 1939. Pablo Picasso: Paloma and her Doll, lithograph, 1952. Pablo Picasso: Jacqueline, lino cut, 1962. Pablo Picasso: Jacqueline, lino cut, 1959.Word count: 537Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Pablo Picasso, the master of the one-liner: [Final Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndWe have met [Pablo Picasso], protean artistic genius. We are familiar with Pablo Picasso, voracious devourer and discarder of women. Now please welcome Pablo Picasso, quipmeister par excellence.[Dennis Boutsikaris], whose dark eyes have some of the piercing quality of Picasso's, delivers the manifestos with the proper ringing tone, the scornful appraisals of ex-wives and ex-lovers with an arrogant smirk. And when Picasso exercises his unexpected fondness for acerbic aphorisms ("If you've spent any time in France, you'll know soap is far more precious than gold"), he displays confident comic timing, leaving the vague impression that Picasso spent a summer or two in the Spanish equivalent of the Catskills.Miss [Fischer], trying to remain firmly in control of this testy colloquy, is not to be outquipped, although her witticisms are sometimes tasteless. "Do you still have queers in Germany?" Picasso asks. "Not so much lately," she replies. [Jill Eikenberry], a sensitive actress, deploys a look of secret suffering to clue us in to Miss Fischer's softer side. The character oscillates between sympathy and antagonism toward her detainee, speaking tenderly of her reverence for Picasso's art in one sequence, baring sharp Nazi fangs in the next. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit We have met Pablo Picasso, protean artistic genius. We are familiar with Pablo Picasso, voracious devourer and discarder of women. Now please welcome Pablo Picasso, quipmeister par excellence.This new view of one of the 20th century's most exhaustively chronicled figures comes courtesy of Jeffrey Hatcher's play A Picasso, a formulaic two-hander that opened Tuesday night at New York City Centre's Stage II in a polished production from the Manhattan Theatre Club.It is the autumn of 1941, more than a year after Paris fell to the Germans. The heavy tread of Nazi jackboots can be heard on the streets outside the underground bunker, where the celebrated painter, played by Dennis Boutsikaris, sits cooling his heels. (Allen Moyer's expert set evokes an atmosphere of clammy claustrophobia.)Enter Miss Fischer (Jill Eikenberry), a coiled, crisp blonde wearing ominous shoulder pads: Joan Crawford styled by Albert Speer. Miss Fischer works for the German cultural ministry and has been charged with the task of authenticating three "confiscated" artworks. She has had the artist detained to help her out. (Hatcher's fictional plot is loosely inspired by actual events.) Picasso is suspicious: What do the Nazis want with his drawings? As he says, "Germans want kittens and dogs and Poland." (Zing!)The first of Hatcher's carefully sprung surprises arrives after Picasso has proudly identified all three paintings as his own. Miss Fischer lets slip that an invitation to a group exhibition in the works won't be forthcoming. The Nazis may be evil to the core, but they aren't so tacky as to invite an artist to witness the burning of his own work.Aghast, Picasso strikes a deal with the secretly simpatico Miss Fischer to disavow the testimonials he has just given, at least in two of the three cases: All his interrogator needs is "a Picasso," a single work to feed the bonfire of "degenerate" art being planned.And so, in the guise of offering Miss Fischer a scholarly assessment certifying two of the paintings as forgeries, Picasso embarks, somewhat illogically, on a series of reminiscences of his life and loves.Hatcher has absorbed the myriad viewpoints put forth in the standard biographies, and, with the help of Miss Fischer's tart rejoinders, reveals both the dark and the light, the tender soul and the ruthless ego of the hard-working womanizer and prolific genius. If it does not contain any real insights into the psychology of a much-scrutinized man, the play does serve as a modest primer for the Picasso-oblivious.Few attempts are made to solve the mystery of his contradictions. Hatcher simply presents them with a shrug. And so Picasso scornfully talks of the artist's supreme indifference to politics - "I do not choose ideologies or countries!" - but in the next breath is loudly proclaiming, "I am prouder of Guernica than of anything else I have ever done."Boutsikaris, whose dark eyes have some of the piercing quality of Picasso's, delivers the manifestos with the proper ringing tone, the scornful appraisals of ex-wives and ex-lovers with an arrogant smirk. And when Picasso exercises his unexpected fondness for acerbic aphorisms ("If you've spent any time in France, you'll know soap is far more precious than gold"), he displays confident comic timing, leaving the vague impression that Picasso spent a summer or two in the Spanish equivalent of the Catskills.Miss Fischer, trying to remain firmly in control of this testy colloquy, is not to be outquipped, although her witticisms are sometimes tasteless. "Do you still have queers in Germany?" Picasso asks. "Not so much lately," she replies. Eikenberry, a sensitive actress, deploys a look of secret suffering to clue us in to Miss Fischer's softer side. The character oscillates between sympathy and antagonism toward her detainee, speaking tenderly of her reverence for Picasso's art in one sequence, baring sharp Nazi fangs in the next.John Tillinger's snappy direction smooths away some of the contrivances of Hatcher's neatly diagrammed plot. But it cannot mask the frequent lapses into mechanical rhythms and predictable cliches. In a discussion of the death of Picasso's great friend Guillaume Apollinaire, Miss Fischer pointedly asks, "What does one call a man who, on hearing of his dearest friend's death, draws his own portrait before anything else?"The booming reply: "An artist."A Picasso, by Jeffrey Hatcher, directed by John Tillinger, is at New York City Centre Stage II, 131 W. 55th St., Manhattan, until May 29. For details, call (212) 581-1212. Title: Abstract
Pablo Picasso's New-Angled Way Of Seeing Things: [FINAL Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndIn his lecture, [Leo Steinberg] fleshed out and nailed down the vague old notion that [Pablo Picasso]'s cubism did away with traditional Renaissance perspective and replaced it with a free-floating modern eye. As Steinberg spelled that old position out, cubism rejected a single view into coherent space caught from a single point of view at one moment in time -- think of any of Vermeer's domestic scenes. Instead, Picasso's cubist pictures pulled apart our vision of reality, even maybe how we think about the world, into all of its component parts. Picasso was "impatient with the conventional image that rations him to one view at a time," Steinberg said.In one impressive dissection, Steinberg showed how the head in one of Picasso's very first, pre-cubist drawings of [Fernande Olivier], which at first seems strangely bloated, is in fact a cobbling together of two different viewpoints. It lets Picasso show his mistress's face in a three-quarters view, while her ear and the back of her head are shown in profile. Split the portrait down the middle, and view each half on its own -- Steinberg did it for us in his slides -- and you see two perfectly coherent glimpses of a head. It's only when they get assembled into a single picture that everything seems somehow off. As the Picasso exhibition shows, Fernande's head went on to become the "preferred testing ground" for the artist's most radical experiments -- for his "shattering of every smug continuity," as Steinberg put it.Steinberg refers to Renaissance realism as nothing more than a "common usage" that Picasso wants to break free of. The artist hoped to end up with a more complete rendition of the world with fewer arbitrary limits. Attacked for his "monstrous" distortions, Picasso replied that his goal was resemblance, "but a resemblance more profound, more real than the real." Picasso works to achieve this goal, according to Steinberg, by making visual thought "approximate the habits of language," with all the flexibility that entails. It's the flexibility to mention a glass, say, without getting any more specific about the precise kind of glass that you have in mind, or to pull apart all the separate features of an object and discuss them one by one -- as Picasso does, in paint, in the still lifes analyzed by Steinberg. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitOn a recent Sunday afternoon, crowds gathered at the National Gallery of Art to see the venerable and venerated art historian Leo Steinberg. He was giving a lecture called "The Intelligence of Picasso," which was inspired by "Picasso: The Cubist Portraits of Fernande Olivier," the gallery's close-up of the Spanish painter's first steps toward cubism that is on display through Jan. 19.At 83, Steinberg delivered a lecture that lived up to his reputation as one of the great thinkers, writers and talkers about art. His talk may be over and done with, but its ideas about Picasso and the birth of cubism -- one of the crucial watersheds in art -- demand long mulling over.Steinberg's argument wasn't revolutionary (unlike some of his past work, on themes such as the sexuality of Christ in art, which put the discipline all in a tizzy). It was illustrated, however, with some of the most perceptive close readings of works of art that you could ever find. Some of Steinberg's larger conclusions might be debated -- but put his acute observations into contact with some current ideas in perceptual psychology, and you can start to understand more of what's going on in cubism.In his lecture, Steinberg fleshed out and nailed down the vague old notion that Picasso's cubism did away with traditional Renaissance perspective and replaced it with a free-floating modern eye. As Steinberg spelled that old position out, cubism rejected a single view into coherent space caught from a single point of view at one moment in time -- think of any of Vermeer's domestic scenes. Instead, Picasso's cubist pictures pulled apart our vision of reality, even maybe how we think about the world, into all of its component parts. Picasso was "impatient with the conventional image that rations him to one view at a time," Steinberg said.In one impressive dissection, Steinberg showed how the head in one of Picasso's very first, pre-cubist drawings of Fernande, which at first seems strangely bloated, is in fact a cobbling together of two different viewpoints. It lets Picasso show his mistress's face in a three-quarters view, while her ear and the back of her head are shown in profile. Split the portrait down the middle, and view each half on its own -- Steinberg did it for us in his slides -- and you see two perfectly coherent glimpses of a head. It's only when they get assembled into a single picture that everything seems somehow off. As the Picasso exhibition shows, Fernande's head went on to become the "preferred testing ground" for the artist's most radical experiments -- for his "shattering of every smug continuity," as Steinberg put it.Steinberg also showed another slightly later Picasso, of a woman in a chair, in which the artist seems to have arbitrarily dropped one shoulder lower than the other -- just to be stylishly odd and angstful, you might think at first. But in yet another demonstration of virtuoso pictorial analysis, Steinberg convincingly showed that by again separating the two halves of the picture, you could identify the raised shoulder as capturing the woman seen from up above, and the lowered one as signaling a view from straight ahead or from somewhat below. Though Steinberg didn't go this far, the implication is that the portrait also conveys two different relationships between artist and sitter: one as the standing artist, in control of the situation, approaches the woman, and the other once he's lowered himself to her level -- as observer, as equal, maybe even as supplicant.Then Steinberg went on to take apart some complex still lifes. He demonstrated how Picasso could show us a standard still life of a table, but with the tabletop seen at once from above and below. In another still life, of a single glass, all the vessel's attributes - - its transparency and its roundness and its shapely profile, as well as the access it gives to the wooden surface of the table seen through it -- could be pulled apart and rendered in different spots on the picture plane. In a third still life, a short stretch of parallel lines stands for the substantial thickness of its table top, but they have nothing to do with another line, a single diagonal this time, that stands for the recession into space of the table's drawer -- a drawer that might just as well come from an entirely different picture, for all it has to do with how all the table's other bits are drawn.This kind of subtle, maybe even intuitive, purely visual conception of a radically new pictorial world is what Steinberg meant by "the intelligence of Picasso" and he shows it operating at genius level. Picasso solves one problem, then moves on to the next, remaining in a state of constant, fertile "exploratory despair," in Steinberg's words, that few other artists have managed to stay in for so long.But I think that Picasso's constant exploration, and maybe his despair, doesn't come from solving problems and then being forced to move on to new challenges. It comes from discovering that, in the case of cubism at least, his problem is inherently unsolvable.Steinberg refers to Renaissance realism as nothing more than a "common usage" that Picasso wants to break free of. The artist hoped to end up with a more complete rendition of the world with fewer arbitrary limits. Attacked for his "monstrous" distortions, Picasso replied that his goal was resemblance, "but a resemblance more profound, more real than the real." Picasso works to achieve this goal, according to Steinberg, by making visual thought "approximate the habits of language," with all the flexibility that entails. It's the flexibility to mention a glass, say, without getting any more specific about the precise kind of glass that you have in mind, or to pull apart all the separate features of an object and discuss them one by one -- as Picasso does, in paint, in the still lifes analyzed by Steinberg.Picasso struggled to turn traditional still life into a "sign situation," where individual bits of information get their meaning by playing off each other, rather than through a fixed relationship to some outside reality. For Picasso, said Steinberg, "the visual representation of things need not mirror them, but could refer to things the way that language does." He imagines these pictures working more like a clever made-up code than like a footprint in the sand that unquestionably shows that someone has passed by.The problem with all this, however, is that in practice -- including Picasso's practice -- it turns out that pictures can't work much like language does. It's true that Picasso does away with a unified perspective that's coherent right across the surface of a single picture. But he can't shake free of perspective-based realism in each of that picture's smallest component parts; he has to follow rules for showing them that have less leeway than anything you'd find in language.Picasso's double-angled view of the seated woman is only recognizable as such because each half has a single point of view: One half is a view from straight ahead, the other one from up above. You could even argue that pictures like this don't undermine perspective at all; they demonstrate its inescapable force in all representation. The portrait's double view could be said to have twice as much perspective as pictures that had come before it, rather than half as much or none at all.In the still lifes that Steinberg does such a brilliant job dissecting, all the separable bits that add up to an object are in fact straightforward, traditional renditions of visual details: A glass's shape is rendered by a drawn profile or a scissored edge; a drawer's recession is shown by a diagonal racing toward a vanishing point; a table's thickness gets an outline drawing of two edges with a gap between -- all standard elements in classic representation. By assembling different aspects of an object into a single picture, Picasso's not doing anything to revolutionize the very nature of depiction: It's what most non-Western cultures do, as well as our own kids before we teach them otherwise.Crowds of contemporary philosophers and psychologists -- unfortunately, only rarely in contact with art historians -- have done work to underline how very different representation is from other kinds of languages and codes and symbol systems. Representation has a special set of ties to features in the world that language simply doesn't have: "Dog" and "hund" and "chien" can all point to the same thing, but there aren't three ways of painting a dog that don't have a lot in common with each other, and with the real-life dog they point a viewer to. If a picture's going to recall an object, it has to capture certain things about the way the world is made. All recognizable pictures seem to be made up of a very few recurring elements that allow flat surfaces to depict the world: They use a handful of cues to tell us about surfaces and edges, about shapes and colors and textures and the other qualities of things. There's not much more that any figurative artist can do than emphasize some of those elements instead of others, or reorganize the way they fit together, as Picasso does.What's more, recent research has shown that a single viewpoint, like the one used by artists from Leonardo to Ingres, is inherent in many of these building blocks of picture-making: Even when people blind from birth are asked to draw, they use lines the way that artists do, and often with a single viewpoint in mind. It may not even be possible to think about an object in space -- which blind people do as well as anyone -- without imagining how its position must relate to yours. So cubism's goal of capturing a roving eye and the special 3-D substantiveness of things -- the idea that things are there to be walked around and touched, as well as calmly contemplated -- may simply be impossible on a flat, unchanging surface like a painter's canvas. Cubism can assemble bunches of static, perspectival glimpses of the world onto a single canvas, but it can't make those glimpses any less static or less bound to a single viewpoint than they've always been.I think that's what Picasso in the end discovered in his exploration. When he tried to show two views of a single woman's head, he didn't really capture an extra sense of roundness. He just got a single head that people tend to read as strangely swollen, unless a thinker as clever as Steinberg spends time unpacking something else the picture might imply.When Picasso tried to find a new way to render the three- dimensionality of Fernande's forehead by turning it into a row of cube-like forms, as in several portraits in the National Gallery show, all he got was a picture of someone who seems to have "pleated brows," in Steinberg's own words. Picasso cannot change the fundamental way a picture renders objects -- that's pretty much a given, because of how the world and pictures work. We're wired to read the world -- including pictures of it -- in pretty much one way, and there's almost nothing any artist or historian can do to change that fact.As Picasso went further and further into his radical cubist project, it drew further and further away from the real world, and closer and closer to complete abstraction. The last portraits in the Picasso exhibition break representation down so thoroughly that they barely render what their titles say they're pictures of. No danger of misreading them as having swollen heads or pleated brows because you can hardly find a head or brow to say such things about. I love the way these almost-abstract pictures look, but I can't pretend that that's because of how they make me see their sitters. In the quasi-abstraction of cubism, Picasso has forged a brand-new, hugely influential and fantastic kind of picture-making. But he hasn't found a brand-new way to make pictures depict the world.Steinberg quoted one of Picasso's last bons mots: "Reality haunts these pictures," he said, "like a perfume." Which means that you can only find the barest whiff of it, for all cubism's claims to forge a whole new form of realism.Word count: 2101Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. to first hitA new exhibition tries to convince us Picasso's last years were as good as the earlier periods, but the evidence isn't thereWITH the very greatest of cultural figures -- the Shakespeares, the Mozarts, the Joyces -- we get a sense that they ultimately desire to cover the world, to turn everything into the subject of their art -- no aspect of human existence is potentially excluded.And yet as their work goes on we begin to feel that beneath its surface vitality, its ceaseless invention, it has only one true topic -- art itself.We begin to feel that -- almost as if they were becoming aware of their own genius, marvelling at themselves along with the rest of us -- whatever their ostensible subject matter, it is only a pretext for the transformative power of their imaginations, for demonstrating the awesome reach of their creativity.Like the unfortunate King Midas, everything they touch becomes a reflection of themselves.So it is with Pablo Picasso, undoubtedly the greatest genius of 20th-century art.His work started off as outward-looking, empathetic -- the depictions of the down-and-outs and demi-mondaines of the blue and pink periods -- or as a confrontation with otherness -- the blankly staring prostitutes of Les Desmoiselles d'Avignon.It could rise at times to the grandiloquence of public speech, as in Guernica, his immortal statement on the horrors of war, fully the equal of his countryman Goya.It could be full of passion, tenderness, pathos, even humour -- witness the wonderful floating elephantine Bathers of the 1930s, without whom Francis Bacon and our own Sidney Nolan would be impossible, and I would even say that without them we could not have had the dancing hippos of Disney's Fantasia.But as it went on it slowly narrowed in focus, lost touch with its original sources and became increasingly self-referential and solipsistic.All those acres of puckered female flesh were no longer a response to anyone living -- for all of the attempts to relate the distinct styles of his works to his various wives and mistresses -- but rather to other paintings.With the death of his long-time artistic rival Henri Matisse in 1954 -- the only other artist he considered his equal -- he no longer had to react with shock and envy when confronted with another's work; he no longer had to adjust his painterly system to take account of another competing style. And soon even Matisse would be incorporated within the wider Picassoean vocabulary -- just one of myriad elements Picasso was able to draw on.It is the ironic paradox of the absolutely singular genius -- there is in the end no one to be influenced by except oneself.After a while -- for some critics after Guernica in 1937, for others even after 1919 with his turn to Neo-Classicism -- the "late" Picasso machine grinds out its endless variations, no longer finding inspiration either in some "original" contact with its artistic materials or in resolving, say, the profound intellectual problems of Cubism.SUCCESSIVELY Ingres, Delacroix, Velasquez and Manet are swallowed up and spat back out in a style that invariably looks like Picasso. There is no longer any real engagement with these works -- with their form or the artistic thinking they represent -- but only with their easily recognisable content. Picasso's late work becomes a series of virtuosic variations on what has effectively been turned into kitsch -- the painterly equivalent of John Coltrane's brilliant but ultimately unlistenable 14-minute version of My Favourite Things.As much as anything, it is this tremendously seductive orthodoxy that has developed around Picasso's work that curator Terence Maloon's Picasso: The Last Decades, currently on at the Art Gallery of NSW until February 16, seeks to overturn.Does Picasso's late period witness a kind of creative impasse, even one brought about by his very genius?Does his final work evidence a decline in his creative powers, perhaps for the obvious reason that he was growing old, that his hand was wavering, that his eyesight was dimming?These questions or doubts Picasso: The Last Decades answers with a resounding no.Take gallery boss Edmund Capon, who writes in his foreword of the "sheer forthrightness of Picasso who, especially in his later years and in characteristic defiance of the inevitability of old age, confronted his life and imaginings with undaunted energy and absolutely no concessions".Of course, this is sheer hype, the kind of thing they let gallery directors get away with at the front of catalogues -- but listen to Maloon himself. As he asks in a series of rhetorical questions: "Distortion was old hat? Picasso distorted with such humour, expressive skills and dramatic force that it could take your breath away."His art a closed book? Picasso could open the chapters at random, and take his pick of innumerable works from the past. Bypassed by history? Picasso could give the younger generation a history lesson which would validate his art's continuing role in it."And so on. The trouble with Picasso: The Last Decades is that, in its desire to rehabilitate the late production of Picasso -- a desire undoubtedly driven as much by the box office as by scholarly rigour -- it risks turning into mere boosterism, or the old tactic of saying that what was bad is now good, what was marginal is now central.Nowhere in the catalogue are the basic questions asked that would allow us properly to consider this question of the "late" Picasso.For instance, what is it that constitutes this "late" period?Continued BAM 2Pablo Picasso's end gameFrom BAM 1The show, predictably, goes for the biographical explanation -- the late period begins in 1953 when Picasso meets Jacqueline Roque, the last of the six important wives or mistresses who were to run through his life.It is an interpretation that -- not coincidentally -- allows the Gallery to include its own Nude in a Rocking Chair (1956) as one of the foundational works in the exhibit, as though it really inaugurated something new.But, as I say, there are art historical readings that see Picasso's late period -- in the sense of a decline in the quality of his paintings -- beginning in 1937 after Guernica, or -- in the sense of the recycling of other artistic styles -- as early as 1919 with his abandoning of Cubism and his adoption of Ingres' Classicism.Beginning as it does with Picasso's work of the early '50s, the show probably does not do enough with the fact that this corresponds to the period of Matisse's death -- the way that the two most important works in the show, Nude in a Rocking Chair and Studio 30 (1955) are a final coming to terms with Matisse's influence, at once a breaking of his spell and his incorporation within Picasso's system.So, if there is a distinctive late style in Picasso, if the last decades herald an unexpected artistic breakthrough, in what does it consist?There admittedly are some extraordinary works in the show, some of the absolute cornerstones of Picasso's achievement -- the series of Studios-- at La Californie on the French Riviera of 1955-7; the variations on Delacroix's Femmes d'Alger of 1954-5, on Velasquez' Las Meninas of 1957, on Manet's Dejeuner sur l'herbe of 1960-1. There are the series of crazed-looking portraits, the so-called "travesties", of the late '60s and early '70s; and the famous Self- Portrait of 1972 with its staring dead eyes, allegedly Picasso's final work.But the kind of painterly Cubist style most of these works represent -- a fusion of the skeletal armature of Analytic Cubism and the colour and decoration of Synthetic Cubism -- was something Picasso had been working on since the mid-'30s, after he had abandoned Surrealism.No, if Picasso's late work does represent a new "formal" principle -- and this is a hypothesis that the catalogue, for all its air of challenging orthodoxy, never gets close to suggesting -- it is the deliberately "bad" painting that overtook Europe a few years after his death in the form of Neo-Expressionism.Picasso was an artist who famously did not edit his work, who advised younger painters to "paint the first thing that came into their head", who decided to let everything out of the studio and allow the public to judge.And it is something like this deliberate flouting of taste and even of artistic competency that is finally compelling about the late Picasso -- it is perhaps this in the end that pushes him past Matisse and makes him a touchstone for our age.The work of Pollock is "ugly" in the same way, and the art historian T.J. Clark recently wrote a book, Farewell to an Idea, that attempted to make a case for the "ugly" and "minor" as the essence of Modernism.This is the true iconoclasm of Picasso -- his deliberate breaking of all the rules of artistic decorum, his willingness to be "minor" - - and it is a far more radical proposition than simply claiming that he continues painting with undiminished power, raging against the dying of the light.Picasso: The Last Decades is not to be missed, but not for any reasons the catalogue gives. If great art is truly "anachronistic", as it claims, it is not to be captured by any straightforward explanation or apology, for it will always turn these against themselves.We have got to think harder about great art than either the humanistic cliche of the genius trapped by their own talent or the simple inversion of this.Our interpretations must be as daring as the art, take as great a risk -- we must in a way say the first thing that comes into our heads: that this art is ugly, that it does fail. And then ask: what does this mean? Why is it like this? Only then might we meet that imposing stare.ART EXHIBITIONS, ART AND ARTISTS IllustrationCaption: Appears on M02 VISION . . . from the left, Woman in a Rocking Chair, The Last Decades (5), Woman with Turkish Headdress and Woman and Children. All by Pablo Picasso. Pictures courtesy of The Art Gallery of NSW. (Copyright Succession Picasso, Paris. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Blues music originated in America's deep south, which is roughly the same direction as the Carlton footy club was heading this year, yet despite finishing south of the top eight somehow finds itself playing in an elimination final.Even outspoken former-president John Elliott would have struggled to muster more than an incredulous "Pig's Arse" at the good news - ironic in that for once he would have almost been right on the money. As it was, the pig's brains and other curious substances in the Essendon supplements saga gifted Carlton a finals wildcard and ensured a showdown with another old foe, Richmond. When Pablo Picasso painted The Old Guitarist he was in the midst of a bleak personal time, known as his Blue Period. Carlton fans questioning their team's finals legitimacy need only look at the Spanish masters' life. Following his Blue Period was his 'Rose' period after which he never looked back. With some justification, Blues talisman and former skipper Chris Judd possibly felt he had experienced everything possible in footy - premierships, Brownlow medals, suspension and accolades. But never, ever the role of a fading star in a mediocre team which still might just have enough music left for one last jig at the big dance.WIN A JIM For details on how to win an original print on fine art paper go to SPORT 20 To download your own print and to see others from the 'Big week in art' series go online to: realfooty.com.au or http://bit.ly/171EuuBWord count: 251Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. NOTES & THEORIES: The ultimate brand management manifesto. By Pablo Picasso: [First Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndThe name is important too. Akio Morita realised this when in 1955 he had the happy insight that "Sony" was snappier than Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo Kabushika Kaika. [Pablo Picasso] had done the same. Born Pablo Diego Jose Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno Maria de los Angeles Remedios Cipriano de la Santisima Trinidad Ruiz Picasso, he rapidly developed a brand strategy of his own. His first paintings are signed with the patronymic "P Ruiz". He later adds his mother's maiden name to become "P Ruiz Picasso". Then "P R Picasso". By 1902, the "Picasso" brand was launched.Initially, it was Picasso's fine product that created his reputation. Later his wealth became a source of fascination in itself. Financially independent by the age of 28, at the time of his death he had perhaps 500 of his own canvases. Today these might be worth several billion in whatever hard currency you care to mention. But Picasso always controlled the relationship between production and distribution. As John Berger said in The Success and Failure of Picasso (1965), he knew that "the works would have to be sold tactfully, so as not to flood the market". Or, in other words, he had a premium product strategy that would be the envy of Unilever. Quite intuitively, it seems, Picasso understood the voodoo of brand management. "Actually, I wanted to become a painter," he once admitted. "Now I have become Picasso." This is wittily explained in a brilliant book by Bernd Kreutz, one of Germany's leading ad men (The Art of Branding, Hatje Cantz Verlag, Ostfildern-Ruit, 2003). [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitW hen German missionaries, bringing architectural doctrine, arrived here in the Thirties, they called the English visuelle analphabetenten. But I have always thought it wrong to say we are visually illiterate. In fact, the English in their way are discriminating about the look of things, not least horses, gardens and foreign cars. Right now it is said that "icon" is the most over- used word in the language. Equally, everywhere you go people talk of "brand values". This use of language betrays our perpetual fascination with imagery.Brands are especially interesting. The word probably comes from the identifying marks cowboys burnt onto steers, but has now mutated into a powerful notion that unites art with business and money. Not that they were ever really separate. In a world where the technical mysteries of production have been solved, the intangibles of a brand are the most valuable assets. Once, people fussed about the importance of product design. Then they fussed about corporate identity. Now all the fussing is being done by brand managers.If you visit the headquarters of Audi at Ingolstadt and meet the chief designer, he gives you a business card that says "Audi Brand Group". The cars may be Volkswagens in drag, but their brand values distinguish them and justify higher prices. Brand values are all about association and expectation and you build them through having a strong identity, a heavy weight of advertising, consistency in PR ... and, of course, a worthwhile product.And the name is important too. Akio Morita realised this when in 1955 he had the happy insight that "Sony" was snappier than Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo Kabushika Kaika. Picasso had done the same. Born Pablo Diego Jose Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno Maria de los Angeles Remedios Cipriano de la Santisima Trinidad Ruiz Picasso, he rapidly developed a brand strategy of his own. His first paintings are signed with the patronymic "P Ruiz". He later adds his mother's maiden name to become "P Ruiz Picasso". Then "P R Picasso". By 1902, the "Picasso" brand was launched.Initially, it was Picasso's fine product that created his reputation. Later his wealth became a source of fascination in itself. Financially independent by the age of 28, at the time of his death he had perhaps 500 of his own canvases. Today these might be worth several billion in whatever hard currency you care to mention. But Picasso always controlled the relationship between production and distribution. As John Berger said in The Success and Failure of Picasso (1965), he knew that "the works would have to be sold tactfully, so as not to flood the market". Or, in other words, he had a premium product strategy that would be the envy of Unilever. Quite intuitively, it seems, Picasso understood the voodoo of brand management. "Actually, I wanted to become a painter," he once admitted. "Now I have become Picasso." This is wittily explained in a brilliant book by Bernd Kreutz, one of Germany's leading ad men (The Art of Branding, Hatje Cantz Verlag, Ostfildern-Ruit, 2003).Every step of his career was handled with calculation and enterprise. Success would never have been achieved in his native Malaga, nor La Coruna, nor even in Barcelona. Instead, Picasso saw that the emerging Paris art market with its new generation of private collectors was ripe to exploit. First he did what the brand managers call "benchmarking", assessing the market leaders. Thus, early Picassos had their similarities to Pissarro, Toulouse- Lautrec, Cezanne and Degas - market leaders in their day. But Picasso had a product development programme of his own. Fifty years before Detroit created the annual model change (which Vance Packard condemned as "planned obsolescence"), Picasso excited demand with new styles. Collectors dutifully moved from his Blue Period to his Rose Period and then to Cubism. Just as Apple launches new products when there is still demand for the old, Picasso's fidgety creativity kept the market alive. The critic Georges Besson said he was as "mercurial as a crowd".And long before anyone recognised the importance of word-of- mouth in getting obscure or advanced products to the tipping point of acceptability, Picasso had established networking. His brand values were continuously reinforced by his critics and his dealers. And Ambroise Vollard, Paul Durand-Ruel, Apollinaire and Gertrude Stein were fed a continuous diet of freebies. He formed a strategic alliance - just short of a merger - with Georges Braque, but did a buy-out when he needed more market share and Braque's sluggish performance was inhibiting growth. Even when collaborating on the Cubist product launch, Picasso's dealer Daniel-Henri Kahnweiler enforced the premium strategy by charging four times more for his pictures than for Braque's.And Picasso was no blurry mystic. Instead, he controlled his brand image with a high degree of self-consciousness. Brand extension was limited to graphics and ceramics (with a few theatrical joint ventures) and he only ever allowed his picture to be taken by the leading photographers of the day: Robert Doisneau, Man Ray and Irving Penn among them. Seven long-suffering women enhanced his reputation for prodigality, confirming the truth of the old saying that a bad reputation never did anyone any harm. PR was important too: Guernica became the most famous painting of the 20th century because of the painter's adroit manipulation of the media. So effective was this communications policy that 20 years after he died an inter-national survey showed that spontaneous recognition of the brand was 84 per cent (higher than that of the US President of the day).Picasso is a metaphor for the condition of art. In exactly the same way brand managers turn imagery into money, Picasso could do the same. It was said that shopkeepers in Antibes never bothered cashing his cheques because, no matter what their face value, the signature alone was worth more. Whatever he wanted - a house, a woman - Picasso simply had to draw. He certainly had the Midas touch ... but, then, Midas starved because you cannot eat gold.Despairing of his former partner's ruthless and inventive creativity, and perhaps a little jealous of his high profile, Georges Braque once said: "Picasso used to be a great painter. Now he is just a genius." Today, for "genius" read "brand".Word count: 1061Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit PARIS -- From playful ink sketches of prostitutes wearing nothing but gaudy stockings to a small, muted watercolour evoking an infinitely gentle embrace, the works in a new Paris exhibit on Picasso are a first compilation of the artist's erotic masterpieces."Art is not chaste," Picasso once said. "Or if it is, it is not art." Despite the artist's bent for frankness, many of his earthier sketches, notebooks and paintings have long been hidden in drawers or behind curtains -- until now.Picasso Erotique (Erotic Picasso), in the Jeu de Paume gallery in the Tuileries gardens, runs through May 20. The show reaches into the artist's prolific sexual imagination and traces a line from his adolescent initiations with prostitutes through his famous romances to his final meditations on love and aging.The exhibit then moves to Montreal's Musee des Beaux-Arts from June 14 to Sept. 16, then Barcelona, Spain.More than half the 300 or so works in the collection have been kept from public viewing until now -- including a 1903 oil painting owned by The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, which has never dared display the scene depicting a very young Picasso in a bordello.Jean-Jacques Lebel, an artist and writer who knew Picasso and was instrumental in mounting the exhibit, said half the works on display are being shown for the first time to museum-goers."This is supposed to be the most famous artist of his century," Lebel said."Everybody's so jaded, and they think they've seen everything, but we're proving that's not the case."Many of Picasso's sketches and paintings were hidden out of fear of tainting his marketability -- especially in North America, home to most of the artist's fans, Lebel said. Collectors on the other side of the Atlantic were unwilling to accept scenes depicting explicit sexual acts, which Picasso drew repeatedly.Other intimate works, especially sketches and notebooks, were carefully guarded by his muses, such as Dora Maar, who became devoutly religious after her breakup with Picasso in the 1940s.One work in the collection, a fanciful sexual comic strip, resurfaced after Maar died in 1997. By then, she had torn out a few of the most revealing pages.Credit: Associated PressWord count: 373Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitMADRID, Spain (AP) -- Picasso, Velazquez, Goya -- it's a show of duelling masters.In an exhibit titled Picasso: Tradition and Vanguard, Spain's Prado and Reina Sofia museums on Tuesday began showing more than 100 paintings by Pablo Picasso alongside the works of the 17th and 18th century masters who influenced him most, namely Diego Velazquez and Francisco de Goya.The exhibit, a cultural highlight of the summer in Madrid, was organized to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the arrival of Picasso's most famed work, Guernica, in Spain from the United States in 1981 following the country's return to democracy after Franco's dictatorship."It's a demanding retrospective of the most important artist of the 20th century," said Prado director Miguel Zugaza. "An exceptional collection which has rarely been seen and will be very difficult to bring together again in the future."The show also celebrates the 125th anniversary of the Malaga- born artist's birthday. Picasso died in Paris in 1973."It's not enough to describe it as a great exhibition," one of the show's curators, Francisco Calvo Serraller, told a pre-launch presentation last week. "It's inconceivable, unheard of, a historic event which transcends art and demonstrates how the tragedies of war were reflected in Spain."The Prado, normally dedicated to pre-19th century works, has given over its elegant central gallery to contrasting Picasso's works with those of painters he confessed were his inspirational mentors.The star attractions of the Prado leg will be comparisons between Velazquez's Las Meninas, painted in 1656, and Picasso's black, grey and white versions of the work from the 1950s. Several metres away are Picasso's versions of Goya's The Naked Maja of 1797.Ten minutes down Madrid's tree-lined Paseo del Prado is the Reina Sofia museum for modern art -- where the second part of the exhibit focuses on the giant anti-war canvas Guernica. Picasso painted it to denounce the 1937 indiscriminate air bombing by Franco's German allies of the small Basque town of the same name.Nearby are Goya's The Shootings of May 3rd and Manet's Execution of Emperor Maximilian.The show, which runs until Sept. 3, was inaugurated this week by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia.Credit: Associated PressWord count: 367Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: The price of Picasso ; Pablo Picasso's Women of Algiers hasset a world record for artwork sold at auction, going for $179.3million at Christie's in New York
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitMOST EXPENSIVE ARTWORKS SOLDAuction(A)/Private Sale(P) Artist Title Year of sale Price (M)P Paul Gauguin When Will You Marry? (1892) 2015 $300.0P Paul Cézanne The Card Players (1893) 2011 $259.0P Mark Rothko No. 6 (Violet, Green and Red) (1951) 2014 $186.0A Pablo Picasso Women of Algiers (1955) 2015 $179.3P Pablo Picasso The Dream (1932) 2013 $155.0A Francis Bacon Three Studies of Lucian Freud (1969) 2013 $142.4A Alberto Giacometti Pointing Man (1947) 2015 $141.3P Jackson Pollock No. 5 (1948) 2006 $140.0P Willem de Kooning Woman III (1953) 2006 $137.5P Gustav Klimt Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I (1907) 2006 $135.0P Leonardo da Vinci* Salvator Mundi (1905) 2004 $127.5A Edvard Munch The Scream (1895) 2012 $119.9P Amedeo Modigliani Reclining Nude With Blue Cushion (1490-1519)2012 $118P Jasper Johns Flag (1954) 2010 $110.0A Pablo Picasso Nude, Green Leaves and Bust (1932) 2010 $106.5P Barnett Newman Anna's Light (1968) 2013 $105.7A Andy Warhol Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster) (1963) 2013 $105.4A Pablo Picasso Garçon à la pipe (1905) 2004 $104.2P Andy Warhol Eight Elvises (1963) 2008 $100.0P Paul Cézanne La Montagne Sainte-Victoire vue du bosquet duChâteauNoir (1904) 2013 $100.0A Pablo Picasso Dora Maar au Chat (1941) 2006 $95.2*******Picasso's life1881 October 25: Born Pablo Ruiz Picasso in Málaga, Spain, son of apainter and art teacher1895 Family moves to Barcelona: attends Llotja School of Fine Arts1896 Painted The First Communion and the Portrait of Aunt Pepa,marking the beginning of his career1897 Studies at the San Fernando Academy of Fine Arts in Madrid.1901-04 Blue Period: Lives in poverty at the "Bateau Lavoir" inParis; often burned his own works in order to keep warm duringwinter; Prominent paintings: The Old Guitarist (1903), Femme auxBras Croisés (1902), La Vie (1903), Le Gourmet (1901) and Les Nocesde Pierrette (1905)1904-06 Rose Period: Meets Fermande Olivier, his mistress for thenext seven years; Paints with vibrant colours. Common subjects wereclowns, circus performers and comedians or harlequins. Painted hisbest-selling painting, Garçon à la pipe (Boy with a pipe)1907 The African Period: Paints Les Demoiselles d'Avignon1909-12 Analytic Cubism Period: Uses monochrome brownish andneutral colours and analyzed shapes1911 Eva Gouel becomes Picasso's mistress1912-19 Synthetic Cubism Period, integrating collage into the work1917 Leaves for Rome to work with the Ballets Russes1918 Marries ballerina Olga Koklova1921 Birth of son Paulo1927 Has an affair with 17-year-old Marie-Thérèse Walter1935 A time of anxiety; He stops painting and writes poetry;Separates from his wife; Marie-Thérèse gives birth to Maya1937 His depiction of the German bombing of Guernica (April 26th)brings him fame1942: Completes Still Life With Guitar1944: Completes The Charnel House; Begins a relationship withFrancoise Gilot, a young art student1947 Birth of Francoise's first child, Claude; Paints ceramics inVallauris1949 Birth of Paloma1950 Receives Lenin Peace Prize1953 Francoise leaves Picasso; He meets Jacqueline Roque1959-60 Experiments with lino cuts and designing large sheet-metalsculpture1961 Marries Jacqueline Roque1963-73 Confronts death in his paintings1973 Dies April 8, at the age of 91, in Mougins, FranceCREDIT: SUSAN BATSFORD, GRAPHICS EDITOR, TWITTER @SBATS1/POSTMEDIANETWORK, SOURCES: WIRE STORIES; GRAPHIC NEWS; WIKIPEDIA;WWW.PABLOPICASSO.ORG; NATIONAL GALLERY OF VICTORIAWord count: 557Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Common subjects wereclowns, circus performers and comedians or harlequins. Painted hisbest-selling painting, Garçon à la pipe (Boy with a pipe)1907 The African Period: Paints Les Demoiselles d'Avignon1909-12 Analytic Cubism Period: Uses monochrome brownish andneutral colours and analyzed shapes1911 Eva Gouel becomes Picasso's mistress1912-19 Synthetic Cubism Period, integrating collage into the work1917 Leaves for Rome to work with the Ballets Russes1918 Marries ballerina Olga Koklova1921 Birth of son Paulo1927 Has an affair with 17-year-old Marie-Thérèse Walter1935 A time of anxiety; He stops painting and writes poetry;Separates from his wife; Marie-Thérèse gives birth to Maya1937 His depiction of the German bombing of Guernica (April 26th)brings him fame1942: Completes Still Life With Guitar1944: Completes The Charnel House; Begins a relationship withFrancoise Gilot, a young art student1947 Birth of Francoise's first child, Claude; Paints ceramics inVallauris1949 Birth of Paloma1950 Receives Lenin Peace Prize1953 Francoise leaves Picasso; He meets Jacqueline Roque1959-60 Experiments with lino cuts and designing large sheet-metalsculpture1961 Marries Jacqueline Roque1963-73 Confronts death in his paintings1973 Dies April 8, at the age of 91, in Mougins, FranceCREDIT: SUSAN BATSFORD, GRAPHICS EDITOR, TWITTER @SBATS1/POSTMEDIANETWORK, SOURCES: WIRE STORIES; GRAPHIC NEWS; WIKIPEDIA;WWW.PABLOPICASSO.ORG; NATIONAL GALLERY OF VICTORIAWord count: 557Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Pablo Picasso's Garcon a la Pipe may fetch $70 million US: [Final Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndGarcon a la Pipe, part of Sotheby's May sales, may become the most expensive [Pablo Picasso] ever sold at auction, Charles Moffett, 58, co- chairman of Sotheby's Impressionist and Modern department, said in an interview. The nonprofit Greentree Foundation, established by [John Hay Whitney] and Betsey Cushing Whitney, is selling the work.Prices expected at Sotheby's Impressionist and Modern sale are higher, with several estimated at more than $10 million. Besides the $70-million Picasso, Sotheby's is auctioning an Edouard Manet horseracing scene, Les Courses Au Bois De Boulogne, for $20 million to $30 million. Photo: Reuters / Edouard Manet's Les Courses Au Bois De Boulogne is expected to sell for $20 million to $30 million.; Photo: Reuters / Pablo Picasso's Garcon a la Pipe will be offered at auction by Sotheby's in New York on Wednesday. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Pablo Picasso's 1905 oil painting of a boy in a blue worker's suit with a pipe in his hand may bring a record $70 million US or more when it is auctioned next week at Sotheby's Holdings Inc.Garcon a la Pipe, part of Sotheby's May sales, may become the most expensive Picasso ever sold at auction, Charles Moffett, 58, co- chairman of Sotheby's Impressionist and Modern department, said in an interview. The nonprofit Greentree Foundation, established by John Hay and Betsey Cushing Whitney, is selling the work.Collectors such as the foundation are eager to convert some of their holdings into cash after three years of record-breaking auctions, Moffett said. New York's fall fine-art sales in November brought in $482.3 million, surpassing previous-year sales by 20 per cent and setting more than three dozen artist records."You're finally getting some of this discretionary selling that we've been hoping for a long time," said auction analyst George Sutton, 36, of Minneapolis-based Craig-Hallum Capital Group LLC. "The old adage that death, divorce and debt are the three things that precipitate sales doesn't seem to be quite as true now."The lure of a seller's market may also be attracting inferior work, Bob Monk, 53, director of the Gagosian Gallery on Madison Avenue, said after examining catalogues for the postwar and contemporary sales."It's not bringing out the best stuff," Monk said. "There are people out there looking for work, so maybe this B and C work will find homes."The Picasso, from the artist's Rose period, is being offered as part of a May 5 sale of 34 paintings from a collection amassed by John Hay Whitney, the philanthropist, diplomat and publisher of the New York Herald Tribune, who died in 1982 at age 77. His wife, Betsey Cushing, left the works to the foundation when she died at age 89 in 1998."There was no pressure" to sell, said Richard Schaffer, 57, president of the Greentree Foundation. "It seemed like a reasonable time given what we hope will be a receptive art market." The proceeds will be used to renovate the 160-hectare Whitney estate in Manhasset, N.Y., which hosts international meetings to promote peace, Schaeffer said.Sellers in May also include New York's Museum of Modern Art, the Anderson Fine Arts Center in Anderson, Ind., and German fashion designer Wolfgang Joop, 59. Another is the Fran and Ray Stark Foundation, established by Ray Stark, the producer of such films as The Night of the Iguana and Annie, who died in January at 88."Some people want to capitalize and sell their assets as close to the top of the market as possible," Moffett said. "Other people want to refine their collections so they trade out of some artists and into others."New York's spring auction season begins Tuesday with a sale of Impressionist and Modern art at Christie's International PLC and continues Wednesday and Thursday with Sotheby's Whitney sale and Impressionist and Modern works from various owners. The following week, both auctioneers offer postwar and contemporary art, as does Phillips, de Pury & Co.Tobias Meyer, 41, worldwide head of contemporary art at Sotheby's, said almost everything he is selling May 12 came from discretionary sellers. In Sotheby's private viewing room, he pointed out a number of works offered this season because their owners expect prices to soar.A Jasper Johns watercolour on paper, Corpse and Mirror, is estimated by Sotheby's at $2 million to $3 million. Meyer said the seller, whom he wouldn't name, told him he wants to sell after owning the painting for 12 years because: "Now is the moment."Monk of the Gagosian Gallery said the Johns work is "a seminal piece from an era when Johns started to focus on abstract work" -- meaning "the estimate is warranted."The Christie's contemporary art sale features a number of works estimated above $1 million, including premiere examples by Andy Warhol, Gerhard Richter and Jackson Pollock.The Pollock, Number 12, 1949, estimated at $5 million to $7 million, is one of nine artworks being sold by New York's Museum of Modern Art to reinvest in "works of greater importance," according to a statement by chief curator John Elderfield, 61.MoMA's Il Grande Metafisico, a 1917 oil by Giorgio De Chirico, estimated at $7 million to $10 million, is a highlight of Christie's Impressionist and Modern sale on Tuesday. The auctioneer also has a 1919 Amedeo Modigliani, Portrait de Roger Dutilleul, for $6 million to $8 million and an abstract Joan Miro of 1947, Le Rouge, Le Bleu, Le Bel Espoir, for $4 million to $6 million.Prices expected at Sotheby's Impressionist and Modern sale are higher, with several estimated at more than $10 million. Besides the $70-million Picasso, Sotheby's is auctioning an Edouard Manet horseracing scene, Les Courses Au Bois De Boulogne, for $20 million to $30 million.It also is offering a 40-inch-by-79-inch (102-cm-by-201-cm) Claude Monet water lily painting, Le Bassin Aux Nympheas, from the Stark Foundation for $9 million to $12 million and Picasso's 1932 depiction of a day at the beach, Le Sauvetage, from a private European collection, for $10 million to $15 million. GREAT WORKS: Women Running on the Beach (1922) Pablo Picasso Muse Picasso, Paris: [First Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndAt the start of Samuel Beckett's novel Watt, a passer-by is watching a couple at a tram stop: 'Mr Hackett decided, after some moments, that if they were waiting for a tram they had been doing so for some time. For the lady held the gentleman by the ears, and the gentleman's hand was on the lady's thigh, and the lady's tongue was in the gentleman's mouth. Tired of waiting for a tram, Mr Hackett said, they strike up an acquaintance. The lady now removing her tongue from the gentleman's mouth, he put his into hers. Fair do, said Mr Hackett. Taking a pace forward, to satisfy himself that the gentleman's other hand was not going to waste, Mr Hackett was shocked to find it limply dangling over the back of the seat, with between its fingers the spent three-quarters of a cigarette.'[Pablo Picasso] (1881-1973) needs no introduction. The Spanish painter became in his lifetime the most famous artist in the world, up there with Chaplin and Disney and Einstein and Hitler. It wasn't just a matter of talent. He lived in the 20th century, the first century of global mass publicity. But he had everything. He was a child prodigy. He worked in every medium. He invented or inspired most modern art " Cubism, Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism. He had genius eyes, unflagging testosterone and political engagement " Guernica. But he was never a really popular artist, not like Van Gogh or Dali. In recent decades his art influence has run out, replaced by Marcel Duchamp's. What was he: the great revitaliser, or the great swan song, of the Western pictorial tradition?MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitAt the start of Samuel Beckett's novel Watt, a passer-by is watching a couple at a tram stop: 'Mr Hackett decided, after some moments, that if they were waiting for a tram they had been doing so for some time. For the lady held the gentleman by the ears, and the gentleman's hand was on the lady's thigh, and the lady's tongue was in the gentleman's mouth. Tired of waiting for a tram, Mr Hackett said, they strike up an acquaintance. The lady now removing her tongue from the gentleman's mouth, he put his into hers. Fair do, said Mr Hackett. Taking a pace forward, to satisfy himself that the gentleman's other hand was not going to waste, Mr Hackett was shocked to find it limply dangling over the back of the seat, with between its fingers the spent three-quarters of a cigarette.'Why is this scene like a picture?It's partly because Mr Hackett is like a picture-viewer, intimately observing an intimate scene, without (it seems) any sense of intrusion or fear of detection. But it's also in how the two lovers are described. They are not presented as entire bodies. They are a series of isolated body parts: ears, hand, tongue, mouth, thigh, another hand. They appear in disconnected fragments and glimpses, which is how bodies often appear in pictures.In pictures, things are always being obscured and interrupted by other things. Bodies disappear behind bodies and then reappear the other side. They exist, not whole, but as a series of emerging parts. It's for the viewer to make the relevant connections, to fill in the missing, unseen pieces.And some pictures deliberately make this difficult. They make it hard to see how the parts of a body are supposed to connect up. Gustav Klimt, for example, scatters his bodies. He paints swathes of ornamental material, and then " here and there " there's a gap, and a bit of flesh appears. He does it in his famous Kiss, where you get the heads, hands, and feet of the lovers, but how these extremities join up into bodies behind their ornate robes is anyone's guess. It's a rather clammy effect. It can also be done with gusto, though. Take Picasso's Women Running on the Beach .Picasso was strongly drawn to the seaside. It is his arcadia. Woods and fields and riverbanks hold nothing for him. It is on the beach, on the shores of the Med, among bathers and sunbathers and beach huts, that he finds his ideal world of love and pleasure and play. It is not always a happy world. There can be pain, cruelty and betrayal in it. But here it's at its most exuberant. The picture is like a beach postcard. Its red-white-blue scheme carries a subliminal feeling of a tricoleur flag flapping in the wind.Things are not absolutely jolly. The two women are running together, hand in hand " but obviously racing too. Picasso doesn't have lesbian fantasies, women alone enjoying each other. He can't put two girls together without suggesting a catfight. The runners are competing, and one of them is dramatically out-running her rival. The dynamic of the picture is in the way each figure is in front of and behind the other one.Picasso sometimes does elaborate and elusive variations on human bodies where you can hardly follow what's going on. Here the distortions are demonstratively clear. You have the two figures, heavy limbed and pelting forward, with a terrific momentum, but both have one head, two arms, two legs, in more or less the standard configuration. What is a bit surprising, given the situation, is that all of these body parts are visible. They're visible because in various ways they've been strategically disarranged.Look at the scale. There's a paradox. The nearer figure is the smaller figure. She should really be further away, and this discrepancy makes the figures jostle against each other. Its aggravated by another spatial 'error' " the great left foot of the bigger figure hits the ground nearer the picture's front than the smaller woman's foot. In terms of distance, the bigger woman is both in front of and behind her rival.It's the same when you see how they race across the picture. The larger figure is clearly miles ahead. Her giant left arm stretches out towards the picture's edge, as if it were gaining the winning post. But when you follow her body as it goes behind the smaller figure, you find a crucial disappearing-reappearing trick. Her right leg and foot emerge " suddenly, impossibly " miles behind the other woman, introducing a great jump into the image. And that right foot presses on the picture's other side, pushing off like a swimmer from the side of a pool.No question who's the winner. The ambiguities of 'in front' and 'behind' don't make the race uncertain. They are not allotted equally. The big figure commands the whole width of the picture, the whole length of the race, both starting and finishing in a single leap. The small figure is left running in the middle, on the spot. The big figure encompasses her spatially too, being both further and nearer, running rings round her.The only equalising tendency lies in the possibility of confusion. It's another use of body-fragmentation: the way, at a glance, you can't be sure which legs belong to which figure. In fact, at a glance " and the impression recurs every time you look at the picture " you may perceive no race at all, no clear distinction of figures. There is simply a centrifugal explosion of energy, rather like the domestic punch-ups in Andy Capp, where the isolated, battling hands and feet of Flo and Andy fly out at random from a swirling ball of dust.THE ARTISTPablo Picasso (1881-1973) needs no introduction. The Spanish painter became in his lifetime the most famous artist in the world, up there with Chaplin and Disney and Einstein and Hitler. It wasn't just a matter of talent. He lived in the 20th century, the first century of global mass publicity. But he had everything. He was a child prodigy. He worked in every medium. He invented or inspired most modern art " Cubism, Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism. He had genius eyes, unflagging testosterone and political engagement " Guernica. But he was never a really popular artist, not like Van Gogh or Dali. In recent decades his art influence has run out, replaced by Marcel Duchamp's. What was he: the great revitaliser, or the great swan song, of the Western pictorial tradition?Word count: 1102Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitDame Edna Everage, one of Australia's four contributions to global culture, revealed yesterday that she had a brief fling with famed artist Pablo Picasso.The bombshell's bombshell was dropped as she was presented with the key to the city of Melbourne."I was just a young Australian tourist," she revealed to the assembled throngs of her countrymen. "I saw this little podgy fellow -- he looked like Paul Hogan, before the operation ... it was just kind of a thing."The self-proclaimed gigastar also claimed the affair happened after Picasso parted ways with Dora Maar, the photographer who documented the 1937 painting of Guernica.Dame Edna said that her home continent -- which also gave us Nick Cave, Peter Carey and the aforementioned Hogan -- would eventually get to see the portraits Picasso painted of her.The alleged paintings, which she said were in storage in Switzerland, will be displayed at Australia's national gallery in Victoria "when they come to their senses."The occasion for yesterday's ceremony was the 50th anniversary of Dame Edna's career. The purple-haired female impersonator is played by Barry Humphries, 72.She was presented the spectacle-topped novelty key by Melbourne's Lord Mayor John So, to whom she referred as an "adorable little multicultural gentleman."Celebrating 50 years on the stage, Dame Edna Everage hammed it up for the cameras after being given the key to the city of Melbourne yesterday. Above, with "adorable, little multicultural" Lord Mayor John So. The Aussie icon said that she "had a deep affection for the city -- I snuck in when the door was ajar" and noted that she really ought to have been given the swipe card to the city.
