[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitA sketch by Bridget Riley and a work by Henri Matisse are among a remarkable collection of modern art assembled by the late film critic Alexander Walker, which will go on display this week.They are part of a legacy of works left to the nation by Mr Walker, whose reviews over five decades could make or break a movie.The work of Pablo Picasso, Lucian Freud and Philip Guston were among 200 prints and drawings left to the British Museum by Mr Walker when he died last year, aged 73. The writer had worked for London's Evening Standard for 43 years and had no family.The museum calls the collection its most important modern art bequest of the past 50 years.The works covered almost every space in Mr Walker's modest flat in London's Maida Vale. So vast was his collection, he had no space to hang a Freud etching: it simply rested against a wall in his bedroom.The Freud was one of a number of works he bought in order to supplement gaps in the museum's collection, after deciding in 2000 the institution should be the beneficiary when he died.Stephen Coppel, curator of the Walker exhibition which opens on Tuesday, said: "He knew in effect he was buying for the museum, in the sense that he would let me know he had bought such and such, so we could avoid duplication."His art collecting was an almost obsessive passion, on which he spent hundreds of thousands of pounds, earned from the royalties on his books - including biographies of Peter Sellers and Vivien Leigh - as well as his review column.Mr Walker, brought up in Portadown, Northern Ireland, had a childhood love of movies. He began his career as a writer on newspapers in Birmingham and started reviewing films in 1953. Seven years later he moved to the Standard. His first purchases, two works by Keith Vaughan, were made in 1965."Given that he had this compunction for things visual, it's not surprising he loved static images when he came home," said Mr Coppel.His eclectic collection concentrated on post-1960 works by US and British artists, and he also had a stable of School of Paris artists - the earliest being a 1908 sketch by Picasso."He never sold any of his works. Once he had made a decision to buy, he would keep it for the simple reason that it showed something about himself at the time he bought it," Mr Coppel said.Philip French, The Observer film critic, recalled: "Visiting his small, beautifully appointed flat in Maida Vale was like being in a reclusive connoisseur's retreat or an art fence's den."Although no one doubted his powers as a film critic, not all his friends were impressed by his abilities as an art connoisseur. Brian Sewell, the Standard's art critic, said Mr Walker was compulsive about buying art. "He would come back from New York dealers with his little trophies saying `I only had to pay $12,000 for this, it was a very special deal just for me'. He would have some American garbage, a discard from the studio floor."Matisse to Freud: A Critic's Choice - The Alexander Walker Bequest runs from Tuesday to 9 January 2005 in the Prints and Drawings Gallery of the British Museum. Entry is free IllustrationCaption: Alexander Walker in his Maida Vale flat, main picture, and clockwise from above, `Joseph and his Brethren' by Keith Vaughan; `Grand Nu' by Henri Matisse; `Study for "Blaze"' by Bridget Riley; Bridget Riley sketch; and `Shouting One Morning' by Avigdor ArikhaWord count: 635Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit AN EXCITING show of works by some of the most influential Modern artists of all time from Picasso, Matisse, Renoir and Chagall to Dali, Cocteau and Miro will be opening at The Drang Gallery in Padstow on Tuesday, and will run until the end of the month.The show embraces original prints, drawings, ceramics and photographs by the leading members of the School of Paris and by Impressionists including Renoir.Works in the collection will be available for sale for a limited period only and range in price from under Pounds 1,000 to Pounds 12,000.This is a rare opportunity to acquire a piece of work with solid provenance from a legendary Modern artist at an affordable price.Lithographs by Henri Matisse and Jean Cocteau are among those in the more reasonably priced category. A Matisse lithograph The Fall of Icarus, 1945 depicts the mythological figure of Icarus in simplified semi-abstract form against a bold royal blue night sky.This piece is characteristic of the artist's playful style and his liberal use of pure colour and comes at a price of Pounds 1,650.Another Matisse entitled Visage (La Peine Devidee ...) from 1946 captures the artist's recognisably fluid line in his simple but strong depiction of a woman's face and has a price tag of Pounds 1,400.Several works by Cocteau another master of the strong stylised line, can be seen at the show. One signed piece entitled The Lovers (Les Amoureux) depicting two lovers kissing, is available for Pounds 1,600. This work explores The young in love - an appropriate theme for the summer and one much hallowed by this artist.The Surrealist artist Salvador Dali is also well represented. One original etching and aquatint in colours entitled Combat des Cavaliers (Knightly Combat, Los Caballeros), 1975 - a vivid representation of jousting horsemen, is available at the remarkably reasonable price of Pounds 600.Highlights of this fascinating exhibition include works by Marc Chagall and Pablo Picasso. A particularly fine signed lithograph by Chagall depicts the return of Ulysses from the Trojan wars.The artist's brilliant use of green makes this an especially eye-catching example of his colourful work.From an edition numbered 21/30 and signed by the artist in pencil, this work was part of a large series for L'Odyssee by Homer, published in a deluxe edition in 1975. It carries the highest price tag in the exhibition: Pounds 11,500. Picasso is well represented with several works ranging from affordable unsigned pieces to more important works.One of the most notable is a large signed aquatint entitled Le Picador depicting a scene from the Corrida where the bull bravely faces up to the picador before his fight to the death. A rare artist's proof from 1979 of the original 1952 aquatint, this significant piece carries a price tag of Pounds 10,000.The Drang Gallery is delighted to be able to bring this fascinating and diverse exhibition of works from the Masters of Modern Art to Padstow then Salcombe. With prices ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand pounds the exhibition aims to cater for most tastes and budgets and is a must for all art lovers.For more information contact The Drang Gallery, Drang, South Quay, Padstow, PL28 8BL. Tel 01841 533114; e-mail enquiries@thedranggallery.comIllustrationCaption: Art coup for The Drang - The Fall Of Icarus by Matisse, Visage (La Peine Devidee ...) Matisse, and The Lovers by Cocteau.Word count: 572Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitRare works by painter Pablo Picasso were a top draw for collectors and investors at the art world's biggest annual fair of modern and contemporary works, Art Basel, which opened to the public yesterday in Basel, Switzerland. At least one -- a 1969 Man with a Pipe, right -- by the Spanish artist has never before been on public display, while others have never been on the open market or even reproduced in books of his work. "Given the prices Picasso is fetching on the market, it is not surprising that a range of his works hardly seen before are here this year," said London gallery owner and Art Basel exhibitor Thomas Gibson. The four-day Art Basel, now in its 37th year, is often dubbed the "El Dorado" of the art business. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit A rare Pablo Picasso painting - showing the artist in a lover's clinch - found lying in a Westcountry bedroom has sold for pounds81,260.The early watercolour by the Spanish artist, called Etreinte (Embrace), was found propped up against a wall in a house alongside two important equine paintings by British painters George Stubbs and Alfred Munnings. They sold for pounds53,775 and pounds65,725 respectively.The anonymous seller is believed to be a member of an international royal family.The paintings were expected to make up to pounds100,000 each when they went under the hammer at Duke's in Dorchester, Dorset. A spokesman said bidding was brisk for the pictures with the Picasso and Stubbs going to UK-based buyers, but the new owner of the Munnings is unknown.Etreinte is an early painting of Picasso with his lover Odette, and the Munnings, The Irish Grey Mare, has never been available at auction.Guy Schwinge, of Duke's, said: "It was a breathtaking find to discover these paintings that were stacked against the wall of a house."To find just one of these works would have been incredible - but to find three was quite exceptional. Of course, everybody has heard of Picasso and this is an early work thought to be of him in a naked clinch with girlfriend Odette."The sexually charged Picasso piece shows the artist and his lover Louise Lenoir, who was known as Odette.She is thought to have been Picasso's first girlfriend in Paris.It was thought to have been painted in 1901 or 1902 when Picasso was a struggling artist in his early 20s and it was authenticated by the man himself in 1969.Word count: 278Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit ON A bench in the Plaza de la Merced, a metal sculpture of the world's most famous artist sits on a bench, quietly surveying the square in front. Although Pablo Picasso was just 13 when he left Malaga for the more bustling city of Barcelona, there are plenty of traces of his boyhood waiting to be found among the quiet town's streets.You just have to be prepared to look.This is one of them - a peaceful space not far from the main shopping district, where his parents, Jos Ruiz Blasco and Maria Picasso Lopez, met.sIn the mid-1880s, he played here to a soundtrack of chattering servants and shouting salesmen selling home-made jams and milk straight from the goat.It was here that he would have seen his first pigeons and doves - later an important symbol of peace in his art.Long before he shrank his incredibly long name - Pablo Diego Jos Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno Maria de los Remedios Crispin Crispiniano de la Santisima Trinidad Ruiz y Picasso - down to the bite-size "Pablo Picasso", he painted his first bird under the careful watch of his father, a well known artist of pigeons.It is not possible to visit the family's home where this took place - a single floor of 32 Plaza de la Merced (today at number 17 since the street has been re-numbered).But just a few doors down is his birthplace, now the Fundacion Pablo Picasso.It's a small space - just a few rooms - with the walls of the front room painted maroon and the floorboards bare giving you a feel for the simplicity of the young artist's life.Several of his father's works are on display, as well as his brother's Christening gown, while a small exhibition of 25 of Picasso's own ceramics fills the rest of the third floor.Jos Ruiz Blasco held the post of Linear Drawing and Decoration teacher at the Malaga School of Fine Arts in Plaza de la Constitucion - spot the plaque on the pavement outside.This was the first place that young Pablo came into contact with the sort of classical plaster models that he would later be asked to copy in his studies at art school in Barcelona.The many painters who passed through the classrooms here provided Picasso with inspiration as he watched first-hand the creation of large historical scenes that were very much in fashion at the time.Another school building with a link to Picasso - albeit a pretty tenous one - is the Instituto de Segunda Enseanza, where he sat an exam shortly before leaving Malaga.A plaque on the wall of the picturesque courtyard states this fact and an ancient-looking leatherbound register locked away in a safe records his name. Beyond this there is little evidence of his presence.Discover The simplest way to discover Picasso's Malaga is to wander the streets.Just drink in the atmosphere, perhaps with the help of a themed audioguide you can hire from Tourist Information.It comes with a handy leaflet, giving brief details about the places linked to the painter, including Iglesia de Santiago where he was Christened. His name, written in the Church register at the name, is prominently on display next to the font.There's also the Malaga Picasso Museum, set up by members of his family in an airy building deliberately reminiscent of the sort of houses he loved.The collection includes 155 works donated by the artist's daughter-inlaw and grandson, Christine and Bernard Ruiz-Picasso, the latter also a major contributor to Tate Liverpool's current exhibition. The gallery has recently been rearranged so that the paintings are displayed in thematic - rather than date - order, giving a clearer idea of the ideas behind them.And when your eyes can't take in any more bright colours, you can indulge your inner Tony Robinson with a visit to the basement where an archaeological site containing Phoenician, Roman and Moorish remains is carefully preserved.While you're in Malaga, it's certainly worth exploring some of the other sites that, while not directly linked to Picasso, would have been part of his experience of living in the town.Towering over the narrow streets below is the Alcazaba, a hilltop fort built in the 11th century that predates the larger Alhambra in Granada.You can walk through the spiraling gardens to the very top for views over the whole area, then get the lift down - or do it the other way around if you're feeling lazy.A few minutes drive into the hills is the Parador of Gibralfaro - a government-run restaurant surrounded by blooming hanging baskets and over-looking the sea.Don't be put off by the government's involvement - the food here is delicious, if not cheap - and it's worth a visit for the views over the bullring, where Picasso first got a taste for painting toreadors.fact file Laura Davis flew with Monarch, who offer year round flights to Malaga from Manchester airport with fares, including taxes, starting from pounds 54.99 one-way (or pounds 90.50 return).Hot and cold meals can be pre-booked or purchased onboard with prices from pounds 3. Seats can be pre-booked at pounds 7.50 per one-way flight to avoid the last minute rush, or pounds 20 for extra-legroom seats. See www.monarch.co.uk Laura stayed at the four-star Hotel Molina Lario, made up of three 19th century buildings close to the Cathedral. It has 103 modern bedrooms, a restaurant, El Cafe de Bolsa, and an open-air swimming pool.Prices vary but you are advised to book online for the best details. Head for www.hotelmolinalario.com.Word count: 942Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. One original etching and aquatint in colours entitled Combat des Cavaliers (Knightly Combat, Los Caballeros), 1975 - a vivid representation of jousting horsemen, is available at the remarkably reasonable price of Pounds 600.Highlights of this fascinating exhibition include works by Marc Chagall and Pablo Picasso. A particularly fine signed lithograph by Chagall depicts the return of Ulysses from the Trojan wars.The artist's brilliant use of green makes this an especially eye-catching example of his colourful work.From an edition numbered 21/30 and signed by the artist in pencil, this work was part of a large series for L'Odyssee by Homer, published in a deluxe edition in 1975. It carries the highest price tag in the exhibition: Pounds 11,500. Picasso is well represented with several works ranging from affordable unsigned pieces to more important works.One of the most notable is a large signed aquatint entitled Le Picador depicting a scene from the Corrida where the bull bravely faces up to the picador before his fight to the death. A rare artist's proof from 1979 of the original 1952 aquatint, this significant piece carries a price tag of Pounds 10,000.The Drang Gallery is delighted to be able to bring this fascinating and diverse exhibition of works from the Masters of Modern Art to Padstow then Salcombe. With prices ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand pounds the exhibition aims to cater for most tastes and budgets and is a must for all art lovers.For more information contact The Drang Gallery, Drang, South Quay, Padstow, PL28 8BL. Tel 01841 533114; e-mail enquiries@thedranggallery.comIllustrationCaption: Art coup for The Drang - The Fall Of Icarus by Matisse, Visage (La Peine Devidee ...) Matisse, and The Lovers by Cocteau.Word count: 572Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit "His cerebral artistry on canvas has few equals in India today, but there was a time when Atul Dodiya almost made up his mind to stop painting. His first real brush with the works of international masters while in Paris on a French government grant to train at the École des Beaux-Arts was as cathartic for his curious mind as it was depressing - just seeing all that had been done before made him doubt there was anything substantial he could offer. The phase lasted almost three years and by the end of it, he realised that it was not a question of being better, but learning from the legends. "Picasso was always my hero. I remember cutting a newspaper clipping about his death when I was just around 13-years-old. In Paris, I lived close to the Picasso Museum and I learnt more about his various phases and his evolution as an artist. I was fascinated by his extreme creativity and the immense risks he took, whether it was in style or subject matter. His life is the greatest lesson for any artist who strives to be fearless and unbound by rules," an animated Dodiya told this diarist. His own later works broke free of any singular motif and regularly contained references to Picasso and his other favourite, Matisse. Now we hear that Dodiya's acclaimed Lamentation (which is now part of Harsh Goenka's art collection) has been requested on loan by the Museum Picasso in Barcelona. It will be showcased as part of a global selection - curated by Dr Fitzgerald, Professor of Fine Art at Trinity College - depicting Picasso's influence on contemporary art. Dodiya is understandably over the moon and the significance of the development for both Indian art and the artist personally is not lost on Goenka. "The curator of the exhibition was very keen to have this work. It's one of Atul's greatest works and has been inspired by the work of Picasso. I had no hesitation in agreeing," he smiled."Credit:Saumit SinhWord count: 339Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Of genius, humanity and sex ; Steve Martin play pairs Pablo Picasso with Albert Einstein: [Ontario Edition]
Full Article: AbstractClocking in at 90 minutes without intermission, it's a light, bright and breezy comedy, "and I wondered how I was going to put my heart into it," says Pettle, who plays painter [Pablo Picasso] opposite Alon Nashman's [Albert Einstein].The play is set in Paris in 1904 at the Lapin Agile, a real-life bistro. There, [Steve Martin] imagines a meeting between the 23-year-old Picasso and Einstein, who is 25.The inspiration for the play came from a photo in a biography of Picasso that Martin was reading. Behind the bohemian group in the photo was a Picasso painting and Martin recognized it as one that had just sold for $40 million. Originally, Pettle says, Picasso probably paid his bar bill with it. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitThe Sept. 11 tragedy in the United States gave actor Jordan Pettle some qualms about appearing in Picasso At The Lapin Agile.Clocking in at 90 minutes without intermission, it's a light, bright and breezy comedy, "and I wondered how I was going to put my heart into it," says Pettle, who plays painter Pablo Picasso opposite Alon Nashman's Albert Einstein."Then I realized that it is a good thing. It is what we (actors) do, and I think people need stories that are life-affirming right now. It feels good to be working on something that has a hopeful centre to it.The play, written by comedian Steve Martin in the early 1990s, opens tonight at the Bluma Appel Theatre, 27 Front St. E., and runs until Nov. 24. This Canadian Stage production is its Toronto premiere.The play is set in Paris in 1904 at the Lapin Agile, a real-life bistro. There, Martin imagines a meeting between the 23-year-old Picasso and Einstein, who is 25.Their careers are about to take off, Einstein with his theory of relativity, Picasso with his revolutionary painting, Les Demoiselles.The inspiration for the play came from a photo in a biography of Picasso that Martin was reading. Behind the bohemian group in the photo was a Picasso painting and Martin recognized it as one that had just sold for $40 million. Originally, Pettle says, Picasso probably paid his bar bill with it.The photo provided Martin with a jumping-off point to explore the creative impulse, and the humanity underneath the genius of the two men.At his core, Picasso was simply a guy who wanted to make beautiful art, and Martin portrays him as incredibly motivated by sex, Pettle says."His creative impulse and sexual impulse come from the same place, which, from all the other reading I have done about Picasso, seems to be true. He went from the brothels to his easel to the brothels. He lived passionately and hungrily."The play is about sex and art, says Pettle, "two things that I enjoy."The 30-year-old Pettle has been a busy working actor since graduating from Montreal's National Theatre School in 1994. Next spring, however, his schedule will be particularly full.First he will star in the Mirvish Productions remount of Adam Pettle's hit play Zadie's Shoes, which runs at the Winter Garden Theatre from the end of March until May 11.He will also direct a revival of Therac 25 written by and starring brother Adam. Therac 25 will be at Factory Theatre from April 25 to May 19."So I'll be directing him in his play by day and acting in his play at night," says Jordan. "We're both a little crazy to take on so much, but I'm very excited about it."Jordan Pettle spent several seasons at the Stratford Festival where his roles included an outstanding Fool in the 1996 production of King Lear. But he was less than happy with his work in 1999, his most recent season there."It took it out of me and I didn't have the best year," he says. "I lost my excitement a bit and that's a scary feeling."Now, however, he feels he's growing and maturing as an actor. "I think I used to stress too much. I'm not being so hard on myself."And his aim now is to open up and to extend his emotional reach."I'd love to give Stratford another shot, I'd love to work with Soulpepper, I'd love to do Chekhov. There's a whole range of different kinds of characters that I would like to step into."OTHER NOTABLESAlumnae Theatre presents the Toronto premiere of Shirley Barrie's The Pear Is Ripe, one woman's personal and political journey, set in 19th-century Paris. Molly Thom directs. It runs from tomorrow until Nov. 10 at 70 Berkeley St.The Vindication Of Senyora Clito Mestres by Montserrat Roig opens tomorrow at the Theatre Centre, 1087 Queen St. W., and runs until Nov. 11. Dragana Varagic stars as an actress preparing to play the role of Clytemnestra and struggling with personal tragedy. Chris Abraham directs.Judith Thompson, Ronnie Burkett, Adam Pettle, Andrew Moodie and Daniel Goldfarb will share their expertise at a playwrights panel about writing for the theatre. It's this Saturday at the Bluma Appel Theatre, 27 Front St. E. Title: Abstract
Impressions of genius ; A museum show of Pablo Picasso prints encompasses his long, varied, prolific career.: [METRO Edition]

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitSpecial to the Star Tribune.Everyone has an opinion of Pablo Picasso, or at least an impression. With good reason, many consider him the 20th century's greatest artist. Others wonder if his astonishing, multifaceted talents were sometimes squandered in overproduction and in the caprices of someone too aware of his own genius.The Minneapolis Institute of Arts is offering a chance to reassess Picasso, in a manageable way, through a tight overview of one medium of his art: printmaking.Picasso (1881-1973) was born in Spain and lived mainly in France. Although best known as a painter, he produced about 2,500 print images, according to exhibit organizer Lisa Michaux, associate curator of prints and drawings at the institute."Printmaking suited the way Picasso worked," Michaux said. "He was impatient, and he was possessive. He'd print an image before it was finished to see how it looked, then change it and reprint it so he could have it in lots of different states."The exhibition showcases the institute's holdings, which include 30 prints and 13 artist's books. Michaux has also borrowed from regional collections to expand the show to more than 80 works.The institute's own "Frugal Repast" (1904) is a famous etching of an emaciated but elegantly rendered couple seated before a stoic meal of table wine and a bread chunk. Eleven images on loan from a Chicago collection make up for the museum's lack of prints from Picasso's cubist phase, 1909 to 1915.In the 1930s, printer Roger Lacouriere helped Picasso master techniques that yielded tones and surfaces reminiscent of painting. From Ottawa's National Gallery of Canada comes a fine impression of Picasso's 1935 etching, "The Minotauromachy," widely considered his greatest print.It shows a big minotaur, a common Picasso alter ego, held at bay by various images representing his pregnant mistress Marie-Therese Walter, whose role as his lover was nearing its end. As a female matador, she still firmly grasps her sword while sprawling over the back of a wounded horse."Female Bullfighter I," an etching from the previous year, suggests a less conflicted period in their love affair. In a swirling harmony of lines, the resplendent bull overwhelms Marie- Therese. Their lips almost touch, and her matador sword is about to fall from her hand."Picasso is all about relationships," said Michaux, "relationships with women, with printers, with dealers and publishers." Picasso's collaboration with printer Fernand Mourlot in postwar Paris defined a major period dominated by lithography."Mourlot would tell Picasso what to do," Michaux said. "Picasso would listen, then do it his own way, and it would be good." An example is "The Striped Blouse," a color lithograph of Picasso's new love, Francoise Gilot. She is sphinxlike in a stark, frontal view that has the ornate look of a face card.Picasso had intense relationships with artists, too. His cubism was a joint effort with Georges Braque, and always Picasso felt the challenge and inspiration of Henri Matisse."Still Life With Cherries and Watermelon" (1962) is a terrific big linoleum block print that displays Matisse's collagelike lyricism in a fanciful plate of fruit under a tilted ceiling lamp that shoots out zigzag rays of light.Picasso did many such linocuts after moving to the south of France in the 1950s. This one is on loan from the Grand Rapids Art Museum, along with a series of proofs leading up to it. A recent institute acquisition, "After the Lance," is a sprightly 1959 linocut of picador, horse and bull.Other well-known prints include "The Dove," "Woman With a Tambourine," "Still Life With a Bottle of Marc," "Bust of a Woman After Cranach" and animal images from the 1942 book "Histoire Naturelle."Picasso's last printing outburst erupted in 1968, when at age 87 he produced his ribald "Suite 347" series of etchings. From that year, the show has only a small, illustrated book. But this is a minor gap in a concise yet sweeping overview of an artist whose vast output, to paraphrase critic Robert Hughes, inspires awe even more than aesthetic pleasure.- Doug Hanson is a Minneapolis freelance writer..IF YOU GOPicasso: Prints in the 20th CenturyReview: A fine chance to reassess the last century's most renowned artist through an illuminating survey of his major periods of printmaking.When: Opens Saturday. Thru Oct. 29.Where: Minneapolis Institute of Arts, 2400 3rd Av. S.Tickets: $6. 612-870-3131. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Selfi is a label that makes one sit up and take notice. It's funky yet simple, fresh and forward-thinking.The brand was created in 2009, but in recent years has been quick to rise, picking up the attention of fashion fiends, blogs and critics across the country.Cape-Town based Celeste Arendse is the brainchild behind Selfi which showcases a range of clothes and accessories for men and women.The label's designs are known for bright colour with minimal design. The Autumn/Winter 2016 collection was launched last week at The Mercedez Benz Fashion Week in Joburg.The collection draws inspiration from the indigenous Khoisan as well as Pablo Picasso's cubist style.The range sees a return to basics, combining linen, kishibo and rayon in simple and comfortable style, but using print and colour in a bold way.The influence of San-rock painting is blended with an African interpretation of Picasso's paintings and the female form during his cubist period.The collection is an exploration of tones of mahogany, chocolate browns and camel that incorporate graphic lines of navy blue, sage and pearl into prints.Collaborations on leather bags were carried out with Cape Town based jewellery designer Giselle Human, from WAIF.Arendse completed her studies in fashion design at Cape Peninsula University of Technology and thereafter worked at a high-end local brand Kluk CGDT.She became Elle's New Talent finalist in 2009 and from there ventured into creating her own brand.Last year, Selfi was exposed at Pure London and New York Fashion Week.The name "Selfi" has no reference to "selfie" as it is known today, but rather was inspired by surrealism, referring to the self and a child-like approach to playing with form and print.l Selfi items can be found at the Old Biscuit Mill (Woodstock), Mungo and Jemima (CBD) and South African Market (CBD).l See www.selfi.co.za. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit D eep in the heart of Somerset lies the beautiful, sparsely-populated Levels, one of the world's most important, and Britain's largest, wetlands.A predominantly reclaimed landscape, it is home to myriad waterfowl, legendary kings Arthur and Alfred, traditional hand crafts - and international modern art."It seems an unlikely venue for exhibitions of world-famous artists' work doesn't it?" admits John Leach, third generation potter, who five years ago opened an art gallery next to his famous family pottery in the ancient Levels' village of Muchelney.The fruition of a cherished dream, John's gallery was meant to enable him and his wife Lizzie to display and sell paintings and craftwork by their favourite West Country artists and makers.But a chance meeting with a respected Midlands gallery owner led also to exhibitions by artists of the calibre of Chagall, Matisse, Miro and Kandinsky."It was incredible," says John. "Suddenly we had people travelling from all over the West Country to see and buy the work we were showing, here in the middle of nowhere!" The next exhibition at The John Leach Gallery, and the most prestigious to date, will be a major show of Picasso original prints, due to open on Monday, March 29.John has acquired 60 original lithographs and etchings which rank among the greatest prints of the 20th century."It's such an honour to be able to put on this exhibition - the prints are amazing," he says.Each is unique, made by hand and vivid in both a tactile and visual sense.Pablo Picasso, born in Spain in 1881, became the most famous, prolific, inventive and influential artist of the 20th century. He is widely considered to be one of the greatest modern artists of our time. He had a love of printmaking and by the time he died in 1973 had produced a substantial body of original etchings, lithographs and linocuts. The subject matter was as varied as his techniques.From 1919, he mostly preferred lithographs and produced more than 850. His early lithographs were often worked on transfer drawings, as opposed to directly on a plate. Pochoirs were created using hand-cut stencils similar to the process of creating serigraphs.Current prices for Picasso pictures at auction houses reflect his enduring popularity and the profound impact of his work.While ownership of an original painting or drawing is, for the majority of us, out of the question, Picasso original prints, made in comparatively small editions, are still relatively accessible, with prices from about Pounds 450.The Picasso exhibition at The John Leach Gallery is open until June 23, from Monday to Saturday, 9am-1pm and 2-5pm. Admission and parking are free and all exhibits are for sale.For more details visit www.johnleachpottery.co.uk or telephone 01458 250324. The John Leach Gallery at Muchelney Pottery is on the fringe of Muchelney, two miles south of Langport, Somerset TA10 0DW.It's such an honour to be able to put on this exhibition - the prints are amazingCredit: Pablo PicassoIllustrationCaption: The prints include Le Gout du Bonheur screenprint, top left, Pounds 750, L'atelier de Cannes lithograph, top right, Pounds 3,000, and Maternita' e Arancia, above, Pounds 975; Potter John Leach in his gallery at Muchelney, Somerset, hanging limited edition prints by Pablo Picasso with co-ordinator of the exhibition Rachael Rees. Title: Abstract
Portrait of the artist as a monster: His granddaughter says Pablo Picasso had to 'destroy in order to create': [Final Edition]

Humiliatingly, her father [Paolo]'s job was as [Pablo Picasso]'s chauffeur and dogsbody. Once he had dreamed of freeing himself by becoming a professional motorbike racer, which Picasso ruled to be too dangerous.Marina's mother, Emilienne, was more in love with the Picasso name than Paolo and the couple separated when Marina was six months old. Too grand to work, Emilienne was reliant on her share of the allowance; a source of loud reproach that distressed the children. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPablo Picasso was a monster who needed to be appeased with human sacrifices like an Aztec god, says his granddaughter, Marina Picasso. The chosen victims were his loved ones. "No one in my family managed to escape his stranglehold. He needed blood to sign each of his paintings."It sounds like hyperbole but the death toll suggests a terrible family malediction. Marina's brother, Pablito, committed suicide by drinking bleach. Her grandmother, the once beautiful Olga, died paralysed. Her father, Paolo, expired as a broken reed. Jacqueline, Picasso's last wife, shot herself. Marie-Therese Walter, the artist's muse, hanged herself.Marina has no doubt that she, too, was an intended victim. "In order to create, he had to destroy everything that got in the way of his creation. However, like him, I have enormous energy and a strong character, otherwise I would be dead, too."She did not escape unscathed, however, spending 14 years in psychoanalysis, marked by uncontrollable tears, fainting fits and screams. "I have been trying all my life to escape the misery created by Picasso," she declares.She has also fallen out with the artist's other heirs, accusing them of greed and "bad taste" in selling the family name to Citroen. They look askance at her for adopting three Vietnamese children and diluting the legacy of her two children, products of a failed relationship.Now an elegant, composed and incalculably rich woman of 50, she divides her time between Geneva and Picasso's huge white house in Cannes, which she once associated with unhappy memories. She also runs a foundation for orphaned children in Vietnam and lends her grandfather's pictures to galleries around the world.She was 22 years old when Picasso died in 1973. Believing that all the family's misfortunes flowed from art, she announced she did not want to inherit anything. Persuaded by French lawyers this was impossible, she accepted a quarter of the inheritance, but stacked the paintings against walls so she could not see them.Her grandfather had reached beyond the grave to cause her brother's death, she believed. Six days after Picasso died, Pablito drank a bottle of bleach."We both loved my grandfather, although it was never reciprocated. When he died my brother and I wanted to see him one last time, but Jacqueline didn't want to receive us. Pablito went to the house alone and they set the dogs on him. He came home and committed suicide."She found him lying on a sofa, blood bubbling from his mouth, and spent the next three months by his side in hospital until he died. She did not have enough money to pay for his coffin because she and her brother were kept in dependent penury. Pablito had told her it was his attempt to escape; few others had succeeded.In a remarkable new book, Picasso, My Grandfather, being published this month, Marina describes how each member of the family became dependent on and cravenly submissive to Picasso's towering ego."The Picasso virus to which we fell victim was subtle and undetectable," she says. "It was a combination of promises not kept, abuse of power, mortification, contempt and, above all, incommunicability. We were defenceless against it."Every Thursday was "allowance day." Marina and Pablito would be led by their father to the big white house to collect their weekly pittance.Once admitted, the supplicants were tortured by the spectacle of a pet goat, leaving its droppings amid canvases piled willy-nilly amid a jumble of priceless sculptures and bric-a-brac. The great man was wont to receive them at his studio in his underpants -- "his overflowing attributes visible" -- in an uncaring display of his omnipotence that he continued until the end of his life."The only mark of love I can remember ever receiving from him was a stuffed fig and date," Marina confesses. Later she learned that such sweetmeats were called mendicants -- beggars.On a good day, her father's subservience would be rewarded with a wad of notes and Picasso's cutting observation that his only son was second-rate and a waste of his time. Humiliatingly, her father Paolo's job was as Pablo's chauffeur and dogsbody. Once he had dreamed of freeing himself by becoming a professional motorbike racer, which Picasso ruled to be too dangerous."After that he didn't attempt to have any financial independence. Even when my grandmother Olga died, he didn't accept the Picasso works she left him because he wanted to do nothing to upset his father."As a boy, Paolo's features had been immortalized in Picasso's studies of Harlequin. But one day the cosseting ceased, paralysing the young man's will. "He also painted Olga in their first years together. But when he had used up someone, he went on to another subject. He tortured Olga and when she was dying he never went to visit her."Marina's mother, Emilienne, was more in love with the Picasso name than Paolo and the couple separated when Marina was six months old. Too grand to work, Emilienne was reliant on her share of the allowance; a source of loud reproach that distressed the children. Sharing her husband's predilection for drink, she also took to picking up toy boys on the beach and bringing them home."I can still remember how humiliated I was as a young teenager when she would walk into a meeting of students and parents dressed in a miniskirt, with a young man barely older than I was."At 14 years old, Marina put her foot down. Resentful of the way they were being manipulated as pawns in a weekly financial transaction, she and Pablito tried to establish a more personal relationship with their grandfather. "We wanted to have our own identity but it was badly received. We were beaten. I don't think my grandfather was really interested," she says.This realization dawned one day at a bullfight he had taken them to. "Why do you cry over the fate of those horses?" he asked me. "They're too old and only good for the butcher's shop." She understood that the fate of those who served his pleasure was secondary.Impoverishment drove the siblings to take summer jobs, an act incomprehensible to those who believed Picasso's grandchildren to be millionaires. In reality, the old man sometimes withheld their school fees.When Marina passed her baccalaureate exam, she announced her wish to attend a medical school and become a pediatrician. "I was told through the lawyers that the course was too long and too costly. They refused."In 1982 she had a breakdown. It occurred while she was driving her two children, Gael and Flore, to school in Geneva. Seized by a violent panic attack, she stalled in the middle of the road, eventually managing to call for help.In the first of many visits to a psychoanalyst, she found herself unable to introduce herself by name. Instead she said: "I am Picasso's granddaughter." That was her identity and the problem.She has now come to realize that her image of her grandfather was distorted. "For a long time I held that Picasso was solely responsible for our misery. Everything was his fault." Now, she has concluded that her grandfather was stolen from her by her irresponsible parents who steeped their meetings in servility.She also concedes that Picasso was so isolated inside his work that he had lost contact with reality. His work was his only language, and it was one the family could not share. So is the Picasso virus extinct at last? "Personally I think I've got rid of it," she says. "One can only hope so." IllustrationPhoto: Pablo Picasso with his grand-daughter Marina when she was a toddler. ; Photo: Paul Cooper / Marina in an undated photo in the garden of her home in Cannes. The home previously belonged to Picasso. ;Word count: 1354Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Gravity and grace of two masters: An exhibition in Paris counterpoints the work of Pablo Picasso and Alexander Calder, writes Rachel Spence
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPicasso came, very early, to my show at [Galerie] Percier and I was introduced," wrote Alexander Calder in the mid-1950s, remembering his first encounter with Pablo Picasso in Paris in 1931. By then the Spaniard was the colossus of European art, a man who had redefined painting through Cubism and his transgressive riffs on Neoclassicism. Calder was an ingénue by comparison; the Percier show was the first vitrine for his abstract sculptures. Only the year before had Calder visited Mondrian's studio in Paris and, on seeing the Dutch painter's static grids, had the revelation that "it would be fun to make these rectangles oscillate." This led to the mobiles for which he is most famous.The duo met on three further occasions — most fruitfully in 1937, when Calder placed his "Mercury Fountain" in front of Picasso's painting "Guernica" at the Spanish Pavilion at the Paris World's Fair. Here Calder's aquatic acrobat brought a cool, abstract balance to the heart-wrenching violence of Picasso's antiwar cry.In 1952, they lunched together at a mutual friend's home in Antibes. The following year, Calder visited Vallauris, where Picasso was making ceramics. Here, another guest told Calder that Picasso "got red in the face" with anger when the American made a quip about one of his plates.Now they are together again at the Musée Picasso in Paris, where their common ground is established in the small opening gallery. Here, we find three iron-wire maquettes fashioned by Picasso in 1921 as possible designs for a monument to his friend, the poet Guillaume Apollinaire, who had died in 1918. Among them is a waif-like sculpture with a tiny disc for a head and creepy little hands and feet. With its multitude of ferrous lines tracing the air, the spindly mischief-maker embodies the poet's own reference to "a statue made of nothing — like poetry and fame". The Spaniard's sculptures are counterpointed by Calder's "Mobile" from 1932. Consisting of variations on the sphere, suspended from tiers of narrow bars, it encapsulates the American's desire to create "out of volumes, motion, spaces bounded by the great space".Writing in the catalogue, the artists' grandsons, Bernard Ruiz-Picasso and Alexander S.C. Rower, claim that this fascination with emptiness which they term an "exploration of the void" is the "key connection" between Picasso and Calder.In reality, the two remain poles apart. Picasso was essentially a figurative artist while Calder concentrated on abstraction. Picasso simmered with an ancient Mediterranean cruelty that drove him to dismantle women both as humans and as subjects. Born in Pennsylvania in 1898 and destined to spend much of his maturity in France, Calder nevertheless embodied New World optimism. While studying mechanical engineering in New Jersey, he was described in his class yearbook as "one of the best-natured fellows", and his weightless art encapsulated that blithe, progressive spirit. These differences sing out spectacularly in the museum's first big gallery, where centre stage is occupied by Calder's "Object with Red Discs" (1931) and "Woman in the Garden", made by Picasso with help from Julio González in 1932. Calder's work centres on multiple discs extending on branches from a long, diagonal bar. Their ethereal, querulous trajectories embody the sculptor's awareness that "each element must move". Nothing so transient animates Picasso's nymph. This spiky, windswept mademoiselle — two jagged fronds suggest hair flying in the breeze — may be no more than a few contours of scrap metal twisted through space yet she is as tough as an ancient marble.Picasso was the artist who once said: "When I paint smoke I want you to be able to drive a nail into it". Nothing better encapsulates his will to create than "Reclining Nude" (1932). A study of his teenage mistress, Marie-Thérèse Walter, this body is as voluptuous as the aforementioned sculpture is meagre. Certainly, there are voids — the comma of blackness between her ecstatic face and the arabesque of her arm, the abyss of her nipples — but such dark matter serves to emphasise the carnal reality of curves celebrated in the fecund, spring-fresh crocus, and apple, crimson and chalky white.Against the backdrop of Calder's genderless abstractions, Picasso's machismo bursts through in all its troubling fury. Like Calder, he was fascinated by questions of void and volume. Musing on the technique of his most influential predecessor, he once observed: "When you look at Cézanne's apples you see that he hasn't really painted apples. What he did was to paint terribly well the weight of space on their circular form." He continued, "It's the rhythmic thrust of space on the form that counts."That "rhythmic thrust" grinds through every room here as one female model after another is snapped, twisted, dissected and reconfigured. Often, as in "Head of a Woman", an original plaster from 1931, Picasso fuses ovarian and phallic forms into a hermaphrodite of the model and her Frankenstein.This compact cluster sits next to "Whale Shark" (c.1933) by Calder. A slender, curving branch perched on a rough obelisk, its elemental liberty is at odds with the stifling codependence of its counterpart.Calder was not immune to the human body. A fascinating section entitled "Drawing in Space" contrasts his wire sculptures such as "Ball Player" (1927) and "Dancer" (1927) with small wire figures by Picasso from 1931. But Calder's figures, twisted out of skinny wire, squiggle through the air like vapour trails, while Picasso's, made from a thicker wire, are stubbornly eternal.The pair's diverging paths are exultantly elaborated in the museum's upper storey. As if spraying drops of blood over the central atrium of the museum's Jupiter Hall, Calder's mobile "Big Red" (1959) appears even more evanescent thanks to the weighty 17th-century stonework of its architectural surroundings. By contrast, Picasso's painting "Couple" (1970), with its palette of cool blues, black and white, the thick contours outlining the dismembered legs, noses and fingers (all suggestive of the penis), announces "man was here" as potently as the grandiose classical busts above the doorways.Only by the sea does Picasso find true buoyancy. Three bronzes — "The Bathers: The Woman with Outstretched Arms", "Woman Diver", "Child" (all 1956) — use insubstantial planes to hint at the precarity of their templates, assembled from found objects including bed legs and broomsticks. But it is with the glorious crayon drawing "Women Before the Sea" (1920) that he takes flight. The flipperish limbs of two women running by the shore are conjured in long, insouciant contours that map the two parallel lines which are all that remains of Picasso's ocean. Surely, these minimalist mermaids will return to the waves — the fleeting dream of an artist who once noted that, sometimes "the superficial took leave of its own accord."On balance, this is a show that underscores that each artist was precious in his own way. Calder once said "the admission of approximation is necessary ... one cannot see or even conceive of a thing from all possible points of view simultaneously."Picasso, particularly but not exclusively through Cubism, devoted himself to demonstrating that the opposite was the case. Above all, he believed that "You must aim hard at likeness ... beyond the shapes and colours."Calder wanted to create nothing out of something. Picasso knew he could make something out of nothing. To see these two alternative journeys simultaneously is exhilarating, unpredictable and profoundly valuable.To August 25, museepicassoparis.frThis is a show that underscores that each artist was precious in his own wayCREDIT: Rachel SpenceCAPTION: Alexander Calder's 'Vertical Foliage' (1941) Calder Foundation, New York/ ADAGP, Paris; ; Carnal: Picasso's 'Reclining Nude' (1932). Title: Swept into the whirlpool Few of Pablo Picasso's children or grandchildren escaped the fallout from his life, or his death: [SURVEYS EDITION]
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPICASSO: The Real Family Storyby Olivier Widmaier PicassoPrestel Pounds 19.99, 344 pagesTowards the end of his life Picasso, maliciously perceptive as ever, prophesied that "When I die it will be a shipwreck. When a large ship goes down many people in the vicinity are swept into the whirlpool." He died in 1973 and, sure enough, before the funeral was over, his grandson Pablito had committed suicide by drinking bleach. Two years later the boy's father, Picasso's oldest child Paulo, was dead from liver cancer brought on by excessive drinking. Next went Marie-Therese Walter, Picasso's former mistress, who hanged herself in 1977; then his second wife Jacqueline Roque shot herself.Those who survived life with Picasso tended to go into print to exorcise the experience. To his distress, two of his lovers published memoirs in his lifetime: Fernande Olivier in 1933 and Francoise Gilot in 1964; now his grandchildren are following. This account, by Olivier Widmaier Picasso, son of the artist's daughter Maya, comes soon after - and largely in angry response to - bitter biographies by another grandchild, Marina, sister of poor Pablito. Fired by a long legal battle, in which Picasso's three illegitimate children fought to be acknowledged as heirs alongside Paulo and Jacqueline, it is a spectacular airing of family linen, which adds little by way of gossip and nothing of scholarship to the Picasso myth.Olivier, born plain Widmaier in 1961, never met his grandfather. Such was the rancour within the extended Picasso clan that he knew few of the other dramatis personae here either. A lawyer, he changed his name in 1985 to Picasso, but affects the disinterested concern of a specialist in unravelling the complicated, multi- billion- dollar Picasso inheritance, the largest ever left by an artist. Four of his six chapters - Family, Money, Death, Eternity - turn on this twist in Picasso's afterlife, of which Olivier will eventually be a beneficiary.The remaining two, one entitled Women, the other Politics, retread familiar ground with generosity, some wit, no rancour and a general banalising suggestion that, chez Picasso, all was for the best in the best of all possible worlds. The timbre of these sections evokes the insouciant, ever-childlike character of their prime source, Olivier's grandmother Marie-Therese, who, as a 17- year-old shop assistant at Galeries Lafayette, was accosted by the already married artist with the words, "Mademoiselle, you have an interesting face. I would like to paint your portrait." She had never heard of him but agreed to a rendezvous "for no special reason, by chance, because he had a kind smile".Thus began, in 1927, one of Picasso's most fertile periods, as he sculpted, dissected and reshaped her body on canvas while keeping the girl in a "gilded cage", hidden from public view in hotel rooms, beach huts, secret apartments, for nearly two decades, before pensioning her off to live in genteel obscurity. "This young woman enjoyed a fabulous destiny," enthuses Olivier. "First he raped the woman, as Renoir said, and after we worked," recalled Marie-Therese cheerfully. Her heyday lasted till 1935, the year Maya was born and Dora Maar began to replace her as muse. "Guernica" was the transitional work: "I was a bit like an angel for him. The other woman, Dora Maar, was war, the poor thing."Following the standard view that Picasso's oeuvre falls into phases roughly corresponding to his important relationships, Olivier, though barely mentioning the work, constructs the comforting, sentimental theory that "what made him so unique was that his raw, living materials were love and humanity". So Picasso, the genial family man, is dredged out of Maya's few holiday-snap memories. The best, in a volume laced with gentle French imperialism, is the story of American journalists visiting Picasso during the liberation of Paris in 1944, and sending home photographs of the new works on his walls which were duly plastered across the American press: they were in fact scribbles by the nine-year-old Maya.But what about the other Picasso, whose adoring mother warned that "my son lives only for himself, no woman could be safe and happy with him", who barred the door to his children and, unable to endure their youth, told his son Claude: "I am old and you are young. I wish you were dead"?A memoir is inherently subjective; this account however reads as white-washing - an attempt, understandably, to sew together in print a family that in life was clearly dysfunctional beyond belief.It is a truism that in great artists, creativity and sexuality are merged and muddled; the fallout for children and grandchildren, overshadowed by fame, shorn of the drive to make a living, is often disastrous. With Picasso the case is more difficult still. He is too big, too near, too burdened in the post-modern mind with holding up figurative art almost single-handedly, for any biography to get the full measure of him. Even John Richardson's magisterial, compelling A Life of Picasso, two volumes so far published out of four, has something of the memoir about it, which is perhaps the only way to approach so multifaceted a genius. For, says Richardson, "whatever you say about him... the reverse is always true. You say he's a mean bastard - he was also an angelic, compassionate, tender, sweet man. You say he was stingy, he was also incredibly generous. You say he was bohemian, but he also had a sort of uptight bourgeois side. He was a mass of antitheses. And that is one of the amazing things about him, that he was able to contain these totally different qualities."Richardson's is the book to wait for; meanwhile aficionados may just find in this book an odd shaft of light catching that endlessly rich prism that is Picasso's life and work, and which has come now to represent the art of the 20th century.Word count: 978Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Your Views: WHAT do you think of a 1932 painting by Pablo Picasso selling for pounds 70m at a New York auction?
Full Article: AbstractDean Clarke, 35, from Middlesbrough, who works in the hospitality industry, said: "It's a better picture than a lot I've seen. If I had a lot of money and a nice house with high walls, I would spend a bit of money on a piece of art but I wouldn't spend that kind of money."You have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. There's a lot more pounds 70m would pay for other than a painting."Dean Clarke, 35, from Middlesbrough, who works in the hospitality industry, said: "It's a better picture than a lot I've seen. If I had a lot of money and a nice house with high walls, I would spend a bit of money on a piece of art but I wouldn't spend that kind of money."Linda Russell, a 48-year-old health care assistant who lives near Stainton Village, said: "Somebody who pays that kind of price has more money than sense."Dannielle Corr, 23, from Eston, who works at Garlands Call Centre, said: "That's absolutely amazing. It must be a fantastic picture."Jackie Sanderson, a 46-year-old nursing assistant from Linthorpe Village, said: "It's ridiculous because people are starving in the world."Word count: 173Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Gravity and grace of two masters: An exhibition in Paris counterpoints the work of Pablo Picasso and Alexander Calder, writes Rachel Spence [Europe Region]
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPicasso came, very early, to my show at [Galerie] Percier and I was introduced," wrote Alexander Calder in the mid-1950s, remembering his first encounter with Pablo Picasso in Paris in 1931. By then the Spaniard was the colossus of European art, a man who had redefined painting through Cubism and his transgressive riffs on Neoclassicism. Calder was an ingénue by comparison; the Percier show was the first vitrine for his abstract sculptures. Only the year before had Calder visited Mondrian's studio in Paris and, on seeing the Dutch painter's static grids, had the revelation that "it would be fun to make these rectangles oscillate." This led to the mobiles for which he is most famous.The duo met on three further occasions — most fruitfully in 1937, when Calder placed his "Mercury Fountain" in front of Picasso's painting "Guernica" at the Spanish Pavilion at the Paris World's Fair. Here Calder's aquatic acrobat brought a cool, abstract balance to the heart-wrenching violence of Picasso's antiwar cry.In 1952, they lunched together at a mutual friend's home in Antibes. The following year, Calder visited Vallauris, where Picasso was making ceramics. Here, another guest told Calder that Picasso "got red in the face" with anger when the American made a quip about one of his plates.Now they are together again at the Musée Picasso in Paris, where their common ground is established in the small opening gallery. Here, we find three iron-wire maquettes fashioned by Picasso in 1921 as possible designs for a monument to his friend, the poet Guillaume Apollinaire, who had died in 1918. Among them is a waif-like sculpture with a tiny disc for a head and creepy little hands and feet. With its multitude of ferrous lines tracing the air, the spindly mischief-maker embodies the poet's own reference to "a statue made of nothing — like poetry and fame". The Spaniard's sculptures are counterpointed by Calder's "Mobile" from 1932. Consisting of variations on the sphere, suspended from tiers of narrow bars, it encapsulates the American's desire to create "out of volumes, motion, spaces bounded by the great space".Writing in the catalogue, the artists' grandsons, Bernard Ruiz-Picasso and Alexander S.C. Rower, claim that this fascination with emptiness which they term an "exploration of the void" is the "key connection" between Picasso and Calder.In reality, the two remain poles apart. Picasso was essentially a figurative artist while Calder concentrated on abstraction. Picasso simmered with an ancient Mediterranean cruelty that drove him to dismantle women both as humans and as subjects. Born in Pennsylvania in 1898 and destined to spend much of his maturity in France, Calder nevertheless embodied New World optimism. While studying mechanical engineering in New Jersey, he was described in his class yearbook as "one of the best-natured fellows", and his weightless art encapsulated that blithe, progressive spirit. These differences sing out spectacularly in the museum's first big gallery, where centre stage is occupied by Calder's "Object with Red Discs" (1931) and "Woman in the Garden", made by Picasso with help from Julio González in 1932. Calder's work centres on multiple discs extending on branches from a long, diagonal bar. Their ethereal, querulous trajectories embody the sculptor's awareness that "each element must move". Nothing so transient animates Picasso's nymph. This spiky, windswept mademoiselle — two jagged fronds suggest hair flying in the breeze — may be no more than a few contours of scrap metal twisted through space yet she is as tough as an ancient marble.Picasso was the artist who once said: "When I paint smoke I want you to be able to drive a nail into it". Nothing better encapsulates his will to create than "Reclining Nude" (1932). A study of his teenage mistress, Marie-Thérèse Walter, this body is as voluptuous as the aforementioned sculpture is meagre. Certainly, there are voids — the comma of blackness between her ecstatic face and the arabesque of her arm, the abyss of her nipples — but such dark matter serves to emphasise the carnal reality of curves celebrated in the fecund, spring-fresh crocus, and apple, crimson and chalky white.Against the backdrop of Calder's genderless abstractions, Picasso's machismo bursts through in all its troubling fury. Like Calder, he was fascinated by questions of void and volume. Musing on the technique of his most influential predecessor, he once observed: "When you look at Cézanne's apples you see that he hasn't really painted apples. What he did was to paint terribly well the weight of space on their circular form." He continued, "It's the rhythmic thrust of space on the form that counts."That "rhythmic thrust" grinds through every room here as one female model after another is snapped, twisted, dissected and reconfigured. Often, as in "Head of a Woman", an original plaster from 1931, Picasso fuses ovarian and phallic forms into a hermaphrodite of the model and her Frankenstein.This compact cluster sits next to "Whale Shark" (c.1933) by Calder. A slender, curving branch perched on a rough obelisk, its elemental liberty is at odds with the stifling codependence of its counterpart.Calder was not immune to the human body. A fascinating section entitled "Drawing in Space" contrasts his wire sculptures such as "Ball Player" (1927) and "Dancer" (1927) with small wire figures by Picasso from 1931. But Calder's figures, twisted out of skinny wire, squiggle through the air like vapour trails, while Picasso's, made from a thicker wire, are stubbornly eternal.The pair's diverging paths are exultantly elaborated in the museum's upper storey. As if spraying drops of blood over the central atrium of the museum's Jupiter Hall, Calder's mobile "Big Red" (1959) appears even more evanescent thanks to the weighty 17th-century stonework of its architectural surroundings. By contrast, Picasso's painting "Couple" (1970), with its palette of cool blues, black and white, the thick contours outlining the dismembered legs, noses and fingers (all suggestive of the penis), announces "man was here" as potently as the grandiose classical busts above the doorways.Only by the sea does Picasso find true buoyancy. Three bronzes — "The Bathers: The Woman with Outstretched Arms", "Woman Diver", "Child" (all 1956) — use insubstantial planes to hint at the precarity of their templates, assembled from found objects including bed legs and broomsticks. But it is with the glorious crayon drawing "Women Before the Sea" (1920) that he takes flight. The flipperish limbs of two women running by the shore are conjured in long, insouciant contours that map the two parallel lines which are all that remains of Picasso's ocean. Surely, these minimalist mermaids will return to the waves — the fleeting dream of an artist who once noted that, sometimes "the superficial took leave of its own accord."On balance, this is a show that underscores that each artist was precious in his own way. Calder once said "the admission of approximation is necessary ... one cannot see or even conceive of a thing from all possible points of view simultaneously."Picasso, particularly but not exclusively through Cubism, devoted himself to demonstrating that the opposite was the case. Above all, he believed that "You must aim hard at likeness ... beyond the shapes and colours."Calder wanted to create nothing out of something. Picasso knew he could make something out of nothing. To see these two alternative journeys simultaneously is exhilarating, unpredictable and profoundly valuable.To August 25, museepicassoparis.frThis is a show that underscores that each artist was precious in his own wayCREDIT: Rachel SpenceCAPTION: Alexander Calder's 'Vertical Foliage' (1941) Calder Foundation, New York/ ADAGP, Paris; ; Carnal: Picasso's 'Reclining Nude' (1932). Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit BOSSES at the National Football Museum have unveiled their latest bigmoney signing - a sculpture by the revered artist Pablo OSSES at the National Football Museum have unveiled their latest bigmoney signing - a sculpture by the revered artist Pablo Picasso.The figurine was crafted by the Spanish master - a football fan - in the 1960s.The figurine was crafted by the Spanish master - a football fan - in the 1960s.Titled 'Footballeur', art experts say it represents the beauty of a player striking a ball.It was bought at auction for around Pounds 40,000 by collector Mark Briere-Edney. It has now been loaned to the museum for 12 months.Director Kevin Director Kevin Moore said the 11 inch-tall sculpture was a 'thrilling asset' to add to the museum's collections.He said: "We are honoured to provide a new home for this fantastic Picasso ceramic."It's a stunning work of art in every sense and should provide a really unique talking point for visitors to the museum."The piece was bought at auction last year and the gentleman said he would love it to go on show at the museum. We are absolutely delighted to have it here.""The piece was bought at auction last year and the gentleman said he would love it to go on show at the museum. We are absolutely delighted to have it here."The figurine." The figurine will sit at the head of the museum's introductorygallery. It was part of the Madoura Collection which went under the hammer at London auction house Christie's last year.will sit at the head of the museum's introductory gallery. It was part of the Madoura Collection which went under the hammer at London auction house Christie's last year.Many Many pieces in the collection had remained untouched for decades at the Madoura Pottery Studios in Vallauris, France, where Picasso created them.Dr Mike O'Mahony, an art historian, said Picasso's passions were boxing and bullfighting, but he was 'moved' by football.He said: "There are not a lot of examples of Picasso's representation of football, but he was a sports fanatic."Football emerged for him in the 1960s."His interest seems to have been motivated by his strong associations with Barcelona, where he spent his formative years before moving to Paris."Picasso enjoyed the aesthetteamed "Picasso enjoyed the aesthetics of physical movement in athletes as much as, if not more than the competitive dimensions of the sport."It is clear that he was very engaged by the beautiful game."Credit: PAUL BRITTONIllustrationCaption: ARTWORK The 11-inch 'Footballeur' sculpture, above, was a tribute by Picasso, right, to the beautiful game Picture: Jason Lock; EXHIBITION >> The National Football Museum >>; Picture: Jason LockWord count: 456Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Let's do this together: THOUGHT FOR THE DAY "Art washes away from the soul the dust of everyday life." Pablo Picasso [Ulster Region]
Full Article: Full TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitYOUR COMMUNITY CORNERAfter years of driving for hours to see granny and grandpa in Norfolk, and then Cambridge, they've moved to a new house just 20 minutes' drive away.It feels strange to have them so close but I'm looking forward to popping in regularly and actually talking about something other than four-hour tailbacks at the Thetford roundabout.I went over this week to help unload a carful of pictures at their forever home (this is the third in five years - and they've been warned if they move again, the family will seek power of attorney) when there was a loud crash of breaking glass.It wasn't followed by any swearing, so I assumed nobody was hurt. Bringing a dustpan and brush to help clear up, I asked what had broken. "Oh, just one of the ancestors," said my sister-in-law Emm."It's a sign," I said. "Yes it's a sign we didn't stack it properly," replied Emm, sensibly."She does look better without the glass, though," said granny, sticking grandpa's grandmother up on the wall in the hallway as he, understandably, didn't want her in the bedroom.Back in the sitting room, granny chose the perfect place to hang the painting of their son David, my late husband, on the wall that overlooks the stream in their back garden.David's fishing in the picture, and I always feel when we're close to water, he's never far away.Please keep your stories, memories and photos coming to siobhan.mcnally@mirror.co.uk or write to Community Corner, PO Box 791, Winchester SO23 3RP.If you would like to sign up to theMirror's coronavirus email newsletter full of the up to date stories and information go to...mirror.co.uk/ newsletterSILLIEST PET SELFIE "This is Frank, my granddaughter's Frenchie waiting to be served when we were on holiday in Cleethorpes," says Bill Mathieson in Sheffield.JOIN in and be a part of our amazing new community. Share your tips, pictures and hobbies, tell us the quote you live by, or nominate your hero of the day. Whatever is happening in your life and whatever you're talking or thinking about, we want to hear it. Email us at siobhan.mcnally@mirror.co.uk, write to Community Corner, PO Box 791, Winchester SO23 3RP, or join the conversation on this Facebook group www.facebook.com/groups/coronavirusnewsupdatesMY AMAZING ARTWORK This splendid oil painting of a stag is by a complete newcomer to art, Brian Wardell, who lives in Sandwich, Kent. The colours in his sky are so complex, it's hard to believe he only picked up a paintbrush seven months ago!The 82-year-old says: "I just got the urge to paint for the first time during lockdown as I couldn't do anything else!I've travelled the world and, at 62, I walked the John Muir trail in the US. All of it gave me great pleasure, but this is the icing on the cake."You're an inspiration to us all, Brian, and you prove that it's never too late to find undiscovered talents.¦ If you would like to see your artwork hung in our gallery, send a photo of yourself and your work, your age and address and tell us what inspires you to siobhan.mcnally@mirror.co.ukINSPIRING Talented BrianINSPIRING Talented BrianMY BEAUTIFUL BACKYARDThe orange of autumn in Jimmy and Pauline McMillan's beautiful back garden in Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, is a feast for the eyes.Now a great-grandfather, Jimmy says: "We've lived here for 25 years and will be celebrating our golden wedding anniversary on March 6 next year - hopefully with family and friends."When we moved into this house the garden was empty. There were no flowers and just a few old vegetables."I've planted all sorts of trees and shrubs, and we have 80 tubs full of many different flowers - angel's trumpets, ferns and lilies of all sizes." ¦ If the leaves on your trees are turning golden yellow and deep red, we'd love to see them. Send your photos to siobhan.mcnally@mirror.co.ukPOETRY CORNERThe entire nation could do with a group hug right now, but while we wait for the storm to pass, Carole Brewer from Belper, Derbyshire, has written a poem called Hugs to remind us why they're so important.Poet Carol, 58, is mum to four children: "Two are mine plus two extra via my husband Chris," and has been a community volunteer for many years since a serious illness and stroke cut short her working life in 2014."I've always loved writing poetry.I'd write it to mark birthdays, weddings, family events - happy and sad - and also when I was in hospital having chemotherapy, I'd write poems to tell everyone how I was doing."During lockdown I decided to do what my family and friends have been urging for ever and finally put something in print, so I published my book Verses the Virus."Our hugs have all gone missing - we need them back real soon They're as urgent as the vaccine, to keep us COVID-safe - immune A hug to say 'I've missed you', 'I'm sorry' or 'well done' A hug that helps heal heartache, or a 'bounce-off ' hug for fun A gentle hug that holds a newborn, a bear hug that squeezes tight Those for bedtime or 'good morning', or 'everything will be alright' A hug's a precious feeling we'd never thought we'd be without Of all the things on hold right now, a hug's right up there, there's no doubt So when this wretched time is over and we're told it's safe to doOur arms will do what's natural and wrap round loved ones close to you ¦ ¦The full version of Hugs appears in Carole's book Verses the Virus, which is available on Amazon and from her website at pencilpoised.com. A donation from each sale goes to NHS Charities Together and Mental Health UK.CREDIT: Edited by SIOBHAN MCNALLYCAPTION: SOLID GOLD Pauline and JimmyWord count: 989Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases.
