Title: Art Museum Shows Picasso's Ceramics Lesser known works by renowned artist to be here for two months: Pablo Picasso is the . . . well, the Picasso of painters. But not everyone knows the suave Spaniard also is the Picasso of ceramists.
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitFor the next two months, the Art Museum of South Texas will display 65 ceramic pieces from authorized Picasso editions. Though not originals, the works exhibit the cubist's unmistakable style, according to the museum's curator, Deborah Fullerton. "You might be looking at something you don't quite understand, and through the course of just a few moments, you realize what you're looking at is a lute player or a swimmer," Fullerton said. "It's quintessential Picasso." The items - functional in design if not in practice - include plates, bowls, pitchers, vases and plaques from the private collection of Edward and Ann Weston of Los Angeles. The exhibit has been traveling the country for more than a year and a half, starting in Denver. After leaving Corpus Christi on Halloween, it will move on to Peoria, Ill. In summer 1946, a 64-year-old Picasso met a couple, Georges and Suzanne Ramie, who owned a pottery workshop called Madoura in Vallauris, France. During the next two and a half decades, Picasso exercised his genius there, painting on thousands of designs. In exchange for being able to use the Ramies' space, Picasso agreed to let the couple replicate and sell 633 of his creations based on his prototypes and under his supervision, an arrangement he never allowed for his paintings. Most of the originals are in museums or belong to the Picasso family. Carey Rote, who teachers art history at Texas A&M University-Corpus Christi, says she's eager to see the exhibit - officially titled "Picasso: 25 Years of Edition Ceramics from the Edward and Ann Weston Collection" - and is encouraging her students to attend, too. "I'll be looking forward to looking at his exploration of the shapes and the forms and the relationship this work has to his other imagery, his painting and his other sculptural work," she said. "I really think he's one of the great artists of the 20th century. He really helped to define modernism, and modernism continues to have an impact today in post-modernism." Picasso became famous for exploring the abstract, but Rote expects his ceramics to be more classically and traditionally influenced. "He was designing them for people to use in their homes, so I think the kind of idea with them is that they are more decorative and are not quite so . . . revolutionary, shocking, upsetting," she said. Rote is not deterred by the fact the items are not originals. "Ideally, you'd want to see the originals, but sometimes you do look at copies and reproductions to get an idea of what the artist was exploring," she said. "I guess this is the best you can do." One of Rote's colleagues, art professor Louis Katz, says he'd actually rather see these editions than the originals. Katz, who teaches ceramics, wants to observe the subtle differences in technique between these pieces and original Picassos. "Somebody else made the brush strokes, and one of the things about art or ceramics or painting is the subtleties, and subtleties are generally what makes works sing," Katz said. "And, so, do they still have it, or do they not? For me, that makes the show more interesting because they're prints of ceramics, and it brings up a lot of really interesting, touchy issues." As an influence on what Katz calls abstract expressionist ceramics, Picasso, in Katz's eyes, has affected all sorts of modern media, in both subtle and overt ways. "I don't see how you can be an artist in the 21st century here without being influenced by the last 150 years," Katz said. "It has an effect on popular culture and design, including Coke bottles, the way people dress, everything. ... Abstract expressionism is part of popular culture and can't be avoided."Graphic: Picasso Exhibit What: Picasso: 25 Years of Edition Ceramics from the Edward and Ann Weston Collection When: Today to Oct. 30. 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through Saturdays; 1 to 5 p.m. Sundays; closed Mondays. Where: Art Museum of South Texas, 1902 N. Shoreline Blvd. Cost: $3 for adults; $2 for seniors (65 or older); free for children 12 or younger Info: 825-3500Graphic: Mark Your Calendar * Sept. 13: At noon, the museum will host a brown bag gallery tour. Attendees can discuss Picasso's influence and watch a short film about him. * Oct. 6: At 7 p.m., the museum will show "Mystery of Picasso," a 1956 French documentary, as part of its foreign film series. * Oct. 16. From 1 to 3 p.m., the museum will host a free "Family Day," at which ceramists will demonstrate their technique and answer questions.Graphic: Did you know? * Pablo Picasso was born Oct. 25, 1881. He died April 8, 1973. * Picasso's full name was Pablo (or El Pablito) Diego Jose Santiago Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno Crispin Crispiniano de los Remedios Cipriano de la Santisima Trinidad Ruiz Blasco y Picasso Lopez. * In addition to painting and doing ceramics, Picasso also worked with bronze, sculpted and wrote poetry. * Several of his paintings are the most expensive in the world. Last year, his "Garcon a la Pipe" was sold for $104 million at Sotheby's, establishing a new price record. * Picasso had a reputation as a womanizer. He had four children by three women and was married twice. * A pacifist, Picasso was a faithful member of the Communist Party until his death. Source: www.wikipedia.comWord count: 900Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: ANDY WARHOL'S 'JACKIE' WORKS WERE HIS 'GUERNICA': Pablo Picasso responded to a Spanish tragedy; 26 years later, Andy Warhol addressed an American one -- albeit differently
Full Article: Abstract [Andy Warhol], just 35 and still finding his artistic footing, took time to figure out how to respond, but when he did, [Pablo Picasso] was his backup. In dozens of paintings of Jackie Kennedy, Warhol transformed Picasso's "weeping women," a celebrated series of paintings, drawings and prints born out of a prominent motif in "Guernica" showing unspeakable grief.Barely 18 months before Kennedy's murder, New York was awash in a celebration of the great Spaniard's art. "Picasso: An American Tribute" was a sprawling, late-April retrospective that filled nine of the city's most prominent galleries. Then came a summer-long Museum of Modern Art exhibition, organized in belated celebration of Picasso's 80th birthday. In all, the civic extravaganza lasted nearly six months. "Guernica" was a centerpiece.Warhol's weeping women are cold, Picasso's are hot. Picasso's boil over, Warhol's remain numb.MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. This functionality is provided solely for your convenience and is in no way intended to replace human translation. Hide full disclaimerLonger documents can take a while to translate. Rather than keep you waiting, we have only translated the first few paragraphs. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitFor art, the 1963 murder of a president became America's Guernica. In style, emotional tenor and generation, Pablo Picasso and Andy Warhol were very different artists. But both made paintings that spoke to an epic social trauma of their day. And both used the same motif -- a weeping woman -- to focus the unfathomable event.Over three hours in the afternoon of April 26, 1937, German bombers pummeled an ancient Basque village in Northern Spain with a hundred thousand pounds of high-explosive and incendiary bombs, reducing the town of Guernica to smoking rubble. Shock waves spread across Europe.Picasso, then 55 and a mature artist, went to work. In a few weeks' time he completed a big painting that would become an anguished modern icon of anti-war protest.The brutal event in Spain's bloody civil war was different in scale from the Dallas assassination of John Fitzgerald Kennedy, the charismatic young president of the United States, 26 years later. But for both, the shock to the public psyche was huge.Warhol, just 35 and still finding his artistic footing, took time to figure out how to respond, but when he did, Picasso was his backup. In dozens of paintings of Jackie Kennedy, Warhol transformed Picasso's "weeping women," a celebrated series of paintings, drawings and prints born out of a prominent motif in "Guernica" showing unspeakable grief.Whereas Picasso made nearly 60 of them, Warhol looked to a single weeping woman. In the first weeks of 1964 he turned to the picture press, especially Life magazine. He chose eight photographs of Kennedy's widow from the mass media's avalanche of assassination coverage, including the run-up and the aftermath, and sent these and other found-photographs to his silk-screen technician, instructing him to dramatically heighten the originals' contrast between dark and light.Black acrylic was used to silk-screen them, sometimes flopped, onto blue or silver canvas panels or sheets of paper. (A few are gold, as if for a Byzantine icon depicting a saint, while other colors turned up in later versions.) The blue and silver palette recalls black-and-white TV; that's how most people experienced the traumatic events of the previous autumn, now being represented at another remove.We never see tears streaming from her profoundly sad eyes. Still, I believe Picasso was essential to Warhol's choice of Jackie, not Jack, for the assassination series.Barely 18 months before Kennedy's murder, New York was awash in a celebration of the great Spaniard's art. "Picasso: An American Tribute" was a sprawling, late-April retrospective that filled nine of the city's most prominent galleries. Then came a summer-long Museum of Modern Art exhibition, organized in belated celebration of Picasso's 80th birthday. In all, the civic extravaganza lasted nearly six months. "Guernica" was a centerpiece.Warhol was obsessed with Picasso -- more specifically, obsessed with his standing as the greatest living modernist. Since arriving in New York from Pittsburgh a dozen years earlier, the ambitious younger painter had gotten nowhere. But just as the Picasso bandwagon rolled into town, he was finally getting traction: His Pop solo gallery debut -- Campbell's soup can paintings at Los Angeles' Ferus Gallery -- even coincided with MOMA's Picasso birthday salute.Once his own star rose, Warhol declared his Picasso affinity. In 1966 he covered a room at New York's Leo Castelli Gallery with a surrogate self-portrait -- bright yellow wallpaper sporting the hot-pink head of a cow. For the effeminate gay artist, the coy pink cow was equivalent to Picasso's famous self-identification with a robust bull or mythic Minotaur."Guernica" was powerful public agitprop. Picasso marshaled grand scale, figurative distortion, mythic narrative and a stark palette of black and white that derived from newspaper accounts of the awful event. At the 1937 Paris International Exposition, where the mural-size canvas had its public debut before an international tour, its prominence in the Spanish Pavilion meant to grab viewers by the lapels.Warhol obviously didn't need to do that for the Kennedy assassination. By the '60s, television's instant communication took care of galvanizing the public.In fact, his paintings worked against the media manipulation that Picasso deftly exploited. Warhol's weeping woman was smudged, repetitive and unemotional. Jackie presents high contrast and low information, all available in mute mathematical permutations -- four panels, eight, 16 or even an entire roomful.Warhol was happy having JFK as president, but he was largely unmoved by the assassination. "(It) didn't bother me that much that he was dead," the artist later said, comparing the public pageant of mourning for Kennedy to a moving funeral for an anonymous peasant that he once stumbled on in India."What bothered me was the way the television and radio were programming everybody to feel so sad," he said. "It seemed like no matter how hard you tried, you couldn't get away from the thing."Warhol's weeping women are cold, Picasso's are hot. Picasso's boil over, Warhol's remain numb.But like Picasso, Warhol understood that art can function as a powerful social lever. His emotionally neutered Jackie portraits used American popular culture as a weapon, not a target. Warhol's icy weeping woman put Picasso squarely in the cross hairs -- Picasso and all the accumulated mythologies and pretensions of established modernist works.The younger artist had no choice. For as long as art's old aesthetic machismo held sway, there simply was no room for the likes of him. So, with the deliberateness of an assassin, Warhol coolly killed it off.cknight@tribune.com IllustrationPhoto (color) RAFA SALAFRANCA Getty-AFP; Caption: Andy Warhol's "Jackie" paintings responded to national tragedy in a way that used American pop culture as a weapon.Word count: 975Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. In the first weeks of 1964 he turned to the picture press, especially Life magazine. He chose eight photographs of Kennedy's widow from the mass media's avalanche of assassination coverage, including the run-up and the aftermath, and sent these and other found-photographs to his silk-screen technician, instructing him to dramatically heighten the originals' contrast between dark and light.Black acrylic was used to silk-screen them, sometimes flopped, onto blue or silver canvas panels or sheets of paper. (A few are gold, as if for a Byzantine icon depicting a saint, while other colors turned up in later versions.) The blue and silver palette recalls black-and-white TV; that's how most people experienced the traumatic events of the previous autumn, now being represented at another remove.We never see tears streaming from her profoundly sad eyes. Still, I believe Picasso was essential to Warhol's choice of Jackie, not Jack, for the assassination series.Barely 18 months before Kennedy's murder, New York was awash in a celebration of the great Spaniard's art. "Picasso: An American Tribute" was a sprawling, late-April retrospective that filled nine of the city's most prominent galleries. Then came a summer-long Museum of Modern Art exhibition, organized in belated celebration of Picasso's 80th birthday. In all, the civic extravaganza lasted nearly six months. "Guernica" was a centerpiece.Warhol was obsessed with Picasso -- more specifically, obsessed with his standing as the greatest living modernist. Since arriving in New York from Pittsburgh a dozen years earlier, the ambitious younger painter had gotten nowhere. But just as the Picasso bandwagon rolled into town, he was finally getting traction: His Pop solo gallery debut -- Campbell's soup can paintings at Los Angeles' Ferus Gallery -- even coincided with MOMA's Picasso birthday salute.Once his own star rose, Warhol declared his Picasso affinity. In 1966 he covered a room at New York's Leo Castelli Gallery with a surrogate self-portrait -- bright yellow wallpaper sporting the hot-pink head of a cow. For the effeminate gay artist, the coy pink cow was equivalent to Picasso's famous self-identification with a robust bull or mythic Minotaur."Guernica" was powerful public agitprop. Picasso marshaled grand scale, figurative distortion, mythic narrative and a stark palette of black and white that derived from newspaper accounts of the awful event. At the 1937 Paris International Exposition, where the mural-size canvas had its public debut before an international tour, its prominence in the Spanish Pavilion meant to grab viewers by the lapels.Warhol obviously didn't need to do that for the Kennedy assassination. By the '60s, television's instant communication took care of galvanizing the public.In fact, his paintings worked against the media manipulation that Picasso deftly exploited. Warhol's weeping woman was smudged, repetitive and unemotional. Jackie presents high contrast and low information, all available in mute mathematical permutations -- four panels, eight, 16 or even an entire roomful.Warhol was happy having JFK as president, but he was largely unmoved by the assassination. "(It) didn't bother me that much that he was dead," the artist later said, comparing the public pageant of mourning for Kennedy to a moving funeral for an anonymous peasant that he once stumbled on in India."What bothered me was the way the television and radio were programming everybody to feel so sad," he said. "It seemed like no matter how hard you tried, you couldn't get away from the thing."Warhol's weeping women are cold, Picasso's are hot. Picasso's boil over, Warhol's remain numb.But like Picasso, Warhol understood that art can function as a powerful social lever. His emotionally neutered Jackie portraits used American popular culture as a weapon, not a target. Warhol's icy weeping woman put Picasso squarely in the cross hairs -- Picasso and all the accumulated mythologies and pretensions of established modernist works.The younger artist had no choice. For as long as art's old aesthetic machismo held sway, there simply was no room for the likes of him. So, with the deliberateness of an assassin, Warhol coolly killed it off.----------cknight@tribune.com Credit: By Christopher Knight, Tribune Newspapers IllustrationCaption: Photo: Andy Warhol's "Jackie" paintings responded to national tragedy in a way that used American pop culture as a weapon. RAFA SALAFRANCA/GETTY-AFP PHOTOWord count: 982Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Gravity and grace of two masters: An exhibition in Paris counterpoints the work of Pablo Picasso and Alexander Calder, writes Rachel Spence [Asia Region]
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPicasso came, very early, to my show at [Galerie] Percier and I was introduced," wrote Alexander Calder in the mid-1950s, remembering his first encounter with Pablo Picasso in Paris in 1931. By then the Spaniard was the colossus of European art, a man who had redefined painting through Cubism and his transgressive riffs on Neoclassicism. Calder was an ingénue by comparison; the Percier show was the first vitrine for his abstract sculptures. Only the year before had Calder visited Mondrian's studio in Paris and, on seeing the Dutch painter's static grids, had the revelation that "it would be fun to make these rectangles oscillate." This led to the mobiles for which he is most famous.The duo met on three further occasions — most fruitfully in 1937, when Calder placed his "Mercury Fountain" in front of Picasso's painting "Guernica" at the Spanish Pavilion at the Paris World's Fair. Here Calder's aquatic acrobat brought a cool, abstract balance to the heart-wrenching violence of Picasso's antiwar cry.In 1952, they lunched together at a mutual friend's home in Antibes. The following year, Calder visited Vallauris, where Picasso was making ceramics. Here, another guest told Calder that Picasso "got red in the face" with anger when the American made a quip about one of his plates.Now they are together again at the Musée Picasso in Paris, where their common ground is established in the small opening gallery. Here, we find three iron-wire maquettes fashioned by Picasso in 1921 as possible designs for a monument to his friend, the poet Guillaume Apollinaire, who had died in 1918. Among them is a waif-like sculpture with a tiny disc for a head and creepy little hands and feet. With its multitude of ferrous lines tracing the air, the spindly mischief-maker embodies the poet's own reference to "a statue made of nothing — like poetry and fame". The Spaniard's sculptures are counterpointed by Calder's "Mobile" from 1932. Consisting of variations on the sphere, suspended from tiers of narrow bars, it encapsulates the American's desire to create "out of volumes, motion, spaces bounded by the great space".Writing in the catalogue, the artists' grandsons, Bernard Ruiz-Picasso and Alexander S.C. Rower, claim that this fascination with emptiness which they term an "exploration of the void" is the "key connection" between Picasso and Calder.In reality, the two remain poles apart. Picasso was essentially a figurative artist while Calder concentrated on abstraction. Picasso simmered with an ancient Mediterranean cruelty that drove him to dismantle women both as humans and as subjects. Born in Pennsylvania in 1898 and destined to spend much of his maturity in France, Calder nevertheless embodied New World optimism. While studying mechanical engineering in New Jersey, he was described in his class yearbook as "one of the best-natured fellows", and his weightless art encapsulated that blithe, progressive spirit. These differences sing out spectacularly in the museum's first big gallery, where centre stage is occupied by Calder's "Object with Red Discs" (1931) and "Woman in the Garden", made by Picasso with help from Julio González in 1932. Calder's work centres on multiple discs extending on branches from a long, diagonal bar. Their ethereal, querulous trajectories embody the sculptor's awareness that "each element must move". Nothing so transient animates Picasso's nymph. This spiky, windswept mademoiselle — two jagged fronds suggest hair flying in the breeze — may be no more than a few contours of scrap metal twisted through space yet she is as tough as an ancient marble.Picasso was the artist who once said: "When I paint smoke I want you to be able to drive a nail into it". Nothing better encapsulates his will to create than "Reclining Nude" (1932). A study of his teenage mistress, Marie-Thérèse Walter, this body is as voluptuous as the aforementioned sculpture is meagre. Certainly, there are voids — the comma of blackness between her ecstatic face and the arabesque of her arm, the abyss of her nipples — but such dark matter serves to emphasise the carnal reality of curves celebrated in the fecund, spring-fresh crocus, and apple, crimson and chalky white.Against the backdrop of Calder's genderless abstractions, Picasso's machismo bursts through in all its troubling fury. Like Calder, he was fascinated by questions of void and volume. Musing on the technique of his most influential predecessor, he once observed: "When you look at Cézanne's apples you see that he hasn't really painted apples. What he did was to paint terribly well the weight of space on their circular form." He continued, "It's the rhythmic thrust of space on the form that counts."That "rhythmic thrust" grinds through every room here as one female model after another is snapped, twisted, dissected and reconfigured. Often, as in "Head of a Woman", an original plaster from 1931, Picasso fuses ovarian and phallic forms into a hermaphrodite of the model and her Frankenstein.This compact cluster sits next to "Whale Shark" (c.1933) by Calder. A slender, curving branch perched on a rough obelisk, its elemental liberty is at odds with the stifling codependence of its counterpart.Calder was not immune to the human body. A fascinating section entitled "Drawing in Space" contrasts his wire sculptures such as "Ball Player" (1927) and "Dancer" (1927) with small wire figures by Picasso from 1931. But Calder's figures, twisted out of skinny wire, squiggle through the air like vapour trails, while Picasso's, made from a thicker wire, are stubbornly eternal.The pair's diverging paths are exultantly elaborated in the museum's upper storey. As if spraying drops of blood over the central atrium of the museum's Jupiter Hall, Calder's mobile "Big Red" (1959) appears even more evanescent thanks to the weighty 17th-century stonework of its architectural surroundings. By contrast, Picasso's painting "Couple" (1970), with its palette of cool blues, black and white, the thick contours outlining the dismembered legs, noses and fingers (all suggestive of the penis), announces "man was here" as potently as the grandiose classical busts above the doorways.Only by the sea does Picasso find true buoyancy. Three bronzes — "The Bathers: The Woman with Outstretched Arms", "Woman Diver", "Child" (all 1956) — use insubstantial planes to hint at the precarity of their templates, assembled from found objects including bed legs and broomsticks. But it is with the glorious crayon drawing "Women Before the Sea" (1920) that he takes flight. The flipperish limbs of two women running by the shore are conjured in long, insouciant contours that map the two parallel lines which are all that remains of Picasso's ocean. Surely, these minimalist mermaids will return to the waves — the fleeting dream of an artist who once noted that, sometimes "the superficial took leave of its own accord."On balance, this is a show that underscores that each artist was precious in his own way. Calder once said "the admission of approximation is necessary ... one cannot see or even conceive of a thing from all possible points of view simultaneously."Picasso, particularly but not exclusively through Cubism, devoted himself to demonstrating that the opposite was the case. Above all, he believed that "You must aim hard at likeness ... beyond the shapes and colours."Calder wanted to create nothing out of something. Picasso knew he could make something out of nothing. To see these two alternative journeys simultaneously is exhilarating, unpredictable and profoundly valuable.To August 25, museepicassoparis.frThis is a show that underscores that each artist was precious in his own wayCREDIT: Rachel Spence Word count: 1244Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit A multi-talented creative genius with an encyclopedic knowledge of art history, Pablo Picasso had a psychic energy and intelligence that emanated from everything he touched and transformed into art.He was a legend of 20th-century art.This fall, two museums are simultaneously exhibiting the art of Picasso.The upcoming "Surrealism and Modernism from the Collection of the Wadsworth Atheneum" at the Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota includes five paintings by Picasso, from 1922 to 1963.Picasso: 25 Years of Edition Ceramics from the Edward Weston Collection at the Polk Museum in Lakeland is an outstanding overview of the master's ceramic art. Included in the exhibition are plates, bowls, vases and platters produced by the Spanish master at the Madoura workshop in Vallauris, France, between 1947 and 1971.These two exhibitions provide a unique opportunity to compare and enjoy two very different media dear to Picasso and to gage his phenomenal emotional range, dexterity and importance to 20th- century art.Picasso and French painter Georges Braque created a new vision of the world that, initially, following the example of Cezanne before them, sought to record the world through geometrical analysis. The art critic Louis Vauxcelles described these pictures as being reduced to "little cubes" and wrote of Braque's pictures in the Salon d'Automne of 1909 as "bizarreries cubiques": the origin of the term and movement called "Cubism."Picasso once told his close friend, Christian Zervos, "In the old days, pictures went forward toward completion by stages. Every day brought something new. A picture used to be a sum of additions. In my case, a picture is a sum of destructions."Later in the same conversation, Picasso added, "When you begin a picture, you often make some pretty discoveries. You must be on guard against these. Destroy the thing, do it over several times. In each destroying of a beautiful discovery, the artist does not really suppress it, but rather transforms it, condenses it, makes it more substantial. What comes out in the end is the result of discarded finds."The Polk Museum exhibition of 65 ceramic pieces reveals the spontaneous invention, humor and sensual mischief in his curvaceous lines. Wonderful vases and jugs are painted to look like bright- eyed girls or goddesses, and platters are decorated with moon-faced women, smiling goats, hypnotic owls and geometrically abstracted fish. This ceramic display makes clear that Picasso's decorative ability was inexhaustible and provided him with a medium that appealed to the lighter side of his nature.The Ringling Museum exhibit is another mood -- a different Picasso -- the intellectual reformulating of all that he had come to understand from his many sojourns to the Louvre Museum in Paris. In his autobiographical painting, "The Painter" (1934), Picasso mischievously substituted himself at far left (as artist looking at the model) for a generalized portrait of his dealer Kahnweiler -- straight nose, bulbous chin and the cuff links that were elements of his dapper style.The vertical alignment of the nude's breast and umbilicus corresponds to the strong, vertical, blue rectangle of the canvas on which the painter paints and the yellow profile of the dealer as artist.Here Picasso's substitution seems to be an oblique joke -- the art dealer as procurer for a collector, who replaces the artist's gaze with that of his own.These two exhibits, when seen together, make clear that Picasso is difficult, sensual and enigmatic, like the flamenco music of Spain vibrating through the colors of his art.TICKETSPicasso: 25 Years of Edition Ceramics from the Edward Weston CollectionOn view through Nov. 28 at the Polk Museum of Art, 800 E. Palmetto St., Lakeland. 10 a.m.-5 p.m Tuesdays-Saturdays, 1-5 p.m. Sundays. Admission is $5, $3 for students and seniors, free ages 5 and under. Exhibit is free 10 a.m.-noon Saturdays. Call (863) 688- 2611 or access www.polkmuseumofart.org.Surrealism and Modernism from the Collection of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of ArtOn view Oct. 23 through Jan. 9, 2005, at the Ringling Museum of Art, 5401 Bay Shore Road, Sarasota. 10 a.m.-5:30 p.m. daily. Admission is $15; $12 for ages 65 and older; free for age 12 and younger accompanied by an adult, museum members and Florida students and teachers. Call 359-5700 or access www.ringling.org. IllustrationPHOTO 4; Caption: COURTESY PHOTO Picasso's whimsical creations mix charm with an innate artfulness. COURTESY PHOTOS Although Pablo Picasso may be best known for his paintings, his ceramics, on view at Lakeland's Polk Museum of Art, show the multi- talented artist in a new light. Title: Abstract
Electric dreams: Coco Chanel and Pablo Picasso's favourite motor, the Hispano Suiza, is back on track. Jeremy Taylor test-drives the £2 million eco-friendly hypercar
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitHispano-Suiza once built extravagant motor cars admired the world over. The Spanish marque was adored by royalty, politicians and celebrities for its stylish limousines that cost more than a Rolls-Royce.Coco Chanel, René Lacoste and even Albert Einstein all chose Hispano-Suizas. Pablo Picasso drove a classic pre-war model until his death, long after the manufacturer finally ceased car production in 1946.Now, more than 70 years later, the family that founded the marque has resurrected the Hispano-Suiza name - this time creating a retro-styled grand tourer. The Carmen reimagines the company's elegant Dubonnet Xenia model of 1938 as a state-of-the-art electric hypercar.Hispano Suiza - today minus the hyphen - has relaunched under the stewardship of Miguel Suqué Mateu. The billionaire is the great-grandson of the cofounder, Damián Mateu, whose enthusiasm for building luxury cars would eventually create an immense family fortune in the early 20th century.'My family has a great passion for the brand that stretches back more than a century,' Mateu says. The dapper, grey-haired sexagenarian is speaking to me from his office near Barcelona, where gilt-framed artworks hang behind the desk. 'We have been approached many times about buying into our name and building a new Hispano Suiza, but we always wanted to own andcontrol the company. It is more than just a name to us.'Hispano-Suiza were the finest cars available for the super-rich of the 1920s and 1930s. Not only was the styling more advanced than any other vehicle, the limousines were equipped with innovative engineering features that resulted in terrific performance and a supremely comfortable ride.'For those who could afford the pleasure, there was nothing quite like driving a powerful, 12-cylinder Hispano-Suiza. Even now, sitting in one of those old cars is an incredible sensation,' Mateu says.The Mateu family today owns the Peralada group of luxury restaurants, vineyards and hotels in Spain. The jewel in the crown is the Peralada Castle in Catalonia, host to a major music and arts festival each summer.The new Carmen is named after Mateu's late mother, who in her senior years dreamt of seeing Hispano-Suiza's famous flying stork emblem affixed to a luxury road car once again. 'My mother was always in love with the brand. She loved to drive and she drove very fast - sometimes she frightened me. She died three years agoand it was a tremendous loss for everyone who knew her. She was the backbone of the family.'Hispano-Suiza was established in 1904 near Barcelona, and the then king of Spain, Alfonso XIII, was an early admirer of the brand. At one point, the car-madmonarch had dozens at his disposal. The company later honoured his patronage by giving Alfonso's name to an open-top model.Today, the American late-night TV star Jay Leno keeps an 18.5 litre V8 model in his garage, and classic Hispano-Suizas can still be found in some of the world's finest private car collections.I travelled to the firm's headquarters to drive the new, carbon-fibre Carmen for the first time at the Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya, where Lewis Hamilton won this year's Spanish Grand Prix.Hispano Suiza has used battery technology from Formula E, the on-road, all-electric racing series, to create an incredible 1,005bhp in the lightweight car. That enormous shove is sent to the rear wheels and will silently slingshot the Carmen from 0-60mph in just three seconds. Top speed is restricted to 155mph.Not fast enough? Try the high-performance Boulogne version I drove. It offers an extra 94bhp and is capable of 180mph. It will outpace a Lamborghini Aventador SVJ from a standing start, racing to 62mph in 2.6 seconds.Just 19 examples of the 'standard' Carmen will be built, from £1.5 million each, plus five of the even sportier Boulogne models at £1.7 million. There are a host of extras for each, so don't expect much change out of £2 million.In the past, no two Hispano-Suizas were alike, featuring bespoke luxury interiors and coach-built bodywork. The 1920s H6 model was regarded as the finest, with a 6.6-litre engine producing almost double the power of a Rolls-Royce.Like an art-deco Batmobile, the new Carmen has taken its design cues from pre-war streamliner cars. The aerodynamically advanced, 'teardrop' shape was famously exploited on the racetrack by Auto Union - which became the Audi brand in the 1960s.To the uninitiated, many hypercars look the same: low, wedge-shaped beasts. But the Carmen can't be confused with anything else on the road: the influence of the classic streamliners gives it a retro style all of its own. 'It'sa car you either love or hate - there's no middle ground,' says Mateu. 'My mother was a glamorous woman and if she had lived to see it, I hope she would have approved.'The tail-heavy, handcrafted body is voluptuous from every angle, flowing rearwards to a pair of circulartail lights with the flying-stork symbol at the centre. Remarkably similar to the Dubonnet Xenia, the carbonfibre Carmen is a unique proposition.The new Carmen Boulogne model basks in that racing heritage, with four rear-mounted motors powered by a 700V battery. A T-shaped lithium-ion battery pack sits in the area behind the two passengers and runs forward, between the front seats. Extensive use of carbon fibre and aluminium suspension trims the weightdown to just 1,700kg - lightweight for an all-electric car loaded with batteries.Entry to the cabin is a performance in itself, with theatrical scissor doors that rise and pivot in one movement. Inside, the cockpit is retro-modern, with carbonfibre seats swathed in leather, hand-trimmed by Spanish artisans. Each interior is finished in rare-wood veneers and copper-coloured aluminium.A perfumer has even been employed to offer customers the right scent for their vehicle. (The car I drovehad a floral bouquet.) A triangular gear selector nods to the style used on the dash in historic models.The Boulogne links to an app on the owner's phone to set the cabin temperature, or a host of other features. That includes a very good alarm, although I doubt any thief would get far in a hypercar that could have been created especially for the Instagram generation.Being all-electric, there's no sound as the Carmenpowers away. I have just three laps of the three-mile Catalunya circuit, with a Tesla acting as pace car. Unlike a noisy Lamborghini, the Boulogne feels easy to drive - a grand tourer for the new millennium, with an explosive burst of speed when required. It sits on ultra-low-profile Pirelli track tyres, which are road legal and wrapped around rather beautiful alloy wheels. Enormous carbonceramic brakes provide the stopping power.The silence is deafening as the Hispano Suiza follows the racing line into the Repsol bend, through La Caixa and on around the seemingly never-ending Banc de Sabadell, without a squeak from the tyres. If it's all too quiet, you can always flick on the six-speaker stereo, which offers 360-degree sound.It's over too soon, but despite the hypercar statistics the Carmen is really a supreme grand tourer rather than a track car. It would make a statement arrival at, say, the Casino de Monte-Carlo, or the Concorso d'Eleganza at Lake Como.Even so, Hispano Suiza seems determined to maintain its links to motor sport, this year taking part in the inaugural Extreme E season. The off-road championship is the newest form of 'green' racing, with all-electric SUVs competing in remote locations most affected by climate change. Both Lewis Hamilton and former F1 champion Nico Rosberg run teams in the global event, with men and women sharing the driver's seat. Hispano Suiza's car is driven by British rallycross star Oliver Bennett and one-time World Rally Championships entrant Christine Zonca.The original Hispano-Suiza declined after the Spanish Civil War. It survived until the 1950s as a manufacturer of weaponry and parts for the aviation industry.The new incarnation of the company also has challenges to overcome, because at least one other firm claims to own the trademark in certain global markets - a problem that could thwart Mateu's team in its efforts to deliver its new baby to some buyers. It's a complicated saga and the dispute is ongoing. However, it would bea shame if intellectual-property law firms became the beneficiaries of a once-legendary brand, regarded as the ultimate in automotive chic.Mateu believes the Carmen could be just the start for Hispano Suiza, suggesting a host of lower-priced offerings will follow. 'We are back to stay, but it is too early to say what will happen next.'It would have been a shame to lose the legacy that my family left us. I think my mother would have approved of this new car we named after her - she certainly would have enjoyed driving it.'A perfumer has been employed to offer customers the right scent for their vehicle (the car I drove had a floral bouquet)Word count: 1483Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: The Crucifixion of Pablo Picasso: In 1932, his 'year of wonders', Picasso's art took a dark turn. Was it inspired by a crisis of faith - or a critical drubbing?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitOne of the most persistent clichés about Pablo Picasso (1881-1973) is that to understand his paintings we must know about his life. The Spanish artist himself, the subject of an astonishing new exhibition at Tate Modern, is, in part, to blame. "The work that one does," he told an interviewer in 1932, "is a way of keeping a diary."At first glance, Tate Modern's Picasso 1932: Love, Fame, Tragedy, the gallery's first monographic Picasso exhibition, appears to reinforce this view. Featuring more than 100 artworks, it will focus on a single year of his life, soon after he had turned 50. His biographer John Richardson once described 1932 as Picasso's "year of wonders", because it witnessed a miraculous sea change in his art, as an inundation of masterpieces flowed from his studio.Many of these sensual paintings seemed to record the high-water mark of Picasso's "amour fou" for the blonde, athletic Marie-Thérèse Walter, his junior by 28 years, whom he had met outside the Galeries Lafayette department store in Paris five years earlier. By 1932, Marie-Thérèse had replaced Picasso's wife, Olga Khokhlova, in the artist's affections.Marie-Thérèse appeared in painting after gorgeous painting over the course of that year, often asleep, sometimes in a carnal red armchair, as in The Dream (Le Rêve), which will be exhibited in Britain for the first time.Meanwhile, poor Olga - who, in the Twenties, had been immortalised as a beautiful icon of Picasso's neoclassical art - was depicted as a shrieking ogress: a nightmare offsetting the voluptuous "dream" of Marie-Thérèse, whom Picasso presented as a moon goddess, to be worshipped and adored.Yet, according to Tate curator Achim Borchardt-Hume, the new exhibition will dispel prurient assumptions about the links between Picasso's love life and his art. "Everyone has a view on Picasso, the man," says Borchardt-Hume. "He's like the Henry VIII of the art world: we recite the wives and lovers, and make easy equations about how they [relate to] the work. The story of 1932, for instance, is all too easily reduced to the dynamic between Marie-Thérèse and Olga. But I think it's more complex."While Picasso's paintings of Marie-Thérèse from the first half of the year are extremely well known - Nude, Green Leaves and Bust, for instance, sold at auction for $106.5million (£77million) in 2010 - his output during the closing months of 1932 is less familiar, and surprisingly different in tone.Arguably the best example of this profound shift, from an exuberant vision of fecundity to something more sombre, is a remarkable series of 13 black-andwhite ink drawings, dating from September and October. All are variations on the theme of the Crucifixion. "Much as I dislike the term, the Crucifixions are masterpieces, on a par with the paintings of the first part of the year," says Borchardt-Hume. "They are extraordinary."Perhaps the biggest surprise about the Crucifixions is that Picasso, who is not known as a religious artist, drew them at all. Yet, on September 17 1932, something compelled him to begin a drawing inspired by a notoriously grisly altarpiece depicting the Crucifixion, by the 16th-century German master Matthias Grünewald. We don't know what sparked Picasso's interest in Grünewald's masterpiece, with its brutalised Christ. Most likely, it was brought to his attention by Christian Zervos, founder of the art magazine Cahiers d'art, who, in 1932, was planning an issue of the journal devoted specifically to the Isenheim Altarpiece (as Grünewald's Crucifixion is known).Whatever the spur, once Picasso had executed this initial drawing, the motif began to obsess him and, as the weeks ensued, he continued to explore the theme, distorting his subject to such an extent that the influence of Grünewald was no longer apparent. The second and third drawings in the series, executed that same Saturday, September 17, are saturated with inky darkness. The fourth, produced two days later, is a synopsis of sinuous abstract lines.The fifth and sixth are considerably stranger, as Picasso transformed the scene into a pile-up of smooth, surreal forms. The various elements look like prehistoric stones, picked out by moonlight against a pitch-black sky, or, in the words of art historian Elizabeth Cowling, "chaplets of bones". To some, the shapes even resemble a crustacean's shattered claws, washed up on a beach. If that sounds fanciful, remember that Picasso's art was, fundamentally, one of metamorphosis. As Picasso himself put it, in conversation with the Hungarian-French photographer Brassaï, "I'd hardly begun to draw [Grünewald's Crucifixion] when it turned into something completely different.""Picasso was always adamant that he didn't control what happened in the work - it flowed through him," explains Borchardt-Hume. "The whole point was to allow his subconscious - his desires, drives, fears, anxieties, emotions - to do their thing."If we were to correlate the Crucifixions and Picasso's biography, what would we discover? For one thing, says Borchardt-Hume, for all his supposed irreligiosity Picasso was, as a Spaniard, raised in a conventional, conservative family. In April 1932, his son Paulo attended his First Communion, a rite of passage so significant that Picasso's mother, and Paulo's grandmother, Doña Maria, travelled from Barcelona to witness it."So, there is this undercurrent of Catholicism," Borchardt-Hume says. "As an artist, Picasso is pagan, but, as a man, he has quite a Catholic moral code."It is worth noting that the Crucifixions of 1932 are not without precedent in Picasso's oeuvre: during his long career, he produced at least 50 versions of the subject. The earliest dates from 1896, the final drawing from 1959, and, in 1930, he produced a small, intensely colourful painting of the Crucifixion, which he did not part with until his death.Abiographer might also "explain" the Crucifixions by contextualising them within the fallout of Picasso's first large-scale retrospective, comprising 225 paintings and seven sculptures, held at the opulent Galeries Georges Petit in Paris over the summer of 1932, before transferring to Zurich.Commercially and critically, it was a flop. Maybe, then, the Crucifixions articulate the anguish that Picasso felt, having subjected himself to a distressing public evaluation of his talents.Ultimately, though, the drawings retain their mysterious, thrilling power precisely because the "key" of biography cannot unlock their meaning. If they are "masterpieces", it is because, in their evocation of agony and atmosphere of foreboding, they anticipate the dreadful drift into darkness that defined European politics during the Thirties.On January 30 1933, little more than three months after Picasso had drawn the final Crucifixion in the series, Hitler was appointed chancellor of Germany. Four years later, in 1937, Picasso completed his moving, mural-sized riposte to fascism, Guernica.Without doubt, the Crucifixions of 1932 are Guernica's pictorial ancestors: witness their monochrome palette and fractured, fragmented forms, the way they articulate emotional and physical suffering, and their elevated atmosphere of tragedy."Picasso liked to build intensely private worlds in his studios," says Borchardt-Hume. "But, in the second half of 1932, he could no longer resist: the world was becoming a tenser place, and it began to seep into his work."Consider Picasso's painting The Rescue, executed in November 1932, one of several scenes of drowning and resuscitation that he made during this period.It may articulate anxiety about Marie-Thérèse, who had contracted a serious viral infection after swimming in the polluted River Marne, and lost most of her blonde hair. But it also feels like a grand statement about perilous times, which were threatening to swamp European civilisation.The Tate's show will end with another Rescue, from January 1933, which Borchardt-Hume calls "a painting of agony, and a clear foreboding of the mother and child in Guernica. Picasso is engaging with the darker side of the human psyche."Perhaps, therefore, we should reconsider what Picasso meant when he compared his work to "keeping a diary"."It's a curious thing," says Borchardt-Hume. "You could say that quote implies that the work is an illustration of his biography. In fact, though, he says his work is his biography. So, I see it differently: that his life is in his work, infused by all the tangible and intangible things we absorb while we are in the world."The EY Exhibition: Picasso 1932 - Love, Fame, Tragedy opens at Tate Modern, London SE1 (020 7887 8888; tate.org.uk), on Thurs'Picasso is the Henry VIII of the art world'Word count: 1382Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: PABLO PICASSO NEW EXHIBIT ILLUSTRATES IMPORTANCE OF PAINTER'S STUDIO, WHICH NOURISHED HIS CREATIVE AND SENSUAL LIFE; AN ARTIST'S STUDIO: WADSWORTH ATHENEUM, JUNE 9 -- SEPT. 23: [STATEWIDE Edition]
Full Article: Abstract"The studio for [PABLO PICASSO] was a crossroads, a doorway into his imagination," says Michael C. FitzGerald, the exhibition's guest curator and a noted Picasso scholar. An assistant professor of fine art at Trinity College in Hartford, FitzGerald is the author of the critically acclaimed "Making Modernism: Picasso and the Creation of the Market for 20th Century Art" (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1995).In fact, one of the greatest paintings among the Picasso treasure trove FitzGerald has rounded up over the past four years, is the brilliant, erotically charged 1934 oil on canvas called "The Studio." Inspired by Picasso's young, beautiful mistress of the time, Marie- Therese Walter, it portrays an artist in his studio painting a sensuous, melon-breasted woman sunk in deep, languorous slumber -- a sleeping beauty in the Land of Id. A pearl necklace around her neck lends the fleshy, pliable, male fantasy figure an aristocratic air, even for all her nakedness and rampant sexuality.In this famous self-portrait, Picasso's face mirrors the mask- like Iberian image he created for his famous "Portrait of [Gertrude Stein]" in 1906. This eerie appropriation of Stein's face as a stand- in for his own, FitzGerald writes in the catalog, "celebrated Picasso's achievement and implied an equivalence between this wealthy and established patron and the recently arrived painter."MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitWilliam Shakespeare wrote that all the world's a stage. But for Pablo Picasso, a bold original and radical revisionist, all the world was an artist's studio.Many authorities regard Picasso (1881-1973) as the greatest and most innovative artist of the 20th century. Nothing intimidated this egocentric genius, who was obsessed with art and with being Numero Uno. So, quite naturally, the great one knew for sure that his studio was the epicenter of it all, a catalyst for his surging creative energies.Studio settings, including the relationship between artist and model and the procreative powers of brush, palette and easel, keep cropping up in Picasso's masterworks. Even in later years, when he could have rested on his laurels, he was painting works whose macrocosmic meanings about art, life, sex and death were rooted in the microcosmic world of his studio.Nonetheless, no museum in the United States ever presented a major exhibition exploring this vital link between Picasso's art and the nourishment and inspiration it drew from his studio.At least not until Saturday, when the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art opened a groundbreaking, mind- and eye-pleasing exhibition called "Picasso: the Artist's Studio."Organized by the Hartford museum and the Cleveland Museum of Art, the show features about 35 paintings and 10 drawings, made up of loans from Picasso heirs, private collections and prestigious museums from around the world. This fresh view of the modern master's art as seen through works with studio themes plays in Hartford through Sept. 23. Then it travels to the Cleveland Museum for its second and only other venue."The studio for Picasso was a crossroads, a doorway into his imagination," says Michael C. FitzGerald, the exhibition's guest curator and a noted Picasso scholar. An assistant professor of fine art at Trinity College in Hartford, FitzGerald is the author of the critically acclaimed "Making Modernism: Picasso and the Creation of the Market for 20th Century Art" (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1995)."In the studio, Picasso enthralled collectors, disputed with critics, negotiated with dealers, seduced lovers and pondered art through the lens of the contemporary experiences that shaped his life, ranging from two world wars and the Spanish Civil War to the succession of cultural movements that swept across the 20th century," FitzGerald says.Cauldron Of CreativityAs a young, art-obsessed, bohemian struggling in Paris early in the century, Picasso ate and slept in the studio where he painted.So it's no shock that this artist -- so exhaustively depicted as a notorious painter/satyr (or what critic Robert Hughes has mockingly called "the image of Picasso as the walking scrotum") -- used his studio digs for seducing his female muses. An impressive succession of wives and mistresses kept the hormonal and creative fires burning even well into the golden years for this priapic Methuselah of Modernism, who died at 92 in 1973. Erotic energies were always central to his art.In fact, one of the greatest paintings among the Picasso treasure trove FitzGerald has rounded up over the past four years, is the brilliant, erotically charged 1934 oil on canvas called "The Studio." Inspired by Picasso's young, beautiful mistress of the time, Marie- Therese Walter, it portrays an artist in his studio painting a sensuous, melon-breasted woman sunk in deep, languorous slumber -- a sleeping beauty in the Land of Id. A pearl necklace around her neck lends the fleshy, pliable, male fantasy figure an aristocratic air, even for all her nakedness and rampant sexuality.In her purple left hand (a seal-like flipper among a sea of curvy lines and shapes), the goddess grasps a flowering vine, a shape echoed on the canvas the artist in the picture is painting.Picasso's male artist -- most often his painters are god-like surrogates for himself -- looks like a Cowardly Lion being swallowed up by his painting materials. "...[T]he scatter of vivid pigments across his palette suffuses his face, beard and hair in a brilliant camouflage that almost leaves him invisible," FitzGerald writes in the exhibition catalog."Picasso reduces the woman's body [the body of his young, real- life lover] to a metaphor of fecundity," FitzGerald says. The following year, the curator notes, Marie-Therese gave birth to their daughter, Maia."It makes you wonder if Picasso was anticipating her pregnancy when he was painting this," FitzGerald says.Trinity Of PleasureAbove all else, Picasso loved art. But, of course, he also loved sex and money.In one of his cubist masterworks in the exhibition, he unites this trinity into one work in "The Architect's Table" (1912, oil on canvas mounted on oval panel).Look closely, and you can see coded references to Picasso's personal life. In the lower right corner, there's a copy of a calling card from Gertrude Stein, the expatriate American writer who was then more noted as an art collector of the cutting-edge style of the day. She was one of Picasso's loyal supporters.Floating off a sheet of music in the painting are the words, "Ma Jolie," Picasso's affectionate nickname for his then-illicit lover, Eva Gouel. It's a semi-hidden, or at least sly allusion to a secret lover. Eva was to die from tuberculosis in 1916, four years after this now celebrated, clandestine cubist kiss on canvas."I think he painted Stein's card there as a way of enticing her back as a patron," FitzGerald says."Stein hadn't bought any works from Picasso in a year or two, and that was a great difficulty for him because he really depended on independent patrons like her to keep him going and to help him pay the bills."Stein had come to see him one day at the studio, but he wasn't in. So she left her calling card. Later, he painted her card into the picture."It was a clear ploy for attention and patronage. It worked. How could Stein refuse to buy it? So she did. Eventually, it went to the Museum of Modern Art when her collection was dispersed after her death," FitzGerald says.Man Of SuperstitionDespite his eventual god-like aura in the art world, Picasso was childishly superstitious. And for all his above-it-all, Olympian status as a superstar, he not only avidly collected press clippings about himself but evidently also read them."He subscribed to a clipping service for most of his adult life," FitzGerald says. "It's a quite wonderful collection for researchers because the articles are all preserved together. They're from all over the world, particularly in the 1950s and '60s, but even back into the '20s."Picasso loved a variety of hokum and believed in magic. His friend, the poet and art critic Max Jacob, who practiced fortunetelling and was knowledgeable about astrology, probably introduced him to palmistry and the Tarot."I think that he felt there was something supernatural about the creative spirit that he had somehow inherited," FitzGerald says."If you questioned it too much, he felt, it could be destroyed, lost forever."So he never threw away any of his clothes because, by throwing out an old coat, some of his essence might be lost," he says.That fear, FitzGerald suggests, made Picasso work every day to make sure that the force was always with him. "Painting," Picasso once said, "is stronger-willed than I; she makes me do what she wants."Wide Range Of StylesThe sweeping stylistic range of the Atheneum show almost gives credence to this cosmic explanation of Picasso as a mysteriously driven force field perpetually evolving, always striving to transcend categories as he mixed classical with avant-garde elements.Even with its total focus on the studio theme, the exhibition covers an exhilarating array of styles, including realist, cubist, symbolist, surrealist, abstract and classical. The pictures span Picasso's career, from penniless, bohemian youth to old age, when he's as rich as Croesus and has invented the modern role of the artist as super celebrity.The exhibition's works range from "La Vie," one of the greatest and most famous works from Picasso's Blue Period, to a suite of preliminary drawings for "Guernica," his searing anti-war, anti- fascist painting of 1937.Picasso completed the symbol-laden "La Vie" in 1903, two years after the tragic suicide of his good friend and onetime studio-mate, the Catalan painter Carles Casagemas, who shot himself to death in a crowded Paris cafe. Carles was only 20, the same age as his beloved Pablo.Casagemas, who may have been impotent, had become despondent over his botched, lovesick attempt at an affair with a beautiful but scornful model named Germaine. He shows up as the forlorn-looking lover in "La Vie," an allegory of sacred and profane love. Sexually disabled, young Casagemas is portrayed in the full monty but for his virginal, white loincloth, a symbol of his sexual inadequacy.Novelist Norman Mailer, in his sometimes unhinged but always entertaining "interpretive biography" of Picasso ("Portrait of Picasso As a Young Man," Atlantic Monthly Press, 1995), speculates that the pistol-loving Casagemas and Picasso may even have been gay lovers, or have "merely played at the edges" of homosexuality."It was thinking about Casagemas," Picasso once confided to a friend, "that got me started painting in blue.""Casagemas's suicide obviously provided Picasso with a catalyst for speculating on questions of life, death, and the artist's fate in the modern world," William H. Robinson, an associate curator of painting at the Cleveland Museum, writes in his catalog essay unearthing layers of meaning in "La Vie."As heartsick, or "blue," as Picasso may have been over his bosom buddy's tragic fate, his grief wasn't so inconsolable that it prevented him from crawling under the sheets with Germaine.`Guernica' And Its KinIn a radically different political and social vein, "Guernica" was Picasso's searing protest against the Nazis' brutal aerial bombardment of a small Basque village in 1937 during the Spanish Civil War.A foreshadowing of the horrific destruction from the air in World War II, the Nazi bombers killed more than 1,600 civilians and left thousands wounded and homeless. Picasso's painting of the martyrdom of Guernica became one of if not the most universally recognized images of the 20th century.One of the preliminary drawings in the exhibition, "The Studio: Painter and His Model," has jarring images evoking some of the horror and sheer visceral power of "Guernica."The exhibition also features a mini-herd of images of Picasso's ominous bulls and Minotaurs (half-man, half-bull creatures), along with two striking self-portraits.Among these latter images of the artist as a young man are "Self Portrait with Palette" (1906, oil on canvas). This painting appeared in the Atheneum's celebrated 1934 Picasso show, the first exhibition of his work held in an American museum.In this famous self-portrait, Picasso's face mirrors the mask- like Iberian image he created for his famous "Portrait of Gertrude Stein" in 1906. This eerie appropriation of Stein's face as a stand- in for his own, FitzGerald writes in the catalog, "celebrated Picasso's achievement and implied an equivalence between this wealthy and established patron and the recently arrived painter."There are classic examples of Picasso's painted challenges of El Greco and one of his many variations on the royal Spanish painter Velazquez's famous view of his studio in "Las Meninas." Both the cubist version of the El Greco and Velazquez paintings are part of Picasso's intensive dialogue with tradition and of his arm wrestling contests with past masters to see who's best.A macho competitor, the short, squat, powerful Spaniard in his later years loved to go into his studio and go mano a mano with the greatest heavyweight painters of all time. Laboring late into the night -- his favorite time for painting after a long day of social and business activities -- he would strive to outpaint everyone from Old Masters like Velazquez to his prime contemporary rival and sometime friend, Matisse.An AllegoryThe exhibition's grand finale, "Painter and Infant" -- painted when Picasso was 90 -- is an allegory of the artist in old age, even within sight of death. The infant, a symbol of youth and spontaneity, clutches a paintbrush, apparently in tandem with the aged artist.It seems to be a celebration of the power of rejuvenation and the glory of continuity, a symbolic passing of the baton from one generation to the next. It seems upbeat, flickering with hope even in the face of the old artist's impending extinction.Or so it seems at first glance.But a closer look shows that the stem of the paintbrush has snapped, and the youth now has total control."Maybe what has happened here is that the baby has snatched the paintbrush away, and the old man is left in the dust," FitzGerald suggests."Maybe the old artist, a stand-in for Picasso, didn't want to give it up. Is it a statement of optimism, pessimism, or both?"That's the kind of game Picasso loved to play," FitzGerald says. "It's complex, ambivalent. It's what he saw as reality."Sponsored by Fleet Bank in its Hartford run, "Picasso: The Artist's Studio" will be on exhibit through Sept. 23 at the Wadsworth Atheneum, 600 Main St. Admission is by timed ticket. Ticket prices are $15 for adults, $13 for seniors and students with ID, $11 for youths ages 6 to 17, $8 for museum members, free for children under 6. The ticket price includes general admission and handling fees. To buy tickets, call VISTA Ticketing toll-free at 877-600-MAIN, or visit Museum Ticketing Network at www.museumtix.com. Museum members should call 877-WADS-MEM. Please do not call the Atheneum.IllustrationPHOTO: (color) PHOTO: (b&w), NATIONAL CENTRO De ARTE REINA SOFIA, MADRID PHOTO: (b&w), TATE GALLERY; Caption: "SELF-PORTRAIT WITH PALETTE" (1906), above, and these pencil studies for self-portraits (1906) are part of "Picasso: The Artist's Studio," at the Wadsworth Atheneum. "PAINTER AND MODEL" (April 1963), above, and "Studio" (1955), below, represent some of the artist's later stages in "Picasso: The Artist's Studio" at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art.Word count: 2320Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract

World class art on their doorsteps ; Earagail Arts Festival brought substantial work by celebrated 20th- century artists, including Henry Moore and Pablo Picasso, to Donegal. Aidan Dunne reports: [CITY EDITION]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndThere is something strange about turning off Letterkenny's busy main street into the library building and descending the stairs to the art centre's basement gallery, a room strikingly devoid of natural light, to encounter substantial sculptures by some of the most celebrated artists of the 20th century, gathered for the exhibition Form. This should not, in itself, be surprising. In the past few years both John Cunningham and Shaun Hannigan, in their different capacities, have worked hard to ensure that, no matter how different it is up there in Donegal, as the tourism slogan has it, residents of the county should be able to see world-class art on their doorsteps. Hence the appearance of the likes of Jeff Koons on the list of artists included in the county art collection.The extraordinary range of sculpture on view in Letterkenny is augmented by an excellent show of graphic work, and some small sculptures, by [Henry Moore] at the Glebe Gallery, in Churchill. Partly because Moore is seen as representative of the high-art tradition of modernism, his work is currently unfashionable. In particular, there is a view that his prominent publicly sited sculptures typify the practice of imposing art on the community. So there is a degree of challenge in situating his work at the heart of a regional arts festival. This is underlined by the citing of Clive Bell's celebrated phrase "significant form", encapsulating his emphasis on the formal elements of a work of art, in relation to Form.Was there, in Earagail, a dialectical tension between the modernist aesthetic embodied in pieces by [Pablo Picasso], Barbara Hepworth, Sir Anthony Caro and Henry Moore and the art engage of [Gerard Mannix Flynn] or Aisling? In the end, not really. It is not a case of arguing that community is good and art establishment bad, for example. Surely it is difficult to look at a wonderful sculpture such as Hepworth's Curved Form - Trevalgan without relating it to forms in the environment beyond the urban sprawl of Letterkenny. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit There is something strange about turning off Letterkenny's busy main street into the library building and descending the stairs to the art centre's basement gallery, a room strikingly devoid of natural light, to encounter substantial sculptures by some of the most celebrated artists of the 20th century, gathered for the exhibition Form. This should not, in itself, be surprising. In the past few years both John Cunningham and Shaun Hannigan, in their different capacities, have worked hard to ensure that, no matter how different it is up there in Donegal, as the tourism slogan has it, residents of the county should be able to see world-class art on their doorsteps. Hence the appearance of the likes of Jeff Koons on the list of artists included in the county art collection.Not that the Earagail Arts Festival visual-arts programme is about bringing high art to the masses in some missionary sense. Rather the issue is one of engagement. Time and again festival events gave the sense that visual culture was something living, something rooted in the world rather than an embellishment to it, something open to debate and up for grabs.The extraordinary range of sculpture on view in Letterkenny is augmented by an excellent show of graphic work, and some small sculptures, by Henry Moore at the Glebe Gallery, in Churchill. Partly because Moore is seen as representative of the high-art tradition of modernism, his work is currently unfashionable. In particular, there is a view that his prominent publicly sited sculptures typify the practice of imposing art on the community. So there is a degree of challenge in situating his work at the heart of a regional arts festival. This is underlined by the citing of Clive Bell's celebrated phrase "significant form", encapsulating his emphasis on the formal elements of a work of art, in relation to Form.In that show Anish Kapoor's enigmatic and compelling objects, their surfaces thickly coated with powdered pigment, could be seen as contemporary counterparts to Moore's forms, with their rhythmic play of masses and voids. Void is the operative word in relation to Kapoor. His textured forms draw you in, trapping your gaze but leaving you curiously adrift as you lose sight of anything to hold on to. He does, as he says, make not so much objects as holes in space. He aims to offer the viewer a transcendent aesthetic experience.All of which could be seen as occupying one end of a spectrum of cultural possibility. If that is so, at the other are events with their feet firmly planted in the community. There is the festival's visual-artist-in-residence, Gerard Mannix Flynn, whose work provocatively addresses the issues that go to the heart of society, chronicling the experience of an individual thrown on the mercy of the State's institutions. And there was Dreamtime/Aisling by An Cosan Glas Cois Fharraige, which has developed an annual outdoor participatory sculpture project, involving artists and children, over the past few years.Aisling, this year's project, differed in that it culminated in a specific performance event, an hour-long beach spectacle at Tr Machaire Rabhartaigh. The organisers weren't sure what to expect in terms of audience interest, but chances were they did not expect the thousands of spectators - and the attendant traffic jam - that the event attracted. This huge response was a startling confirmation that there is an appetite for ambitious cultural projects with significant community involvement.In fact Aisling, with its 20 performers, winged willow-and-paper figures, articulated sculptures and environmental son et lumire, drew on the skills and labour of 70 children, not to mention the adults, including Seamus Kennedy, Deirdre N Bhraonain, Annjo Carr, Ewan Berry, Billy Wynter and more. It is worth pointing out, though, that technology and pyrotechnics were never in danger of eclipsing the essence of the thing as a sculptural project that drew its materials and inspiration from the elements and the environment in a profound way.Flynn's residency allowed him to assemble several of his series of recent, highly successful projects and work with them in a new context. His presence was crucial to this process, and both the text- based installations and his performative interventions elicited extraordinary responses from the audience. In complementary ways, Victim Impact Report and Not To Be Read in Open Court chronicle the experiences of an individual, James, who, put into the care of the State, is subject to institutional abuse. The works chart the levels of damage inflicted and the network of mutual reinforcement that operated between various authorities.Flynn's breakthrough in terms of articulating this issue in visual form came with his employment of the documents and language of the powerful, of the institutions themselves, so that we get a dual account, from the points of view of the subject and the powers- that-be charged with his care, that is cumulatively chilling. It is also exceptionally accessible, and the siting of Victim Impact Report in the bandstand in Market Square in Letterkenny made it even more so. It helped, of course, that Flynn's commitment was total.In another sense, so is the commitment of another festival visitor, Billy Childish, who was there in several capacities, primarily musical, perhaps, but backed up with poetry and, at the county museum, paintings. An unmistakable presence around town, Childish (known partly as a former partner of Tracey Emin) cut an anachronistic figure, tall and skinny with a prominent moustache and attired in first World War garb.All of his work is characterised by a quality of outpouring, by a seeming need to constantly express his personality. He is extraordinarily prolific in everything he does. His paintings have a rough, expressionist character with a leaning towards icons of extremity, evoking feelings of isolation, suffering and pessimism.Rather more understated by comparison, Element by Claire McLaughlin, at An Grianan Theatre, is a subtle show of small but outstanding ceramic work. Sidestepping the predictable, McLaughlin allies ceramic to the techniques of paintings and printmaking, and apparently involves the impress of natural materials, to make beautifully judged, delicately textural panels that pursue a dialogue concerning nature and culture. It is very fine, understated work that needs to be seen at first hand.Was there, in Earagail, a dialectical tension between the modernist aesthetic embodied in pieces by Picasso, Barbara Hepworth, Sir Anthony Caro and Henry Moore and the art engage of Mannix Flynn or Aisling? In the end, not really. It is not a case of arguing that community is good and art establishment bad, for example. Surely it is difficult to look at a wonderful sculpture such as Hepworth's Curved Form - Trevalgan without relating it to forms in the environment beyond the urban sprawl of Letterkenny.For all the "development", Co Donegal remains a place in which the influence of the sea, the landscape and the weather is pervasive and enriching. Certainly, Hepworth, Moore and a sculptor such as David Nash, some of whose work brilliantly integrates geometric form with natural materials and processes, look thoroughly at home in the wider physical context of the county and, perhaps more importantly, help to shape the way we might see it.- Exhibitions continue at the Glebe Gallery until August 27th and Letterkenny Arts Centre and Donegal County Museum until August 28thWord count: 1237Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases.
