Title: Abstract

News of the Weird: Economic indicators A 1958 Pablo Picasso original, "Atelier de Cannes," was placed on sale recently by the discount chain Costco (at its Web site Costco.com), priced to move at the retail-type listing of $129,999.99. Costco began offering art on
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitHOW LONG IS REALLY SAFE? In July 2004, as News of the Weird mentioned, a federal appeals court ruled that the leak-safety standards for the long-awaited nuclear waste depository at Nevada's Yucca Mountain were too weak, in that the Environmental Protection Agency would regard the facility as safe for only 10,000 years (almost five times the length of time since the birth of Jesus). One National Academy of Sciences panel had recommended against the site unless leak safety could be certified for at least 300,000 years. In August 2005, EPA issued a revised durability standard, now claiming the site would be free of unsafe leaks for a million years. (Context: 110 years ago, science had not even discovered radioactivity.) VIRTUAL REALITY A Pakistani company, The Resource Group, seeking more call-center work from U.S. firms, set up an office this year in Washington, D.C., a block from the White House, and installed a receptionist, live from Karachi, via a flat-screen TV on the office wall. According to a May Washington Post report, Saadia Musa cheerily greets visitors, answers and routes phone calls to the Washington office, lets in deliverymen, and orders sandwiches from down the street. UGLY DOG CROWNED AGAIN Sam, the 14-year-old Chinese crested, won in June for the third time as the World's Ugliest Dog at the Sonoma-Marin Fair in California. According to an Associated Press reporter, the hairless dog's "wrinkled brown skin is covered with splotches; a line of warts marches down his snout; his blind eyes are an alien, milky white; and a fleshy flap of skin hangs from his withered neck. And then there's the Austin Powers teeth that jut at odd angles from his mouth." Owner Susie Lockheed said that even the judges recoiled when they first saw him. (Fortunately, for those concerned with dog beauty, Sam has been neutered.) SHOT AND EVICTED According to police in Jacksonville, N.C., Dorothea Thomas was shot six times by her boyfriend in June and forced to jump from her apartment's second-story balcony to survive, but by the time she returned from the hospital, her landlord of nine years, United Dominion Residential Community, had posted an eviction notice, kicking her out for letting such a dangerous man come onto the property. INCOMPETENT CRIMINALS Jeremy Suggs, 21, was arrested in Las Vegas in August and charged with robbing a Wells Fargo bank, done in by the familiar lapse of having accidentally left behind his wallet and a name-imprinted deposit slip. Also, according to police, he fired two shots in the bank out of frustration at noncompliance with his demands, with one narrowly missing his own head, and had to re-count down a threat to shoot ("5, 4, 3, 2, 1") when no one gave him money the first time. His alleged partner and getaway driver supposedly had talked him into the crime by assuring him that there were no surveillance cameras, but of course there were. BRIGHT IDEAS The owner of Al's Lock and Safe in North Platte, Neb., made a truck key in June based entirely on looking at an X-ray of the key inside the stomach of Arthur Richardson, who had accidentally swallowed it in an inept attempt to play a prank on the friend of his who owned the truck. The friend said he needed the truck right away and couldn't wait for Arthur to receive a nature's call. GRANNIES AND STREET CRED Grandmother-of-six Mari Savage and other senior friends in Margate, England, began a campaign this summer to wear hooded sweatshirts and baseball caps, to discourage teenagers from dressing that way, which Savage believes encourages gang behavior. Said Savage, to the Daily Telegraph, "Once older people like us get hold of (these garments), they lose all their street cred."Word count: 623Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Gazing out over the packed beaches of the Cote d'Azur, Picasso once admitted he had 'a lot to answer for'. It was true. Before the great artist first visited Saint Raphael in 1919, the Riviera was best known as a winter retreat for pale-skinned Britons, but by the mid-Twenties it had become a fashionable summer destination for the cultural elite. Exiled Russian royals, English aristocrats, European intellectuals and American bohemians streamed to Nice, Cannes, Monaco and Antibes in search of good times.The American socialites Gerald and Sara Murphy - whose motto was 'Living well is the best revenge' - were trendsetters of the era. F Scott Fitzgerald was so mesmerised by their style that he fictionalised them as Dick and Nicole Diver in his novel Tender Is The Night.The Murphys went to Cap d'Antibes in 1922 to visit Cole Porter, who had hired a villa next to Hotel du Cap. The hotel was then open only in winter but they persuaded the owner to remain open for the following summer and invited Pablo and Olga Picasso to be their guests. This marked the real beginning of the Riviera boom.Walking into this calm but palatial hotel today and feeling the sea breeze waft through the Bellini Bar, it's hard to see why Riviera summers were ever considered a bad thing. What's not to like about luxurious lawns, a rose garden bordered by mimosa trees, an infinity pool blasted out of the rocks, a dining pavilion that gives you the feeling of being on the deck of a ship, and a regal avenue running down to the ocean's edge?But you have to remember that before the Twenties, a sun tan was a stigma rather than a statement and beaches weren't places to play. Back then, La Plage de la Garoupe - the closest beach to Hotel du Cap - was so strewn with seaweed and stones that the Picassos and Murphys routinely took spades, rakes and a sieve with them to clear space. Tans came into vogue only when Coco Chanel returned to Paris in 1923 with her skin accidentally browned after visiting Cannes on board the Duke of Wellington's yacht.Although Picasso would eventually rue many of the changes his holiday choices had brought about, he didn't stay away. Born in Malaga, he had a lifelong love of the Mediterranean's clear light and bold colours. He was inspired by the forms of bathers, the clarity of shapes lit by the sun and the primal nature of rocks, shells, ocean and sand.In the Twenties, he rented villas in Juan les Pins but in the Thirties, on the recommendation of the surrealist poet Paul Eluard, he moved inland to the small hilltop village of Mougins. Here, from his balcony at the Hotel Vaste Horizon, he could see not only the blue of the ocean but the green of cypress groves, the mustard colours of buildings and, in the far distance, the snow-white tops of the Prealpes.The medieval village of Mougins is a welcome layby from the modern world. The narrow streets are lined with lovingly tended old buildings, many draped in green foliage or fronted by terracotta pots sprouting flowers and bushes. Cats stretch out in the sun knowing that they can remain undisturbed by traffic.If Disney had to create a cute corner of southern France for one of its theme parks, it would probably base it on Mougins.It may well be the Picasso connection that has allowed Mougins to focus on beauty and pleasure. The village has become renowned as a centre for food and art. Almost every commercial outlet is a gallery a craft store, a restaurant or a grocer's. Each September, chefs descend to battle it out at the Festival International de la Gastronomie.Its galleries sell everything from ashtrays for tourists to large sculptures for collectors.Some artists, such as Patrick Duperron, who can be seen painting at his gallery on Rue des Lombards, are obviously influenced by Picasso, but many aren't. Mary Larsson, who shares space with two other female artists at The Mougins Art Studio, was encouraged to paint by the work of Van Gogh and is now inspired by Scandinavian myths and Indian religious philosophy.Picasso remains a presence in Mougins but not an overpowering one. The local hero is Amedee-Francois Lamy, who was born in Mougins in 1858 and died in battle in 1900. He was a career soldier who served in Algeria, Tunisia and the Congo before helping France conquer Chad - and his statue stands at the entrance to the village.Picasso is more quietly celebrated at the Musee de la Photographie, where the top floor is dedicated to a collection of black-and-white prints of him (mostly by Andre Villers) taken during the early Fifties.On the outside wall of the building, there is a framed poster of him characteristically stripped to the waist with his arms folded over his barrel chest.The Hotel Vaste Horizon, where Picasso lived with his lover, Dora Maar, Paul Eluard, photographer Man Ray and other kindred spirits in the Thirties, had different names before closing last year. Picasso once decorated the walls of his room here in colourful paints, only to be told by the owner to return it to its original condition.It is now destined to become the town's tourist office and there is nothing to indicate that this was where one of the 20th century's creative geniuses plotted his future.The Second World War kept Picasso away from the Riviera, but the summer visits restarted after Paris was liberated. In 1946, he came to the annual pottery exhibition at Vallauris, a town just a few kilometres inland from Golfe Juan.He was particularly intrigued by the work of local ceramicists Suzanne and Georges Ramie and began collaborating with them, supplying designs for their plates, dishes, pitchers, vases, cups and plaques. Two years later, he moved there with his new lover, Francoise Gilot.Vallauris has none of the charm of Mougins. For a Picasso tour of the town, you hardly have to veer from the Avenue Georges Clemenceau that climbs steadily towards a public square. Every other shop you pass sells ceramics.Halfway up, on Rue Ramie, is the now derelict Madoura pottery where Picasso produced 4,000 ceramic works with Suzanne and Georges. The gates are now locked and weeds sprout through the gravel pathway to the front door.In the square stands Picasso's bronze sculpture L'Homme Au Mouton, which he donated to the municipal council. It's a dark, craggy piece that suggests a mood at odds with the children scrambling in front of the library, the old men swallowing their beers and the women exchanging gossip. He never commented on its meaning. It could be the Good Shepherd of the Gospels returning with the lost sheep or merely a peasant with some fresh meat.Afew metres away, housed in an old priory, is the Musee National Picasso. It's a grand name for a small and limited collection focused mainly on posters and ceramics created during his five-year stay in the town. There's plenty of space, but not a lot of guidance. There wasn't even a catalogue for sale.In the priory's small chapel, the walls and ceiling of its barrelvaulted chancel are covered with the wooden panels of a grand fresco, La Guerre Et La Paix, painted by Picasso in 1952. Although large and ambitious, the work seems cursory and the thinly applied paint gives the impression of a job done in a hurry.When Picasso started working with ceramics, he was offered work space at the Palais Grimaldi - Antibes' museum. In gratitude for the city's generosity, Picasso donated many paintings, drawings and ceramic works and in 1947 they went on display. Almost 20 years later, its collection having been expanded by further donations and acquisitions, the Palais Grimaldi was renamed Musee Picasso.It's a wonderful place to view Picasso's work, not just because of the spaciousness of the rooms and the building's superb position overlooking the sea, but because almost everything on display was created locally. What you experience is his wide-eyed and joyous embrace of his new Riviera life.Opposite Musee Picasso, at Ceramiques du Chateau, it is still possible to buy from some of the 633 designs Picasso allowed to be produced in limited editions. They are predominantly dishes from the Fifties and start at about EUR 2,000. The most expensive plate in the gallery - Scissors And Grapes, produced in 1948 - is unique and signed. It has a price tag of EUR 60,000.From Vallauris, Picasso moved to Cannes. He had a new woman in his life, Jacqueline Roque, and wanted more space for his work and more privacy. He bought a huge white villa overlooking the town, which became known as La Californie. Although no longer in the Picasso family, the house remains secluded. It is now called Pavillon de Flore.For the final stage of his life, Picasso went back to Mougins.Tiring of the tourism of Cannes, he bought a house on the side of a hill outside the old village and named it L'Antre du Minautore. He died here in 1973, aged 91.In accordance with his wishes, his body was taken to Vauvenargues, a 14th century chateau he had bought for Jacqueline in 1958 on the hills outside Aix-en-Provence. He was buried in the grounds, his resting place marked by one of his sculptures. After Jacqueline committed suicide in 1986, she was buried next to him.Last year, for the first time, the public were allowed to view the house which had remained virtually untouched since his death. It is open again this summer until October 2 for visitors who pre-book.Ninety years after his first visit, Picasso is still drawing people to the south of France.GETTING THEREINSPIRATION: A 1957 Picasso of the Cote d'AzurAer Lingus - aerlingus.com - flies to Nice from Dublin and Cork. Ryanair -ryanair.com - flies to Nice from Dublin. Rooms at Hotel Martinez, Cannes, start at EUR 560 per night during the high season. - hotel-martinez.com, (0033) 492 987 410. Hotel du Cap - (0033 493 613 901, hotel-du-cap-edenroc.com - offers rooms from EUR 480 per night.WHERE TO SEE PICASSO'S WORK THIS SUMMER...Picasso: Peace and Freedom at Tate Liverpool until August 30, 2010. A major exhibition of more than 150 works by Picasso from across the world. Admission Pounds 10 (EUR 12). Pre-book tickets at www.tate.org.uk/liverpool or call (0044) 845 604 7083.Picasso: The Mediterranean Years (1945-1962) at Gagosian Gallery, Britannia Street, London. Until August 28, 2010. Entrance free. For more information, see www.gagosian.com.Vauvenargues Castle will be open until October 2 for guided visits. Visit www.chateauvauvenargues.com or call (0033) 4 42 38 11 91.For information on Picasso events on the French Riviera this year, as well as the artistic routes that can be taken in the area, visit www.picassoenprovencecotedazur.com.Before the Twenties, tans were a stigmaCredit: Steve TurnerIllustrationCaption: HAUNTING: Picasso's Self Portrait Facing Death painted in 1972 PICTURE PERFECT: The Antibes coastline and the Palais Grimaldi, right, once Picasso's studio, now a museum dedicated to his work; CORBIS; PICTURE PERFECT: The Antibes coastline and the Palais Grimaldi, right, once Picasso's studio, now a museum dedicated to his work; STATE OF THE ART: Steve Turner with Picasso ceramics in Antibes' Musee Picasso; GRAND DESIGNS: Pablo Picasso, with some of his painted ceramic works at his studio in Vallauris. The celebrities' favourite, Hotel du Cap in Antibes, above; CORBISWord count: 1926Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract

THE ARTIST AND HIS MUSE [ET Panache]: Pablo Picasso immortalised French artist and lover Dora Maar through his paintings. Now, she is stepping out of his shadow, with a retrospective of her works at the Pompidou Centre. A look at other artists and their troubled bond with their inspirations
Full Article: Full TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitmodel behaviourPicasso was almost 30 years older than Walter when he met her in 1927. The painter and his muse had a secret affair for over eight years before Walter got pregnant and the affair was discovered by Picasso's wife, Olga. At the time, Picasso was also having an affair with Dora Maar. The artist suggested that both his muses fight it out for his affections. Walter continued to be involved with Picasso till the early 1940s.Gala, born in Russia, was first married to poet Paul Éluard. The two had an open marriage and Éluard would introduce Gala to new artists, including Max Ernst, who became one of her lovers. Gala met Salvador Dali in 1929 and soon after, they began to live together. Almost immediately after they met, Dali began featuring Gala in his paintings. She became his muse, portrait model and business manager. He even signed his paintings with both of their names. The two tied the knot in 1934, but Gala continued to have affairs. Her death in 1982 reportedly took a terrible toll on the artist.Bacon's relationship with Dyer was fraught with conflict and had a tragic end. Their relationship began in late 1963 in a pub in Soho and was infused with passion, alcohol and drugs. From then, Dyer became Bacon's muse. However, their relationship started to go downhill, and Dyer's addiction worsened with time. Two days before the opening of the Francis Bacon Retrospective at the Grand Palais in Paris in 1971, Dyer committed suicide. Bacon painted the renowned three 'Black Triptychs', which portrayed a few moments before and after Dyer's suicide.Siddal was the muse and model for many pre-Raphaelites before sitting for Rossetti in 1851. Within two years, Siddal and Rossetti began to work with each other exclusively. By 1853, the couple lived together and reportedly became absorbed in each other to the point of becoming anti-social. Some reports suggest that Siddal was plagued by insecurities that she would be replaced by a younger muse and Rossetti worried about his family's approval. The two married in 1860. Siddal died of an overdose of laudanum two years later.Claudel was a French sculptor who started to work as the assistant of renowned sculptor Auguste Rodin. Rodin was drawn to her and soon, she was his lover and muse. What followed was a tumultuous 10-year relationship. Rodin, already in a committed relationship, was not prepared to leave his long-term partner. The destructive aftermath of the affair turned Claudel into a paranoid recluse. She threw away most her of work and spent the last 30 years of her life confined to a mental institution.Word count: 442Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Art with a Latin flair: On a plain white canvas, bright hues of yellow, red and green spring forth to form the outline of a rooster. The feathered creature?s image originally was painted by renowned artist Pablo Picasso in 1933, but on Wednesday it was the artistic focus of M
Full Article: Full TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitSpanish students re-create landmark works of the culture?s mastersshaight@insidevc.comOn a plain white canvas, bright hues of yellow, red and green spring forth to form the outline of a rooster.The feathered creature?s image originally was painted by renowned artist Pablo Picasso in 1933, but on Wednesday it was the artistic focus of Matt Bouvet, a 16-year-old Moorpark High School sophomore. He re-created Picasso?s painting as part of an assignment for his upper-level Spanish class.Bouvet?s reproduction, and those of other students, hung inside the school?s library Wednesday as part of a one-day art museum meant to enhance the culture, traditions and art of Mexico, Spain and Latin America.Works of artists such as Anita Munman, Dania Sierra and Diego Velazquez were both researched and re-created by students, many of whom showed their own artistic flair using oils, acrylics or charcoal.Spanish teacher Sharon Konish said the project, which she said is in either its eighth or ninth year, helps cultivate artistic talents that many students didn?t know they possessed.It?s also an ongoing tradition that targets not only Spanish students, but those in history, special education and science because teachers will often send them to the museum as part of an assignment, Konish said.?It?s reinforcing research (that students did) of the culture of the language,? she said.For his piece, 17-year-old junior Cody Holland chose ?The Open Window,? by Juan Gris.He spent many hours tracing, sketching and refining his reproduction of the Spanish cubist painter and sculptor?s work, finishing his work a week before the actual deadline.Holland said he specifically picked Gris? work because of its appeal.?You look outside an open window and everything is so free,? Holland said.In researching the artist, he was able to understand more about his specific style of art and the mind-set behind his works.For others, like Bouvet, the reproductions of fellow classmates became a history lesson.In one painting, ?Guernica,? Picasso used abstract images of a mother holding her dead child, a dying horse and a fatally wounded soldier clutching a broken sword, to capture the gruesome reality and agony of war.?Different artists were drawing things they had done in their lives. Picasso drew pictures of war in a negative way,?Bouvet said.If Picasso were alive today, Bouvet believes, he would create similar anti-war paintings to depict what?s happening in Iraq.CREDIT: Word count: 397Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPablo Picasso is best known for his paintings, bold works such as "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon" and "Guernica" that profoundly influenced the course of modern art. This fall, the Museum of Modern Art plans to showcase a less-celebrated aspect of Picasso's output--his sculpture--with a major survey of three-dimensional works that spans the artist's entire career. Featuring around 150 pieces from major collections around the world, "Picasso Sculpture" will run from Sept. 14, 2015 to Feb. 7, 2016. The show will occupy the entire fourth floor of MoMA's galleries, the museum announced on Thursday, and includes a number of sculptures that will be on view in the U.S. for the first time. It is the largest U.S. exhibition of Picasso's sculptures since MoMA mounted "The Sculpture of Picasso" in 1967, according to the museum. The exhibition follows recent high-profile Picasso shows at Pace Gallery and Gagosian Gallery, and comes as the value of Picasso's sculptures has been on the rise. Some 50 sculptures were borrowed from Paris's Picasso Museum. The exhibit will also include pieces lent from other major museums and some from MoMA's collection. A self-taught sculptor, Picasso worked in materials ranging from bronze and sheet-metal to plaster and plywood. "She-Goat," a life-size work from 1950, was assembled from plaster and objects found near his studio in the French town of Vallauris and later cast into bronze. A wicker basket, for example, forms the goat's rib cage, while two ceramic jugs were fashioned into udders. Many pieces remained in his possession until his death. The MoMA exhibition will be divided into chapters covering the various periods when Picasso focused on sculpture, and will also include some works on paper and photographs of his three-dimensional works. Diana Widmaier-Picasso, the artist's granddaughter, has been working with MoMA curators Ann Temkin and Anne Umland, on the catalog and to coordinate loans for the show. "I am eager to see it," she said. Write to Jennifer Smith at jennifer.smith@wsj.com Credit: By Jennifer SmithWord count: 328Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract

The Irish paparazzo who charmed Picasso: ARTThe Dublin-born son of a Guinness worker, Edward Quinn was a club singer on the French Riviera during its glittering heydey. After getting his hands on a professional camera, writes LANIE GOODMAN, he began a career that would see him forge a friendship with the great artist Pablo Picasso that lasted 19 years
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitOn a warm summer day in July 1951, Monaco-based Irish photographer Edward Quinn was paging through the local newspaper and something caught his eye. The great master himself, Pablo Picasso, would be attending the opening of the yearly ceramics exhibition in the nearby hilltop village of Vallauris, known for its pottery.Armed with his Rolleiflex camera, 31-year-old Quinn jumped into his car and arrived on the scene to shoot a series of images that captured the artist in all his spontaneity. Little did it occur to Quinn (a cabaret singer, musician and self-taught emerging freelance photographer) that this brief encounter with Picasso would lead to a close friendship between the two men lasting 19 years, right up to the end of the artist's life.Quinn had an eminently likeable quality that inspired trust. Tall, thin, and handsome, with a dapper little moustache and shy, friendly smile, the Dublin-born photographer hardly fit the intrusive image of a celebrity-chasing paparazzo. As he would later recount in his book The Private Picasso, the real secret was knowing how to keep out of Picasso's way. "This one doesn't disturb me," Quinn heard the artist tell a friend.Along with discretion, Quinn's keen eye and superb black-and-white portraits prompted Picasso to invite him into his world, both inside the studio and at home with friends and family.Now the fruits of that friendship have gone on display at the Musee Picasso in the south of France. Housed in the 12th-century stone Chateau Grimaldi in Antibes, 'Picasso Sans Cliche, Photography by Edward Quinn', has 126 images that span from the 1950s to 1972, a year before the artist's death.The pictures offer privileged glimpses into Picasso's persona, capturing fleeting meditative moments when the artist is absorbed in creation. Highlights include a close-up of the 70-year-old artist at the 1951 Vallauris ceramic exhibition, brows furrowed in thought, smoking a cigarette as he gazes intently at something outside of the frame. Another shows the artist kneading a small bird clay sculpture at the Madoura atelier, where Picasso discovered his newly-found passion.Quinn also captures the excitement of summertime bullfights held in Vallauris -- in the grandstands, we witness a complicitous moment between Jean Cocteau, Picasso and his future wife, Jacqueline, applauding with radiant smiles; and there is the artist, bare-chested, in an open woven shirt and sombrero-style hat, flanked by his two young children, Claude and Paloma, eyes riveted on the arena.Over the years, Quinn shot more than 9,000 photos of the artist and was a regular visitor to Picasso's villa, La Californie in Cannes, and Notre Dame Vie in Mougins. "In Quinn's photos, you can really feel Picasso's presence in the studio, even in his absence," Jean-Louis Andral, the exhibition curator, tells me. "Since Picasso pretty much lived where he worked, there was no real separation."Indeed, the empty studio shots -- a joyous jumble of sculptures, paintings, drawings and tables overflowing with paints, newspapers, books and rolled canvases -- offer compelling portraits of the artist."What I also find very touching is how Quinn was able to capture the tenderness between Picasso and Jacqueline," Andral says. "You can really get a sense of their passion, despite the 43-year age difference."Predictably, Quinn's reputation as Picasso's photographer made it easier to approach other painters on the Cote D'Azur, including Marc Chagall, Salvador Dali, Francis Bacon and David Hockney.The son of a Guinness brewery worker and educated in Dublin, Edward Quinn earned certificate in metal-plate work, only to decide he'd rather play guitar and double bass a band in Belfast. After World War II, he switched jobs to became a radio navigator for Chartair, an airline based in Tangier, and he took his first pictures with a simple folding Kodak camera. In 1948, Quinn met his future wife, Zurich-born Gret Sulser, on a flight to Marseille. Before long, they were married in Monaco, where she had settled.Working as a Latino-style crooner in Riviera nightclubs (under the name of 'Eddie Quinero'), Quinn eventually got his hands on professional camera and began shooting bathing beauties on the beach, hoping to find something more newsworthy to sell to magazines. In 1950, after learning an Irish horse had won a jumping contest in Nice, he packed up his gear and photographed the triumphant horseman, Captain Turbidy. The Irish Independent published the photo, Quinn's first. "At that moment," Quinn later recalled, "I began to take my work as a photographer seriously... and transformed the tiny kitchen of a kindly Monegasque friend into a darkroom."In the 1950s and 1960s, when the Cote d'Azur was a millionaire's playground, teeming with celebrities, film stars and crown heads of Europe, Quinn's easy charm would serve him well. He started working for Paris-Match and other agencies, and photographed the likes of Grace Kelly, Prince Rainier III (immortalising their first shy handshake), Brigitte Bardot, Liz Taylor and Marlon Brando, among others."He had a knack for getting close to stars and became good friends with people like Frank Sinatra and Kim Novak," says Quinn's nephew, Wolfgang Frei, a Swiss TV journalist who often accompanied his uncle as an assistant ("I basically drove him around when was in my twenties")."In those years, there were no agents or PR people so the contact was direct. Quinn knew all the concierges at the Carlton and the Majestic in Cannes. He also had connections at the airline companies for tip-offs on stars arriving at the Nice airport."Among his uncle's favourite anecdotes was Quinn's account of meeting Audrey Hepburn back in 1951 when the still unknown actress was shooting a film called Monte Carlo Baby."He spotted something special about Hepburn right away and suggested a photo session in the perched medieval village of Eze, about 30 minutes away. So, they climbed into Quinn's little Belgian car, which was quite old, and chugged up the steep hill. On the way there, the car broke down, so he had to ask Audrey to get out and push it."" Today, Frei and his wife Ursula manage the Edward Quinn archive and continue to publish stunning posthumous books (Riviera Cocktail [2007], Stars and Cars of the 50s2008], Celebrity Pets [2014]) from a bygone era. "We have something like 180,000 negatives in the archives and only 30,000 have been scanned," says Frei.Their next project is organising an exhibition based on Quinn's book, James Joyce's Dublin [1974], a compilation of street scenes matched with selected quotes of Joyce's works. "Quinn is known as a Riviera celebrity photographer, but he was also interested in shooting street children, bars, the races and the poor," Frei says. "He would have really liked to do a show in Dublin -- Ireland always remained very important to him."Picasso Sans Cliche: Photographies d'Edward Quinn takes place at the Musee Picasso in Antibes until July 2Word count: 1139Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Close to the sun: Pablo Picasso's wives, muses and mistresses had an enormous impact on his art, while his effect on their lives was no less profound. For a forthcoming BBC series, Alastair Sooke met three women who were intimately involved with the artist in the 1950s and who survived to tell the tale

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Pablo Picasso often compared his paintings to the pages of a journal. Yet he hated the idea that art historians and biographers might confine the scope of his work or his character within an article or a book. Born in Malaga in 1881, the artist grew up to become a shape-shifter. He worked in many different styles, to avoid becoming mannered, and would periodically change his friends, his entourage, his homes, his pets and, of course, his lovers. As his old friend and secretary, the Spanish poet Jaime Sabartes, once said, 'That's his strength! The key to his youth. Like a moulting snake, he leaves his old skin behind him and begins a new existence elsewhere.' Nearly four decades after his death in 1973, he remains a surprisingly slippery figure. According to his biographer, John Richardson, Picasso was so paradoxical that almost any statement made about him tends to be no less true in reverse. How can we be sure of anything about such a mercurial man? This question has preoccupied me while writing and presenting Modern Masters, a new four-part television series about modern art, which will be broadcast on BBC One next month. Each programme is devoted to a different figure that dominated the art of the 20th century. Inevitably, one of the artists is Picasso (Matisse, Dali and Warhol are the other three). To try to understand the nature of Picasso's genius, I met several women who featured prominently in his life, and inspired him to make art. Women were extraordinarily important for Picasso, who was by turns kind and cruel to all his wives, muses and mistresses. According to the French painter Francoise Gilot, who was his mistress for a decade after they met in 1943, Picasso was fond of saying, 'For me, there are only two kinds of women: goddesses and doormats.' Yet even the 'doormats' (and there are many instances of the artist psychologically trampling over his nearest and dearest) played an important role in the evolution of his art: after all, one of the cardinal myths about Picasso is that his work changed direction whenever a new woman became the principal lover in his life. As he once said: 'When I love a woman, that tears everything apart - especially my painting.' As a result, certain women are associated with different periods of his career. His first significant lover, Fernande Olivier, a model with copious reddish hair, is the roseate goddess who dominated Picasso's output during the first decade of the 20th century. Olga Koklova, a dancer with Diaghilev's Ballets Russes who became Picasso's first wife in 1918, presided over what one of Picasso's poet friends satirically called his 'duchess period', when he fraternised with the rich and famous and produced neoclassical work. The blond Marie-Therese Walter, with whom Picasso began a passionate affair in the mid-1920s, inspired a run of sumptuously erotic canvases, full of squidgy, pliant female flesh. Dora Maar, the Surrealist photographer who became Picasso's companion in the 1930s, will forever be remembered as the 'Weeping Woman', immortalised in the famous painting of that name in the Tate. Few of these women met happy ends: as one mistress put it, 'Picasso was a sun all on his own. He lit up, burned, consumed and reduced to ashes anyone who approached him.' Fernande was impoverished for most of her life, while her former lover amassed inordinate wealth. Olga and Dora both suffered mental-health problems. Marie- Therese and Picasso's second wife, Jacqueline Roque, both committed suicide. Yet three women, all of whom were intimately involved with the artist during the 1950s, survived the experience of flying close to the sun that was Picasso. While filming Modern Masters, I met them all: Francoise Gilot, Genevieve Laporte and Sylvette David. In different ways, their memories illuminate Picasso, both as a man and as an artist. By the early 1950s, Picasso's life was disintegrating. For part of each year he was based in the southern French town of Vallauris, where he had been making innovative ceramics at the Madoura pottery since 1947. But he was no longer considered to be in the vanguard of modern art, and the market for his work had become sluggish. The response to an exhibition of almost 150 ceramics in Paris in 1948, for instance, had been indifferent ('They expect to be shocked and terrorised,' Picasso said. 'If the monster only smiles, then they're disappointed'). Moreover, his relationship with Gilot, who had given him two children, was collapsing. In part, this was thanks to Picasso's affair with Genevieve Laporte, a pretty poet whom he had met as a schoolgirl in Paris soon after the liberation. In September 1953 Gilot took the children, bought a one-way train ticket to Paris, and walked out on Picasso - a display of independence that distressed his male ego. That winter he made a series of drawings, which the French Surrealist writer Michel Leiris described as 'the pictorial journal of a detestable season in hell'. The following spring, searching for a new lease of life, Picasso began a series of about 40 paintings, drawings and sculptures inspired (unusually for him, since he ordinarily worked from memory) by a real-life model called Sylvette David. Picasso had spotted Sylvette, a gorgeous 19- year-old who wore her hair in a dishevelled blond ponytail, in Vallauris, where she was living with her English boyfriend, Toby Jellinek, a sculptor and furniture designer. Sylvette never became Picasso's mistress, and their friendship faded in the summer of 1954. By the end of the year, Jacqueline Roque, a 27-year-old divorcee who had worked in the Madoura pottery's saleroom, had replaced Gilot. Picasso married Jacqueline in 1961, seven months short of his 80th birthday. Today Gilot, 88, lives in an apartment in Manhattan decorated with many of her own colourful canvases, as well as a painting by Georges Braque, with whom Picasso pioneered Cubism. When we meet, her wide face looks melancholic. Her lips often droop at either end, creating the impression of an inverted smile. I am reminded of the curse that Picasso laid on her when she broke the news that she was leaving him, as recorded in Life with Picasso, her vivid memoirs that chronicled many intimate details about the artist . 'Even if you think people like you, it will only be a kind of curiosity they will have about a person whose life has touched mine so intimately,' Picasso told her. 'For you, reality is finished... you're headed straight for the desert.' The artist was outraged when Life with Picasso was published in 1964 because it presented him at times as childish, egotistical and a misogynist (at one point Gilot suggests that he had 'a kind of Bluebeard complex that made him want to cut off the heads of all the women he had collected in his little private museum'). He tried unsuccessfully to prevent the publication of the book in France. The stress exacerbated his stomach ulcers, and in 1965 he travelled to Paris to undergo an operation that left him unable to paint for 18 months. Picasso later avenged himself on Gilot by banishing their children, Claude and Paloma, from his sight. Gilot first visited Picasso's studios at 7 rue des Grands-Augustins on the Left Bank of Paris shortly after they had met in a restaurant in May 1943, during the German occupation. On the floor, next to Picasso's celebrated sculpture The Man with the Sheep, stood a still life of oranges, painted by Matisse in Morocco in 1912. 'Picasso's secretary, Sabartes, was there,' Gilot tells me. 'As we were going up the stairs, I gasped and said, "Oh, what a fantastic Matisse." And Sabartes said, "No. Here there is only Picasso."' Picasso greatly admired Matisse's luminous Basket of Oranges, which he had acquired from a dealer in exchange for one of his own early paintings in 1942. But Sabartes was alerting Gilot that, as she put it in her memoirs, the studio was 'the temple of a kind of Picasso religion'. After the Second World War, Picasso resumed his tense friendship with Matisse. In February 1946 Picasso took Gilot to meet the French artist, who by this time was a semi-invalid (he had almost died from complications following an operation for duodenal cancer in 1941). But despite being increasingly bedridden, Matisse was still able to paint and create colourful paper cutouts. 'When we arrived, Picasso introduced me to Matisse, and Matisse answered right away that he would be pleased to make my portrait,' Gilot recalls. 'That shocked Picasso, because Picasso had not made any portrait of me as yet. And Matisse added, "Yes, I would make her skin a pale blue, and her reddish hair would have to be green." That was amusing: they liked to provoke each other a little bit. It was a competition as well as a friendship.' The meeting stimulated Picasso to use a palette of greens and cool blues to make The Woman-Flower, his quintessential portrait of Gilot, later that year. Does Gilot feel haunted by Picasso's ghost? 'Absolutely not,' she says immediately, her eyes suddenly combative. 'Otherwise I would have stayed where I was. I didn't stay because I had a right to have my own experiences. You can't live somebody else's life.' Gilot was in her early thirties when she left Picasso. 'Later, I married Jonas Salk, who discovered the polio vaccine,' she says, before attacking her next three words with hissing staccato: 'And so what?' A pause. 'It proves I was up to it. You know, I'm not tame. I had always liked my freedom, and I kept my freedom. That's very important. Otherwise what do you become - the caretaker of a museum?' In her memoirs, Gilot denies that she left Picasso because she no longer wanted to live with a 'historical monument', as had been reported in newspapers at the time. But perhaps that was the case after all. Picasso's mistress Genevieve Laporte, who was embroiled with the artist while he was still living with Gilot, paints a different picture. 'Picasso was just the contrary of what you read,' says Laporte, a former Resistance fighter who became a documentary filmmaker as well as a poet, and in 2005 auctioned off 20 sketches by Picasso that the artist had given to her. 'He was shy, full of tenderness, very delicate.' As we talk over lunch in Paris, Laporte, now in her eighties, shows me reproductions of naturalistic drawings that Picasso made of her, often sleeping and in the nude, in 1951. Seven of the drawings were used to illustrate Les Cavaliers d'ombre, a volume of her poems that appeared in June 1954. 'When he drew me,' she says, 'he would put on his glasses, and his look was that of a man in love - very soft, very tender. Then he changed completely. I was dressed, but I had the feeling that I was naked. He drew like a hurricane. Then, suddenly, it was over. He would take off his glasses, and timidly show me the drawing to find out what I thought. The hurricane was lost.' Laporte and Picasso began their affair in 1951, seven years after they had first met when, as a 17- year-old schoolgirl, she arrived at the rue des Grands-Augustins to interview the artist for her student newspaper in October 1944. During that initial meeting, Laporte infuriated Picasso by suggesting that young people did not understand his painting. 'He became absolutely mad,' she recalls. 'He got up and said, "Painting is not meant to be understood. My painting is not mathematics. Do you 'understand' the songs of birds? Do you 'understand' pommes de terre?"' When they became lovers, Picasso was 70. 'But his behaviour was very youthful,' Laporte tells me. 'We laughed a lot. He told me, "Everybody thinks that I am dramatic, but I want to laugh." He told me that his life with Gilot had become hell. He said to [his friend, the Surrealist poet] Paul Eluard, "She [Laporte] makes me laugh. She has saved my life."' She pauses. 'Maybe things would have fallen apart later, I don't know. But Picasso never painted a woman smiling, except me. His portraits of other women are often very hard. I think of his drawings of me as Picasso's tender period.' According to Laporte, their relationship ended soon after Gilot had left Picasso for good. Laporte, who was living in a farmhouse in Arbonne on the edge of the forest of Fontainebleau, less than an hour's drive from Paris, had not seen Picasso for several months (they had kept in touch 'merely' by exchanging letters). But one day she received a telegram from Picasso urgently summoning her to the rue des Grands-Augustins. 'We had lunch together, and then he said, "Now I can go with you to Fontainebleau,"' Laporte says. 'We left in my car, and he said, "You can't imagine how much I loved you." We spent the night together in a hotel in Barbizon. The next day, Picasso asked me to come with him to Vallauris. And I said an awful thing: "First, change your sheets." Gilot had only left the previous morning.' Laporte and Picasso did see each other again, but this encounter marked the end of their affair. The months that followed proved difficult for Picasso, who was unaccustomed to living alone. In December 1953 he painted a number of haunting paintings in blacks, whites and greys, including The Shadow, which is often seen as a meditation on loneliness and loss. Then, the following spring, he spotted the lusciously freckled face and slender young body of Sylvette David in Vallauris. 'It was a chance encounter,' recalls David, an ethereal, gentle woman who is an artist in her own right, more indebted to Marc Chagall than Picasso. Today she is called Lydia Corbett (she took a new Christian name when she was baptised, and goes by her married surname), and lives in rural Devon, which is where we meet. In the early 1950s she was fresh out of school, leading a carefree existence with a boyfriend, Toby Jellinek, and her English-born mother, a potter based in Vallauris. In April 1954 she was chatting to friends in a cafe when, on the other side of the wall, Picasso held up an Impressionistic drawing of her that he had done from memory. She had caught his eye. She subsequently visited his studio, and he asked her to model for him. 'He loved my ponytail and my long neck,' Corbett recalls with a dreamy giggle as she sifts through a battered leather trunk that she calls her 'memory suitcase' because it contains black-andwhite photographs of her younger self, as well as clippings about her and Picasso from newspapers and magazines such as Paris Match. 'For several months, I used to visit his studio once or twice a week, and each session would last two or three hours,' she says. 'There was always a mountain of blue Gitanes cigarette packets in the studio.' (One of the paintings, created on May 1 1954, will be included in Tate Liverpool's exhibition Picasso: Peace and Freedom, which opens on May 21.) She pauses. 'He must have been about 73 - my age now - but when he looked at me I felt his youth. I was very serious. I didn't dare open my mouth. So he tried to make me laugh. He showed me a little room with a bed and a window, and he jumped on the bed - he was very agile for a man in his seventies. I think he wanted me to jump with him, like little children do. But I wasn't going to do that. He understood that I didn't want to play games.' On another occasion, Picasso led Sylvette to a barn that housed his ancient Hispano-Suiza car. 'He invited me to sit with him on the big leather seat in the back and he told me lots of stories, about Spain, about his youth, about how he loved to write poetry, how he loved his animals - his monkey, goat and dogs. He talked about the circus [acrobats and harlequins had played a prominent role in Picasso's early paintings]. I think he was going back into his youth. If I had been different, maybe we would have fallen in love, but I had a boyfriend.' Picasso paid Jellinek to assist him in making folded-metal sculptures of Sylvette's head, one of which will be included in Picasso: The Mediterranean Years, a new exhibition opening at the Gagosian Gallery in London in June. 'Picasso asked if I would like to be paid for being a model,' Corbett says, 'but I was afraid that if he paid me he would make me pose in the nude. Older men can be really naughty and flirtatious, but Picasso wasn't at all - he was lovely. He was always like a father figure, really: sweet. He immortalised me. I'm like the Mona Lisa. At the time, I felt like I was dancing on clouds.' 'The whole episode came to an end in early June 1954,' says Elizabeth Cowling, professor of art history at the University of Edinburgh, who has written extensively on Picasso. 'It was a natural cycle. Picasso had worked intensively on this group of paintings and sculptures and drawings of Sylvette, and he'd come to the end of it.' Cowling believes that we should think differently about Picasso's women. 'I have no doubt that the women in Picasso's life were a very important inspiration for his work,' she says. 'But you could see it another way, and say instead that Picasso found the right woman to correspond with his aesthetic needs. He was driven by the imperative of his art. So to make everything turn around the women is to my mind a great mistake.' Picasso died at his villa near the village of Mougins in the hills above Cannes in April 1973. He left behind him a vast and varied body of work, consisting of more than 43,000 pieces - the largest recorded output of any artist ever. As the women I met attest, everything he made was relentlessly rooted in his own life. His nature encompassed everything - and so did his art. He presented humanity in all its rawness, and excluded nothing. There is no emotion or sensation, no matter how exalted or how depraved, that Picasso did not express visually in a brilliant and arresting new way. So who was the real Picasso? The unfaithful control freak who tormented Francoise Gilot? The tender, timid lover who seduced Genevieve Laporte? Or the playful, chain-smoking father- figure described by Sylvette David? The answer is that he was all of these and none of these. Picasso's identity was supremely complex. One minute, he could be charming as an angel; the next, he was diabolically foul. The unifying factor was his compulsion to make art. As he said: 'Painting makes me do what it wants.' 'Modern Masters' begins on BBC One next month 'He was like a father figure: sweet. He immortalised me. I'm like the Mona Lisa. At the time, I felt like I was dancing on clouds' 'I kept my freedom,' Gilot says. 'Otherwise, what do you become? The caretaker of a museum?' According to Francoise Gilot, Picasso was fond of saying, 'For me, there are only two kinds of women: goddesses and doormats' 'He showed me a little room with a bed and a window, and he jumped on the bed - he was very agile for a man in his seventies' Credit: Alastair Sooke IllustrationCaption: Above Gilot in 2003, in front of her own oil painting, Night Sky (1999). Right Genevieve Laporte in 1951, the year her affair with Picasso began; one of his sketches of her from that year; and with one of the works that she auctioned in 2005; PAUL COOPER/REX FEATURES. CORBIS. GETTY IMAGES. SIPA PRESS/REX FEATURES. Above The Woman-Flower (1946), Picasso's portrait of Gilot; ROBERT CAPA (c) 2001 BY CORNELL CAPA/MAGNUM PHOTOS. EDIMEDIA/CORBIS (c) SUCCESSION PICASSO/DACS, LONDON 2010; From left Sylvette David, Picasso's muse for several months in 1954, holding one of his sketches of her; David is now known as Lydia Corbett and living in Devon; Sylvette (1954), an oil of David that will be displayed as part of a show at Tate Liverpool next month; PHOTO (c) THE ALBERTINA, V IENNA. Title: Abstract

When Picasso came to play: Antony Penrose's mother was the surrealist photographer Lee Miller, his father Roland Penrose, a painter and the biographer of Pablo Picasso, who was a frequent visitor to the family's farm in East Sussex. In these extracts from his new children's book, illustrated with Miller's photographs and Picasso's paintings, Antony recalls his youthful encounters with the great artist
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEnd One time my dad visited Picasso by himself, and that's when something special happened. Picasso asked after me, and my dad explained that I was unhappy because I had been sent to a very strict school to make sure I passed my exams. Picasso thought this was a terrible idea! To cheer me up he sent me a little drawing. It showed a bull watching a dancer playing a flute, with a centaur listening. The drawing has cheered me up ever since.; PABLO PICASSO: LEE MILLER AS LARLSIENNE, 1937. GRASSHOPPER BULLS, 1950. SUCCESSION PICASSO/DACS, LONDON 2010. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Picasso was great fun to play with. His tweed jacket was nice and scratchy. He smelled good, too. He smelled of cologne and French tobacco. But eventually it was time for him to go home to France, where he had four children of his own. The oldest was a boy called Paulo. The next oldest was a girl called Maya. The next next oldest was a boy called Claude (he was the same age as me). The youngest was a little girl called Paloma. One day we all went to the south of France to visit Picasso. He kept a side-table piled high with masks and funny hats. We all had to choose a disguise and wear it for most of the day. Can you see me here? Even Mum used to dress up. She must have liked her new nose because she took this photo of herself in the mirror... One time my dad visited Picasso by himself, and that's when something special happened. Picasso asked after me, and my dad explained that I was unhappy because I had been sent to a very strict school to make sure I passed my exams. Picasso thought this was a terrible idea! To cheer me up he sent me a little drawing. It showed a bull watching a dancer playing a flute, with a centaur listening. The drawing has cheered me up ever since. Extract from 'The Boy Who Bit Picasso' by Antony Penrose (Thames & Hudson, Pounds 8.95), published on September 6. Title: Abstract

If you had $100m, which painting would you buy? ; Pablo Picasso's `Garcon a la Pipe' became the world's most expensive painting when it sold for $104m in New York. `The Independent' asked artists, critics and other leading figures from the art world to nominate the masterpiece they would buy if they had the money - and why?: [First Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEnd`The Baptism', Piero della Francesca, 1442 "I would probably choose Piero's Baptism from the National Gallery. I remember the first time I saw it when my father took me to the gallery when I was about six or seven and it made a big impression on me. The painting does have the most extraordinary relationship between time and light. I do believe that if you could live with this painting, you could probably live for longer. It's all about renewal and it's about the continuity of life in all its forms. There's also a sense that it's full of hope. If I bought the painting, I think I would probably hang it in the kitchen of my home and I'm sure it would make me live longer.""Sometimes, it's hard to understand why people pay so much money for such incredibly expensive works of art. But in the case of the [Pablo Picasso] painting, I can absolutely understand why. It reflects a moment in Picasso's career which is among the most tantalising. It's supremely beautiful and was painted when he reached the pinnacle of that particular style. There's no comparable painting. But I would personally choose [Raphael]'s Portrait of Bindo Altoviti. It's just the most astonishing and melting picture. The man in the painting has this long, blond hair and an incredibly sultry look. There's something very romantic about it: the ambiguity of his expression, the quality of the gaze, his blazing blue eyes. As in all the best portraits, he looks as though he's on the verge of starting a conversation. It's extraordinary because it's incredibly sultry but I don't find it at all sexy; in fact there's something quite chilling about it. Historically it's also very interesting as it's a portrait of a young man who went on to become a prominent Florentine banker. I saw it a month ago and I honestly think it's the most beautiful portrait in the world. I could look at it for ever."MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. But in the case of the Picasso painting, I can absolutely understand why. It reflects a moment in Picasso's career which is among the most tantalising. It's supremely beautiful and was painted when he reached the pinnacle of that particular style. There's no comparable painting. But I would personally choose Raphael's Portrait of Bindo Altoviti. It's just the most astonishing and melting picture. The man in the painting has this long, blond hair and an incredibly sultry look. There's something very romantic about it: the ambiguity of his expression, the quality of the gaze, his blazing blue eyes. As in all the best portraits, he looks as though he's on the verge of starting a conversation. It's extraordinary because it's incredibly sultry but I don't find it at all sexy; in fact there's something quite chilling about it. Historically it's also very interesting as it's a portrait of a young man who went on to become a prominent Florentine banker. I saw it a month ago and I honestly think it's the most beautiful portrait in the world. I could look at it for ever."Julian Opie, ArtistGiotto, La Cappella degli Scrovegni, 1303-05, Padua"Choosing a single work of art is a very tricky thing to do as I tend not to have favourites and what is meaningful changes as time goes on. But if I absolutely had to spend that amount of money on art, I think I would go for the Scrovegni Chapel that Giotto painted in Padua, Italy. I'd buy the whole thing. I'd also get a little house near by. The reason I would choose that is because it really is the most charming place. You are simply surrounded by his paintings wherever you are. It's quite a radical approach to looking at a church, you literally walk into the art. There's a whole story that's being told in the pictures in a very cartoon-like way. It's wonderful, I always try to visit when I'm at the Venice Biennale."Sandy Nairne, Director of the National Portrait Gallery`Equestrian Portrait of Charles I', Sir Anthony van Dyck, c1637"Acquiring the Van Dyck portrait is a fantasy of a very hypothetical kind as it is in fact sitting in the National Gallery. I suppose museum directors are often jealous of artwork in other people's galleries but this painting has become a favourite of mine. In very simple terms it is a five-star sitter by a five-star artist. It demonstrates a great combination of political power and individual personality entwined together on a very grand and overwhelming scale, which is why it is so extraordinary. This is a doomed king who could not expect to survive the difficulties and exigencies of his time. But here, we see him appearing extremely calming despite the obstacles he was facing. It conveys a brilliant sense of calmness."Sir Christopher Frayling, Chair of the Arts Council and Rector of Royal College of ArtOne of the original 1952 series of the `Screaming Popes', by Francis Bacon"I would spend the money on the artists of tomorrow rather than the artist of yesterday. Picasso was 24 when he painted this picture and the average age of my students at the Royal College is 26. I would set up a fund for grants for young artists to ensure they flourish. I would also create a new gallery complex that opened its doors widely and allowed everyone to enjoy the works of artists alive and dead. The third thing I would do is set up a scheme where I send artists into schools all over the country to inspire and excite young people towards visual arts. With any change I have left over, I would buy one of Francis Bacon's original Screaming Popes, the portraits of Pope Innocent X after Velazquez, and put it up in my office, because it occasionally embodies my state of mind."Richard Calvocoressi, Director of the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art`Self-Portrait with Lowered Head', Egon Schiele, 1912"It is just a small head of the artist looking very tense and drawn and brooding. The figure is very ... muted. It's a very powerful, intense, brooding, neurotic, introspective portrait. It has a death-like quality about it. The skin is ... almost diseased- looking. We borrowed it for an exhibition at the Tate Modern a few years ago. It's really quite small but it makes a big impact. I think it has a power disproportionate to its size. I chose the painting because Schiele is such an important artist for the 20th century for the development of portraiture, body art and performance art but he is completely unrepresented in Britain ... It made such a big impact on postwar art."Antony Gormley, Artist`The Baptism', Piero della Francesca, 1442 "I would probably choose Piero's Baptism from the National Gallery. I remember the first time I saw it when my father took me to the gallery when I was about six or seven and it made a big impression on me. The painting does have the most extraordinary relationship between time and light. I do believe that if you could live with this painting, you could probably live for longer. It's all about renewal and it's about the continuity of life in all its forms. There's also a sense that it's full of hope. If I bought the painting, I think I would probably hang it in the kitchen of my home and I'm sure it would make me live longer."Anna Somers Cocks, Editor of `The Art Newspaper'Francois Boucher's `Louise O'Murphy', 1751"I would like to put Boucher's Louise O'Murphy on my bedroom wall. The picture of a naked girl lying on her tummy with her bottom in the air is just so sensuous and funny at the same time. She has delicious pink skin and she is lying on luxurious sheets with a perfume burner in front of her. The work is a great study in sensuality. The girl in the painting has an air of real expectancy, as if she is expecting her lover any second to jump on top of her. I first saw the painting as a 17-year-old schoolgirl in Paris and I thought, even then as a naive and inexperienced girl, what a sexy picture it was. I have now come to regard it as sexier and sexier."Word count: 1094Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract

SEX, JUGS, POTS & BOWLS ART ART A hugely prolific painter, draughtsman, sculptor and ceramicist, Pablo Picasso is regarded as the supreme artist of the 20th century, and his private life continues to fascinate. But exactly why is he so widely accepted as a genius? Ahead of two major exhibitions in Scotland, Peter Ross asks the experts: [Final Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndIn order to try to answer the question of what makes [PABLO Picasso] great, I arrange to meet the curators of the Dean and National Museum shows, Patrick Elliott and Rose Watban, as well as Elizabeth Cowling, an expert based at Edinburgh University. All three speak with enthusiasm bordering on awe. Elliott and Cowling often use the present tense as if Picasso is still painting away on the Cte d'Azur, and Elliott in particular seems, at times, like a schoolboy with a crush "He's just so cool!" Cowling is the author of Picasso: Style And Meaning, regarded as one of the definitive books on the artist. She talks of Picasso as if she were Ahab and he were the whaleagreatmysterious beast to follow, glimpse but never quite capture. "I've spent such a long time working on him, " she says, "yet when I look at the catalogue raisonne of his work, I'm always dumbfounded and think, 'Oh my God! There's another lot that I've not understood or even thought about'. My book only goes up to 1940 because I knew it would take me another 15 years to finish the rest.Patrick Elliott shows me a pieces which exemplify Picasso's nervejangling approach. The first is a 1934 ink drawing called The Death Of Marat. Ostensibly a homage to Louis David's 1793 painting of the French revolutionary writer murdered in his bath, Picasso's drawing is thought to represent his first wife Olga Khokhlova, who wouldn't accept a divorce, stabbing his pregnant lover Marie-Therse Walter. "It's amazing, " says Elliott, "the way he can do that screaming head a sort of blob with little strokes for teeth which stands more than any realistic work for absolute anguish and horror and venom. You can't even see her body. It's just a raging mouth. That's what Picasso can do reduce a figure to a mouth." Elliott then turns to Weeping Woman I, an etching from 1937 based on drawings Picasso made in preparation for his iconic painting Guernica.Photograph Roger-Viollet/Rex Features Top: Minotauromachie (1935). Above: Earthenware vase, made by the Madoura Pottery in Vallauris in the south of France, adapted by Picasso.Right: With Portrait Of A Young Girl (1958), Picasso invented a new technique for making linocuts. Left: Bullfighting scene plate (1959).Previous page: Picasso in 1948, working on ceramics in Vallauris Left: Les Demoiselles d'[Avignon] (1907) is regarded as one of the most important paintings of the 20th century. Unlike the other works in this feature, it is not in either of the Edinburgh shows, but is included here as illustrative of Picasso's genius Below: The Death of Marat (1934) is thought to represent Picasso's first wife murdering his pregnant lover Right: Picasso photographed by Arnold Newman in 1956 at La Californie, his villa in Cannes Clockwise from above: Woman. Front and Profile (1926) was long thought to be a portrait of Picasso's lover Marie-Therse Walter, but it later turned out that it was made months before they met. There is a theory that Picasso was attracted to real-life women who resembled the women of his imagination; Nude (1910) is a typical example of Cubism, the revolutionary art movement which Picasso and [Georges Braque] developed; Weeping Woman I, an etching from 1937 based on drawings Picasso made for his iconic painting Guernica. The face is modelled on his then lover [Dora Maar] Left: The Frugal Meal (1904) is a print based on a painting of The Blue Period. Above: Head Of A Faun (1947), a plate made in Vallauris Photographs: Succession Picasso/ DACS 2007MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases.
