[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit PABLO Picasso was born in Spain in the last years of the 19th century, the age of industry, and died in France towards the end of the 20th, the age of extremes. He was a man of his era extremely industrious and industriously extreme and like all people who live for a long time, he encountered unexpected turbulence. In his lifetime were two world wars, the Spanish Civil War, Guernica, Korea and Hiroshima. His 91 years also encompassed the death of Queen Victoria, the liberation of Auschwitz and the release of Dark Side Of The Moon, and he made art which was as fractured, frightening, chaotic, kinetic and oddly beautiful as the times.Picasso was not always as adored as he is now. There were periods during his life when he was regarded as a failure. People said Guernica was the last thing he painted which was worth looking at, and in his dotage he was considered by some to have become a sort of King Leer, driven mad by age and sex. Yet, in the 21st century, he is almost beyond criticism. Along with Van Gogh, Monet and Warhol he is an icon whose art attracts crowds to blockbuster shows around the world, who sells for meaninglessly large sums and who, perhaps even more than those other artists, enthralls with his life story just as much as his life's work.He has become a brand: Esso, Tesco, Picasso. His name sells cars and perfume and, along with Shakespeare, Einstein and Mozart, is shorthand for genius. Everyone agrees Picasso was a great artist. To say otherwise is a sort of flat-earth heresy. But no one ever really asks why. What makes him great? What is it he did that deserves a century of acclaim?We will have the chance to judge for ourselves this month when two Picasso exhibitions open in Edinburgh. Picasso On Paper, at the Dean Gallery from July 14, encompasses drawings, pastels and prints made between 1899 when Picasso was 18 and 1971 when he was 90. Picasso: Fired With Passion, at the National Museum of Scotland from Friday, draws on work created from 1947 to 1961 in an attempt to reveal connections between his private life and artistic career. The show will include ceramics, metalwork, painting and lithography, as well as photographs of Picasso by his friend Lee Miller.In order to try to answer the question of what makes Picasso great, I arrange to meet the curators of the Dean and National Museum shows, Patrick Elliott and Rose Watban, as well as Elizabeth Cowling, an expert based at Edinburgh University. All three speak with enthusiasm bordering on awe. Elliott and Cowling often use the present tense as if Picasso is still painting away on the Cte d'Azur, and Elliott in particular seems, at times, like a schoolboy with a crush "He's just so cool!" Cowling is the author of Picasso: Style And Meaning, regarded as one of the definitive books on the artist. She talks of Picasso as if she were Ahab and he were the whaleagreatmysterious beast to follow, glimpse but never quite capture. "I've spent such a long time working on him, " she says, "yet when I look at the catalogue raisonne of his work, I'm always dumbfounded and think, 'Oh my God! There's another lot that I've not understood or even thought about'. My book only goes up to 1940 because I knew it would take me another 15 years to finish the rest.I used to long for him to have died earlier. It shocks fellow Picasso scholars when I say, 'Oh, but don't you sometimes wish he had fallen out of an aeroplane when he was 60?'." Although it frustrates her, Cowling believes one of the things that makes Picasso great is his extraordinary prolificacy. "The volume of his work is huge. I don't know how many tens of thousands of works he produced. Quality control is not always maintained. There's a lot of second-rate, third-rate stuff. That said, if you were to count up the major works he produced, it still runs into hundreds or thousands."And it's not just in one medium. As well as painting, he's a key figure in the history of 20th-century sculpture and printmaking. He's a great draughtsman. Even people who hate his work agree on that. He was a key figure in early 20th-century stage design. Some people would argue, based on the surrealist texts and plays, that he's actually a major writer. Also, he reinvents ceramics. So you've got this vast quantity of work in different media, and those media have been revolutionised by what he's done. You never come to the end of his work. You can always find something else." For Elliott, Picasso's genius is even more straightforward. "He was the greatest artist of the 20th century, or for me the greatest artist full stop. He just couldn't stop being inventive and imaginative.The most imaginative artist of all time."Toprove his point, he shows me Minotauromachie, an etching from 1935 which is one of the key works in the Dean show. "This is probably the greatest print of the 20th century, " he says, shaking his head."Picasso made it in less than a day." Pablo Picasso was born in Malaga on October 25, 1881. His father, Jose Ruiz Blasco, was a painter with a penchant for pigeons who realised early on that his son was extremely talented. Picasso received his first formal art lessons when he was 10 and before his teens was producing impressive drawings based on antique sculpture. In 1895, he enrolled at art school in Barcelona."As a teenage boy, poor little lad, he was propelled into painting really big canvases which won local prizes, " says Cowling. "His first exhibition in Paris in 1901, when he was completely unknown in France, was extremely hyped. When he was only 20, people started calling him Le Petit Goya the little Goya. So that was the aura around him and he clearly did fascinate people. Not only women, but a lot of his peers.People say that when he was a student alongside them, and usually quite a few years younger than they were, he was more advanced in every way.They knew he was the coming man." Picasso's early paintings were realistic works, not the sort of thing we now visualise when his name is mentioned. In 1900, he visited Paris for the first time, painting the gloom and glitter of the demi-monde.The following year, he entered what has come to be known as his Blue Period. One of the major paintings to come out of this phase was The Frugal Meal which, in 1904, he made into an etching. "That's only the second print he ever made, " says Patrick Elliott, pointing to a reproduction in the catalogue for Picasso On Paper. "He was 22 and had never studied how to make a print, but a friend gave him an old metal plate to use, and he was immediately good and instinctive. The Frugal Meal is typical of this period when he was obsessed with poverty, prostitution and blindness. He was fond of brothels at the time and very poor. He was literally burning drawings at night to stay warm." Picasso rented a studio in the Bateau-Lavoir, a run- down building in Montmartre, and began work on the Hen Broon harlequins and similarly lanky acrobats of his Rose Period. In 1907 influenced by antique sculpture he saw in the Louvre and African and Oceanic art he saw in the Musee d'Ethnographie du Trocadero he began work on the painting that marks the point when people stopped thinking of him as a young man of great promise and began to regard him as an unassailable genius. Les Demoiselles d'Avignon bears roughly the same relation to the development of painting as splitting the atom does to physics it changed things and opened up a world of possibilities.With its range of contrasting styles, the painting is emblematic of all Picasso's work, and its jagged geometry can be regarded as pointing towards Cubism, the fractured, semi-abstract style that Picasso together with his friend Georges Braque would invent and develop."Cubism is a completely different way of viewing the world, " says Elliott. "It comes about partly because a photograph can look more like a human than Picasso can ever paint, and everyone by 1910 has got a box Brownie, so trying to make things look real is no longer the artist's main preoccupation. Also, the world's changing at an amazing rate you've got the telephone coming in, radio, cars, trains and art's got to change too. So Picasso began painting things from different angles all at once.It's as if you're rotating around the figure and everything's speeded up."He started using collage, too. Again, a completely new way of looking at the world. Instead of painting something trying to copy it with a pencil or a brush why not just take the thing and stick it on the canvas?This is a complete revelation, a new relationship between reality and representation. Cubism and collage are the biggest moves in art since the invention of perspective around 1500." Another important aspect of Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, a quality it shares with much of Picasso's output, is that it provokes sensations in anyone who sees it. It is thought to be set in a brothel, and a man moving his eyes from left to right across its eight-foot square surface may well feel a degree of sexual arousal followed by detumescent horror; that crouching figure on the bottom on right, all angry snout and hunkers, is like something from The Exorcist her head appears to be slowly spinning round. Emmanuelle it isn't."It's very important that his work is not just a stylistic game, it's intensely emotional, " says Elizabeth Cowling. "You may not like what you see, but he stirs you up. He does engage with human feelings. And they are quite violent, these pictures. They are very often extremely ugly.They are often outrageous and shocking, and actually that's important."As Picasso himself said, art is not just for decoration of apartments. It should keep you alert and make you think. He can be very tragic as an artist, but also extremely funny. He's very good at storytelling and there's a lot of drama and interaction in his work. This is why he didn't like completely abstract art. The removal of human emotion, which happened in a lot of abstract art, didn't happen in his work." This emotionalism, and the related fact so much of his work had people in it, is probably one of the reasons Picasso has remained so popular. It's art to make the heart beat harder. You can't really say that about true abstract artists like Mondrian or Jackson Pollock. Galleries ought to dish out defibrillators at shows of their paintings.Patrick Elliott shows me a pieces which exemplify Picasso's nervejangling approach. The first is a 1934 ink drawing called The Death Of Marat. Ostensibly a homage to Louis David's 1793 painting of the French revolutionary writer murdered in his bath, Picasso's drawing is thought to represent his first wife Olga Khokhlova, who wouldn't accept a divorce, stabbing his pregnant lover Marie-Therse Walter. "It's amazing, " says Elliott, "the way he can do that screaming head a sort of blob with little strokes for teeth which stands more than any realistic work for absolute anguish and horror and venom. You can't even see her body. It's just a raging mouth. That's what Picasso can do reduce a figure to a mouth." Elliott then turns to Weeping Woman I, an etching from 1937 based on drawings Picasso made in preparation for his iconic painting Guernica."This is one of the great prints of the 20th century, " he says. "Both eyes are on the same side of the head, the nose is some kind of bulbous banana, but emotionally it works, with these knitting needle things stabbing in, and the handkerchief repitched as a sort of shard of glass. It's one of the great images of pain and passion in art. Fantastic thing. I think that's something anyone can love." The face of the Weeping Woman is based on Dora Maar.The French woman was a lover of Picasso and documented his painting of Guernica. "All his work has an autobiographical edge, " says Elliott, "and if you can pin events in someone's life on to the work, or read it through the human personality, it becomes more digestible. For example, he had seven or eight mistresses in his life, and you can structure his entire oeuvre according to different mistresses." Elliott points to a 1926 drawing of a woman with bobbed hair and says something remarkable. "This was always taken to be a picture of MarieTherse, his girlfriend. It looks just like her. But in fact there is proof that it was made six months before he met her. So he was making these pictures of this invented woman and then in 1927 sees, outside Paris's equivalent of Jenners, someone who looks just like them. So he goes up to Marie-Therse and asks her out. She was 17. He seemed to be attracted to women who resembled those he had imagined and painted.The same thing happened with Francoise Gilot and Jacqueline Roque." Picasso married twice and had four children by three different women.Marie-Therse Walter bore him a daughter, Maya, though they never married. She hung herself four years after his death. "He's had a bad press from feminists for racing through all these girlfriends, " says Elliott."It was just like styles. He'd go through styles, go through men and women, wring them out emotionally, absorb it and leave them dry. Many people just couldn't recover from it. Amazing to know him but, once he'd sucked you dry and spat you out and moved on to the next style or woman or printer or friend, you were in a pretty parlous state." He seems to have been an unstoppable force of nature, a kind of comet using whoever came into his orbit as fuel and then leaving them burned out in his wake. "Even in photographs of Picasso in his shorts and slippers, he has this energy that I think almost comes out of the picture at you, " says Rose Watban of the National Museum of Scotland."So meeting him must have been unbelievable."Watban's show Picasso: Fired With Passion concentrates on a relatively domesticated period of his life. In 1944, he had begun seeing a young art student, Francoise Gilot, and they had two children together, Claude and Paloma. Following the war, which he had spent in Nazi-occupied Paris, Picasso began holidaying in the south of France, where the culture and climate reminded him of his native Catalonia.In 1946, he visited Vallauris, a town famous for its pottery since the Roman era. Picasso was attracted to the ceramics being made by the Madoura Pottery and in 1947 began to work there, at first simply painting on to existing plates and vases, then later adapting unfired pieces, transforming a jug into a female form, a bottle into an insect and so on. Just as he had done with printmaking, Picasso quickly introduced technical innovations that astounded people who had spent their lives working with ceramics. He produced more than 2000 pieces in the first year. Apparently, Madoura could hardly keep up with him."Until after Picasso was dead, in a lot of quarters his ceramics were regarded as a bit of a joke, " says Watban. "The paintings of the period are looked upon as very interesting and great work. In Vallauris, he painted Massacre In Korea. He also painted War And Peace. So there were these political things coming out and at the same time he was painting these funny wee faces on to ceramics. But what Picasso did was lift ceramics up from an artisanal craft into something that could be looked at as art." It would be foolish to sneer at Picasso's ceramics. If they are the product of personal happiness and encapsulate his joie de vivre then, surely, they are as significant in their own way as the major paintings?Picasso painted Guernica because he hated death, and the reason he hated death is because he loved life. The joy of the ceramics comes, ultimately, from the same place as the horror of the paintings the mind and soul of an artist in love with creation.So what, then, is so great about Pablo Picasso? Perhaps one reason that question is so rarely asked is that it is so difficult to answer.Certainly, he was hugely influential and prolific, a virtuoso able to leap between media and styles as easily as one of his acrobats. We must also acknowledge the sheer force of his personality has kept him high in our estimation and made him the ideal artist for our celebrity age.Ultimately, though, Picasso's greatness is mysterious; we sense it but cannot explain it simply by deconstructing the elements of his work, just as transcribing the score of Don Giovanni will not explain the power of its overture. Picasso himself was always loath to analyse his painting, which some regard as a cunning tactic to keep the public interested.Perhaps the reason was deeper and simpler than that he couldn't."What's interesting to me about his work is that I can't explain it, " says Patrick Elliott. "It's difficult to put your finger on why it's so good. I remember going to a lecture by John Golding, a world expert on Picasso, who said the more he studied his work, the less he understood it. He also said he felt Picasso didn't really know what he was doing."I think it's totally true that he just got on with things without thinking too much about them. If you read some of the books on him, all the meaning they invest in his work and the rhetoric that goes along with that is just a load of crap. Picasso was simply a magical visual artist with an amazing ability to invent." Picasso: Fired With Passion is at the National Museum of Scotland, Chambers Street, Edinburgh, July 6-October 28. Picasso On Paper is at the Dean Gallery, Belford Road, Edinburgh, July 14-September 7. Elizabeth Cowling's book Picasso: Style And Meaning is published by PhaidonIllustrationCaption: Photograph Roger-Viollet/Rex Features Top: Minotauromachie (1935). Above: Earthenware vase, made by the Madoura Pottery in Vallauris in the south of France, adapted by Picasso.Right: With Portrait Of A Young Girl (1958), Picasso invented a new technique for making linocuts. Left: Bullfighting scene plate (1959).Previous page: Picasso in 1948, working on ceramics in Vallauris Left: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon (1907) is regarded as one of the most important paintings of the 20th century. Unlike the other works in this feature, it is not in either of the Edinburgh shows, but is included here as illustrative of Picasso's genius Below: The Death of Marat (1934) is thought to represent Picasso's first wife murdering his pregnant lover Right: Picasso photographed by Arnold Newman in 1956 at La Californie, his villa in Cannes Clockwise from above: Woman. Front and Profile (1926) was long thought to be a portrait of Picasso's lover Marie-Therse Walter, but it later turned out that it was made months before they met. There is a theory that Picasso was attracted to real-life women who resembled the women of his imagination; Nude (1910) is a typical example of Cubism, the revolutionary art movement which Picasso and Georges Braque developed; Weeping Woman I, an etching from 1937 based on drawings Picasso made for his iconic painting Guernica. The face is modelled on his then lover Dora Maar Left: The Frugal Meal (1904) is a print based on a painting of The Blue Period. Title: Abstract

Today is Tuesday, April 8, the 98th day of 2003. There are 267 days left in the year.: Thirty years ago, on April 8, 1973, artist Pablo Picasso died at his home near Mougins, France, at age 91. In 1513, explorer Juan Ponce de Leon claimed Florida for Spain. In 1935, the Works Progress Administration was approved by Congress.

General Assembly admitted the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia as its 181st member. Singer Marian Anderson died in Portland, Ore., at age 96. Title: Victims of 'the Picasso virus': Pablo was an incredible artist -- and incredibly cruel to his loved ones, Stuart Wavell discovers.: [Final Edition]

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Pablo Picasso was a monster who needed to be appeased with human sacrifices like an Aztec god, says his granddaughter, Marina Picasso. The chosen victims were his loved ones. "No one in my family managed to escape his stranglehold. He needed blood to sign each of his paintings."It sounds like hyperbole but the death toll suggests a terrible family malediction. Marina's brother Pablito committed suicide by drinking bleach. Her grandmother, the once beautiful Olga, died paralysed. Her father Paolo expired as a broken reed. Jacqueline, Picasso's last wife, shot herself. Marie-Therese Walter, the artist's muse, hanged herself.Marina has no doubt that she, too, was an intended victim. "In order to create, he had to destroy everything that got in the way of his creation. However, like him, I have enormous energy and a strong character, otherwise I would be dead, too."She did not escape unscathed, however, spending 14 years in psychoanalysis, marked by uncontrollable tears, fainting fits and screams. "I have been trying all my life to escape the misery created by Picasso," she declares.She has also fallen out with the artist's other heirs, accusing them of greed and "bad taste" in selling the family name to Citroen for its people carrier. They look askance at her for adopting three Vietnamese children and diluting the legacy of her two children, products of a failed relationship.Now an elegant, composed and incalculably rich woman of 50, she divides her time between Geneva and Picasso's huge white house in Cannes, which she once associated with unhappy memories. She also runs a foundation for orphaned children in Vietnam and lends her grandfather's pictures to galleries around the world.She was 22 years old when Picasso died in 1973. Believing that all the family's misfortunes flowed from art, she announced she did not want to inherit anything. Persuaded by French lawyers this was impossible, she accepted a quarter of the inheritance, but stacked the paintings against walls so she could not see them.Her grandfather had reached beyond the grave to cause her brother's death, she believed. Six days after Picasso died, Pablito drank a bottle of bleach."We both loved my grandfather, although it was never reciprocated. When he died my brother and I wanted to see him one last time, but Jacqueline didn't want to receive us. Pablito went to the house alone and they set the dogs on him. He came home and committed suicide."She found him lying on a sofa, blood bubbling from his mouth, and spent the next three months by his side in hospital until he died. She did not have enough money to pay for his coffin because she and her brother were kept in dependent penury. Pablito had told her it was his attempt to escape; few others had succeeded.In a remarkable new book, Picasso, My Grandfather, to be published Nov. 8 by Chatto & Windus, Marina describes how each member of the family became dependent on and cravenly submissive to Picasso's towering ego."The Picasso virus to which we fell victim was subtle and undetectable," she says. "It was a combination of promises not kept, abuse of power, mortification, contempt and, above all, incommunicability."But, it is pointed out to her, many families have a monster and relatives learn to keep their distance. "No one dared to," she replies. Besides, they were connected by a financial blood-drip that kept them in poverty.Every Thursday was "allowance day." Marina and Pablito would be led by their father to the big white house to collect their weekly pittance. More often than not, an elderly Italian retainer would inform them: "The maitre can't see you today. Madame Jacqueline has asked me to tell you that he's working." The dismissals varied: "The maitre is sleeping," "the maitre is not here." Jacqueline's phrase was memorable: "The sun does not want to be disturbed."Once admitted, the supplicants were tortured by the spectacle of a pet goat, leaving its droppings amid canvases piled willy-nilly amid a jumble of priceless sculptures and bric-a-brac. The great man was wont to receive them at his studio in his underpants -- "his overflowing attributes visible" -- in an uncaring display of his omnipotence that he continued until the end of his life."The only mark of love I can remember ever receiving from him was a stuffed fig and date," Marina confesses. Later she learned that such sweetmeats were called "mendiants" -- beggars. Like everyone else, she loved him or, more correctly, she was in awe of the myth he spun around himself.On a good day, her father's subservience would be rewarded with a wad of notes and Picasso's cutting observation that his only son was second rate and a waste of his time. Humiliatingly, her father Paolo's job was as Pablo's chauffeur and labourer. Once he had dreamt of freeing himself by becoming a professional motorbike racer, which Picasso promptly ruled to be too dangerous."After that, he didn't attempt to have any financial independence. Even when my grandmother Olga died, he didn't accept the Picasso works she left him because he wanted to do nothing to upset his father."As a boy, Paolo's features had been immortalized in Picasso's works. But one day the pampering ceased, paralysing the young man's will. "He also painted Olga in their first years together. But when he had used up someone, he went on to another subject."Marina's mother Emilienne was more in love with the Picasso name than Paolo and the couple separated when Marina was six months old. Too grand to work, Emilienne was reliant on her share of the allowance; a source of loud reproach that distressed the children. Sharing her husband's predilection for drink, she also took to picking up boys on the beach and bringing them home."I can still remember how humiliated I was as a young teenager when she would walk into a meeting of students and parents dressed in a miniskirt, with a young man barely older than I was."At 14 years old, Marina put her foot down. Resentful of the way they were being manipulated as pawns in a weekly financial transaction, she and Pablito tried to establish a more personal relationship with their grandfather. "We wanted to have our own identity but it was badly received. We were beaten. I don't think my grandfather was really interested," she says. Title: Abstract

A WRITER AT LARGE: Lunch with Pablo, dinner with Henri ; In 1946 RAYMOND MASON, a young English sculptor, packed his bags and moved to Paris, then the undisputed artistic capital of the world. In this extract from his memoir of half a century as part of the city's competitive cameraderie, he recalls his friendships with two of the 20th century's greatest artists, Pablo Picasso and Henri Cartier-Bresson: [FOREIGN Edition]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndOur conversation continued gaily, then in came some Spanish dancers touring the coast, friends, of course, of [Pablo Picasso]. Before long, the woman in the company, a beauty, had climbed on to the table and broken into a wild dance. The noise was deafening, and I was just saying to myself how marvellous it was to have lunched with Picasso and too bad about the photos, when all of a sudden he clapped his hands and called for silence, saying: "Yes, but that's not all. We have here a young artist who has come to show us his work." It was a little glimpse of Picasso's cruel side. All my fellow artists' eyes were now focused unkindly on me, as I laid out the few works I had accomplished to date. There were busts of children, done to make money, that Picasso passed over in silence, a few reliefs and, finally, Barcelona Tram, my first, recently completed high relief. It is one of my good works, one on which I can be judged, and Picasso's enthusiasm was immediate. (It's only lately that I have understood Picasso's emotional fixation on that city. Moreover, the scene depicted in my relief was the facade of the Estacin di Francia, the station from which Picasso had set out more than once for Paris.)Picasso continued to sing my praises, before adding: "You're an English artist." I deflated at once, but Picasso, seeing my disappointment, hastened to reassure me that he was very fond of English art, and without a moment's hesitation or a single omission rattled off in chronological order all the important English artists from Hogarth down to the turn of the 20th century. "But nowadays there's no English art any more. It's become cosmopolitan" - a word he was fond of - "like that sculptor, what's his name? You know the one." I didn't dare breathe. "M-M-Moo-Moo," he went on, tapping me on the chest. "Moore," I timidly suggested. "That's it, Moore. He's the same thing." I could hardly believe it. Moore, who had had the honour of seeing Picasso painting Guernica, being talked about in this way. I should add that in 1954 there was little chance of Picasso knowing much, or even anything at all, about Francis Bacon. By way of conclusion, Picasso told me to go and see Kahnweiler in Paris and to tell him he had sent me, a spectacular recommendation. Only on the road back, still glowing with pleasure from my afternoon with Picasso, did I remember that I hadn't asked him a thing about the potters in Vallauris![Henri Cartier-Bresson] is essentially an artist. He has lived all his life in Paris, a city of art and artists. The Louvre is right outside his door, and you can still see him there today, sitting on his shooting stick drawing the Old Masters. It is his eye, perfectly formed by study of the masterpieces of painting, which enables him to confront the tumultuous disorder of the outside world and place it instantaneously in a formal order of beauty. The poet Yves Bonnefoy has told me that when he was Henri's neighbour in the Alps of Haute Provence, he had to meet him at the coach stop at Simiane one day. They were crossing the sunlit and rather sleepy village square together when Yves saw Henri make a movement with his hand while talking. We later saw what he had captured by firing from the hip like the hero in a Western: an arcaded vantage-point with some young people and a few animals, all distributed in significant poses, and, above all, with all the pillars of the building perfectly vertical despite the offhand manner in which he had taken the photo. There's no doubt about it, Henri shoots faster than Lucky Luke - with this notable difference, that a single shot from the latter left people dead whereas Henri makes them live for ever. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitI met Pablo Picasso for the first time in the summer of 1952. When Mimi, my girlfriend, and I went to visit him in Vallauris with his nephew, the delightful Xavier Vilato, he was working on ceramics in the studio of the potter Ramie. There were seven or eight of us in all, and Picasso had decided to show us his studios on the hills overlooking Vallauris. They were giant barns, and when Picasso made to open the largest of the doors I realised for the first time just how small he was, for the key, attached to a chain on his belt, only just reached the key-hole.What he particularly wanted to show us were the huge surfaces waiting on the walls for the moment he would paint the compositions of War and Peace, destined for the disused chapel of Vallauris. "It's big, isn't it?" he kept asking all round. "Oh yes, maitre," everyone chorused back, this being the required response at all times. "It's as big as the Sistine Chapel," he added. In Paris, to make a bit of money, I had just finished translating a book on the Sistine Chapel into English. I knew perfectly well, therefore, what its dimensions were, and without even thinking about it, a "No" slipped out of my mouth. It was indeed as though Picasso had never heard the word before, since he asked all round, disbelieving: "What did he say?"I repeated what I had said, explaining why, but he interrupted me to declare in a loud voice: "Well, almost," glaring at me with his dark eyes. "And that's not all," he went on. "I now have to paint them. Matisse, of course, would just lay on a few flowing lines and it would be done. But I, Picasso, will have to work much harder. It's dreadful!" My English sense of humour led me to open my mouth for a second unfortunate time. "Yes; but console yourself, maitre. Once it's finished, it will be even more dreadful." I intended this as a compliment to the terribilita of Picasso; instead, everyone present gave a cry of horror, and Vilato was so alarmed that he dragged me out of the studio, and I didn't even get to hear Picasso's reaction.Just the same, I caught up again with the procession when it was looking at the ceramics workshop, crammed with daring inventions. (It had all begun with Joan Mir making a few ceramics with his friend, the great Catalan potter Artigas. When Picasso saw them, he decided to try his hand, and in a year had turned out 1,760 works!) We finally came to the studio reserved for works in progress. The room was long and narrow, and while Picasso held forth with the women at one end, I wandered around with Xavier examining things at the other. A matador's sword was hanging on the wall, and taking it to be a collector's item I mumbled to Xavier that it was almost certainly not sharp. In a bound Picasso was at our side, grabbed the sword from the wall and placed its tip against my throat: "Not sharp, hey? Shall I press down then?" With a roll of the eyes, I didn't utter a word, begged for mercy and the master returned, triumphant, to the women. Xavier separated me once and for all from the assembled company, saying gloomily: "It's just too bad. He doesn't like you."Two years later, recovering from an operation for peritonitis, I was convalescing at Mimi's father's home behind Grasse. I felt very weak. My survival had been a miracle of friendship. I had been rushed into the hospital at Sevres, where my friend Charles Odic, the mayor of the town, was also head doctor. On the evening of the operation, Odic was dining in Paris, but in the middle of the meal had stood up to drive out to the hospital and see how the operation was getting on. He found the surgeon sewing me back up, saying there was nothing to be done with such a bouillabaisse. Odic begged him to reconsider the case of his young friend...I felt just strong enough to do, say, a few small reliefs in terracotta, and bizarrely I thought of Picasso at Vallauris, who could open the doors of any pottery studio to me. Mimi was in Spain, and I had taken the big, light-blue Dodge to drive to Golfe Juan. On my way down from Vallauris to the coast, I saw a mother and child waiting at the bus stop with their bathing things under their arms. I offered to take them to the beach, and they got in, delighted. A few moments later, I was overtaken by a Vespa. Recognising the driver, I muttered under my breath: "It's that cretin Pignon." Needless to say, the woman sitting next to me was Madame Edouard Pignon, the writer Helene Parmelin in other words, and hardly had we arrived at the beach than I saw her explaining to her second-rate painter husband what a pig I was.IT WAS A BEACH TYPICAL of the Cote d'Azur, with a hundred or so people tanning themselves under a beautiful sun and thinking of nothing. In reality, of course, everyone was thinking of only one thing. They all knew that on the dot of noon Picasso would arrive at the beach and sink his parasol in the sand like an emperor's standard. The waiter at the restaurant nearby said that Picasso was so punctual that he could set his watch by his arrival each day. And here he was, with most of the bathers already on their feet, walking towards him. Having only just arrived, I found myself standing next to him and, since I was among the first, was able to ask him if, later on, he would care to look at a few photos of my work. "There's nothing I enjoy more than looking at photos. See you later," and he ran down to the water for a dip.Pleased with the way things were turning out, I went for a swim, then sat down on my towel to take a look at this unusual beach. All of a sudden, Francoise Gilot arrived. The previous year, she had walked out of Picasso's life, declaring with great style that she didn't want to live with a national monument any more. Now she had brought her two children to see their father during the holidays. I knew her well. Before meeting Picasso, she had had a boyfriend, Luc Simon, a young painter the same age as me, and since the break-up had gone back to live with him. Being figurative artists the pair of us, a certain camaraderie had grown up between Luc and myself, and just recently he had settled down with Francoise in the rue du Val de Grace, not far from my studio in the Latin Quarter. I had been there for dinner several times, to talk about art late into the night, with the children Claude and Paloma tucked up in their cots in a corner.This explains why Francoise made straight for me that morning on the beach to bid me a friendly "Bonjour". At that precise moment, I noticed Picasso's piercing gaze fixed on us in the distance, and it became agonisingly clear to me that to engage in conversation with this contentious beauty would be to rule out all chance of speaking to Picasso again and showing him my work. It was a predicament worthy of Corneille, and to wriggle out of it I acted like a coward. I lowered my eyes and remained silent when Francoise said "Bonjour" for the second time.At that point she understood. Understood above all that I was a miserable creature unworthy of her interest and she turned on her heels. I was upset by this, and when I focused my attentions on the beach once more, it was to see everyone leaving. Picasso himself came rushing out of the water and disappeared with a group of friends into the restaurant on the beach. Soon I was the only one left and, with a heavy heart, started gathering up my affairs. At that moment Picasso came out of the restaurant and said: "Aren't you coming?" "But..." "Come on, come and have lunch, old man."I thus found myself seated at table opposite Picasso, together with a number of other artists, among them Pignon and the sculptor Adam, whom I knew slightly. I was astonished to see that none of them uttered a single word, being quite happy just to be eating at the master's table. The master, on the other hand, talked a great deal, and I, therefore, who greatly enjoy a good conversation, turned out to be his only interlocutor. This time, I had my work cut out. Pablo's talk was every bit as inventive as his art and was littered with jokes and booby-traps. "Where do you live?" (He used the familiar form "tu" when addressing me, as is de rigueur among artists, great or small.)On learning that I lived in the Latin Quarter, he asked me where exactly. "Not far from Maubert-Mutualite." He was overjoyed. "Maubert is all I know. I even have a canvas of the place Maubert- Mutualite. Now, who painted it? You must know him. A curious fellow. I can't remember what he did for a living: a baker, a postman, a station-master? No, I've got it, he was a customs man." He was referring to the Douanier Rousseau painting with the place Maubert in the background, Les Representants des puissances etrangeres viennent saluer la Republique francaise en signe de paix, which formerly belonged to Picasso and is now in the Musee Picasso in Paris.Our conversation continued gaily, then in came some Spanish dancers touring the coast, friends, of course, of Pablo. Before long, the woman in the company, a beauty, had climbed on to the table and broken into a wild dance. The noise was deafening, and I was just saying to myself how marvellous it was to have lunched with Picasso and too bad about the photos, when all of a sudden he clapped his hands and called for silence, saying: "Yes, but that's not all. We have here a young artist who has come to show us his work." It was a little glimpse of Picasso's cruel side. All my fellow artists' eyes were now focused unkindly on me, as I laid out the few works I had accomplished to date. There were busts of children, done to make money, that Picasso passed over in silence, a few reliefs and, finally, Barcelona Tram, my first, recently completed high relief. It is one of my good works, one on which I can be judged, and Picasso's enthusiasm was immediate. (It's only lately that I have understood Picasso's emotional fixation on that city. Moreover, the scene depicted in my relief was the facade of the Estacin di Francia, the station from which Picasso had set out more than once for Paris.)He told me that he liked the work because it was my own, wasn't cosmopolitan or in keeping with the style of the day. Thereupon, he called Adam over to come and look at the Tram. Adam, who made bulky abstract forms, looked at it and declared: "Yeah, it's not bad, but it's not sculpture." To which Picasso retorted: "It's precisely because it's not sculpture that I like it. Sculpture that's just sculpture gives me the shits." Adam, sensing the remark was aimed at him, hurried back to his seat.Picasso continued to sing my praises, before adding: "You're an English artist." I deflated at once, but Picasso, seeing my disappointment, hastened to reassure me that he was very fond of English art, and without a moment's hesitation or a single omission rattled off in chronological order all the important English artists from Hogarth down to the turn of the 20th century. "But nowadays there's no English art any more. It's become cosmopolitan" - a word he was fond of - "like that sculptor, what's his name? You know the one." I didn't dare breathe. "M-M-Moo-Moo," he went on, tapping me on the chest. "Moore," I timidly suggested. "That's it, Moore. He's the same thing." I could hardly believe it. Moore, who had had the honour of seeing Picasso painting Guernica, being talked about in this way. I should add that in 1954 there was little chance of Picasso knowing much, or even anything at all, about Francis Bacon. By way of conclusion, Picasso told me to go and see Kahnweiler in Paris and to tell him he had sent me, a spectacular recommendation. Only on the road back, still glowing with pleasure from my afternoon with Picasso, did I remember that I hadn't asked him a thing about the potters in Vallauris!As it happens, I didn't go to Kahnweiler's, I didn't take advantage of the recommendation that thousands of artists would have envied me, and here is why. Roughly one year earlier, there had been a big private view of Picasso's work at Kahnweiler's old gallery in the rue d'Astorg. At the time, I was desperately searching for somewhere I could use as a studio, and it occurred to me that since everyone who was anyone in the Paris art world would be present at this event, it would be an excellent moment to hand out a leaflet at the entrance to the gallery saying that I would accept anything, anywhere, that I might use as a studio. That is exactly what happened.I spent two uncomfortable hours standing outside the gallery pestering people, and when I had nothing left to hand out I went inside to see the exhibition. In those days I saw a good deal of the fine arts delegate for the British Council in Paris, Frank McEwen, and I found him there with his friends, among whom was Georges Charensol from Radiodiffusion Francaise. Charensol was rounding people up to talk about the exhibition, and instead of doing it in the rooms of the gallery, he was taking his group down to the radio studios. Frank, who was taking part, suggested it would be interesting to have the views of a young artist, myself it just so happened, and Charensol said fine, good idea.There were some important figures at the studio. Kahnweiler himself, Michel Leiris, Andre Fraigneau and three or four others. While these leading lights were singing the great man's praises, the rest of us were asked to make sounds as though we were in the midst of a private view. For the same purposes of reconstruction, Charensol said at the end: "Ah, but I can see above the heads of the crowd a young English artist. This way, laddie, don't be nervous. Tell us what you think of Picasso." I cleared my throat: "Picasso is the king." "Bravo, bravo," said Kahnweiler and his company. "Provided," I added, "we understand that today le roi s'amuse." Bam! that was the end of the live broadcast. Kahnweiler started screaming: "Who let that little cretin in?" With everyone furious and Frank none too pleased, I scurried off home. Some time after this, with all the nonchalance of youth, I returned to the gallery to see an Andre Masson exhibition. Kahnweiler must have seen me from his glass-fronted office. A secretary came to show me the door. How could I possibly return there, even with a word from Picasso on my behalf? I had my pride.I met Picasso once or twice after that. I introduced my mother to him the following year, and he very graciously shook hands with her and did a little pirouette to show that, though he didn't know a word of English, he did know how to dance. My mother's reaction was equally amusing. The moment we were in the car I asked her how she felt after meeting the man everyone was talking about. "Very clean. He's very clean." "For God's sake, is that all you have to say?" But it was true, he was always very clean, impeccably turned out.Another time, I was with my two English friends, Ralph and Pauline Daubeny, who had driven all the way to the hotel at Eden Roc in a small Austin that Ralph had painted by hand on the eve of their departure. It wasn't until they parked their car among the Cadillacs and Rolls-Royces that they noticed in the strong sunlight that the brushmarks didn't even reach all the way down the bodywork, the bottom of which was of a different colour. They wanted a photo of Picasso and myself, so we stood there with our arms round each other's waist waiting for Ralph to fire the camera. There was nothing to be done. The camera, like the car, wasn't made for the Cote d'Azur. Impatient, Picasso, though photographed a million times over, didn't want to miss this one either. On all fours in the sand, he tinkered with the machine and, by golly, got it working again. We resumed our pose. We then said our farewells, everyone was very pleased, and there were the usual promises to send the photos on.A few weeks later, Ralph wrote to me from England to inform me that the photos were fantastic, and that he would be "sending them on". Nothing arrived, and a few months later I learned that my two charming friends had decided to divorce. They then did precisely that, and in the upheavals my photos with Picasso were lost.I MET HENRI CARTIER-BRESSON in 1973 thanks to Sam Szafran, who frequents the upper crust of Parisian society and is very generous in introducing his friends. The period of his great photos, or of his great reportages rather, was over, and he was returning to his first love, art. He had painted before the war, but now, having spent a lot of time with Alberto Giacometti, his only aim was to master drawing with the aid of an HB pencil and a few sheets of paper. He would pick up his famous Leica from time to time, and the result would be as extraordinary as ever; but, as I have said, there just wasn't the same interest any more.He lives in a fifth-floor duplex in the rue de Rivoli, overlooking the Tuileries gardens and above the apartment formerly inhabited by Victor Choquet, the friend and collector of the Impressionists. This means that Cezanne and Monet had often looked at the same view, and many of Cartier- Bresson's drawings take up the same landscape scenes first painted by Monet, Renoir and Pissarro. In this low-ceilinged apartment full of charm, Henri hangs works by his artist friends and receives a steady flow of interesting company, in general involved in the arts and literature. The food and drink served by his wife, the photographer Martine Franck, are first-class, and at table Cartier-Bresson gives free rein to his youthful enthusiasm for an endless array of subjects.Occasionally, this turns into equally spontaneous rage if something doesn't suit him - for example, the day he saw me putting water in my wine: "What, you're putting water in my lovely wine! Stupid Englishman. Get out!" I had got as far as the lift-cage when Henri caught up with me. I mention this to show that even today at his great age there isn't a trace of decrepitude in the man.One day he showed me some drawings he had made of the panorama of Paris from the roof above his flat. An excellent draughtsman, his love of Giacometti's work had, in my view, made him overemphasise the lines of structure, disembodying his subject, and I told him that it wouldn't do. "Well, then, I'm going to take you up on to the roof and watch you do it," said Henri firmly. We had arranged to do this a few days after, but the great heat wave of the summer of 1976 had started and I wanted to put off the experiment until later. Cartier-Bresson, however, once he gets an idea into his head, won't let it drop. Out we went, then, on to the sea of white-hot zinc of the roofs of the rue de Rivoli, only to see before us a young girl lying naked on her back, sunbathing. With apologetic smiles, we were preparing to step across her body when Henri, deciding the situation merited better, disappeared down the hatch and came back with a bottle of champagne. The young lady accepted a glass with good grace, while rolling over slightly on to her front.Once this interlude was over, we advanced as far as the chimney that was to be my vantage-point. And, from there, we saw in a window further down a slender young girl with a pink turban on her head, the spitting image of one of the famous photos Cartier-Bresson had brought back from India or Bali. It wasn't that, of course, simply a young woman who'd just washed her hair, and the turban was merely a coloured towel. Hardly had I recovered than, looking up in the direction of the great view towards the Sacre Coeur and Montmartre, I saw a Zeppelin like a white cigar circling the white dome. In 30 years of living in Paris, I had never seen such a thing. Astonishing. Then Henri left me on my own while I got set up and, looking around me, I discovered that the Zeppelin had vanished, the girl in the turban as well. Nor was there any sign of the naked woman.The whole thing had been the charms that life puts on show for him wherever Henri the magician passes. For luck and fate go with him always. During a stay in India, he was received by Gandhi in his tent. When he came out, the man going in was none other than Gandhi's assassin, and Cartier-Bresson found himself a witness to the most incredible scenes, standing with his camera just below Nehru when he leaned over the wall of the palace to announce the death to the people.ON THE CHIMNEY, I showed Henri that to make a drawing of that particular view you had to begin at the top and finish at the bottom. As moreover I was drawing, as is my wont, directly in ink, Henri gave a nod of the head and did not stay long. On his way down, from the window below, he fired off once with his Leica, and, while my drawing is good, his photo is extraordinary. There are two figures on a roof, myself cap on head (because of the heat) and the chimney with its own hat, and, starting from my profile, a whole zigzag of chimneys and asperities likewise profiled against the sky all the way down to the bottom right-hand corner of the photo. On the left, behind my back, is the bare horizontal of the roof, and below, filling the left-hand corner, the perfect black square of an open window. Like all Cartier-Bresson's photos, it is framed by a thin black band. This indicates that there has been no recropping, that it is simply what the camera saw. At the same time, Cartier- Bresson's photographs are of a complexity and precision of composition which almost defy understanding.Henri Cartier-Bresson is essentially an artist. He has lived all his life in Paris, a city of art and artists. The Louvre is right outside his door, and you can still see him there today, sitting on his shooting stick drawing the Old Masters. It is his eye, perfectly formed by study of the masterpieces of painting, which enables him to confront the tumultuous disorder of the outside world and place it instantaneously in a formal order of beauty. The poet Yves Bonnefoy has told me that when he was Henri's neighbour in the Alps of Haute Provence, he had to meet him at the coach stop at Simiane one day. They were crossing the sunlit and rather sleepy village square together when Yves saw Henri make a movement with his hand while talking. We later saw what he had captured by firing from the hip like the hero in a Western: an arcaded vantage-point with some young people and a few animals, all distributed in significant poses, and, above all, with all the pillars of the building perfectly vertical despite the offhand manner in which he had taken the photo. There's no doubt about it, Henri shoots faster than Lucky Luke - with this notable difference, that a single shot from the latter left people dead whereas Henri makes them live for ever.In those days, I had a house in Provence, at Menerbes opposite the Luberon, and Henri and Martine were installed in an old farmhouse near Reillanne on the Grand Luberon. Our two houses were equidistant, 20 kilometres to either side of Apt. It is at Apt that the Luberon mountain chain is divided into the Grand and the Petit Luberon by the valley leading down to Lourmarin on the south slope. Though close to one another, our two landscapes were very different. While I looked straight out on to the Petit Luberon, abrupt and spectacular, across a cheerful valley rich in vineyards and fruit trees, Henri was perched on the side of a mountain much like any other in the Alpine forelands, but with a splendid panorama of wheat fields and pasture-land before him. We shared the same pure climate and the same beautiful sun, which is extremely important for artists like ourselves who like to see.Alas, between us ran a wicked, typically Provencal road lined with plane trees whose roots made bumps in the surface all the way to Forcalquier, where there was an arts centre in an old building run by a mutual friend of ours, Lucien Henry. It was here, moreover, that Henri held one of his first exhibitions of drawings. Since then, exhibitions of his drawings have been held pretty much all over the world, but I would be very surprised if any of them equalled that at the Ecole Nationale Superieure des Beaux- Arts in Paris in 1989, prodigiously well hung by his publisher, Robert Delpire.Here is another side of Henri Cartier-Bresson. In 1984, I had just finished my monument for Montreal and needed a photo of the entire sculpture. I had to have it, moreover, that weekend, for the work would be leaving the moulder's studio the coming Monday. I thought of a-young disciple of Henri's, Marc, who had the plate camera essential for art photos. I called Henri to get Marc's phone number. He asked me why I wanted it and, when I explained, said in an annoyed tone: "But I can't do the photo for you, I don't have the time." I assured him that Marc was the only one who could do it, and grudgingly he gave me the number. Five minutes later, he phoned back to say he would do the photo himself, and that I would have to go and pick him up in the car to drive the 30 kilometres to Brie- Comte- Robert. Knowing that he didn't have the right instrument for the job, I was put out by his announcement, but, since this great friend of mine was also a great man, there was nothing further to be said.While I was rolling pleasantly along towards our destination, Henri suddenly said: "If you continue driving at this speed, I'll throw myself out of the car." We were off to a good start and, sure enough, the moment we entered the Haligon studio in Brie, Cartier- Bresson, seeing how enormous the monument was, cried out: "What! I can't photograph a thing like that!" (He always told me his interest was exclusively for small sculptures, Giacometti's or those of his brother-in-law, Pierre Josse.) It was my turn now to shout: "You're the one who insisted on coming. I wanted Marc. But I have to have the photo at all costs."We both stood there sulking. At that moment, the moulder Olivier Haligon pointed out a problem to me at one spot on the sculpture, and while I was giving it my attention, someone called out my name. I turned round in the direction of the call and was astounded to see Cartier-Bresson at the top of a tall, metal ladder that he hadn't even bothered to pull away from the wall. The photo was done. It was not the documentary photo I wanted, but a marvellous image of an artist lost in his great work. It served as the frontispiece for my catalogue at the Pompidou Centre, and Cartier-Bresson included it in his album. I have related this anecdote to illustrate the sprightliness of the man, who was then 76. In the Midi, he photographed me on some land near Menerbes which dropped sheer down to the valley. To get the angle he wanted, I saw him run up the embankment backwards. Try doing it.He took many portraits of me, none of which quite came off. Though he has taken some great portraits, the best are always those taken in situ and not the head alone. I have in mind the portrait of William Faulkner and his dog, or that of Colette with her maid standing behind her. Everything he has done of me in a context is very good. He was present outside the Jeu de Paume in the Tuileries - he only had to come down from his apartment - on the day of Arctic cold in January 1986 when the installation of The Crowd in bronze was inaugurated. He and Martine took the usual photos of me and the officials standing in front of the work, but the one that is always used is yet again an oblique view from behind, with me alone looking round - in response to a call - into Henri's Leica.Afterwards, we all beat a retreat to the nearest cafe on the rue de Rivoli for a hot grog. The people from the ministry were delighted to be sharing a table with Henri Cartier-Bresson, a living legend, but the business of the Glass Pyramid of the Louvre was still fresh (Henri and I were against this monstrosity), and Cartier- Bresson seized the opportunity of having these gentlemen in front of him to tell them yet again what he thought of it all. Since more than a grog was needed to warm up the atmosphere, we soon parted. Good old Henri!Clearly, the fact that he's nice-looking and not remotely threatening has made it easier for him to slip into all kinds of situations, record them on film then leave without being spotted. This is also the place to note that most photographers confine themselves to the dramatic and the tragic, and even a photographer out to amuse, like Robert Doisneau, has his subjects pose for him, thereby killing off any vivacity. Henri Cartier-Bresson gives us life in its entirety, the spectacular and the dramatic but also the moments of unruffled happiness or unbridled mirth, as a result of which at an exhibition of his photos we always hear people laughing. The mixture of the serious and the comical is always very potent in a creator and gives his work an added dimension.This ability to feel optimistic about life is a rare gift in this brilliant man. Not long ago, he was about to undergo an operation of some gravity for a man of his age. He told me about it in a little casual note which he signed "En-rit" - laughing about it.Henri, just back from a voyage, phones to tell me that, during a stop- over in Berlin, he visited a museum where he noticed in the rooms a man of imposing presence. He was introduced to him. It was "your ambassador" the British ambassador. "Ah, Monsieur Cartier- Bresson, you've taken a lot of photographs in our country. I hope you never had any difficulties doing so," said the latter politely. "On the contrary," replied Henri, "every time I pointed my camera at one of your fellow countrymen he would duck and say `sorry', because in his modesty he thought I was photographing something behind him." mThis is an extract from At Work in Paris: Raymond Mason on Art and Artists (Thames & Hudson, pounds 18.95). Raymond Mason's work will be exhibited at Marlborough Fine Art, 6 Albemarle Street, London W1, 9 May-7 June IllustrationCaption: Cartier-Bresson: `The ability to feel optimistic about life is a rare gift in this brilliant man.'; Pablo Picasso: `On the dot of noon each day he would arrive at the beach and sink his parasol in the sand like an emperor's standard. A waiter at the restaurant nearby said he could set his watch by him'PORTRAIT OF RAYMOND MASON, LEFT, BY HENRI CARTIER-BRESSONWord count: 5565Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract

The purpose of art is washing the dust of daily life off our souls. This remark by Pablo Picasso accompanies a picture of a pewter piece by crafter and author Sandy Griffiths in her new book Pewter Impressions.: Crafter Sandy Griffith's latest book makes it easy for beginners to start creating their own works of art with this versatile alloy

"It is a lovely soft metal, an alloy of tin and other metals, sometimes lead, which is easy to mould. There are only two basic techniques used in the art of pewter - low relief and high relief - and once you have learnt these techniques, the world of pewter is yours.""I was presenting workshops at a large craft expo and as there was nothing available in print on pewter art, I put some notes together and sold them. Wislia Metz, of Metz Press, who specialises in craft books, was at the expo, and she asked me if I would write a book on pewter. In a moment of complete madness I said 'Sure'. I was lucky, I was in the right place at the right time.""I never expected to hear from her again," says [Sandy Griffiths], "but three months later I received an|e-mail from her saying I had seven months to write the book. This remark by Pablo Picasso accompanies a picture of a pewter piece by crafter and author Sandy Griffiths in her new book Pewter Impressions.She demonstrates how pewter relief modelling can be used to add unique decorative touches around the home, and says relief modelling is a completely different craft from cast pewter.Her book illustrates how thin sheets of the metal with raised or relief designs, created with special tools, can be used to decorate window shutters, candles and create beautiful finishes on mosaics.Griffiths, who has been working with pewter for 10 years, is an experienced crafter. Her studio is in Devil's Peak, Cape Town, where she has been teaching pewter and several other crafts for many years."Working with pewter is surprisingly easy," she says. "It is a lovely soft metal, an alloy of tin and other metals, sometimes lead, which is easy to mould. There are only two basic techniques used in the art of pewter - low relief and high relief - and once you have learnt these techniques, the world of pewter is yours."Griffiths says many people are inhibited about being creative as they believe they cannot draw, but this is easily solved by using the tracing paper which is part of a pewter kit. "No drawing skills are required."The idea for a craft book on the metal came about after Griffiths tried to source information for her workshops."I was presenting workshops at a large craft expo and as there was nothing available in print on pewter art, I put some notes together and sold them. Wislia Metz, of Metz Press, who specialises in craft books, was at the expo, and she asked me if I would write a book on pewter. In a moment of complete madness I said 'Sure'. I was lucky, I was in the right place at the right time."Metz took a copy of Griffiths's notes to present to her colleagues."I never expected to hear from her again," says Griffiths, "but three months later I received an|e-mail from her saying I had seven months to write the book. So I just did it."Pewter Impressions is her third book on the subject. It includes a collection of more than 30 original pewter projects, illustrated with gorgeous photographs of all the finished projects as well as templates for all designs used in the book.It has easy-to-follow step-by-step instructions and clear photographs. It starts at the beginning so that novices do not need to go back to earlier books.Beginners' exercises explain the basics, teaching crafters how to apply the art of embossing and then add lustre, radiance and dimension to their design. These are followed by a wide range of stunning projects which include combining pewter with mosaics, canvas, glass paint, gold and silver leaf foil, crystals and more, offering a variety of looks and finishes.The projects vary from fabulous frames and beautiful boxes to gifts and decor items.In addition to the projects, Pewter Impressions covers:-- Essential tools and how to use them.-- Tracing and transferring patterns.-- Low and high relief embossing.-- Moulding-- Texturing-- Adding colour and patina.-- Cutting out and sticking designs to various surfaces.Griffiths says one of her favourites is the gift tag project, a beginner's exercise: "They are simple, elegant and look really unique. You can let your imagination run wild while dreaming up designs or simply trace mine. And they are so easy to make."Her other books, Easy Pewter Projects and Pewter, are popular. She also has a DVD, filmed by Andrew Ingram, called Pewter It, aimed at beginners. It is a hands-on workshop giving the viewer a close-up view of low and high relief creations. It also covers gold leafing and applying glass stain to pewter.New to pewter? No problemWord count: 657Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Picasso's Hidden Figures; Technology has revealed the earlier versions of Pablo Picasso's 'Family of Saltimbanques' and the painting's evolution.
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitThe often romantic theme of itinerant entertainers and street performers enjoys a long history in France, going back to the royal court of Louis XIV. Among this king's amusements was the commedia dell'arte, a troupe of Italian actors--dressed as characters Harlequin, Pierrot and Columbine--as well as jugglers and acrobats, these latter called saltimbanques from their jumping motions.When the king's mistress Mme. de Maintenon dismissed them from court in 1697, these actors and saltimbanques performed in public, traveling to newer locations. Their descendants appear in works from Honoré Daumier to Edouard Manet to Georges Seurat. Perhaps the most famous is Pablo Picasso's "Family of Saltimbanques" (1905).The grandest picture of his pre-Cubist period--it measures over 7 by 7 1/2 feet--this work has been in the National Gallery of Art's collection since 1963, a bequest of patron Chester Dale. It moved to the Gallery's East Building when it opened 40 years ago this weekend. There, in 1979, we began a joint art-history and technical study of the picture."Who are these rambling acrobats?" the poet Rainer Maria Rilke asked in his "Fifth Duino Elegy" (1923) after seeing it in the summer of 1915. Far from being a random, anonymous group as they are in other treatments of the subject, the figures here have specific identities. Harlequin bears Picasso's features; that of the small acrobat those of his friend, the poet Max Jacob. The deep-browed acrobat and the ample jester resemble, respectively, colleagues André Salmon and Guillaume Apollinaire.But the painting did not originally appear as it does now. Freely brushed and near-transparent paint areas in the foreground and the woman's hat suggested to us that Picasso had made changes to an earlier composition. So in 1980 we made X-radiographs of the entire picture, a process that, combined with subsequent art-historical research, disclosed the painting's complex metamorphosis.A crucial clue about Picasso's original intentions came from Fernande Olivier, who recalls in her published journal that Picasso painted "a large canvas, a group of acrobats on a plain. Some are resting, the others working.... If I remember correctly, this canvas was repainted several times."Although she didn't mention what happened to that "large" picture, Olivier's description fit the "Circus Family" (1904-05), a small drawing in the Baltimore Museum of Art. Looking at the X-radiographs, we found the lost painting embedded under the surface of "Family of Saltimbanques."The spectral presence of the "Circus Family" was one of many stunning discoveries that we made. In penetrating all the layers of "Saltimbanques," these technical images captured a second picture, this one the mirror image of a mid-sized gouache, "Two Acrobats With a Dog" (1905), now owned by the Museum of Modern Art. Pervaded with a blue tonality, this work is closer to the current "Family of Saltimbanques," presenting two costumed performers standing in a barren landscape.The X-radiographs also disclosed that changes had been made to the third composition, or the topmost layer of the painting.Three separate galaxies of saltimbanques now formed, serving to navigate us through Picasso's months-long campaign on the National Gallery's painting. The first group is from the initial "Circus Family" layer, a second set is related to the composition of two young acrobats, and a third is connected to the present state of the painting.One of us (Ms. Hoenigswald), after technically examining Picasso's work for decades, has found a pattern of his compositions evolving directly from his earlier imagery. We see that in the "Family of Saltimbanques," where one layer morphs into a second and a third. Moreover, he intentionally leaves clues, so-called pentimenti, revealing, for example, a shift in the woman's hat, or the thin leg under the boy's puffy pants, and cracks revealing unrelated colors or obscured textures, all to draw the viewer's attention to the picture's process.Picasso's life played a role in the "Family of Saltimbanques." Already noticed as part of the avant garde in Barcelona, he moved to Paris in 1900 seeking recognition in this center of Modernism. A year of obscurity led next to his traveling between the cities until 1904, when he returned to Paris, meeting Olivier, Salmon and Apollinaire (he knew Jacob earlier). In December of that year, these friends became regular visitors to the Cirque Medrano, a local small circus show where Picasso sketched many acrobats backstage.Picasso transformed this experience into his large canvas's initial layer of a "Circus Family." But the genius of the "Family of Saltimbanques" came when he portrayed his artist friends in the final picture, and transformed their status as outsiders by identifying his characters with the historic, wandering troupe of once royal entertainers. The isolation of Picasso's figures, presented in this virtual frieze of symbolic and poetic images, lifts the work to greatness.Mr. Carmean is a former curator and Ms. Hoenigswald is a former paintings conservator, both at the National Gallery of Art.Credit: By E.A. Carmean Jr. and Ann HoenigswaldWord count: 818Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Isabel strikes out on own creative path: Born in Paris in 1963 to a French artist who was once Pablo Picasso's muse, sculptor ISABEL COULTON grew up in the midst of the bohemian art world of 1960s France. Reporter LAURA DALE went to meet the talented sculptor at her South Brent home, which she shares with her clock-maker husband Simon and their children.

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit RIGHT in front of me were Lawrence Dallaglio's hands. Huge and knotted, they clasped the rugby ball which had earned England a place in World Cup history in 2003.The iconic winning moment had been delicately captured first in wood and then in bronze.For Isabel, the technical sculpture of her brother-in-law's hands marked a turning point in her career away from the strict technique of restoration work to the freedom of sculpture."The World Cup was very exciting because Lawrence was in it. I thought it would be great to commemorate it in some way, so I asked if I could make a sculpture of his hands."I cast his hands in plaster and then I carved it out of one solid chunk of wood-- the ball is only touching on three points which made the carving of the ball very difficult as well as hands being technically very hard anyway."It marked a letting go from my old way of working. It was the turning point and I realised I had to make sculptures."As a teenager Isabel was reluctant to follow into the fine art world her family had entered."I did shy away from it for a long time -- you try and break the mould when you're a teenager."I left home and went to work with mentally handicapped children. I loved my job, but things didn't work out so I decided I would go to art school and see what it was like."My dad is an antique dealer and he works with early oak furniture. He said why didn't I try carving, so I went to an evening class and I loved it."Isabel studied the art of carving and gilding -- and polychrome finishes -- for three years.She supplemented her knowledge and income doing restoration work on Robert Adam, Chippendale and Thomas Hope furniture."I worked for two different carving workshops in London. One of them worked on beautiful furniture from Lady Diana's family, the Spencers."I worked in restoration for eight years. I wanted to learn my craft. Wood is a difficult medium to work with and if you don't learn your technique properly then you are limited in what you can do."Her first wood carving was of Aphrodite. Carved in deep relief the Goddess is feminine and soft.Isabel has captured her beauty and sexuality in carefully chiselled features and grains in the wood.On the reverse is a shepherd carved in shallow relief because, Isabel jokes, 'he is a mere mortal'. A knot in the wood looked like a sheep's bottom to Isabel, so she carved the animal meekly resting over the shepherd's shoulders.She used medieval techniques to paint the background, by grinding natural pigments and mixing them with animal glue. The result is a stunning piece of carving, seemingly simplistic yet every feature has been chiselled to perfection.I ask her if it's hard to part with her artwork considering the physical and emotional effort she carves into each piece."To begin with it was very strange delivering a piece like Aphrodite -- you feel like you're leaving something behind." But she reassures me: "It's great that it sells and I'm okay with it now."Isabel's portfolio is full of ornate carvings -- mirrors, small heads and hands."I'm fascinated by hands -- they say a lot about a person. For me they describe the soul."I carved my own hands out of a piece of stone. I held them up and copied them, had a look and carved a bit more. Using stone was very different to wood. It's a great medium because I find it stops me from being too detailed."One of her clients asked for a carving of his teenage daughter's forearm. Isabel cast it and carved it in wood and now the lone limb sits eerily on his desk, the fingers gently holding his business cards."He has a great sense of humour and it is the sort of sculpture people used to have in their homes."Other sculptures include an athletic looking boxing hare carved out of lime wood, a mother and child relief and a charging bull cast in bronze, which was eagerly snapped up by dealers and taken to the South of France, Monaco and Miami.Exploring sculpture work has given Isabel 'a freedom' in her artwork and the confidence to push herself and hone her own style.She has been successful with public art commissions, including the creation of a wooden apple core with aluminium pips for the playground at Stoke Gabriel Primary School.In between commissions, she has spent the last five years chain-sawing and chiselling 11 trees destined for the chop into towering pieces of art at a housing estate in Brixham.A seagull, a fox and a buzzard perch and climb on one tree, while a figurine of St Mary looks out to sea from another tree."The first one took me three months to complete. It has been a labour of love. I started with fine, fiddly stuff in my restoration work, but you have to be very decisive when you use a chain saw."Sculpting is always really frustrating. It doesn't matter what medium you're working in, it's always a real struggle. There comes a point when you think 'Why aim I doing this, it's too hard' but you are driving to continue and make it right. Sculpting with a chain saw is slightly worse. The chain saw is heavy, it's dusty work and it's noisy."I come home covered in dust and my arms are aching, but there's something strangely satisfying once you've done it."Isabel's mother Lydia Corbett (nee Sylvette David) was Picasso's muse for three months in 1954.The image of the striking, insouciant teenager with the high pony tail, her blonde hair cascading down to her shoulders can be found in up to 50 of Picasso's works.Thousands of women appropriated her style including the then unknown Brigitte Bardot, before she became a Hollywood icon.In 1965 Isabel was taken to meet Picasso. In a recent interview her mother recalled the visit: "It was moving but he couldn't hear so well. He was sweet. My two-year-old daughter was turning him round and round in a swivel chair and he remarked that she was like an English painting."Isabel refers to her mother's experience as a 'fairy tale', but I wonder if it's something which at times has overshadowed both of them.Interestingly Isabel finds herself drawn to hairstyles as a means of inspiration for some of her carvings."Hairstyles sometimes inspire me, like a thick plait or a high ponytail. I did a few sculptures with ponytails in them and I thought 'what is this about', but I worked through it."Now in her late 40s, Isabel is hitting her artistic stride. She is experimenting with her skill through her ideas and concepts, which have 'stacked up' over the years while having her three children and are finally been set free.The Dallaglio hands (her sister Alice is Dallaglio's longterm partner and the mother of the couple's three children) symbolise a 'personal freedom of work'.Isabel teaches wood carving privately. For more information ring 01364 73120or email info@isabelcoulton.comSculpting is always really frustrating, especially with a chain saw.
