Title: Jacqueline Roque: Picasso's Wife, Love & Muse; Cubist artist Pablo Picasso's most painted subject was his controversial wife, Jacqueline Roque. Now an exhibition at Pace Gallery explores their relationship and the works it inspired
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitTHINK OF PICASSO, and it's impossible not to envision the women he loved, tormented and painted, like Fernande Olivier, whose distorted features are indelibly associated with early cubism, or Dora Maar, often depicted weeping, or Marie-Thérèse Walter, whose face and body the artist sundered so violently during his surrealist years. "For me, there are only two kinds of women--goddesses and doormats," he told his postwar partner, Françoise Gilot, as she recounted in Life with Picasso, her 1964 memoir. Since Picasso's death in 1973, the works emerging from these liaisons--and the gripping tales behind them--have provided fodder for countless museum and gallery shows. In the past three years alone, Gagosian Gallery, in conjunction with the Picasso biographer John Richardson, mounted two well-received New York exhibitions, Picasso and Marie-Thérèse: L'Amour Fou in 2011, and Picasso and Françoise Gilot in 2012. (On October 28, the gallery will open Picasso & the Camera, curated, like the others, by Richardson.) Now Pace Gallery, which has presented many Picasso shows of its own, will focus an extensive, two-gallery exhibition around the least celebrated and most controversial of the artist's amours, Jacqueline Roque, a dark-haired divorcée 45 years the artist's junior, who became his second wife in 1961. Their relationship endured for more than 20 years, until Picasso's death at 91, making Jacqueline, who took his name when they married, his longest-lasting consort and most persistent muse. Yet she has inspired only a few exhibitions. The last was in 2006, at the Kunst Museum Pablo Picasso in Münster, Germany. In part that's because Picasso's late work has often been dismissed as irrelevant and kitschy. But decades have elapsed since his death, and the work he produced while he was with Jacqueline is beginning to be hotly desired by collectors. Pace, which has organized seven shows around the late work since 1981, hopes to introduce audiences to the person who, despite all that's said of her, was arguably the most important love of Picasso's life. In a 1988 essay, Richardson called Picasso's late years "L'Époque Jacqueline." "It is so free and full of love," says the Guggenheim Museum curator and Picasso scholar Carmen Giménez of the master's work from this time. "Jacqueline created peace for him.  That did not happen before." Yet the paucity of shows about Jacqueline may also be related to the ambiguous role she played for Picasso's family and friends. Early on, she developed a reputation for being manipulative, avaricious and conniving, initially because she came between Picasso and Gilot. Once installed at La Californie, the artist's grand Cannes villa, she guarded his privacy jealously, shutting out even his children and grandchildren so he could focus on work. After his death, Jacqueline disappeared into seclusion for three years, emerging only to battle with his heirs over the disposition of his estate. And in 1986, still racked with grief over the loss of Monseigneur, as she called him, Jacqueline killed herself with a pistol at Notre-Dame de Vie, their castle in Mougins, becoming one of many Picasso intimates to die tragically. (Others include Walter, who hanged herself in 1977; Picasso's son Paolo by his first wife, the dancer Olga Khokhlova, who drank himself to death in 1975; and Paolo's son Pablito, who downed bleach after Jacqueline barred him from Picasso's funeral.) Their relationship--and Jacqueline's sphinxlike demeanor, as rendered in more than 125 artworks--will live again in Pace's Picasso & Jacqueline: The Evolution of Style, from October 31 through January 10, 2015. Nearly half of the work is drawn from the holdings of Picasso's heirs, and the rest from other private collections and museums, including the Centre Pompidou and the Museum of Modern Art. The exhibitions will include every sort of medium, from painting and sculpture to drawings, ceramics and prints. Only a handful will be for sale. "There are more portraits of Jacqueline than any other woman in Picasso's life," says Arne Glimcher, Pace's founder. "The range of interpretation of her image is quite extraordinary. We've selected works representing all of these moments, from the time he meets her and draws her like Ingres, till the end of his life, when his work was marked by wild expressionism. So you see the transformation of his late style only through these portraits of Jacqueline." Glimcher worked on the show for five years with Catherine Hutin, Jacqueline's daughter, now in her late 60s and based in Paris. Hutin lived with the couple and, after her mother's death, inherited a large portion of Picasso's estate. Although Hutin was not Picasso's child, Glimcher notes, "she lived longer with him than any of the other children and saw more work being made than anybody else, besides Jacqueline. She really knows the work inside out." Most of the paintings and sculptures will be downtown, at Pace's Chelsea outpost at 534 West 25th St., with the bulk of the works on paper at 32 East 57th St. Also included are photographs by the Life photojournalist David Douglas Duncan, who began shooting the couple in 1956, when he stopped by La Californie on a whim, snapped Picasso in the bathtub and soon won carte blanche to shadow them for the rest of the artist's life. The prints, 56 in all, show the couple together--walking, talking and even holding hands just after marrying in secret. The photographs offer a glimpse into their unguarded private life at a time when they had closed so many out. Many depict Jacqueline in the shadows, watching Picasso work, a dynamic both evidently enjoyed. Now 98 and still living near Cannes, Duncan, who tends to irascibility, has little patience for Jacqueline's critics. "To hell with that noise!" he snaps. "She closed the goddamn door to keep people out. She probably added 15 years to his life." As one of a lucky few regularly welcomed, Duncan recalls he couldn't stay away for long, even though his docket was full of assignments. "It was a hell of a story," he says. It began in 1952 when the 72-year-old artist, one of the most famous people in France, met the 27-year-old Roque at a pottery studio in Vallauris. He was making ceramics there, and she was a salesgirl. Although he was still entangled with Gilot, he wooed Roque by chalking a white dove on the wall of her house and sending her single red roses. His friends viewed her as "not up to the job," Richardson recounts one of them saying in The Sorcerer's Apprentice, his 1999 memoir of his years in Picasso's inner circle. When Gilot, seemingly unaware of the new attachment, left Picasso a year after it began, Jacqueline suffered through their attempts to reconcile, as well as his dalliances with others. But she eventually won out, largely because she was slavishly reverent of him. Patrick O'Brian, another Picasso biographer, observed in 1976 that the artist recognized in her "the devotion of a lifetime." The art historian Barbara Rose, a contributor to Pace's catalog, puts it somewhat differently: "She thought he was God and he thought he was God," Rose says. "The two of them were in love with him." Perhaps that's why, during their years together, Picasso became even more prolific than usual, as Jacqueline blithely neglected her daughter to run the household, monitor his social life and spend hours in the studio. Moved in turn by her classical profile, her almond-shaped eyes and her exotic features, Picasso cast her in his reworkings of French and Spanish masters like Manet and Velázquez, which so obsessed him during his final years. One painting from 1954, Jacqueline avec une Écharpe Noire, shows her draped in a black scarf that suggests a hijab, smiling enigmatically--a modern, Orientalist-inspired interpretation of El Greco's Lady in a Fur Wrap. Later that year, Jacqueline's habit of crouching on the floor, like an idealized odalisque, moved him to incorporate her form in a series of 15 paintings that deconstruct Eugène Delacroix's 1834 Femmes d'Alger. (The Chelsea show will include a roomful of the many drawings, etchings and paintings Picasso made on this subject.) Jacqueline also appears in other homages, such as the cubist-style, sexualized rendering of Manet's 1863 Le Déjeuner sur l'Herbe (1961), and the erotic 1968 etchings known as Suite 347, in which Picasso depicts Raphael and his model, la Fornarina, making love. But he also represented Jacqueline as herself, sculpting her likeness in bronze and painted sheet metal, and drawing her reading, playing with his children, petting her cat and just gazing into space. Duncan, in his 1988 book Picasso and Jacqueline, describes the artist's messy, crowded studio as being full of images of Jacqueline, "who often appeared to be stepping out of one canvas into another of herself." Overall, however sexualized or aggressive Picasso's characterization, there is also a serene, joyful quality to the work. Perhaps that's because, as Duncan recalls today, the couple's love for each other was abundantly evident. "Absolutely, one hundred percent, no mention of anybody else ever," he insists. "They loved each other from the first time they met, until they both died." And today a depiction of that love lies with them in their joint grave at Vauvenargues, their château in Provence. At Jacqueline's funeral, Duncan tucked a photograph into her coffin: Taken in 1962, it shows her sitting with Picasso on the steps of La Californie with his portrait of her behind him. They snuggle together, laughing, waiting for the paint to dry.Credit: By Carol KinoWord count: 1568Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: 'Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up," said Pablo Picasso, the defining artist of the 20th Century. His devoted fan, Lamaat Mahmood, had that very problem, but it's one he has been able to overcome --something which quickly becomes apparent as he conducts a guided tour of his fascinating home in Co Wexford.: Lifestyle

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitRaised in Pakistan, Lamaat Mahmood's medical training brought him to Ireland, discovers Mary O'Sullivan. But it was only when he'd built his elegant home in Co Wexford that he had the space to emulate the work of his artistic idol'Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up," said Pablo Picasso, the defining artist of the 20th Century. His devoted fan, Lamaat Mahmood, had that very problem, but it's one he has been able to overcome --something which quickly becomes apparent as he conducts a guided tour of his fascinating home in Co Wexford."Picasso," he says, pointing out a picture on the right-hand side of the hallway and then, turning to the left side, he points at another picture and says with a gentle note of pride, "me", and so it goes throughout the house. Lamaat has hung prints of Picasso's most iconic Cubist works everywhere, and alongside them can be found his own works, inspired by those of the Spanish giant.Lamaat's work is all quite recent because, even though he loved art as a child growing up in Lahore, he wasn't encouraged to pursue it. "I wanted to be an artist, but my parents chose medicine for me. My first inspiration was Sadequain, a Pakistani painter. He also painted in the Cubist style, like Picasso. He was particularly known for his calligraphy. During the Islamicrevolution they burned his work; there's very little left," Lamaat muses.A seemingly easygoing sort, Lamaat doesn't resent the fact that he was directed into medicine instead of art by his parents -- he recognises that his father, a lawyer, and his late mother, a school headmistress, wanted the best for him. Fortunately, he enjoyed studying medicine and opted to specialise in anaesthesia, but he resolved quite early on that he would try to combine the two disciplines."My sister did a masters in fine art and sculpture. At the time I had just finished medicine, and I started painting. I used her half-dried paints and her used brushes to paint landscapes and seascapes, but I was always interested in Cubism. I have a mathematical mind, I think that's why I was attracted to Cubism," he recalls. "At that time I tried to do abstract works like Picasso's, but I couldn't. Then I came to Ireland and I stopped painting altogether," he says.He came initially for his training in anaesthesia but stayed to work, and he now holds a joint Irish/Pakistani passport. He moved around the country, starting with Wexford in 1995, then working in hospitals in Cork, Mayo and Kilkenny consecutively. He came back to Wexford General Hospital in 1998, and he works mainly in obstetrics and day surgery.He tried to resume his painting, but it didn't work out for him due to a combination of circumstances. The work routine at the hospital took time to get used to and he also had logistical problems; at the time he lived in quite a small house with no space for a studio. Then there was the whole question of trying to adapt to a different way of life. "At first I didn't know anyone, then I made friends of all nationalities and it became easier," he says.He's just back from his annual month-long holiday in Pakistan, so he's in reflective mode. "Each time I go home and come back, I feel quite homesick -- so homesick that I feel like a misfit. Eventually, after a few days at work, I get back into life here," he confides, adding that, conversely, he feels like a misfit in Lahore, too."The ways there are so different to here. For example, I can't drive there. The way they drive -- you need a large horn and bumpers all around your car. My body freezes if I sit in the driver seat," he exclaims. "And I can't shop. I'm used to shopping here, but there they are not polite. You can't be polite. You have to be abrupt. So my sister [he has three sisters] does it for me. And the climate! I've lived in Ireland so long I can't bear the heat, so I always visit in winter," he says in his accented-though-fluent English; he always spoke English at school and Urdu at home. He also speaks Punjabi, the language local to his hometown.Despite his conflicted feelings, Lamaat loves his native land and ensures that there are plenty of Pakistani mementos and artefacts throughout his home. He built the house in 2007 when he finally got the site he wanted in the Wexford countryside; and the necessary planning permission, which took a while.He designed the house himself and project-managed it. In the process he ensured that not only would it be big -- the ground floor is 4,000sq ft -- but that there would be an ample attic for his painting. And suddenly he found he could paint like his hero. His paintings are not copies of Picasso's; inspired by the Spanish genius, he paints objects which are broken down and then reassembled seemingly at random -- abstract works, if you will."When I moved here I converted the attic, and that's my haven. I built the house in 2007 and in 2008 I got a present of an art-shop voucher. I bought paints and brushes and I found I could follow the Cubist style, and I've been painting ever since," Lamaat explains.He has even exhibited several times, showing his oils and acrylics at the RDS Art Fair, and during the Opera Festival in 2009 and 2010. He also has pieces on view at the Clyne Gallery in Temple Bar and is part of an art website run by vision 94 online gallery -- see www.wexfordpictureframing.ie or .com.According to Lamaat, the two careers work well together. "I don't know if I feel happier painting. They're two separate entities. I enjoy my work at the hospital and then I detoxify myself, destress myself with the painting," he says. "Painting is a good cut-off from work."Lamaat also says his colleagues have been very supportive, turning up at his exhibitions and even buying his work. They'll get a further opportunity to buylater this month -- he's currently working on paintings for an exhibition at the Farmlane Gallery in Moycullen, Co Galway, starting on March 26. The attic studio is full of his preparations and therefore a tad messy.However, the rest of the house is pristine -- Lamaat is someone who likes everything ordered and in its place. Given his artistic nature, it comes as no surprise that his home is tastefully decorated. The public areas are floored in marble; the bedrooms are carpeted. "I used to have wooden floors in the bedrooms of my last house, but I do like a little bit of comfort, and getting out of bed, it's nice to have a soft surface to stand on," he notes.The walls of all the rooms are white with one accent wall in each room. Most of the furniture is modern and there are lots of leather sofas, but any hard edges are softened with textures and textiles -- Lamaat is big on cushions and changes them to suit the seasons. Many of the curtain fabrics are silk, and came from Pakistan.Each room has interesting pieces from around the world; there are paintings by Lamaat's sister in Pakistan and lots of buddhas brought back from the east. There are also pieces from South Africa; a close friend, Patrick Meehan, goes to work for the Niall Mellon Township Trust every year for a week and always brings back a wall hanging, mask or some other artwork.Lamaat likes to have friends around to the house -- because he lives in the country he has four en suite bedrooms so that they can stay overnight. Dinner parties are his forte, so, naturally, a good kitchen was a priority. Patrick actually designed the kitchen, which is fitted with black high-gloss units finished with brushed stainless steel and covered with sillstone worktops. There are some particularly clever details in the design -- for example, the dishwasher is placed at a higher level than normal so that the person filling it doesn't have to bend. It, like all the other appliances, is by Neff. The funky Norm 69 light in the kitchen is retro in style.While he did a lot of research to get just the right thing for all the rooms, he found much of what he wanted in chain stores: the trio of lamps over the dining table is from Ikea. And, when he can't find what he wants, he often designs it himself. The Japanese-style coffee tables as well as the matching sideboards were designed by Lamaat and made by the company who fitted he kitchen.As well as the dining area, there are two other reception rooms -- the area Lamaat calls his media area, which has music, a television and computers; and secondly, the more formal area.Unusually for an Irish house, the entrance hall is enormous, almost a room in itself. Apparently it's a Pakistani thing. "Hallways in Pakistan are bigger. I think the hallway is the most used space so I wanted it to be particularly nice."Of course, it is also perfect for hanging pictures -- both Picasso's and Lamaat's.LWord count: 1570Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Passion flows in the Picasso bloodstream and a 21st-century passion of the descendants of Pablo Picasso is litigation...
Publisher: London Evening Standard, West End final [ed.]
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndPepita Dupont met [Jacqueline Roque] in 1982, four years before she killed herself, and takes a predictable line. She asserts that Jacqueline had a special role in anaesthetising and making happy the convulsive Picasso at the end of his life. She called him 'Monseigneur', 'Maitre' and 'Le Soleil'; he called her 'Mummy'; she got his teeth fixed and nursed his gall bladder and allowed his stinking goat to roam the ground floor of their house in Mougins. She was not much interested in sex - 'I have had to give up f***ing and smoking since I turned 90,' Picasso complained to the photographer Brassai, 'but I still think about them' - but theirs was otherwise an ideal marriage, and Picasso was a mile from a monster, Dupont coos. He was just a restless genius whom Jacqueline knew how to handle when the other women didn't. Ooh la la.'I'll see if the Maitre can receive you,' [Marina Picasso] remembers the elderly Italian concierge telling her and her father on one visit. After an 'endless' wait outside a locked gate, he reappeared. 'The Maitre can't see you today. Mme Jacqueline has asked me to tell you that he's working.' Marina's terse com-menwas: 'Even he's not fooled. He's ashamed.' The only point beyond dispute is that from 1953 Jacqueline Roque, a pottery sales lady in Vallauris, acted out with Picasso the role of Catherine Parr, sixth wife of Henry VIII. She soothed, stabilised and calmed down this lifetime seducer, as last wives do, whispering to him, 'Oh, [Pablo Picasso], you give them roses and they give you thorns,' and similar guff. In their time together at Chateau de Vauvenargues near Aix en Provence, at the Villa la Californie and at the hill farm of Notre Dame de Vie at Mougins above Cannes, Jacqueline changed into something softer, more sensuous and housewifely than the long-necked, sharp-nosed, ponytailed beauty of the 1954 portrait in the Musee Picasso. She also became, as Marina tells it, vastly manipulative.There is common ground between Marina and Mlle Dupont that [Pablito] had a very rough time. Both agree that he was treated with contempt by Picasso. In 1955, awestruck by his grandfather, he turned up, aged seven, with his younger sister at the Chateau de Vauvenargues and was told to get out and get lost. He dissolved into a lifetime's tears, as did Marina. It was the first of many humiliations Pablito received. When he appeared at Picasso's door in Mougins, he was routinely handed messages that Monseigneur was sleeping or working or eating. When he was rarely let in, he might be asked, 'How's school?' or 'Are you going away on holiday?' After this, Jacqueline would say, 'It's time to go. Pablo needs to be alone. You've made him tired.' Marina appears to have no problem with the accuracy of this. In her own memoirs in 2003 and 2007, she calls Picasso a monster, a tyrant, an egotist and a dark shadow on the lives of those around him, and claims he never showed Pablito 'the smallest affection'. He treated Pablito, she says, with 'sadism' and 'indifference'. But so, too, did Jacqueline. Marina writes in Picasso, My Grandfather that as news of Picasso's death reached the family, Pablito rushed to Mougins and rang the bell. No answer. Pablito kept ringing. A guard appeared with the Afghan hounds .MoreYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit This summer, Marina Picasso, 58, granddaughter of Picasso by his first wife Olga, returns to the courts for her favourite sport. In June she issued her fourth writ against Pepita Dupont, a Paris Match journalist and author whose own special passion in life is 'justice' for Picasso's second and last wife, Jacqueline Roque. Jacqueline has been utterly defamed and insulted by the Picasso grandchildren and by his other women, Pepita Dupont believes. She has written a bestseller to say so.The defamation of poor Jacqueline, who shot herself in 1986, is along the lines of Private Eye's nickname for the youthful Mrs Rupert Murdoch, 38 years younger than her husband: Wendi Oldmansnuffsitigetthelot. Dupont's targets on behalf of Jacqueline thus include not just Marina but half a dozen biographers who portray her as a Trojan Horse shoved into Picasso's life in his seventies to grab the pictures and the loot.Pepita Dupont met Jacqueline in 1982, four years before she killed herself, and takes a predictable line. She asserts that Jacqueline had a special role in anaesthetising and making happy the convulsive Picasso at the end of his life. She called him 'Monseigneur', 'Maitre' and 'Le Soleil'; he called her 'Mummy'; she got his teeth fixed and nursed his gall bladder and allowed his stinking goat to roam the ground floor of their house in Mougins. She was not much interested in sex - 'I have had to give up f***ing and smoking since I turned 90,' Picasso complained to the photographer Brassai, 'but I still think about them' - but theirs was otherwise an ideal marriage, and Picasso was a mile from a monster, Dupont coos. He was just a restless genius whom Jacqueline knew how to handle when the other women didn't. Ooh la la.These claims affront the amour-propre of the Picasso clan, who not only know something different about the great man's vices but remember Jacqueline with hatred for barring the door to them. Thanks to her, Picasso could only be met by appointment between 1955 and 1973 (when his heart finally stopped), not just by friends and grovellers but by his family. Guards on the gate with snarling Afghan hounds held them at bay.'I'll see if the Maitre can receive you,' Marina remembers the elderly Italian concierge telling her and her father on one visit. After an 'endless' wait outside a locked gate, he reappeared. 'The Maitre can't see you today. Mme Jacqueline has asked me to tell you that he's working.' Marina's terse com-menwas: 'Even he's not fooled. He's ashamed.' The only point beyond dispute is that from 1953 Jacqueline Roque, a pottery sales lady in Vallauris, acted out with Picasso the role of Catherine Parr, sixth wife of Henry VIII. She soothed, stabilised and calmed down this lifetime seducer, as last wives do, whispering to him, 'Oh, Pablo, you give them roses and they give you thorns,' and similar guff. In their time together at Chateau de Vauvenargues near Aix en Provence, at the Villa la Californie and at the hill farm of Notre Dame de Vie at Mougins above Cannes, Jacqueline changed into something softer, more sensuous and housewifely than the long-necked, sharp-nosed, ponytailed beauty of the 1954 portrait in the Musee Picasso. She also became, as Marina tells it, vastly manipulative.Marina asserts against Dupont that the holy Jacqueline was the cause of universal grief. What has affronted her specifically, since you might wonder how any of the above is of the smallest interest to a French judge, is a claim by Mlle Dupont in her modestly titled work The Truth about Jacqueline and Pablo Picasso (published by Le Cherche Midi in Paris but available in English) that Marina's older brother Pablito burgled his grandfather's house to steal paintings while sky-high on drugs.Marina, who clearly loved Pablito dearly, calls this defamation. It's not clear whether she is alleging no burglary or no drugs, and even less clear who is being defamed, since Pablito has been dead for 36 years and isTHE PICASSO WOMEN - The present Paris quarrels descend from the artist's first wife, the Russian ballerina Olga Khokhlova. Picasso married her in 1918. By her he had one son, Paulo, who died in 1975. Paulo Picasso gave his father three grandchildren. From his first marriage came Marina, now 58, Picasso's only legitimate living heir, and Pablito, who died in 1973, three months after swallowing bleach. From Paulo's second marriage came Bernard, now aged 50.- Olga and Picasso had separated by 1928.When Olga died in 1955, Picasso gallantly offered his hand in marriage to the mistress for whom he gave her up, Marie-Therese Walter. Marie-Therese, Picasso's lover from 1929 to 1938, by all accounts a generous lady, thanked him but refused. She bore him a child, Maya, in 1935. She hanged herself in 1977 in Juan Les Pins. In 1962, Maya had a son, Olivier, who wrote an idolising biography of Picasso.- The mistress-in-residence from 1936 to 1944 was Dora Maar, a photographer who briefly cohabited with Marie-Therese and got into a fist fight with her in 1938. She insisted to Picasso that 'one or other of us has got to go', but Picasso refused to choose between them and professed satisfaction with the situation. Marie-Therese exited, Dora won. She refused Picasso children but, being an expert black marketeer during the Second World War, kept him supplied with outstanding food and wine. Picasso left her in 1944 and she died in 1997.- Arriving circa 1943, surviving to 1954, was the art student Francoise Gilot, the only mistress to walk out on Picasso. She later expressed hatred, contempt and loathing of Picasso in a candid autobiography that the artist sought to suppress, but bore him two children, Claude, 62, and Paloma, 60. Gilot now lives between New York and Paris.- Other ladies of extreme youth, such as the Bardotesque Sylvette Jellinek and Genevieve Laporte, floated through Picasso's portraits and his life in the early 1950s, following the fashion of old men pursuing young blondes.- The girl with staying power proved to be Jacqueline Roque, a pottery sales lady in Vallauris, 45 years younger than the lecherous Picasso. She was introduced to him in 1953 by a financially interested friend who saw her as a deathbed romance. Jacqueline surfaced in his portraits from 1954: Picasso made over 400 of her. Like Dora, she gave him no children but married him in Vallauris on 2 March 1961. She magnificently stayed the course to the end and became the infinitely rich owner of a vast number of his paintings and artworks. Most of them went to the nation (the Musee Picasso in Paris) after she shot herself in 1986.beyond the reach of libel. And it is possible Marina is stronger on passion than on legal judgment, since in two of her immense previous actions against Dupont she won the gigantic damages of EUR 1 in each case. But she is angry, sans aucun doute.We won't know the detail until a judge rules in September whether the dead can claim damages. But Marina's problem with Pablito and Pepita Dupont centres on why Pablito swallowed a bottle of bleach four days after Picasso died in 1973 and thus ended his misery. La Dupont says, broadly, that he was a multiple drug addict and depressive who gave up for those reasons, but adds that he killed himself also from his undoubted hatred of Picasso. Marina says, au contraire, he killed himself from his undoubted hatred of Jacqueline. She was his wicked step-motherPicasso, 'a genius without mercy', was 'in thrall' to her.There is common ground between Marina and Mlle Dupont that Pablito had a very rough time. Both agree that he was treated with contempt by Picasso. In 1955, awestruck by his grandfather, he turned up, aged seven, with his younger sister at the Chateau de Vauvenargues and was told to get out and get lost. He dissolved into a lifetime's tears, as did Marina. It was the first of many humiliations Pablito received. When he appeared at Picasso's door in Mougins, he was routinely handed messages that Monseigneur was sleeping or working or eating. When he was rarely let in, he might be asked, 'How's school?' or 'Are you going away on holiday?' After this, Jacqueline would say, 'It's time to go. Pablo needs to be alone. You've made him tired.' Marina appears to have no problem with the accuracy of this. In her own memoirs in 2003 and 2007, she calls Picasso a monster, a tyrant, an egotist and a dark shadow on the lives of those around him, and claims he never showed Pablito 'the smallest affection'. He treated Pablito, she says, with 'sadism' and 'indifference'. But so, too, did Jacqueline. Marina writes in Picasso, My Grandfather that as news of Picasso's death reached the family, Pablito rushed to Mougins and rang the bell. No answer. Pablito kept ringing. A guard appeared with the Afghan hounds .'Go away!' he shouted. 'You can't come in. I have orders from Mme Picasso.' Pablito insisted on his wish to say goodbye.The warder turned nasty. 'Clear off!' he shouted. 'Get out of sight or I'll release the dogs!' With that, Marina narrates, he rushed out and threw Pablito's moped in a ditch.There was one final humiliation for Pablito: what caused him to drink the bleach was the ban imposed on Marina and her brother from attending Picasso's funeral.'Who barred us other than Jacqueline?' asks Marina. For Pablito, it was a rejection too far; without it, he might still be with us. He took the bleach and died in anguish three months later. But Dupont's answer differs. It was not Jacqueline but Picasso who kept the grandchildren from his funeral. He had, she says, given instructions long beforehand.Pepita Dupont attracts writs as skilfully as she attracts publicity. She has provoked the wrath not just of Marina but of Jacqueline's daughter Catherine by her previous marriage to the engineer Andre Hutin. Catherine Hutin-Blay objects to 20 passages in The Truth about Jacqueline and Pablo Picasso but notably a suggestion by Dupont that she ignored her mother's wish that 61 Picassos be presented after her death to Spain. Somehow they stayed in France. Naturally she, too, is suing for breach of privacy.Pablo Diego Jose Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno de los Remedios Cipriano de la Santisima Trinidad Clito Ruiz y Picasso is a case for Dr Freud. He does not emerge well from the memories of his descend- ants. His long shadow, his immense narcissism, caused Pablito to drink the hemlock, Jacqueline to blow her brains out, his pretty mistress Marie-Therese Walter to hang herself and Marina to spend 14 years in therapy, in which last misery Picasso was, according to Marina, totally uninterested. In 21st-century analysis and parlance, Picasso was a psychopath.'His life,' declares Marina, 'didn't centre around Pablito, or me, my father, my mother, my grandmother Olga, or the women whose deaths he brought about. There was only one thing that mattered to him: painting. In order to create, he had to destroy everything that got in the way of his creation. He had also to destroy us... we were merely the fallout from his art.' This is not quite right. There were other things that mattered to Picasso quite as much as painting. One was sex, the other money, as his snarl-ups with his dealers, notably Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler, make clear.Picasso should have married a lawyer because much of his time when not outpouring sex at the easel was spent agonising over the fate of his money after death. It paralysed him. French law prohibited 'children in adultery' from inheriting until 1972, a severe case of the sins of the father being visited on the children.The moment the barrier lifted, there began a desperate scramble among the Picasso mistresses and grandchildren to get themselves legitimised by Paris lawyers. Picasso helped by dying in the middle of it all in June 1973 - as you guessed, intestate. His principal bequest was a lawyer's paradise.The grandchildren took four years to sort it out. In the oh-we-are-so-happy account of the Picasso family by the starry-eyed Olivier (grandson by Marie-Therese), Picasso: the Real Family Story, it was all peaches and cream and a cause for congratulations by 1977.Not quite. Claude, son of Picasso and the very clever Francoise Gilot, saw trouble coming early and went to the Paris courts in 1969 for orders on distributing the Picasso estate. 'Just as if I'm dead already,' Picasso said to Jacqueline as the world concluded that he was finally ready to step into his grave. He had four years to go, on every day of which he made wildly erotic drawings. 'We must show new work or Claude will persuade them that I am dead or paralysed,' he asserted to Jacqueline. The result was a vast exhibition of bullfighters and matadors at the Palais des Papes at Avignon in 1970, a memory for Picasso admirers comparable as a legend to Damien Hirst's Freeze show in 1988.When the lawyers and notably the French taxman moved in on the Picasso estate after his death in 1973, at the front of the family queue was Paulo, the only child of the first marriage to Olga. But Paulo died in 1975 after a short and vivid spending spree on a Jaguar, a Daimler, a Bentley, several Rolls-Royces, a Range Rover and numerous Mercedes. Marina, his daughter, took his place and the largest share of the inheritance. She aimed for three-quarters of the estate but lost. She claimed Jacqueline had stashed pictures away but failed to prove it (and was herself convicted of illegal export in 1996). She tried to get all of Picasso's illegitimate children confined to half-shares, and the mistresses excluded, but failed. They all got themselves legitimised before settlement in 1976.Of the Pounds 92 million estate, Jacqueline received approximately 30 per cent, Marina and Bernard (her half-brother, Paulo's son) 20 per cent each, and Maya, Claude and Paloma (Picasso's illegitimate children) ten per cent each. For all their quarrels, the Picasso children and grandchildren are happily still cashing in. They are an enlarged nuisance to Sotheby's and Christie's and to the London, New York and Paris. art trade for regularly selling inherited paintings but demanding high prices. A line in the London art trade is that what the family owns are the pictures Picasso couldn't sell. 'He got every penny for a picture he could lay hands on in his lifetime,' comments a Chelsea dealer. In other words, the family possessions aren't that brilliant and Sotheby's and Christie's have failed to sell a number of them .Nevertheless, the descendants also cash in magnificently from the EU tax called droit de suite, or 'right of followers' - in this case, their right to claim up to four per cent on every sale within Europe of an artwork created in the last 70 years: Pounds 5 million at auction? The family gets Pounds 250,000. There are more than 200 sales a year at auction of Picasso's paintings and drawings. Galleries in London and Paris. do as many.Whatever the grief, tragedy, vulnerability and shattered lives of Maya, Francoise, Marina, Claude, Paloma and Olivier, they have this comfort to keep them warm on dark nights and long days in court, while they continue to fight over their tragic and wonderful legacy.beyond the reach of libel. [...]Guards on the gate with snarling Afghan hounds held Picasso's grandchildren at bayA line in the London art trade is that what the family owns are the pictures Picasso couldn't sellCredit: Words by Godfrey BarkerIllustrationCaption: From top: Portrait of Olga in an Armchair, 1917; Reading, 1932; Portrait of Dora Maar, 1937; Portrait of Francoise Gilot, 1947-48; Portrait of Jacqueline Roque with Roses, 1954; Opposite page: Picasso and Jacqueline at Mougins in 1969. Above, from top: Pablito Picasso, in hospital in Antibes after a suicide attempt, with his sister Marina and mother Emilienne Lotte; Marina with a Picasso portrait of her grandmother Olga Khokhlova, in 2002; Camera Press. Rex Features. Corbis. Portraits Pablo Picasso/(c) DACS/The Bridgeman Art Library; Surviving Picasso; Thtruth about Jacqueline: author Pepita Dupont (above); Above from far left: Marina and Pablito in the mid-1950s; the Chateau de Vauvenargues near Aix en Provence. Right: Picasso and Jacqueline in Mougins in 1969; Rex Features. Corbis. Title: Abstract

Pablo Picasso once said: "Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up." It's a struggle that seems to go with the territory and which acclaimed local artist Nicola Russell almost succumbed to.: Acclaimed Northern Ireland artist Nicola Russell talks about her stunning art and reveals how her work helped her to win her breast cancer fight. By Stephanie Bell

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPablo Picasso once said: "Every child is an artist. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up." It's a struggle that seems to go with the territory and which acclaimed local artist Nicola Russell almost succumbed to.As a young, struggling artist making no money, Nicola, now 47, was at one point forced to give up her painting to try and make a living in the "real world".Thankfully after just a year of doing odd jobs she was drawn back to the easel and has since built up an international reputation for her work, which has been praised by royalty and presidents.Her journey has been unconventional, driven by her passion rather than any desire to make her fortune, an approach that has earned her recognition for a series of high-profile paintings.A battle with breast cancer in 2007 reinforced for her the importance of enjoying life and persuaded her to fulfil a lifetime's ambition of doing a large-scale painting.One of her favourite subjects is horses and in spring 2009 she launched a campaign called The Big Horse Project with the Irish Field, Horse Racing Ireland and The Irish Times to find the nation's favourite race horse of the last 25 years.Horse lovers voted in their thousands and with no commission and taking a year and a half to complete, she produced a massive 10ft by 13ft canvas of Ireland's favourite racehorse -- Istabraq.The magnificent portrait was finally unveiled on May 3 this year in the parade ring at the Punchestown Irish National Hunt Festival by Istabraq's famous owner JP McManus, trainer Aidan O'Brien and jockey Charlie Swan.Now, the huge canvas has just gone on public display at Dublin Airport.It's the latest high in an eventful career that saw Nicola earn early acclaim as an artist when commissioned to paint a portrait of Bill Clinton to commemorate his visit to Belfast. It was unveiled in a fanfare of publicity by Senator George Mitchell.In 1998 she met the Queen when she was invited to present her with her painting Wild Irish Colt at a reception for the arts at Windsor Castle.A year later there was more press attention when she presented Mo Mowlam with a portrait and in the same year she became the first artist to exhibit in the windows of Brown Thomas in Dublin.But it could all have been so different as, at the age of 30, a disheartened Nicola reluctantly decided that she could not longer sustain her art as a way of supporting herself and gave it up in search of a more secure income.She recalls those early years after she graduated from Winchester School of Art: "You come out of college in your early 20s burning with enthusiasm and convinced you are going to be the next Picasso."You work your way through the system applying for Arts Council grants and trying to get exhibitions in public galleries because that's what you are trained to do."Your enthusiasm carries you through even though you are making no money and pretty much starving in the garret."You are living this life as an artist, all quite bohemian and fun and then reality hits and you have to start to think about the future and how you are going to survive."It's at that point that a lot of artists give up and go into teaching or other professions."I knew I needed to make money and so I tried training in IT, I did window dressing and various other jobs for a year."Nicola grew up in Portadown but now lives in Belfast, where she has her own studio and gallery in Queen Street.Her dad George is a retired vet and her mum Jill ran The Irish Times office in Belfast. She has one brother, Richard, who lives in California, and a sister, Gail, who lives in Newquay.Although not married, her partner of eight years, Kenny Body, works alongside her as director of her studio.As well as portraits and horses, Nicola is well known for beautiful paintings of flowers, which are what drew her back to her passion after her year of trying to pursue a career outside of her art.She explains: "I had this impulse to paint the flowers in my mother's garden, it was like an impulse you get to go for a walk or have dinner, and I couldn't ignore it."At first I resisted because there was no cerebral content in them but because of the love of what I was seeing I decided to do it."I did several and people either wanted to buy them or told me I should try and sell them so I did an exhibition and they sold out."This encouraged Nicola to set up her first studio, which she opened in the Farset Enterprise Centre on the Springfield Road in Belfast.She was 33 and applied for a LEDU start-up course to learn about business and also decided to join the Belfast Chamber of Commerce and the Federation of Small Businesses."I immersed myself in and surrounded myself with business people as I really liked their work ethic and I learnt so much from them."It was through her business contacts that she was commissioned to do the portrait of President Bill Clinton, a painting that catapulted her as an artist into the public eye.After two years in Belfast she moved to a new studio in Holywood where she decided to do a portrait of Mo Mowlam, again with no financial gain but purely out of admiration for the then Secretary of State.She recalls: "I admired her enormously and she was getting quite a lot of criticism at the time from politicians for going into prison to talk to paramilitaries."I felt very strongly that she had put her career on the line and shown incredible courage and I was aggrieved that she was not being acknowledged for that."I did the portrait and she came to the gallery in Holywood and there was a massive turnout."At the time she was terminally ill but hadn't told anyone. She seemed to love it and I was really glad that I had done it."Later, I was told by someone who had been at her house that she had it hanging over her mantelpiece, which made me realise that she really must have liked it."In November 2007, Nicola completed a portrait of Baroness May Blood MBE which was also unveiled by Senator George Mitchell, Chancellor of Queen's and which now hangs in the University's Great Hall.In the same year her world was rocked when she was diagnosed with breast cancer.The news was all the more shocking because she had no lump and her symptoms were of the kind not normally associated with breast cancer.She said: "I always thought breast cancer was detected by a lump. I had noticed that my nipple appeared to have flattened and wasn't really concerned about it; I just thought it was maybe down to my age and my body shape changing."It then became sore and I developed a bit of a rash so I went to the doctor; it wasn't my usual GP and she told me that I had an infection and gave me antibiotics."It didn't clear up and I went back and pretty much insisted that I needed to see someone about it, although I still didn't think for one minute it was cancer."A week later she was in the Ulster Hospital where a biopsy was carried out and results delivered that same day revealed a cancerous tumour.Nicola had to have her breast removed and then received the strongest course of chemotherapy available, followed by radiotherapy.During her illness she walked every day and it was during her walks that she became acutely aware of the sound of the birds around her.This led to her doing a series of paintings on endangered birds and last month she donated a series of spectacular prints of the Yellow Hammer to raise funds for the Ulster Cancer Foundation and Friends of the Cancer Centre.She says: "The Yellow Hammer is so sweet and he just made me laugh when I looked at him and he summed up how I was feeling -- so grateful to be alive and able to appreciate what was around me."When I was ill, I received counselling from Dorothy Smallwood of the Ulster Cancer Foundation, who sadly passed away from cancer last August."She helped me so much. You can cope with the physical stuff but the emotional upset is harder to deal with."I wanted to do something to ensure that other people can benefit from the service and money raised from the prints will go towards helping to fund the counselling service."Nicola's Yellow Hammer prints were launched at a special event in the Ulster Museum last month, hosted by the Duke and Duchess of Abercorn and sponsored by Cleaver, Fulton and Rankin.Nicola adds: "When you face something like cancer, it changes you. I wake up happy every day because I have that sense of being alive. You become very grateful for what you have and you learn not to waste time worrying."To buy a print and support the Ulster Cancer Foundation contact Maeve Fox, tel: 028 9066 3281 or email maevefox@ulstercancer.org.IllustrationCaption: SURE BET: Nicola, JP McManus, Charlie Swan and Aidan O'Brien with the Istabraq canvasCAMPAIGN: Nicola and The Duke and Duchess of Abercorn with her Yellow Hammer prints that are raising funds for the Ulster Cancer FoundationUNVEILING: George Mitchell and Baroness Mary Blood at Queen'sADMIRER: mo loved the portrait (left) that Nicola painted for hersupport: Nicola and the QueenHIGH PROFILE: Nicola with Bill Clinton and (left) her portraitWord count: 1646Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitThe face seems familiar, likewise the mantilla. The woman on the screen is clearly Spanish, maybe at a bullfight. At any rate, she is wearing a veil, a comb and an arch expression, and she's smoking. She folds her lipsticked mouth into a moue, bats her eyelids, flicks a lighted match at the camera. Then it strikes you where you've seen this vamp before: that she is Pablo Picasso, and that he's dressed in the role of Carmen.There may be more unlikely drag artistes than Picasso, though few spring easily to mind. Macho is a Spanish word meaning male or virile, and Picasso - cradle-snatching, bullfighting, eternally priapic Pablo - was the living embodiment of both. Yet here he is, not just in a veil but bridling and pouting, in a short film by Man Ray called La Garoupe (1937). The movie takes you aback, though by the time you reach it your ideas about Picasso may already have changed.The film is the last work in a show called Picasso - Carmen, which traces the artist's interest in the titular cigar girl. In Madrid in 1898, long before he went to Paris, Picasso produced a sketch called Carmen. Its subject was to recur in his work, directly and indirectly, for the next 70 years, culminating in a series of illustrations to Merimee's novella made in the 1960s.This seems an unlikely f ixation for a man who led his life like a character from Hemingway, and yet, as you walk through this show, Picasso's love for the gypsy seems inevitable. Most obviously, her story brings together the two stars in his firmament, women and bulls. Picasso's reclaiming of Carmen also has a national flavour. For Merimee and Bizet (and particularly for Picasso's hero, Manet), "Spanish" was a synonym for "exotic". Taking Carmen back from the French - repossessing her mantillas, her camp, her ineffably Spanish kitsch - counts as something in the way of justice for a Spaniard working in Paris.More surprising is what this kitsch meant to Picasso. As I've said, he was the soul of machismo, and yet objects from his archive hint at something more equivocal. The show opens with Picasso's collection of postcards of toreadors and maja - portraits of Francisco Madrid, girlish in powder blue and sequins; of a dancer called "La Preciosilla", her gaze stronger than the toreador's, more manly. This gender-bending continues with a series of erotic cards in which male bullfighters with female genitals wave capes at penises on legs. Hemingway was never like this, and nor, until now, was Picasso.Aptly, the first work in Picasso - Carmen is not by Picasso but by Manet, his cod-Hispanic Angelina. It's tempting to see the role played by Carmen in Picasso's oeuvre as roughly that of Olympe in Manet's. Both women, sexually free-wheeling, challenge the stereotype of masculine dominance which both men seem to back up.Once you spot this self-subversion in Picasso's work, you see it everywhere: in the Carmen-esque mantilla worn by Dora Maar in a 1937 cliche-verre; in the extraordinary Corrida: la mort de la femme torero (1933), where the implied femininity of toreadors is made actual. The gender of the actors in Picasso's pictures shift about. Sometimes his horses are mares, sometimes stallions; Europa is raped by a bull, but the bull-man in The Vanquished Minotaur is un-manned by a woman. The womanliness of Francisco Madrid has its equal in the Michelangelesque shoulders of Picasso's Standing Female Nude (1906- 7), in the columnar neck of his 1903 Head of a Woman. Even Picasso's marriage is open to gender reassignment, his 1955 photograph in the guise of a torero being matched by one of his second wife, Jacqueline, in identical costume. And then, of course, there is La Garoupe.What does all of this add up to? One of the clever things about this show is that it makes no great claims for itself. There is little in the way of signage, less of polemic in its wonderfully camp catalogue. There are no hints at funny goings-on in Picasso's bedroom, nor of unrealised desires in his life. Picasso - Carmen is, as the French say, a jeu d'esprit, as witty in its way as its subject's art.It is also something more than that. It has certainly changed the way I think about Picasso, and is likely to change the way you do.To 24 June (00 33 1 42 71 70 84, www.musee-picasso.fr)Word count: 767Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitPicasso and the Camera Gagosian Gallery (W. 21st St., NY) Through Jan. 3, 2015 New York -- 'Picasso and the Camera," organized for the Gagosian Gallery by John Richardson (in partnership with Bernard Ruiz-Picasso), is so stuffed with drawings and paintings guaranteed to satisfy hungry eyes and minds that one feels ungrateful in pointing out that the exhibition never actually fulfills its claim that the artist devoted a lot of thought or effort to photography. As they have proved in spectacular fashion before, when Gagosian teams with Mr. Richardson, Picasso's foremost biographer, they can elicit quality loans. This joint venture is no different. The wall of drawings from 1908-10, on the left as you walk in, is mostly borrowed from private collections. Picasso's cubist studies -- in which he methodically breaks down the continuous human figure, including the eyes and ears, and forges the parts into stronger, baser elements -- are often more enjoyable to behold than the finished result. Cubism was a way to replicate and remake the appearance of all things, as was photography. Mr. Richardson proposes that the automatic abstracting found in black-and-white printing aided in Picasso's and Braque's visual revolution. To back up the argument, the catalog reproduces a 1982 article from the Art Bulletin by Paul Hayes Tucker, then professor of art history at the University of Massachusetts, Boston, in which he suggests that a 1909 group of photographs taken by Picasso in Spain may stand behind the cubist landscapes he painted that summer in Horta de Ebro. Two paintings cited by Mr. Tucker -- one from the Museum of Modern Art, one from the Denver Art Museum -- hang here next to two of those photographs. Viewers can decide whether the rooftops going every which way and the canted perspective in the monochrome prints shaped the tightly interlocking planes in the brown-green-gray painting "Le Reservoir." Mr. Tucker was careful not to overstate the impact of Picasso's photography on the work, concluding that "all of this, of course, remains somewhat speculative; there were many other influences that Picasso synthesized that summer." A vitrine nearby features his snapshots of his paintings from this period. The fact that as a young artist he wanted to document his work in photographs is more telling than the photographs themselves, which are small and in many cases faded. Picasso developed a mania to date everything he did, and the camera aided in the chronicling of his legend. As he told the photographer Brassai in the 1960s -- in words that sanctioned the attention of biographers like Mr. Richardson -- "it's not enough to know an artist's works. One must also know when he made them, why, how, under what circumstances." In the photographs Picasso took and the even greater number taken of him, the show also traces his active social life, as well as his marital, and extramarital, relationships. There are smiling portraits of his first wife, the ballerina Olga Khokhlova, from 1917, as well as less happy ones done a few years later. Sergei Diaghilev, Leonide Massine, Natalia Goncharova and Jean Cocteau have cameo roles in snapshots of larky excursions in Paris, Rome, Barcelona and Monte Carlo. Playing on four monitors in the center of the room are loops of home movies from the 1930s (one taken by Man Ray) that capture Picasso with friends on vacation in the south of France. Other shorter clips show him as doting father, with his son Paul, and as owner of a Great Pyrenees, a dog almost bigger than he is. The series of photographs Picasso made in 1931 at the Chateau de Boisgeloup (on the back wall at Gagosian) had a more serious purpose: He wanted to catalog the constant alterations he was making to the clay sculptures based on his mistress Marie-Therese Walter. For the first time, he seems careful about lighting and angles. In a photograph of Olga posed outside his studio, where the bust of Walter is visible behind her, he may even be leaving clues for posterity -- and making a cruel joke -- about where his true feelings lay. (When Brassai's photographs of these phallic sculptures were published in the surrealist magazine Minotaure, in 1933, they created a sensation.) Picasso also at times relied on photographic images as source material for paintings. Jean Painleve's underwater film documentaries from the late 1920s were beloved by the surrealists, and Mr. Richardson suggests a connection between one of them, about an octopus, and "Femme nue couchee," a 1932 portrait of Walter with arms like tentacles. The 357 photographic reproductions of archaic Greek sculpture in Christian Zervos's 1934 book "L'art en Grece" likely inspired Picasso's sculptures and drawings around the same time. But beyond these examples, there isn't much here to back up the statement in the press release that Picasso used photography as "an integral part of his studio practice." He didn't pick up a camera to explore its unique potential for picture-making, as did, say, Degas and Brancusi. Nor was he curious how it might serve to open a door to the uncanny, an obsession of his lover Dora Maar and of Man Ray. The largest part of the show, fascinating in its own right, documents how Picasso exploited photographers -- and they him -- in creating the myth of the protean genius with the bald head and burning gaze. A celebrity before he was 30, he sustained that status to the end of his life and beyond, thanks in no small part to photography and film. Picasso had his portrait taken more often than any other 20th-century artist (except probably Andy Warhol) and many of those who helped to burnish his image -- Brassai, Lucien Clergue, Arnold Newman, Edward Quinn, Jacques-Henri Lartigue, Man Ray, Andre Villers -- are included here. Filmmakers played their part, too. In 1949, two years before Jackson Pollock did a painting on a sheet of glass for Hans Namuth's camera, Picasso drew with a light stick for Gjon Mili and Life magazine. Bare-chested, wielding his pen like a sword, the middle-aged artist is like an athlete who doesn't imagine that he might ever make a mistake. One feels the swaggering self-confidence that intoxicated so many who entered his circle. Dora Maar's photographs of him from the mid-'30s (some only in the catalog) reveal a more inward-looking man and are more sensitive than any Picasso took of others. Perhaps because during their intense love affair she was using photography to explore surrealist effects, he didn't see a need to compete with her. Or perhaps he didn't think that a mechanical device could do much for his hand-generated art. Mr. Richardson says that the idea for "Picasso and the Camera" began with a work (found on the gallery's right wall) that he owns and that adorned the cover of the third volume of his biography. It is a pencil portrait of Picasso done in 1921 by his lover Valentine Hugo. When she photographed it in 1937 and presented it to him, he drew motifs from "Guernica" around his chin, like a beard. Such treatment does not indicate a high regard for photographs as objects. They were just another material to rework with his pen, much the same way that he cut up Andre Villers's prints with his scissors for their 1962 collaborative series, "Diurnes." It is hard not to conclude from this generous display that Picasso used the camera mainly to document his progress as a towering artist, and that the images he made with this slavish tool are more precious to art historians and biographers than they ever were to him. --- Mr. Woodward is an arts critic in New York. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitJesus Fuertes, a Spanish cubist painter and protége of Pablo Picasso whose works have been exhibited in prominent museums around the world, died of heart failure on June 18. He was 68. Born in Madrid during the Spanish Civil War, Mr. Fuertes was exposed to great artists early in life because his father associated with surrealist Salvador Dali and poet-dramatist Frederico Garcia Lorca. Dali introduced the younger Fuertes to Andre Breton, father of the surrealist movement. Mr. Fuertes met Picasso in France and delved into neo-cubism, mixing geometric shapes with bright colors. Several of his most well-known works involved the use of stunning shades of blue, which earned him the moniker "Painter of Blue." He often chose women or cats as his subject matter.His works can be found around the world, including in Queen Sofia of Spain's museum in Madrid, the Beaux Arts Museum in Brussels and the Contemporary Art Museum in Vienna. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitIt's been almost 60 years since the National Gallery in Ottawa last exhibited all 100 prints in Pablo Picasso's Vollard Suite. Perhaps the master's most celebrated series of etchings, the suite, named after Ambroise Vollard (1866-1939), Picasso's early dealer and publisher, was purchased by a savvy NGC in 1957 and displayed to the public shortly thereafter. Individual prints and grouplets thereof have been exhibited since then, but never the complete set. The NGC rectifies the lacuna Friday when it presents all 100 prints in an exhibition running through Sept. 5. The suite, commissioned in 1930 by Vollard, who "paid" Picasso in paintings by Cézanne and Renoir, was completed in 1937. However, printing the estimated 300 or so sets wasn't done until 1939, by which time Vollard was dead and the Second World War in full swing. It was only in the mid-1950s that the sets finally were distributed, the NGC being one of the few museums in the world to acquire the entire ensemble.Word count: 175Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Pablo Picasso: Print as an Original Art Form
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitAlan Cristea Gallery, LondonHere is Christmas shopping for the few (prices start at pound(s)6,000) and for everyone else a delightful, intimate accompaniment to the NPG's Picasso Portraits show. Sourced from private owners, this selection of etchings, aquatints, lithographs and linocuts spans Picasso's graphic output in every medium and concentrates almost entirely on the figure, often with overt eroticism.From the Vollard Suite in 1933 are crisp line drawings in playful mood depicting sculptor and model, and compositions illumined by painterly washes of light and darkness when the sculptor morphs into the monstrous though gentle Minotaur. He contemplates the soft flesh of his sleeping lover, recognisably languid, supple Marie-Therese Walter, in the marvellous "Minotaure caressant une dormeuse": "he is studying her, trying to read her thoughts . . . trying to decide whether she loves him because he's a monster," Picasso explained.The lithographs "Les Deux Femmes Nues", made in 1945-6 during Picasso's relationship with Francoise Gilot, are more cerebral, exploring how the form of a double portrait can evolve from intricate, traditional representation to a thoroughly cubist, abstracted image at the end of the series. Coloured linocuts of Gilot's successor Jacqueline Roque experiment similarly with flattened stylisation and extravagant 16th-century fancy dress: "Portrait Stylise de Jacqueline", "La Dame a la Collerette (Portrait de Jacqueline a la Fraise)". Most poignant is the "347" series (1968), dramatising impotence and women's power over men in comic old age narratives - "Petit Vieux Flatte par la Celestine", "Grosse Prostituee et Mousquetaire". "I enjoy myself no end inventing these stories," Picasso said, "and I spend hour after hour while I draw, observing my creatures and thinking about the mad things they're up to." alancristea.com, 020 7439 1866 to January 7 Credit: By Jackie WullschlagerWord count: 290Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitFEBRUARY ON the East Coast can be gloomy. During these hibernating days, the frozen garden offers little color to cut and bring indoors. So when the time came to choose a piece of art to serve as this month's inspiration, I sought out something vivid, playful and mood-elevating. A number of factors conspired to lead me to "The Red Armchair" (1931), a painting by Pablo Picasso (1881-1973). I had recently seen an exhibit of his sculptures at New York's Museum of Modern Art, so he was on my mind. I'd also come across a white earthenware vessel, known as the Medusa vase, by ceramist Frances Palmer. The wriggly stripes she'd pinched into the clay and the looping handles recalled Picasso's work in general and specifically the face in this painting, a canvas that met my criteria for February-doldrums-banishing. Vessels are important. They should give you as much joy empty as full, and different styles serve different functions: Straight-sided shapes give flowers a vertical modern rigor; a form that nips and flares, like an ironstone pitcher, lets blooms fall horizontally for a looser, romantic look. From the flower market and a local deli I sourced a bold mix of purple anemones, yellow roses, red parrot tulips, orange kumquat cuttings with green leaves, deep plum ninebark and nandina foliage. I then grouped hues to reference the canvas's color blocking. The yellows and oranges on the painting's left were supplied by roses and kumquats. Anemones and ninebark evoke the upper right quadrant, and red tulips mimic the stripes. To give depth to the floral tableau, I tucked another of Ms. Palmer's vases, porcelain in sang de boeuf glaze, to the left and let a single red tulip drape over the rim. This spirited, intense mix of colors--some from blooms, some from citrus--successfully dispelled even the most ferocious February cabin fever. Credit: By Lindsey TaylorWord count: 311Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Printing Pablo Picasso
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitIndia, Nov. 12 -- Nothing like the memory of a jealous lover to set fire going for a prestigious art exhibition. The event in this case was the ongoing Vollard Suite show at the Instituto Cervantes in New Delhi, which has on display 100 prints by the Spanish artist, no he was not French, Pablo Picasso. They were created by Picasso, undoubtedly the Father of Contemporary Art, as copper etching plates for art dealer Ambroise Vollard, who gave Picasso his first solo exhibition at Vollard's gallery in Paris.Commissioned between 1930-37, the prints were categorised under different themes Picasso dealt with earlier. The Battle of Love (five images), Rembrandt (four images), The Sculptors Studio (46 images), The Minotaur and The Blind Minotaur (15 images) and lastly, three portraits of Vollard. There were to have been more, but Vollard, an art dealer and a publisher, died in a 1939 car accident. The etching plates went to one Henri Petiet and changed hands several times. The collection last belonged to an art dealer named Mrs Kahnweiller. So we were told by Alberto Manzano Martos, President of the Institute of Culture MAPFRE, who now own the lot.While showing us around the temperature controlled gallery at the Spanish Cultural Centre which is located on 48 Hanuman Road, Martos shared with us it was only the second time the exhibits had travelled from Spain. "The first show outside was in Columbia." He added that The Sculptor's Studio section was particularly interesting, "because it revealed the sculptor's relationship with the model, parallelling Picasso's relations with his much younger lover, Marie-Therese. And also how he tried to transform his sculptural work to this other medium."He then indicated that one of The Minotaur prints had a screaming, disfigured face in the background and we laughed wickedly at the misery of the jealous lover preserved for posterity, as he shared "it was an irate Olga Kohklova." Picasso was married Kohklova at the time of his affair with Marie-Therese. Martos also added that "back in Spain, the etchings are not regularly open to the public being extremely sensitive to light. So, if they are exposed one day, then they are left for the next three or more in the dark."For a short history on the copper etchings which Picasso had done in exchange for paintings by famous artists he wished to own, you might be interested to know the artist was then based in Paris, where he spent most of his life. And he was around 50 when he began to do them. He was also between the women in his life, as he constantly seemed to be. Much has been written about Picasso's various wive's and mistresses. They have also been remembered in film. The famous ones include model Ferdnande Oliver, Eva Grouel, Olga Kohklova, Marie Therese Walter, Dora Maar and Francois Gilot.In 1930, Picasso had begun to have affair with the Rubenesque 20-year-old Marie Therese, by whom he had a son. He was also spending time with Olga Kokhlova whom he had married in 1918. Eva Gouel was dead of tubercolosis and he was yet to begin another tempestuous relationship with Yugoslavia photographer Dora Maar whom he would meet in 1936.The Sculptor's Studio etchings mainly represent the period with Marie Theresa who inspired them and of whom he made plaster sculpture models. They seem to have been somewhat derived in treatment from the classical fable about sculptor-king Pygmalion who fell in love with a statue he made of the woman, Galatea. Similarly, The Minotaur series, which often represent the artist as the brutish Minotaur, also contain classical references that possibly resulted from trips Picasso made in his younger days to cities like Naples, Pompeii and Rome.His smaller series on Rembrandt is a tribute to the Dutch master who was himself a fine etcher. Hardcore art buffs will probably be interested in some of the techniques this innovator par excellence applied, like the 'sugar lift' which gave some of his etchings a deeper tone.Picasso usually began his work with a line etching, then adding both drypoint and aquatint for a light-dark effect. Incidentally each plates produced 313 prints, with Vollard or Picasso's watermark on 260 of them, on a paper known as Montval. They are in the possession of around five museums.A further 50 of the etchings were printed on paper about 2 inches in length and breadth. It appears that there are apparently three signed copies on parchment, but they are not available to the public.Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. Title: Memories of pablo Picasso
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... Antony's talk begins at 7pm in the Gulbenkian Cinema, Canterbury. Tickets are priced at Pounds 6.50 per person, with concessions at Pounds 4.50. The title is taken from a self-portrait Picasso painted in 1901, when he was 19 years old.Surviving Picasso In this 1996 biopic, Picasso (Anthony Hopkins, right) is an older man in his 60s, but he still has plenty of lust for life, and for women. The story is told from the point of view of his lover and muse of ten years, Francoise Gilot (Natascha McElhone); she was the mother of his children Claude and Paloma, and was also a writer and critic.Modigliani Set in Paris in 1919, this 2004 biopic of Italian artist Amedeo Modigliani (Andy Garcia) charts how the friendship between Modigliani and Picasso (played by British comedian Omid Djalili, right) develops into a rivalry over a competition that both artists are drunkenly coerced into entering.33 Dias Antonio Banderas is developing a film about the 1937 antiwar mural Guernica, which took Picasso 33 days (33 dias) to paint in oils. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit NEW DELHI, India, Feb 10 -- On Wednesday evening, to get to the first sale of Pablo Picasso in India, one had to first negotiate the maddening traffic of Okhla at rush hour to get to the brand new Vadehra Art Gallery. The exhibition cum sale, of course, seemed worth it for some collectors, artists and art dealers as 10 of the 40 Picasso-signed knick-knacks (mostly prints and ceramics) were picked up. The exhibition was curated by London's Grosvenor Gallery, the gallery's trading partner. Conor Macklin, the representative from Grosvenor, said that though he usually disassociated himself from reproductions, "Picasso's influence as a printmaker was immense." Picasso made more than 1,000 prints including etchings, engravings, drypoints, woodcuts, lithographs and lino cuts and almost single-handedly returned printmaking's centre to France. This sale, worth Rs 9 crore, will be on till March 2 and the month-long exhibition will include nine drawings, 11 lithographs, seven etchings, four aquatints, two linocuts, two round dish prints and a set of eight ceramic plates. While the National Museum did hold an impressive Picasso exhibition in 2002, where 120-odd works were displayed, this is the first time that a private gallery has brought an important European master. That too, for sale. Present from the Capital's artist fraternity were Gopi Gajwani, Satish Gujral with wife Kiran, Arpita and Paramjit Singh, A Ramachandran as well as sculptor K S Radhakrishnan. Also seen browsing were artist Blanca Peralta, fashionista Nainika Karan, Palette Art Gallery's Rohit Gandhi and former diplomat Bhaichand Patel. The Hindustan Times is provided through HT Syndication, New Delhi.Word count: 271Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. A childhood with Pablo Picasso
