[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Watch the video on nelsonmail.co.nzNot many people can say they have bitten Picasso or had him bite them back but Antony Penrose, who grew up with famous artists for friends, can.Penrose, the son of English surrealist painter Sir Roland Penrose and American model-turned- photojournalist Lee Miller, had the unique experience of growing up on a farm in the English countryside that was frequented by many artists, including Pablo Picasso and Joan Miro.Penrose, who lives in England, is travelling throughout the country as a guest of the Decorative and Fine Arts Societies of New Zealand. He is on a lecture circuit and speaking to children where he can about his books, The Boy Who Bit Picasso and the soon-to-be released Miro's Magic Animals.Penrose, who wrote a children's book about the time he bit Picasso as a youngster, entertained kids at Lake Rotoiti School with stories about growing up with famous artists for friends.He was pleased to have had the opportunity to visit the school yesterday to share some of the stories from his books."I think it is the most delightful school I have been to in the world," he said."Such a wonderful strength and vision."Penrose has many stories about his time spent with Picasso including tales of Picasso's many pet animals and the time Penrose did indeed bite the famous artist on the arm during a pretend bull fighting game, after which Picasso bit him right back.He said Miro was a quiet and friendly man who loved painting animals and they had visited London Zoo together.Growing up among famous artists was a great influence on the young Penrose - it encouraged him to remain curious and look for the deeper meaning within images and objects, he said."I think if I came away with anything it was a kind of automatic reaction to always try and look beneath the surface of things to see what else was going on," Penrose said."Why does it interest Picasso or Miro or whoever else, to make this thing that he did. What was he communicating to us?"That curiosity is evident in his two children's books, which are both filled with paintings, drawings and photographs that tell the stories and adventures he shared with the famous artists. It is that curious spirit that he encourages in children, his books introduce art and adult subjects in a way they can understand."The trick is, I think, if you can just get the children's attention by appealing to them on a child's level then the art just goes in naturally and they just take to it," he said."[Art] is readily understandable by children, I think they have an easier time with it than adults."He has another two books in the pipeline, Molly The Cat Who Loved Opera, based on a true story about a stray cat who called Glyndebourne Opera house home and My Surrealist Mum, that describes living in a home frequented by different artists. The house in which he grew up, Farley Farm in East Sussex is now a museum and Penrose has been dedicated to curating his mother's photographic work and taking it to exhibitions around the world.One of those exhibitions brought him to New Zealand in 1995 and he hopes to bring another exhibition of his mother's down under in 2018."It was before Lee Miller had reached the elevation that she has now yet she was still very well received and accepted here in this country which was rather touching," he said.As a child, he recalls being drawn to photographs of the New Zealand landscape, it became an ambition to travel here, one that was fulfilled in his 20s when he travelled throughout the country in the early 1970s, spending some time working in Auckland."I had always been drawn to the photographs of New Zealand as a youngster. The mountains and wild, wild beaches and things like that made me think as a kid, that [New Zealand] would be a wonderful place ... that certainly stayed with me and the ambition has never been disappointed."Credit: SAMANTHA GEEIllustrationCaption: Antony Penrose, author of The Boy Who Bit Picasso. Title: Abstract
PABLO PICASSO ARTIST OF THE CENTURY
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitA stunning exhibition of one of the greatest art figures of the modern era is expected to lure visitors in their droves to the National Gallery of Victoria Pablo Picasso was a genius but was he also a dirty old man? That may be the wrong question to ask about the Spaniard who changed the course of 20th century art but in the age of cancel culture it’s a question that has been posed, appropriately or not. In the era of #MeToo his apparent chauvinism has been highlighted and even harped on by some. But, as they say in the movies, it’s complicated. Picasso, who died in 1973 aged 91, had many relationships, some of them torrid and troubled and he even admitted to one mistress that he found it hard to relate to women other than as “goddesses or doormats”. His personality, relationships and artistic legacy will be discussed in the public program that is part of National Gallery of Victoria’s landmark exhibition The Picasso Century at the NGV International until October 9. The man who created and curated the show, Didier Ottinger, deputy director of the Musee national d’art moderne, Centre Pompidou, Paris, says the exhibition is, among other things, “an answer to many of the criticisms now being addressed about Picasso”. “There are some very fierce feminists who have called him a misogynist and violent and so on,” Ottinger says during a whirlwind tour of the exhibition. “But what you will discover in this show is that he was very sensitive, emotional and you just look at his work and you can see that. It’s not the work of an aggressive man. He is passionate, yes, and of course he was macho … he was from the south of Spain. If you really want to understand his feelings just listen to flamenco music. “I hope this exhibition will show who Picasso really was and that might calm things down a bit.” It will also excite people too because it is an extraordinary cavalcade of 20th century art charting the amazing career of Picasso in dialogue with many artists, poets and intellectuals with whom he interacted in his adopted city of Paris including Guillaume Apollinaire, Georges Braque, Salvador Dali and Gertrude Stein. Developed exclusively for the NGV by the Centre Pompidou and the Musee national Picasso-Paris, the exhibition features 80 works by Picasso alongside 100 by more than 60 of his contemporaries. Curated by Ottinger, The Picasso Century sprawls across the ground floor at the NGV International in Melbourne as it examines the diverse influences, encounters and collaborative relationships that steered Picasso through many distinct artistic periods such as his Blue Period, Cubism and Surrealism and it draws lines between Picasso’s famous creations and the world around him. Somewhat ironically the exhibition, part of the NGV’s Melbourne Winter Masterpieces series, could be said to have had its genesis in Brisbane where NGV director Tony Ellwood served as director of QAGOMA – he was the man who put the then brand-new Gallery of Modern Art (GOMA) on the map. “I made an exhibition for Brisbane devoted to Surrealism with Tony,” Ottinger says. “That’s when we began working together. Then he moved to Melbourne and said, ‘We have to do something of the same period with the masterpieces from Paris.’ We thought, ‘What shall we do?’ Then we thought, ‘We will do Picasso and the 20th century, let’s go.’” Ellwood was keen to get it done as soon as possible but Ottinger warned it would take a while. In fact it took a decade to secure the right works but it was worth the wait he says. “Now this is the occasion for anyone interested in 20th century art,” Ottinger insists. “You come to this show and you will not only know Picasso, the genius, but you will see him in context and get a whole new idea of Picasso.” Ellwood says he wanted something special and was prepared to wait. “I did ask why I had to wait that long though,” he points out. “To request key works was difficult. Didier said if we wait 10 years we will get everything we want. He has created a unique thesis for Melbourne and an exhibition that has never happened before.” Ellwood says with interstate travel back on the agenda he’s hoping people from Brisbane and elsewhere will make the trek to Melbourne for a bit of cultural tourism. With that in mind the gallery has partnered with Sofitel Melbourne on Collins which is part of a French hotel group located at what is, fortuitously, known as “the Paris end of Collins St”. Of course Picasso made his career in the French capital and Sofitel Melbourne on Collins has recently revamped rooms with French style in mind and incorporated French inspired photography in its new guest rooms. It has also created a Spanish themed lunch menu as a tribute to Picasso, available from July. The chef is working on the finer details of the Picasso Winter Lunch menu; each dish will have a link to Pablo Picasso and they’re working on the content that will be included on the printed menus. The NGV International meanwhile has refashioned its Garden restaurant as Bar Lourinha at NGV, featuring Matt McConnell and Jo Gamvros’s Iberian-Mediterranean food which complements the art. I came away from lunch there having eaten one of the great desserts of my life – blood orange crema and burnt orange caramel. What has that got to do with art? Well it is the whole deal that Ellwood wants people to experience when they go to Melbourne for the exhibition, which includes a free NGV Kids exhibition titled Making Art: Imagine Everything is Real. The Picasso Century culminates, as usual, in a gorgeous gift shop. There are quite a few people walking around now with Picasso umbrellas. There will also be Friday night performances and other associated attractions. But, of course, the whole experience is centred on the exhibition itself with plenty of film footage and other added extras. It will take a few hours to do it justice and make sure you linger a while and watch the film about the making of Guernica, Picasso’s mural masterpiece against fascism. There is film footage of both world wars and the Spanish Civil War because Picasso’s career was punctuated by these earth-shattering events and they helped shape him and his art. His commitment to communism, which also made him a target for criticism, can be explained as a response to the rise of fascism in Europe. As for the work itself, you will stand in awe of some of these masterpieces including classics such as Weeping woman, painted in 1937, an iconic work that is actually owned by the NGV. The painting has a chequered history having once been stolen but later returned by a group calling itself the Australian Cultural Terrorists. The 1932 work Reclining woman (femme couchee) depicted Picasso’s romantic partner and muse from 1927 to about 1932, Marie-Therese Walter, and is one of the many depictions of the reclining female nude motif created by the artist during his lifetime. Another important woman in his life was photographer Dora Maar, who became his muse after they met in 1935, serving as the inspiration for many of his portraits including the 1938 Portrait of a woman (Portrait de femme) which is featured in the exhibition. The question of Picasso’s legacy in the 21st century is posed through the last work you will see before exiting to the gift shop (where you can purchase the 441-page book The Picasso Century), a 2009 video work entitled I see a woman crying (Weeping Woman), Tate Liverpool by Rineke Dijkstra. The work shows a group of schoolchildren who were asked to observe and describe Pablo Picasso’s (1881–1973) portrait Weeping woman 1937, in the Tate’s collection. (He did a few weeping women) A reproduction of Picasso’s painting hangs outside the frame of the camera for the children to look at but is never shown in the video. Dijkstra made the work during the exhibition The Fifth Floor: Ideas Taking Space at Tate Liverpool in 2008-9 and it’s a lovely, somewhat whimsical finale. ■ Melbourne Winter Masterpieces 2022: The Picasso Century at NGV International, St Kilda Rd, Melbourne until October 9, tickets $28/$30, children $10, ngv.vic.gov.auCREDIT: Story PHIL BROWNWord count: 1392Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Ademas, Picasso ilustro la obra de su padre, el dramaturgo Ferdinand Crommelynck, Le cocu magnifique.Nacido en Milan (norte de Italia) en 1934, Crommelynck se inicio en el grabado de estampas o en dulce en la capital francesa de la mano de Roger Lacouriere, junto a sus hermanos Aldo y Milan.Tras abrir un taller en 1959 en Paris, en el que colaboraron los principales artistas de la epoca, instalaron sus prensas en Mougins (sureste de Francia), cerca de la casa de Picasso.Cuando el pintor espanol murio, Piero y Aldo Crommelynck volvieron a abrir un taller en Paris y, anos despues, se separaron. Desde entonces, Piero Crommelynck dedico gran parte de su tiempo a la promocion de nuevos artistas.Word count: 170Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
REVIEW --- Masterpiece: Pablo Picasso's 'Bull's Head' (1942): A Magical Metamorphosis of the Ordinary
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit There's a remarkable moment about three-quarters of the way through "Picasso: Masterpieces From the Musee Nationale Picasso, Paris," now at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. (After it closes on May 15, the show travels to San Francisco's de Young Museum.) The revelation comes in a gallery with work Picasso did during World War II. Long gone is the joie de vivre of earlier decades -- the colorful paintings of sunlit beach scenes with frolicking bathers, and ever- available women. This is Picasso's bleakest period. His palette is restricted to browns, grays and blacks, pictorial space is sharply constricted, with figures and objects often literally boxed in, forms are painfully contorted, and themes of mortality preoccupy him, most powerfully in "Death's Head" (1943), a bronze sculpture of a pitted, scabrous skull. Then, out of the blue, comes a moment of wit and whimsy: "Bull's Head" (1942), a sculpture made from a bicycle saddle and handlebars. At once both childlike and highly sophisticated in its simplicity, it stands as an assertion of the transforming power of the human imagination at a time when human values were under siege. Consisting as it does of only two elements, "Bull's Head" is Picasso's sparest sculpture. And it is unique among his assemblages for its transparency. In most of them, the identity of the found objects, though not disguised, isn't emphasized. The toy car that forms the monkey's face in "Baboon and Young" (1951) is recognizable for what it is, yet at the same time is subsumed under the larger image of which it forms a part. In "Bull's Head," by contrast, there is no attempt to play down the real-world identity of the constituent parts. Indeed, the sculpture's reductiveness and simplicity draw attention to them. Picasso's frank acknowledgment of these elements has prompted scholars to see affinities between this work and Marcel Duchamp's Readymades, where the Dada artist took commercially made, utilitarian objects and, with little or no modification, exhibited them under his name as works of art. The first of these, "Bicycle Wheel" (1913), can be seen in replica at the Museum of Modern Art. Yet there would seem to be more going on with "Bull's Head" than affinity. It is such an uncharacteristic work for Picasso that it is hard not to see it as, on some level, a direct response to Duchamp. What would make Picasso spare a thought for the clown prince of modern art at the very moment when there were far more important issues at stake, such as the fact that everything he held dear -- the values of Western civilization that formed the wellsprings of his art -- was going up in flames? Perhaps the fact that Duchamp himself represented a similarly sweeping threat. Readymades are antiart objects. Their purpose was nothing less than to overturn the entire tradition of artmaking as it had existed since ancient times, a tradition of which Picasso was both heir and beneficiary. If art was to be redefined as simply a question of shifting a pre-existing object from one context to another, then that meant an end to the idea of the art object as a product of the artist's hand, craft skill, culture, eye and imagination. Above all, that meant the end of the idea of the artist as shaman, a person able to transform and transfigure, who could conjure one thing, a work of art, out of another, its raw materials and constituent parts. Picasso, who worked at all hours, was single-minded in his pursuit of his art. Yet he also made it his business to stay abreast of what was going on around him. He was notorious for keeping tabs on other artists, dropping by their studios, visiting their exhibitions to check up on what they were doing -- all to ensure that his position as leader of the avant-garde remained unchallenged. In the same spirit, he would borrow and adapt their ideas and attempt to one-up them in other ways. He certainly knew about Duchamp, and indeed there had been an earlier point of contact between them. In the third volume of his biography of Picasso, John Richardson notes similarities between another Picasso sculpture, "Head" (1928), and Duchamp's "Rotary Demisphere (Precision Optics)" (1925), the two works having in common a circular form supported on tripod legs. In a 1912 collage, Picasso had pasted a portion of a newspaper headline that reads "La Bataille S'est Engage" ("the battle is joined"). And in "Bull's Head" the artist -- for whom so much of life was about gaining the upper hand, be it with his mistresses, portrait subjects or artists living and dead -- seems to be operating on the same principle. For he's taking on Duchamp on the Dadaist's own turf. Picasso's explicit acknowledgment of the saddle and handlebars makes "Bull's Head" a kind of Readymade-by-Picasso, a fact reinforced by the artist's description of the work's genesis: He "often described how he had found the bicycle parts by chance and 'seen' them immediately as a bull's head, adding that, ideally, one day a cyclist would find his assemblage in a tip and 'see' it as a saddle and handlebars; in that way there would be a 'double metamorphosis," writes Elizabeth Cowling in "Picasso: Sculptor/Painter." Yet his purpose in annexing Duchamp's aesthetic of the Readymade is not to embrace it but to neutralize it and thus trump it. Duchamp's combinations are deliberately disjunctive. His bicycle wheel and stool are joined together precisely because they have nothing in common and, together, suggest nothing beyond themselves. Not so Picasso's. He goes all the way to the Duchampian brink, allowing the individual elements to stand for themselves to such a degree that he almost reaches the point at which illusion collapses, leaving us with just a bicycle saddle and some handlebars. But only almost, for despite that we are never in doubt that we are at all times looking at an image of a bull's head. Therein lies the bewitching power of "Bull's Head," and Picasso's triumph. --- Mr. Gibson is the Journal's Leisure & Arts features editor. Title: Abstract
Pablo Picasso ARTIST of the CENTURY
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitA stunning exhibition of one of the greatest art figures of the modern era is expected to lure visitors in their droves to the National Gallery of Victoria Pablo Picasso was a genius but was he also a dirty old man? That may be the wrong question to ask about the Spaniard who changed the course of 20th century art but in the age of cancel culture it’s a question that has been posed, appropriately or not. In the era of #MeToo his apparent chauvinism has been highlighted and even harped on by some. But, as they say in the movies, it’s complicated. Picasso, who died in 1973 aged 91, had many relationships, some of them torrid and troubled and he even admitted to one mistress that he found it hard to relate to women other than as “goddesses or doormats”. His personality, relationships and artistic legacy will be discussed in the public program that is part of National Gallery of Victoria’s landmark exhibition The Picasso Century at the NGV International until October 9. The man who created and curated the show, Didier Ottinger, deputy director of the Musee national d’art moderne, Centre Pompidou, Paris, says the exhibition is, among other things, “an answer to many of the criticisms now being addressed about Picasso”. “There are some very fierce feminists who have called him a misogynist and violent and so on,” Ottinger says during a whirlwind tour of the exhibition. “But what you will discover in this show is that he was very sensitive, emotional and you just look at his work and you can see that. It’s not the work of an aggressive man. He is passionate, yes, and of course he was macho … he was from the south of Spain. If you really want to understand his feelings just listen to flamenco music. “I hope this exhibition will show who Picasso really was and that might calm things down a bit.” It will also excite people too because it is an extraordinary cavalcade of 20th century art charting the amazing career of Picasso in dialogue with many artists, poets and intellectuals with whom he interacted in his adopted city of Paris including Guillaume Apollinaire, Georges Braque, Salvador Dali and Gertrude Stein. Developed exclusively for the NGV by the Centre Pompidou and the Musee national Picasso-Paris, the exhibition features 80 works by Picasso alongside 100 by more than 60 of his contemporaries. Curated by Ottinger, The Picasso Century sprawls across the ground floor at the NGV International in Melbourne as it examines the diverse influences, encounters and collaborative relationships that steered Picasso through many distinct artistic periods such as his Blue Period, Cubism and Surrealism and it draws lines between Picasso’s famous creations and the world around him. Somewhat ironically the exhibition, part of the NGV’s Melbourne Winter Masterpieces series, could be said to have had its genesis in Brisbane where NGV director Tony Ellwood served as director of QAGOMA – he was the man who put the then brand-new Gallery of Modern Art (GOMA) on the map. “I made an exhibition for Brisbane devoted to Surrealism with Tony,” Ottinger says. “That’s when we began working together. Then he moved to Melbourne and said, ‘We have to do something of the same period with the masterpieces from Paris.’ We thought, ‘What shall we do?’ Then we thought, ‘We will do Picasso and the 20th century, let’s go.’” Ellwood was keen to get it done as soon as possible but Ottinger warned it would take a while. In fact it took a decade to secure the right works but it was worth the wait he says. “Now this is the occasion for anyone interested in 20th century art,” Ottinger insists. “You come to this show and you will not only know Picasso, the genius, but you will see him in context and get a whole new idea of Picasso.” Ellwood says he wanted something special and was prepared to wait. “I did ask why I had to wait that long though,” he points out. “To request key works was difficult. Didier said if we wait 10 years we will get everything we want. He has created a unique thesis for Melbourne and an exhibition that has never happened before.” Ellwood says with interstate travel back on the agenda he’s hoping people from around the country will make the trek to Melbourne for a bit of cultural tourism. With that in mind the gallery has partnered with Sofitel Melbourne on Collins which is part of a French hotel group located at what is, fortuitously, known as “the Paris end of Collins St”. Of course Picasso made his career in the French capital and Sofitel Melbourne on Collins has recently revamped rooms with French style in mind and incorporated French inspired photography in its new guest rooms. It has also created a Spanish themed lunch menu as a tribute to Picasso, available from July. The chef is working on the finer details of the Picasso Winter Lunch menu; each dish will have a link to Pablo Picasso and they’re working on the content that will be included on the printed menus. The NGV International meanwhile has refashioned its Garden restaurant as Bar Lourinha at NGV, featuring Matt McConnell and Jo Gamvros’s Iberian-Mediterranean food which complements the art. I came away from lunch there having eaten one of the great desserts of my life – blood orange crema and burnt orange caramel. What has that got to do with art? Well it is the whole deal that Ellwood wants people to experience when they go to Melbourne for the exhibition, which includes a free NGV Kids exhibition titled Making Art: Imagine Everything is Real. The Picasso Century culminates, as usual, in a gorgeous gift shop. There are quite a few people walking around now with Picasso umbrellas. There will also be Friday night performances and other associated attractions. But, of course, the whole experience is centred on the exhibition itself with plenty of film footage and other added extras. It will take a few hours to do it justice and make sure you linger a while and watch the film about the making of Guernica, Picasso’s mural masterpiece against fascism. There is film footage of both world wars and the Spanish Civil War because Picasso’s career was punctuated by these earth-shattering events and they helped shape him and his art. His commitment to communism, which also made him a target for criticism, can be explained as a response to the rise of fascism in Europe. As for the work itself, you will stand in awe of some of these masterpieces including classics such as Weeping woman, painted in 1937, an iconic work that is actually owned by the NGV. The painting has a chequered history having once been stolen but later returned by a group calling itself the Australian Cultural Terrorists. The 1932 work Reclining woman (femme couchee) depicted Picasso’s romantic partner and muse from 1927 to about 1932, Marie-Therese Walter, and is one of the many depictions of the reclining female nude motif created by the artist during his lifetime. Another important woman in his life was photographer Dora Maar, who became his muse after they met in 1935, serving as the inspiration for many of his portraits including the 1938 Portrait of a woman (Portrait de femme) which is featured in the exhibition. The question of Picasso’s legacy in the 21st century is posed through the last work you will see before exiting to the gift shop (where you can purchase the 441-page book The Picasso Century), a 2009 video work entitled I see a woman crying (Weeping Woman), Tate Liverpool by Rineke Dijkstra. The work shows a group of schoolchildren who were asked to observe and describe Pablo Picasso’s (1881–1973) portrait Weeping woman 1937, in the Tate’s collection. (He did a few weeping women) A reproduction of Picasso’s painting hangs outside the frame of the camera for the children to look at but is never shown in the video. Dijkstra made the work during the exhibition The Fifth Floor: Ideas Taking Space at Tate Liverpool in 2008-9 and it’s a lovely, somewhat whimsical finale. Melbourne Winter Masterpieces 2022: The Picasso Century at NGV International, St Kilda Rd, Melbourne until October 9, tickets $28/$30, children $10, ngv.vic.gov.auCREDIT: Story PHIL BROWNWord count: 1391Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Pablo Picasso's fashionable theories in painting
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitSri Lanka, July 24 -- Pablo PicassoWell possessed by extremely dynamic feelings, Picasso personally preferred his ordinary life and art career marked with revolutionary trends. The impressively dramatic changes which came over his political life and married life are numerous and he was the subject of favourable appraisal and hostile criticism levelled from the modern world of art. In personal life he was married to a lady around forty years younger and was an ardent communist in 1944. Most critics of his paintings rate him the superlative painter in the modern world of art and perhaps in the history of art. On the other hand, some critics charge him with the crime of mishandling and misdirecting the field of art by creating nonsense paintings.Whatever is said of him, Picasso provides a perfect example for promoting the art of painting. That is to say, an artist permanently damages the quality of art if he keeps strictly to the conventional ways and tradition. Picasso himself registered his protests against the non progressive trends for and adorations of traditions.Published by HT Syndication with permission from Sunday Observer (Sri Lanka).For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.comWord count: 208Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitBERLIN (EFE).- La aparicion de un desperfecto en un cuadro de Pablo Picasso, que se exhibe en Tubinga (sur de Alemania), junto con un centenar de obras del pintor espanol, ha causado desconcierto entre los organizadores.Una restauradora del museo descubrio en el cuadro La pareja (1906) una raya a lapiz de alrededor de un centimetro de largo, sobre cuyo origen no hay explicacion.Lo unico que por el momento esta claro es que el dano tuvo que producirse antes de su llegada a Tubinga, explico el director del museo, Goetz Adriani."La exposicion habia pasado anteriormente por Viena y despues fue devuelta a su propietario", el nieto de Pablo Picasso, Bernhard Ruiz Picasso, preciso."El desperfecto tuvo que producirse en algun momento antes de que el cuadro llegara a Tubinga. Los protocolos de los restauradores y los documentos de la compania de seguros demuestran que la obra salio en perfecto estado de Viena", anadio.Adriani hizo especial hincapie en que la sala de exposiciones no se siente responsable del dano, que "no es tan grave como pudiera pensarse y es una tarea menor para cualquier restaurador".El cuadro, que Picasso pinto en Paris, permanecera en su estado actual en la exposicion y sera restaurado hasta que regrese a manos de su propietario, quien ha sido informado del caso.La obra forma parte de la coleccion de mas de un centenar de oleos, dibujos, acuarelas y gouaches, propiedad del nieto del pintor malagueno.Son obras de las que Picasso nunca quiso desprenderse por "quererlas tanto" y entre ellas figuran 67 que nunca habian sido expuestas hasta su presentacion en Viena, en septiembre de 2000.La muestra permanecera abierta hasta el proximo 16 de junio.Word count: 285Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit Madonna thinks artists deep into their careers should stop if they don't have anything more to say. But at 56, the singer says she still has things to talk about, and in short, she feels like Pablo Picasso."I like to compare myself to other kinds of artists like Picasso. He kept painting and painting until the day he died. Why? Because I guess he felt inspired to do so," she said. "Life inspired him, so he had to keep expressing himself, and that's how I feel."Madonna released her self-titled debut album in 1983, and her latest album, "Rebel Heart," earlier this year. She said the key to sticking around is her continual desire to inspire others."I don't think there's a time, a date, an expiration date for being creative," she said. "I think you go until you don't have any more to say." The pop icon will launch her Rebel Heart Tour on Sept. 9 in Montreal. The tour includes more than 60 shows across North America, Europe, Australia and Asia."The theme I really truly explore in this show more than anything is love and romance," she said in a phone interview from her home in New York City last week. "I want people to walk out like they're feeling inspired and like they've seen something they've never seen before (and) felt something they've never felt before."Comedian Amy Schumer, whose new movie "Trainwreck" opened impressively at No. 2 with $30.2 million last weekend, will open for three Madonna shows in New York.Credit: Wire ServicesWord count: 261Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
The Pablo Picasso Alzheimer's Therapy
Publisher: New York Times, Late Edition (East Coast)
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit SITTING the other day in front of Picasso's rapturous ''Girl Before a Mirror'' at the Museum of Modern Art, Rueben Rosen wore the dyspeptic look of a man with little love for modern art. But the reason he gave for disliking the painting was not one you might expect to hear from an 88-year-old former real estate broker. ''It's like he's trying to tell a story using words that don't exist,'' Mr. Rosen said finally of Picasso, fixing the painter's work with a critic's stare. ''He knows what he means, but we don't.'' This chasm of understanding is one that Mr. Rosen himself stares into every day. He has midstage Alzheimer's disease, as did the rest of the men and women who were sitting alongside him in a small semicircle at the museum, all of them staring up at the Picasso. It was a Tuesday, and the museum was closed, but if it had been open other visitors could have easily mistaken the group for any guided tour. Mr. Rosen and his friends did not wear the anxious, confused looks they had worn when they first arrived at the museum. They did not quarrel in the way that those suffering from Alzheimer's sometimes do. And when they talked about the paintings, they did not repeat themselves or lose the thread of the discussion, as they often do at the long-term care home where most of them live in Palisades, N.Y. At one point, a member of the tour, Sheila Barnes, 82, a quick-witted former newspaper editor who suffers from acute short-term memory loss, was even uncharacteristically aware of the limitations of her memory. ''If I've told this story before, then somebody just say, 'Cool it, Sheila,''' she announced, laughing. She was a test subject, in a sense, in a growing effort to use art as a therapeutic tool for those in the grip of Alzheimer's. Art therapy, both appreciating art and making it, has been used for decades as a nonmedical way to help a wide variety of people -- abused children, prisoners and cancer and Alzheimer's patients. But much of this work has taken place in nursing homes and hospitals. Now museums like the Modern and the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, are trying to bring it into their galleries, using their collections as powerful ways to engage minds damaged by dementia. It seems to be working, though no one knows exactly how. While extensive research has been conducted on the effects of music and performing arts on brain function -- the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function in the Bronx has been studying the phenomenon for a decade now -- there has been comparatively little work done in the visual arts. What exists mostly is a stockpile of anecdotal evidence, encouraging but murky. Why did Willem de Kooning become more productive, almost maniacally so, as he descended into Alzheimer's? Why does frontotemporal dementia, a relatively rare form of non-Alzheimer's brain disease, cause some people who had no previous interest or aptitude for art to develop remarkable artistic talent and drive? ''Certainly it's not just a visual experience -- it's an emotional one,'' said Oliver Sacks, the neurologist and writer. ''In an informal way I have often seen quite demented patients recognize and respond vividly to paintings and delight in painting at a time when they are scarcely responsive to words and disoriented and out of it. I think that recognition of visual art can be very deep.'' The Museum of Modern Art began to experiment with short, focused tours a year ago, working with an Alzheimer's care company called Hearthstone, based in Lexington, Mass. The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, began to reach out to Alzheimer's patients more than five years ago, offering tours alongside those for other disabled groups. And the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich, Conn., also offers tours, in addition to conducting a program in which it sends educators to Alzheimer's care facilities to help with art therapy. At the Modern, which plans to expand the Alzheimer's program next year to families and other care providers, the effects of the tours are often striking and seem to speak -- in a world of reproduction -- to the power of the original. (For now, the tours focus on representational art, on the theory that it's an easier touchstone for narratives and memories. There are no Pollocks, for example.) Besides improving patients' moods for hours and even days, the tours seem to demonstrate that the disease, while diminishing sufferers' abilities in so many ways, can also sometimes spark interpretive and expressive powers that had previously lay hidden. Mr. Rosen, for instance, who had little interest in art when he was younger, talked with ease and inventiveness about the composition of Rousseau's ''Sleeping Gypsy.''''If you met these people back where they lived on an ordinary day, you simply would not see them being this articulate and this assured,'' said John Zeisel, the president of Hearthstone, who conceived the program with Francesca Rosenberg, the Modern's director of community and access programs. On that Tuesday, as the group of two men and three women and a volunteer museum educator wound their way slowly through the empty galleries, Kerry Mills, who runs the residence in Palisades, pointed out one elderly man in particular, Frank Ertola, a former New York City police detective who was making his third visit to the museum. Mr. Ertola, 86, burly with a thick sweep of white hair, had been living in the residence for almost three years and had recently begun to struggle with his emotions. ''The smallest things in the world irritate him, and it's become very hard to get him engaged,'' Ms. Mills said. But as he sat on a folding stool in front of Andrew Wyeth's ''Christina's World,'' he smiled, listened and at one point -- after abandoning a wheelchair he had requested when he arrived -- stood and speculated on why there was an ellipse of mown grass surrounding the haunting farmhouse in the painting's upper right corner. ''It's to let you know that someone lives there,'' he said. Later, in front of Matisse's ''Dance,'' he was asked to provide a title for the painting, and on a notecard wrote ''Dance of the Beauties.'' He smiled rakishly when asked to explain. ''I see a naked woman?'' he said, shrugging. ''I think it's beautiful.'' Ms. Mills was surprised to see him so talkative. ''He was like he was last year,'' she said later. ''He's such a fun person and such a gentleman, and all those things come out when he's at the museum.'' More than four million Americans suffer from Alzheimer's disease, and the number is expected to rise as the nation's overall population ages. With no cure on the horizon, caregivers are increasingly exploring art as a way to help manage the disease, and they take encouragement from the results with music. Dr. Sacks noted that exposure to music can even result in lowered dosages for patients being medicated for cognitive and emotional disorders. One avenue of thinking about both music and art, he said, is that it engages parts of the brain that remain intact long after the onset of dementia and that have to do with procedural memory -- the kind that governs routine activities like walking, eating, shaving. One musician whom Dr. Sacks has observed has almost entirely lost his memory, but his musical memory is intact. ''Nietzsche used to say that we listened to music with our muscles,'' he said. The question is whether a similar mechanism is at work in making and looking at art. The National Institute on Aging held a conference in Alexandria, Va., last year to allow researchers to compare notes on Alzheimer's and artistic activity. One speaker, Bruce L. Miller, clinical director of the Memory and Aging Center at the University of California, San Francisco, said he believed that even sitting and looking at art is much more active than most people assume, and such activity could have positive effects on damaged brains. ''There's a lot of general excitement in this area, but not much known about it,'' he said later in an interview. ''I think there is, tucked in there, a research question that really hasn't been answered yet, which is: by looking at or making art, is there a way to improve the brains of those with Alzheimer's?'' Museum and Alzheimer's care officials say that at the very least, they see temporary but palpable, and moving, improvement in the small group of people who have participated in the tours. Hannah Goodwin, the manager of accessibility at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, recounted watching an elderly man react to a Stuart Davis painting. ''Very spontaneously, he just starting talking about the painting and about the time period in New York,'' she said. ''He was talking about jazz and improvisation and everything. It was very beautiful and unexpected. There was this absolute clarity and connection that I think was really sparked by the painting.'' Irene Copeland Brenton, 73, one of the visitors to the Modern on that Tuesday, suffers from a kind of Alzheimer's that has made it very difficult for her to read and to find the right words to say. But in front of the Wyeth and later the Rousseau, she was almost loquacious. Her husband, Myron, said that while specific memories of the museum might evaporate, she seemed to retain a kind of emotional memory long after the visit ended. When he reminded her that she had visited the museum and that Ms. Mills had written an account of it, he said, ''her face lit up.'' ''She really wanted to hear about the whole thing,'' he said. ''It seemed the experience relived itself when I prompted her.'' That day at the museum, looking longingly at the figure lying in a field at the bottom of the Wyeth painting, she seemed to identify deeply with the thin young woman in the dress, her left hand reaching out toward the farmhouse. ''You can't see her face,'' Ms. Brenton said, ''but looking at her you get the feeling she's happy.'' She was asked why. ''Because you know she's going to get to the house,'' she said, adding: ''I'd like to go into that house, too.'' Photograph Irene Brenton talks to Xanthe Alban-Davies about Andrew Wyeth's ''Christina's World'' at MoMA. (Photo by Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)(pg. 1); Xanthe Alban-Davies discusses Picasso's ''Girl Before a Mirror'' with, from left, Frank Ertola, Rueben Rosen, Irene Brenton and Sheila Barnes at the Museum of Modern Art. ''It's like he's trying to tell a story using words that don't exist,'' Mr. Rosen said. Title: Abstract
Antonio Banderas set to play Pablo Picasso
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitLondon, Feb 22 (ANI): Antonio Banderas has been confirmed to star as Pablo Picasso in the new biopic '33 Days'.Antonio, 51, will portray the co-founder of the cubist movement and his emotional struggle while working on his masterpiece mural Guernica.It seems the 'Puss in Boots' star is finally feels ready to tackle a part that he revealed has always fascinated him."He is a character that followed me for a long time, but had always rejected it," the Daily Mail quoted him as telling Spanish newspaper El Pais."He deserves a lot of respect because I am Malagan."I was born four blocks from where he was born. It has always fascinated me," he said.The movie will also examine the relationship between the artist and his French lover Dora Marr, who was with him at the time he made 'Guernica'.It will also show his reaction to the destruction of the town that gave the artwork its name during the Spanish Civil War.Picasso, who died in 1973 at the age of 91, has long been of interest to art lover Banderas, as they come from the same city on Spain's southern coast.The movie is slated to have a budget of 7.9 million dollars, and will be directed by Carlos Saura.It means a big pay cut for the actor, who usually commands multi-million dollar fees.The film is slated to be shot in Paris and Guernica next summer. There's no fussiness here, no wasted space. There's stowage for Africa - or France! - with drawers under the front seats, two boxes at the feet of the rear passengers, and even the boot floor can be positioned at two levels so you get a beautifully flat and useful surface when the rear seat is folded down.With its brilliant styling, its overall appeal and performance - and did I mention the humungous amount of boot space? - the price tag of R206 400 isn't over the top. [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitI'VE ALWAYS had a soft spot for the little Spaniard whose creative genius and unique cubism art made him famous. And how can you not love a car named after the man who once said: "There are only two types of women: goddesses and doormats"? He should have known. Pablo Picasso was a noted philanderer, and loved women all his life.The Citroen C3 Picasso is actually one of the most fun cars I've seen in ages. And, oh boy, does it make people smile! It turns heads wherever you go, and it was with real reluctance that I handed back the keys to the vehicle.It's more than just a cube on wheels, or a "spacebox", as Citroen calls it: the remarkably cleverly designed car oozes ingenuity, and innovation. Flexibility, versatility and thoughtfulness were obviously key in the designers' minds when they sat down with their first drawing boards. The result is a funky little multi-purpose car that delivers driving pleasure and great aesthetics.Picasso once remarked that "art is the elimination of the unnecessary", and Citroen has taken this to heart with the car. There's no fussiness here, no wasted space. There's stowage for Africa - or France! - with drawers under the front seats, two boxes at the feet of the rear passengers, and even the boot floor can be positioned at two levels so you get a beautifully flat and useful surface when the rear seat is folded down.Loved the leather steering wheel with its chrome inserts, but the sunroof, with its double blind opening system, could possibly be improved upon. A male colleague, a surfer with meaty biceps, was in the front passenger seat and decided to open the blinds: he nearly expired of heart failure, as did I, when they shot apart and almost ripped themselves off the roof. Only later, when reading the instructions, did I see that you're supposed to "Guide the shutters completely open. Do NOT let them go when opening as this can cause damage". Point noted, Citroen!However, the rest of the car got the thumbs up all round. The 1 600 is super quiet on the road, has a more than satisfactory five-speed manual gearbox, and goes like the clappers when you want it to. An unusual feature is the scented air freshener, operable via a control knob - which took me ages to find. I liked the auto headlight and rain-sensor windscreen wipers, and the fact that it has six airbags, ABS, EDB etc. Loved the choice of colours, too.With its brilliant styling, its overall appeal and performance - and did I mention the humungous amount of boot space? - the price tag of R206 400 isn't over the top. I don't think the C3 Picasso will date too quickly, either. It's likely to become a classic ... and to immortalise the words of Pablo, who said, "We don't become older, we become riper!"Credit: Peta LeeWord count: 493Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Abstract
Pablo Picasso's non-Cubist hits
Full Article: Abstract [Pablo Picasso] - at least the artist's ever-evolving reputation - has morphed into the equivalent of the Steven Spielberg of the museum circuit, capable of providing a major blockbuster about every two years. The Met's show - with 300 pieces totalling most of the museum's Picasso holdings, including its 200 prints - is matched in downtown Manhattan by "Picasso: Themes and Variations" at the Museum of Modern Art, with 100 of the artist's prints. The rivalry has not gone unnoticed. This doesn't make the Met's "Picasso" a good show. It's far too ersatz for that. It does make it a surprisingly involving exhibition, something that cannot be said about a number of other recent Picasso shows. MoMA's "http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/966Themes and VariationsEND," while more consistent than the Met exhibition, feels like a textbook placed on its walls. Sexy it's not. "We don't do it anymore, but the desire for it is still with us," Picasso once said about sex. Evidence of the artist's undiminished erotic imagination is found everywhere in the last gallery in the Met show, showing his 347 Suite of etchings printed by the Crommelynck brothers, Aldo and Piero, who'd set up their shop near the artist's studio in Mougins near Cannes. (If any aspect of Picasso's genius can be said to be "hidden," it's his staggering virtuosity as a printmaker equally at home with dry point and aquatint. He made around 2,400 prints over the years.) Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit NEW YORK A picture hangs in the cool Metropolitan Museum of Art that has a good percentage of the art world all hot and bothered. Erotic Scene shows a young man with a look on his face of quiet self-satisfaction as he lazes on a couch in the manner of Francisco Goya's The Nude Maja enjoying the oral ministrations of a naked young woman who appears to be turning a bluish purple in the process. La Douleur - as the painting has come to be known - indicates nothing more graphic than Internet browsers have already come across in the way of erotica. Yet because the 1902 (or 1903) painting is by Pablo Picasso, La Douleur has taken on many new layers of meaning and brought a lot of new attention to the rest of the exhibition around it, "Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art." The undisguised actuality of the scene gives gallery-goers and critics alike a jolt of recognition - something akin to finding a bit of truth in a TV sitcom - when something from real life finds its way through the made-up world around it. Picasso - at least the artist's ever-evolving reputation - has morphed into the equivalent of the Steven Spielberg of the museum circuit, capable of providing a major blockbuster about every two years. The Met's show - with 300 pieces totalling most of the museum's Picasso holdings, including its 200 prints - is matched in downtown Manhattan by "Picasso: Themes and Variations" at the Museum of Modern Art, with 100 of the artist's prints. The rivalry has not gone unnoticed. The Met came late and reluctantly to Picasso, mostly because of Gertrude Stein's decision in 1946 to give it her famous portrait by Picasso, where she looks as if her angular face were chipped out of Paul Cezanne's chiselled Mont Sainte-Victoire. The work, Gertrude Stein (1905-06) - the best-known piece in the Met show - "is the only reproduction of me which is always I, for me," the expatriate American writer insisted. Met co-curator Gary Tinterow helps explain the Picasso gap between the two museums with the admission in his show's catalogue that, "unlike the much larger and well-balanced" MoMA collection, the Met's Picasso collection "developed by happenstance rather than by design." (The Met's Susan Alyson Stein is the other curator.) Happenstance has its rewards, though. For one thing, it brought to the Met a wealth of Picasso's early work, particularly his moody Blue period work where his socialist sympathies saturate the remarkable The Blind Man's Meal (1903). Happenstance also can allow a lot more speculative latitude. In exhibiting lesser pieces - La Douleur is a primo example - the Met offers work that would never have made it into a show filled only with Picasso's Greatest Cubist Hits. With "http://www.metmuseum.org/special/se_event.asp?OccurrenceId={cd70b3f0-d1b8-4501-9b63-085d213e0e9b}Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of ArtEND" - savaged in a New Yorker blurb as akin to "the second hour of a yard sale" - the Met sees its Picasso holdings from the inside out, mostly in terms of the many donations made to the collection. The catalogue includes a number of photos showing well-heeled collectors inside of their homes. But for the rest of the world, the Met show could as easily be called "Picasso for the Viagra Generation." Most Cubist-period Picasso shows suggest the artist wasn't up to much before 1910 - the Cubist sweet spot when Picasso had gone totally geometric alongside Georges Braque - and that he never did much of anything after to match that fabulous period in his life. The Met's "Picasso" pushes for something quite the opposite. It emphasizes - perhaps unintentionally - sexuality as the other driving force in the artist's life, not only when he was a young stud, new to Paris, but well into his 90s. (Born in 1881, he died in 1973.) This doesn't make the Met's "Picasso" a good show. It's far too ersatz for that. It does make it a surprisingly involving exhibition, something that cannot be said about a number of other recent Picasso shows. MoMA's "http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/966Themes and VariationsEND," while more consistent than the Met exhibition, feels like a textbook placed on its walls. Sexy it's not. Picasso's sexuality would hardly seem to be new news when stories of his rough effect on women - Marie-Therese Walter, his zaftig early mistress, shot herself after his death, as did his second wife, Jacqueline Roque - have led him in recent years to be described in almost monstrously deviant terms. Picasso-as-Scary Monster theory is the basis of Arianna Huffington's Picasso: Creator and Destroyer. Francoise Gilot in particular led the way in encouraging this ominous Portrait of the Artist as a Sexy Beast after Picasso denied their two children, Claude and Paloma, the right to use the Picasso name. Gilot, as far as I remember, is the only one of the artist's lovers to not be exhibited in the Met show. Two lovers who did make the cut - first wife Olga Khokhlova and the photographer Dora Maar - appear as exploding shapes. Ignoring a suggestion of anti-Picasso sexist rhetoric, the Met's "Picasso" suggests the artist's instinct for the erotic wasn't something channelled only by anger but was rarely far from everything he produced, from the beginning to the very end of his life. Early on, that meant hurried painting of soft porn such as La Douleur for someone else's consumption as a way to make some quick cash. Mid-career works reveal the assured sensuality of Man with a Lollipop (Aug. 20, 1938) - a far more erotically ramped-up figure than any of Picasso's Satyrs - where the artist has seemingly given himself both male and female genitalia. "We don't do it anymore, but the desire for it is still with us," Picasso once said about sex. Evidence of the artist's undiminished erotic imagination is found everywhere in the last gallery in the Met show, showing his 347 Suite of etchings printed by the Crommelynck brothers, Aldo and Piero, who'd set up their shop near the artist's studio in Mougins near Cannes. (If any aspect of Picasso's genius can be said to be "hidden," it's his staggering virtuosity as a printmaker equally at home with dry point and aquatint. He made around 2,400 prints over the years.) Picasso's boisterous old musketeers looking for love in all the right places, the chubby hookers willing to give it to them and The Fat Courtesan Greeted by Three Gentlemen are together far more suggestive of the funhouse than the whorehouse. Close to death, Picasso's imagination was still up for a tumble. "Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art" continues to Aug. 1 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. "Picasso: Themes and Variations" is at the Museum of Modern Art in New York until Aug. 30. Credit: Peter Goddard "Picasso in the Metropolitan Museum of Art" continues to Aug. 1 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. "Picasso: Themes and Variations" is at the Museum of Modern Art in New York until Aug. 30. IllustrationCaption: Above: Picasso's socialist sympathies saturate The Blind Man's Meal, from 1903. Below left: The sketch Three Bathers by the Shore, from 1920. Below right: Picasso's famous portrait of Gertrude Stein, circa 1905-06. Title: Abstract
How art shapes our lives: Pablo Picasso
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit There is no doubt that we are all significant as human beings. But, to be considered as significant in the world of art: That is a big deal! An artist’s contribution can only be assessed, and fully realized in retrospect. Once an artist is given credit for having changed the world in some way, then they are considered as significant. That distinction may be given as a result of insight, talent, timing, or affiliation.Every once in a while a visionary will come along who is recognized to be a significant artist during their own lifetime. This was certainly the case with Spanish-born Pablo Ruiz Picasso (1881-1973). Credited as being the most important artist of the twentieth century, this individual was so prolific, (50,000 plus artworks), and ever changing, that his work is divided into segments. These eight distinct periods (which correspond with events in his life), include: All work done before 1901, the Blue period, the Rose period, the Cubism period, the African period, the Surrealist period, and then, all of the Later Works.Picasso demonstrated an amazing artistic talent in his early years. The thing that most people do not realize is that he painted in a realistic manner throughout his childhood and adolescence. He received formal training in traditional art at a very young age by his father who was an art professor. He was then admitted to the Academy of Fine Arts in Barcelona, Spain at age 13. To see some of his earlier works gives prospective to how good Picasso was as a realist. It was after 1901 that his style changed as he began to rebel by experimenting with different theories, techniques, and ideas. Always seeming to be one step ahead of what would be the next important thing in art, his work was in constant flux. I would like to point out just a couple of Picasso’s many contributions:Analytical Cubism, (1907-1911) is a style which was developed by Picasso, and employed the use of monochrome neutral colors. His theory, (at the time), was that objects could be taken apart visually, and then analyzed in terms of their shapes and sizes. In doing this, everything could then be converted into a triangle, rectangle, or circle. Love it, or hate it, this thinking revolutionized European, and then American painting and sculpture. It also helped to inspire related movements in music and literature. After that movement took hold, Picasso was joined by many other artists as the style evolved into what was called Synthetic Cubism, (1912-1919). This new movement took his concept one step further by introducing different textures and surfaces into the work. This was the beginning of collage materials becoming ingredients of fine art work.Picasso devoted all of his energy to his work, and seemed to become more daring as time went on. His art also became more colorful, and expressive along the way. As late as the 1960s until his death at age 91, (while in his 80s), he was still producing an incredible amount of artwork. These final works were a mixture of many different styles. Toward the end of his life he was quoted as saying, “My childhood was spent learning to paint like an adult, and then the rest of my life was spent learning to paint like a child.”*Sal Maccarone is an American author, designer, furniture maker and sculptor. He is best known as a master craftsman, and for his internationally distributed woodworking books such as ‘Tune Up Your Tools,’ and ‘How to Make $40,000 a Year Woodworking’. Title: Pablo Picasso painting sells for US$100m
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitA PAINTING by Pablo Picasso has sold for more than US$100 million — marking the fifth work by the Spanish artist to sell for a nine-figure sum.“Woman Sitting Near a Window (Marie-Therese)” sold for US$103.4 million Thursday at Christie’s auction house in New York.That figure comprises US$90 million for the painting itself, with fees and commissions on top, Christie’s said.The auction house had estimated the painting would sell for US$55 million.The work, titled “Femme Assise Pres d’Une Fenetre (Marie-Therese)” in Spanish, was sold after 19 minutes of bidding.The impressive sales figure is a sign of the art market’s vitality, which will be a source of relief for the industry after an uncertain year amid the COVID-19 pandemic.Bonnie Brennan, president of Christie’s America, said the success of Thursday’s auction “signals a real return to normal and also a message that the art market is really back on track.”It also confirms the continuing significance and popularity of works by Picasso, who was born in 1881 and died in 1973.The painting, which depicts Picasso’s young mistress and muse, Marie-Therese Walter, was acquired only eight years ago at a London sale for US$44.8 million, less than half the price it sold for Thursday.Picasso is one of a very small number of artists to have sold multiple works for more than US$100 million, alongside Jackson Pollock, Vincent van Gogh and Francis Bacon.The record for a Picasso is US$179.4 million, which was paid for his painting “The Women of Algiers” in 2015.(SD-Agencies)Word count: 257Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. to first hitEn la casa del pintor en Malaga exhiben ropa, muebles, libros y retratos que lo acompanaron en sus primeros anosPALABRA/EnviadoMLAGA.- Ademas de tener el don de la ubicuidad para estar en toda la ciudad en letreros de bares, tiendas y restaurantes o en playeras, plumas, mascadas, vestidos, sudaderas, carteles y demas souvenirs, el pintor Pablo Picasso (1881-1973) "abre" las puertas de su casa natal para que sus admiradores puedan conocer la habitacion en la que "nacio muerto" y fue revivido por el humo de cigarro de su tio Salvador, quien le dio los primeros auxilios.Llena de anecdotas e informacion documental sobre el creador del "Guernica", la Fundacion Pablo Ruiz Picasso-Casa Natal esta abierta al publico desde 1988 en la Plaza de la Merced, un conjunto arquitectonico decimononico presidido por el obelisco funerario dedicado al general Jose Maria de Torrijos y sus companeros, fusilados en 1831, y a 100 metros del Museo Picasso Malaga.Aunque solo vivio nueve anos en Malaga, Picasso siempre estuvo unido a Andalucia, asegura Pilar Rodriguez, documentalista de la Casa Natal, quien explica que fue en Malaga donde el pintor desperto su amor por la pintura (al seguir los pasos de su padre, el pintor Jose Ruiz Blasco)."Lo que comprueba claramente que Picasso siempre estuvo unido a Malaga es que su obra estuvo marcada por dos grandes iconos de esta ciudad: las palomas y los toros."Ademas de que el pintor es un andaluz al 100 por ciento, con un caracter abierto y amigable que es tipico de los espanoles del Mediterraneo", apunta Rodriguez.Salvador Bonet, segundo documentalista de la Casa Natal, recuerda que en Malaga es donde Picasso forja todas aquellas actitudes que lo caracterizaron en vida, como su enorme gusto y apego a las mujeres, su aficion a la pintura y su adiccion al tabaco."Sabemos que a Picasso siempre le gusto estar rodeado de mujeres y eso se entiende porque de nino en Malaga estuvo acompanado y mimado por su madre, sus tias y su hermana. Siempre fue un nino consentido", explica Bonet.Su aficion por el cigarro, abunda el documentalista, se puede explicar un poco por la anecdota mas famosa de Picasso, que cuenta que el pintor nacio muerto."Dicen que estaba azul y no respiraba. Entonces su tio Salvador intento revivirlo sin mucho exito; pero, por una extrana razon, el tio estaba fumando y fue el humo del cigarrillo lo que hizo entrar en shock al bebe y puso a andar su corazon", indica.Bonet anade que los inicios de Picasso en la pintura resulta muy claro para sus historiadores, ya que fue su padre quien desde sus primeros anos le inculco, sin querer, el amor al arte."Su padre era un pintor mediano, por no decir mediocre, que pintaba palomas. Eso le permitio a Picasso estar en contacto desde su ninez con los pinceles y la pintura. El mismo contaba que junto con su hermana Lola robaba las acuarelas de su padre y los dos pintaban durante la noche, escondidos debajo de las sabanas, iluminados con una vela", narra el tambien investigador.En la Casa Natal de Picasso se exhiben de forma permanente, justamente en la habitacion donde nacio el pintor, un oleo de Jose Ruiz Blasco, que tiene como personajes centrales a siete palomas que descansan al lado de una escalera, ademas de los pinceles, la paleta y las vasijas de pintura que tambien pertenecieron al padre."Su padre le marco de por vida, porque queda claro que en la obra de Picasso existen dos iconos recurrentes. Las palomas, que eran parte de su cotidiano en casa y en la calle, ya que estas aves siempre han existido y aun existen en la Plaza de la Merced; pero tambien los toros, que conocio de nino cuando su padre lo llevaba a la Malagueta a ver la fiesta brava".En la Casa Natal de Picasso tambien se exhibe ropa, muebles, esculturas, espejos, libros, retratos que acompanaron los primeros anos del creador, pero no conserva su estructura original debido a que se acondiciono como galeria, biblioteca y centro de investigacion para atender a los visitantes.Ademas de presentar exposiciones temporales relacionadas con el artista, como la muestra que actualmente se dedica a la obra de su hermana, Lola Ruiz Picasso (1884-1958), el recinto tiene el acervo documental mas completo sobre el andaluz, con libros, revistas, periodicos, fotografias y documentos, que se prestan a los visitantes.A detallePara consultar todo lo relacionado con la Casa Natal de Picasso en internet, puede accesar a la direccion www.fundacionpicasso.es.Word count: 759Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. PABLO'S A PICASSO: Leeds……2 Bristol City……0Hernandez hailed a master of his art as promotion tilt is reignited
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitELLAND ROAD went through the Roofe as Leeds United picked up their Premier League promotion push.Kemar Roofe sent his side on their way to victory with a 69th-minute strike to help wipe out the bitter memory of their hammering at West Brom in their previous game.And then Pablo Hernandez - who played a huge role in the opener - scored himself three minutes from time to send a packed house home in ecstatic mood.Spaniard Hernandez was later saluted for his "influence" by delighted manager Marcelo Bielsa as his Yorkshire heavyweights kept the Championship pace-setters Norwich well within their sights.Bristol City will point to the 55th-minute sending off of Josh Brownhill for two yellow cards - the first early bath of his career - as the turning point of the game. They were holding their own until that point and Leeds boss Bielsa admitted it was a major flashpoint in the contest.The Argentine said: "The fact we played with one more player made it easy for us. It's difficult to think that we deserved to lose the game. We dominated for long parts."I could see that we virtually didn't concede any chances to the opposition."Bielsa had special praise for game-changer Hernandez. "Pablo is always a player with a lot of influence," he said. "He always improves the style of our team and when he scores goals he's even more important."His opposite number, Lee Johnson, left Yorkshire cursing his side's bad luck in having Brownhill dismissed.But he believed his Bristol City players could journey back to the West Country with their heads held high despite sinking to a fourth straight defeat.Johnson said: "We were looking like a side which was going to win the game. I was very pleased with the performance."Our shape was good. We hustled. We harried. And it was important we got our identity back."The back four worked extremely hard. The individuals will go away knowing that they will have got their game back."Leeds are a good side but we nullified them for long periods." It was obvious from the first few minutes that Leeds were up for this one after the horror of The Hawthorns HE'S ¦which still haunts Bielsa, who took full responsibility for the 4-1 loss.Marcelo thrilled Now, here was the chance to change his tactics - and his gameplan worked in his favour.There was no faulting Leeds' purpose and passion in a rousing opening 45 minutes when the deadlock should have been shattered.Leeds threw everything at Bristol City, spurred on by a restless full house who were in the mood to cheer goals. But none came despite an abundance of half-chances with both sides lacking a true killer instinct. Ezgjan Alioski thought he had struck gold in the 18th minute with a blockbuster which was brilliantly saved by Bristol City keeper Niki Maenpaa.And Roofe was totally frustrated when his effort was blocked instead of sending the back of the net bulging.The visitors threatened in periods with quick-silver build ups of play and pops at debut keeper Will Huffer.But there was no end result - much to Leeds' relief.The hosts were given a huge helping hand when Brownhill was sent off 10 minutes after the break when he fouled Roofe for his second bookable offence.And the Leeds striker showed no side effects when he found himself clear, only to pull his shot wide of the target. Barry Douglas thought he had done the business in the 67th minute when his curled shot was tipped away by Maenpaa to produce even more sighs.But spirits were lifted two minutes later when Roofe fired Leeds ahead.Hernandez did well to carve out the opportunity, swivelling to shoot for goal - and Roofe made no mistake to send Elland Road into a frenzy.And then with three minutes left, Hernandez got on to the end of a cross from substitute Samuel Saiz to clinically head home.There was a collective sharp intake of breath all around the famous old stadium as Leeds United took another huge step back to the big stage which they last starred on in 2004. They host lowly Reading on Tuesday night.STAT ATTACK LEEDS UNITED have lost just two of their 24 league games against Bristol City in the second tier - and those two defeats were separated by more than 90 years (0-1 in both 1921 and 2016).CREDIT: By Steve Millar At Elland RoadCAPTION: ¦ HE'S SITTING COMFORTABLY: Marcelo Bielsa was thrilled with the winWord count: 764Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Pablo Picasso on exhibit as art historian
Full Article: Abstract His most intense confrontation with the past is on view at the Musee d'[Orsay]. There, a small suite of galleries has been devoted to Manet's great Dejeuner sur l'herbe and to 41 of Picasso's variations on it done in the early 1960s.At the Louvre, one side of its great Salon Denon has been cleared for Delacroix's famous harem scene from 1834, the Femmes d'Alger and for [Pablo Picasso]'s two dozen versions of it, done in 1954 and '55.You have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Click the button below if you want to translate the rest of the document.Translate AllFull TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit There's no doubt that Pablo Picasso is one of the greatest,and most popular, artists of all time. As proof, Parisians have been lining up hour after hour for a show called "Picasso and the Masters."It sets the modern master high up on a pedestal, alongside established geniuses such as El Greco, Velazquez, Poussin, Rembrandt, Delacroix, Manet and Renoir. And it allows him to colonize three of the city's most famous venues This Picasso project stretches from the Louvre to the Musee d'Orsay to the Grand Palais.But here's the truly peculiar thing about Picasso Those of us most smitten with him don't necessarily admire all of his individual pictures. What we love is how, across a seven-decade career filled with works that can be ugly or dumb or debauched, he constantly tests how pictures work and what they mean."Picasso and the Masters" turns out to be not so much about Picasso the artist as Picasso the art historian. It shows that Picasso the great painter could never have existed without his scholarly self.His most intense confrontation with the past is on view at the Musee d'Orsay. There, a small suite of galleries has been devoted to Manet's great Dejeuner sur l'herbe and to 41 of Picasso's variations on it done in the early 1960s.At the Louvre, one side of its great Salon Denon has been cleared for Delacroix's famous harem scene from 1834, the Femmes d'Alger and for Picasso's two dozen versions of it, done in 1954 and '55.And in the Grand Palais display - with 210 pictures, it's the main ring in this Picasso circus - we catch up with the artist two years further on, digging deeper into Velazquez's Las Meninas. The show hammers home a point that could be made about almost any major artist Picasso's innovations depended on a thorough knowledge of earlier art.
