Title: Pablo Picasso, Marlon Brando, Bubbles the chimp: 10 amazing Quincy Jones stories
Full Article: Full TextTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitQuincy Jones is 84 years old and has, at least reported count, 29 Grammy Awards, 22 girlfriends and countless stories concerning nearly every famous person you could mention - including Adolf Hitler. He believes he’ll live until he’s 110, and still spends his days engaged in music (he rates Chance the Rapper, Kendrick Lamarr and Ed Sheeran, but has little time for Taylor Swift ), business (he’s working on a project that purports to be like Netflix, but for old jazz footage) and the dissemination of grade A-level gossip.Most recently, Jones caused a sensation by revealing that he had dated 24-year-old Ivanka Trump (when he was 72) - although he still considers her father ”a crazy m---------. Limited mentally - a megalomaniac, narcissistic”. He also wasted little time in dismissing The Beatles as “The worst musicians in the world.”Jones’s life story - from the poverty-stricken son of a schizophrenic mother and mob-related father to most influential man in pop - has won comparisons to that of fictional character Forrest Gump so often he’s coined his own moniker: “the Ghetto Gump”. Kidada, one of his six daughters of seven children, prefers LL “Loose Lips” QJ. Here are some of his greatest stories.1. Bubbles, Michael Jackson’s chimpanzee, bit Rashida JonesRashida Jones is now known as the Emmy-nominated producer of provocative Netflix documentaries about the porn industry and series regular in comedy Parks and Rec. But she is also Jones’s fifth child (with actress Peggy Lipton, his third wife), and she grew up in his world. In the early 1980s, that meant hanging out with Michael Jackson, whose records helped Jones become a star, and Jackson’s ever-expanding coterie of animals.There was Muscles, the boa constrictor, who terrified Jones when he snaked across the console in the studio and ate Jackson’s parrot - “and here this cat, man, is hanging out of the parrot cage. His mouth is inside, but he just ate the parrot so he couldn't get out of the cage. So he's just hanging there till he digests it,” as Jones recalled - and Bubbles, the King of Pop’s pet chimpanzee. Jones wasn’t a fan: “He was a pain in the ass,” he told GQ. “He bit Rashida. My poor baby."2. Adolf Hitler, and the rest of the Nazis, were fuelled by cocaineEven now, Jones makes no bones about the affection he holds for Leni Riefenstahl, best known for making propaganda films for the Nazis, including the Triumph of the Will. Jones considers her “one of the greatest filmmakers that ever lived” and Riefenstahl was so enamoured with his work that, when he was in Berlin with Nastassja Kinski - his partner in the early Nineties, and mother to his two youngest children - he was invited to dine with her.During that lunch, Jones learned several things, including that she used 211 cameras (“think I'm going to tell Hitler, "One more time, Adolf!"?) and that “everybody in the Third Reich was on cocaine”. The revelation “really hit home” for Jones because he “knew all about her”, and remains convinced that “she was Goebbels’s girlfriend” - although historians attest otherwise.3. Nelson Mandela tried to make him touch a cheetahIn 1997, Jones joined the then-South African President Nelson Mandela on Blue Train, a five-star hotel on rails that had been luxuriously refitted. The super-producer was on a starry guestlist that included Jemima and Imran Khan, Mia Farrow and Naomi Campbell. Whether it was during this trip or an earlier one, Jones didn’t specify, but GQ did print an intriguing aside in their January interview with Jones about “the time Nelson Mandela tried to get him to touch a cheetah”. All we know? That Quincy “couldn’t do it”.4. Tupac dissed him, then proposed to his daughterTupac Shakur & fiancée Kidada Jones. pic.twitter.com/UzNBkoKGPm- boqor riya. (@hausofriya) March 26, 2015In 1993, Tupac Shakur lambasted Jones - not for his musical efforts, but his fondness for marrying and dating white women and “make f----- up kids”. The latter slur became particularly awkward considering that the rapper went on to date, live with and become engaged to his daughter Kidada. He even died in her arms after being shot.It was Rashida, however, who fought her father’s corner, writing a letter addressed to Shakur that read: “Tupac, if you learn one lesson, let it be that at least my father took the time to look at how f----- up life would be if he didn’t get his s--- together early on. I don’t see you ﬁghting for your race. In my opinion, you’re destroying it and s------- all over your people.”Jones remembers the first time Kidada and Shakur met, when the three of them were in a deli. “He was hitting on her… And I went over the back of the seat and did like that on his shoulders: 'Pac!' And then I said, 'Come here, m-------, I've got to talk to you.' And we went and talked, and after that we hugged and made up." Shakur apologised to Jones, and Kidada was smitten. She later described him as “the love of her life”.5. He was nearly killed in the Manson murdersThe devastating attack of Charles Manson’s followers at 10050 Cielo Drive in 1969 shook America. Fifty years later, and the murder of Sharon Tate by the cult is still fascinating Hollywood - three films are being released about the incident in 2019 alone. Jay Sebring, Jones’s hairdresser, was among the victims, and Jones had arranged to meet Steve McQueen at Tate’s home on the evening of the murders to watch a rough cut of Bullitt. But then Jones forgot. The next morning, he received a call from Bill Cosby, who was calling from London to tell Jones that Sebring was dead, along with the other five guests at Tate’s home. Jones’s reaction, looking back over his lucky escape? “That's the Ghetto Gump s---. Life is a trip, man. Life is a trip."6. He enjoyed the Pope’s shoesIt’s worth knowing, at this juncture, that Jones is good friends with Bono. So good, in fact, that Bono lets him stay in his “castle” when he visits Ireland, as the country, along with Scotland, is “so racist it's frightening”. Their friendship is the kind that means that when Bono was invited to meet Pope John Paul, he took Jones along. They both dressed the part, along with “all the guys in the Vatican”, with “Vatican black shoes”. But John Paul? “He had on some burgundy wingtips, man, with thin tan rib socks, man,” Jones told GQ. “When I kissed his hand, I looked down and saw those shoes and it just fell out of my mouth. I said, 'Oh, my man's got some pimp shoes on.' And he heard me."A brief note on Bono and Jones’s relationship, though: while Jones is fond of the U2 frontman, a recent interview with Vulture would suggest he is not a fan of the band’s music.7. Jones and Marlon Brando called each other LeroyJones met Marlon Brando when he was 18. The actor was fresh from A Streetcar Named Desire and was with Sidney Poitier and Harry Belafonte when they bumped into Jones leaving New York jazz club Birdland. Together, they went up to a club in Harlem - Brando was “the only white dude in the whole place” - whereupon Brando approached a group of women and their pimp. He asked one to dance, “he’d dance his ass off”, and then returned the woman to the group.Brando had, however, in a heightened sense of paranoia after smoking a joint. He thought the pimp was looking at him, and went back to say, “Look, I was a gentleman, man, I came and asked you first, man,” to which the pimp replied, “The name ain't ‘man’, it's ‘Leroy’ L-E-R-O-m-----------Y.”As Jones recalled: “at that, Marlon turned around and freaked out. He got paranoid-got outside and ran 15 blocks, nobody after him. So we called each other Leroy till the day he died."The incident didn’t prevent Brando and Jones from enjoying a short lifetime of dancing together, though. Brando would join Jones cha-cha dancing, and offered the producer respite on his island in Tahiti when Jones had a breakdown. Jones also maintains that Brando was an avid bisexual, who would “f--- anything. Anthing! He’d f--- a mailbox. James Baldwin. Richard Pryor. Marvin Gaye.”8. He has 19 mobile phonesFor an octogenarian, Jones prides himself on his comfort with new technology. What he can’t get into, though, is enslavement to the smartphone. When The Guardian asked him, in 2014, if he had “every celebrity’s number on his phone”, Jones replied: “No way. I got 19 of them [mobile phones]. I don’t carry one with me. My security guy handles that. Every minute those suckers go off. It’s the age of cocoonism.”He went on to explain that Apple send him the latest smartphones, but he doesn’t want them, for the valid reason that: “everybody on the f----- planet is sitting at home fiddling with their goddam phones.”9. Frank Sinatra tried to set him up with Marilyn Monroe - and failedSinatra and Quincy met in suitably glitzy surroundings: he arranged a benefit concert by Ol’ Blue Eyes at the invitation of Princess Grace at the Monaco Sporting Club in 1958. By the mid-1960s, Jones was an integral part of the Rat Pack’s musical output, conducting and arranging when they performed with Count Basie in Las Vegas and beyond. They became firm friends: Sinatra called Jones Q, and Jones called Sinatra FS or Francis.As Jones says, “He either loved you with all of his heart or else he'd roll over your ass in a Mack truck in reverse. He was tough, man. I saw all of it.” And “all of it” really was inclusive. Jones recalls: “We'd do one-nighters, I'd fly with him on his Learjet, he said, 'Let's get on the plane before Basie's drummer's cymbal stops ringing.…' Six Playboy bunnies on that."Sinatra showed his affection for Jones by giving him a signet ring that he still wears on his little finger (he can’t take it off), which is stamped with Sinatra’s Sicilian family crest. He also made Jones excellent pasta.Famously, the female company the Rat Pack kept were as famous as they were, including Rita Hayworth. “Frank was always trying to hook me up with Marilyn Monroe,” Jones told GQ “but Marilyn Monroe had a chest that looked like pears, man.”10. He changed the face of ETJones and Steven Spielberg met in the early Eighties, when he was working on Thriller and the director was doing E.T at Laird Studio. Jones remembers “we met and fell in love”, and the pair - with Jackson - went on to create the film’s audiobook and soundtrack album. Spielberg gave Jones a viewfinder used by directors and Jones gave him a synthesizer, and the director also consulted Jones on the first model of E.T.It never reached the big screen because, Jones says, “he looked too much like a brother. That’s why the second one had blue eyes.” Jones also bonded with the other star of E.T: Drew Barrymore: “[She] used to stay at our house,” he said. “I used to hang out with her dad, John Barrymore, in Rome and Copenhagen.”Credit: By Alice Vincent, Entertainment WriterWord count: 1910Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases. Title: Saturday Review: arts: Comic strips and cubism: As the blockbuster Matisse Picasso exhibition nears, Jonathan Jones reveals how Gertrude Stein and a newspaper cartoon called the Katzenjammer Kids pushed Pablo Picasso towards the most revolutionary artistic discovery since the Renaissance
Full Article: AbstractTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndAs [Alice B Toklas] tells it, she and Stein were worried about [Pablo Picasso] and Fernande, his partner in these years, because they had broken up. So they went to see Picasso and Stein gave him a gift: a package of newspapers. "He opened them up, they were the Sunday supplement of American papers, they were the Katzenyammer [sic] kids. Oh oui, Oh oui, he said, his face full of satisfaction, merci thanks [Gertrude Stein], and we left."When we think of Picasso and caricature, it's usually in terms of philistine jibes. "Picasso, the painter," JJ Hunsecker asks his henchman Stanley in The Sweet Smell of Success, "one 's' or two? Item: he dates three-eyed girls." It seems almost blasphemous, crudely debasing, to suggest that what Picasso did when he imaginatively remade the human face was a kind of caricature, with some of the comic energy of a cartoon. But that's what is going on in the Portrait of Gertrude Stein. The face Picasso gives Stein is not unrelated to her real one; it is a heightened graphic game of distortion. She instantly recognised the portrait as authentic.The story of its making is part of modernism's folklore. Stein sat for Picasso again and again, but in the end he set it aside, saying he couldn't get the head right. "I can"t see you any more when I look," he said irritably, she remembered. Everybody went away, the Steins to Italy, he to Spain. What it was he saw there - ancient Iberian art or the desiccated faces of peasants - has been debated, but something changed. Back in Paris, relates Stein, "Picasso sat down and out of his head painted the head in without having seen Gertrude Stein again. And when she saw it he and she were content." [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hit'It is very difficult now that everybody is accustomed to everything," wrote Gertrude Stein, looking back on her first encounter with Pablo Picasso and Henri Matisse, "to give some idea of the uneasiness one felt when one first looked at these pictures on these walls." She wrote that in 1933 when there was still some way to go in the domestication of modern art. Today, as we prepare to queue for the exhibition Matisse Picasso opening next month at Tate Modern, her words ring all too true. Everybody is accustomed to everything, and modernism is the lingua franca.Yet if anyone can make us see modern art as if for the first time, it is Stein, modernist writer, cubism's headiest chronicler, and the subject of this art movement's founding masterpiece, Picasso's 1906 Portrait of Gertrude Stein. In a sense, she is the missing third name in Matisse Picasso, because she and her art- collector brother Leo introduced Picasso to the more established Matisse.But it was Picasso who really caught Stein's imagination. They shared a raw, violent energy, a more guttural sensibility than Matisse. Gertrude and Pablo were unlikely friends: she a German- Jewish lesbian American heiress, he an Andalusian tough guy with a reputation for putting his women first on, then under, a pedestal. But they shared a truly modern sensibility.This needs to be asserted - because Stein gets a bad press. Anyone who blows their own trumpet as loudly as she did is bound to make enemies, even beyond the grave. Stein was the Oscar Wilde of the Paris modern movement - a flawed but brilliant writer, but even more, a larger-than-life personality with a flair for self- promotion. To read The Autobiography of Alice B Toklas, the memoir purportedly written by her lover that made Stein a star, you would think - in fact she says outright - that she and Picasso dreamt up the modern movement between them, with Matisse hovering in the background.She exaggerated. But a lot of male memoirists and biographers went to great lengths to belittle her. Ernest Hemingway was Stein's literary protege in Paris in the 1920s - she coined the name "Lost Generation" for Hemingway and his contemporaries. In his memoirs, Hemingway titles his chapter on her Miss Stein Instructs, and damns her writing with faint praise.To be fair, Hemingway helped get Stein published, but he owed more than he admitted to the harsh rhythms and mythic American scope that Stein encompassed. Her writing, particularly Three Lives, published in 1909, and The Autobiography of Alice B Toklas, is far more readable than caricature has it; there is a line that connects her novel The Making of Americans with Pynchon's Gravity's Rainbow.In his biography of Picasso, John Richardson repeats Hemingway's charge that Stein was indisciplined as a writer. This becomes an excuse to belittle her as any kind of intellectual influence on Picasso. Stressing factual inaccuracies in The Autobiography of Alice B Toklas, Richardson dismisses the fact that she was taught by the philosopher and psychologist William James, claiming she inflated James's fondness of her.Maybe - but the intellectual connection between James, Stein and modernism is real. James (himself influenced by the French philosopher Henri Bergson) argued that experience is falsely parcelled into discrete moments and objects by "intellectualist" philosophers, when in reality experience is continuous: one part of our life slides into another. It was James who coined the term "stream of consciousness" which, through Stein, became the definition of modernist writing as practised by her, as well as by James Joyce and Virginia Woolf.And there is another important modernist influence that Stein shared with Picasso: American comics. Many books have been written about the intellectual origins of Picasso's Cubism. Ancient Iberian sculptures, African masks, the philosophy of Bergson and even - although they knew nothing at the time of each other's work - Einstein's theory of relativity all help to understand the revolutionary transformation of visual experience that Picasso initiated in Paris in the years before the first world war.But as Stein relates in The Autobiography of Alice B Toklas, there was another visual influence on which Picasso fed voraciously when she first knew him in Paris in 1906, when he was pushing towards the most revolutionary artistic discovery since the Renaissance: a comic strip called The Katzenjammer Kids.As Alice tells it, she and Stein were worried about Picasso and Fernande, his partner in these years, because they had broken up. So they went to see Picasso and Stein gave him a gift: a package of newspapers. "He opened them up, they were the Sunday supplement of American papers, they were the Katzenyammer [sic] kids. Oh oui, Oh oui, he said, his face full of satisfaction, merci thanks Gertrude, and we left."Next they went to see Fernande, who asked if Stein had any American comics left. But Picasso had got the lot of the Katzenjammer kids. "That is a brutality that I will never forgive him," said Fernande.Next to the masks, next to what philosophy Picasso may have picked up, we have to consider as a visual influence that he voraciously consumed Hans and Fritz Katzenjammer, the disruptive twin sons of German immigrant Mamma Katzenjammer, who first appeared in the Sunday comic supplement of the New York Journal in 1897.It was owned by William Randolph Hearst, who hired the artist Rudolf Dirks to create a cartoon for Sundays. The Katzenjammer Kids revolutionised newspaper cartoons, using speech bubbles systematically for the first time, as well as the strip format and colour. It is still recognisably modern. Above all, it was outrageous, especially in its use of street language, mocking German immigrants - then a particularly poor community of lower east side New York.Hans and Fritz torment Mamma, her live-in sea dog companion Der Captain and the school disciplinarian Der Inspector, all of whom speak in parody German accents. "We are playing circus - you be der clown Ma," say the kids. It's hard to think what Picasso made of the words, but it's easy to see why Stein was a fan. She was born to German- Jewish parents in Pennsylvania, and the cartoon reflects the German ethnicity she often emphasises in her writing, such as her story The Good Anna, about a servant "of solid lower middle-class south German stock" whose awkward use of English she comically relishes.And Picasso and Stein had plenty of time to discuss comics and the ideas of William James and Henri Bergson in the stream of consciousness shared by painter and sitter during the 80 or 90 sessions when he worked on her portrait in the winter of 1905-6.Picasso's Portrait of Gertrude Stein is one of his most astonishing, hypnotically disruptive works. It began as a traditional painting, almost a return to convention after the poetic symbolist experiments of Picasso's blue and rose periods. There is a massive insistence on the concentrated reality of Stein; her body is hunched over in her chair, as if caught in mid-speech, as if she were expounding.But something happens in this painting, something weird, inexplicable. Stein's face is not painted realistically like the rest of her body. It is a dry, stony, geometric mask that seems to have been fixed under her flesh, or to have magically grown out of her skull. It is a cartoonish effect, because this is not a case - as in some of the figures in Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, which Picasso painted the following year - of putting an African mask in place of someone's face. If anything, it is more troubling. Here the mask is flesh. It has the same colour as Stein's realistic hands and there is no disjunction between it and her neck. It is portrayed as flesh, but twisted, reconfigured. And that takes us back to the Katzenjammer Kids.When we think of Picasso and caricature, it's usually in terms of philistine jibes. "Picasso, the painter," JJ Hunsecker asks his henchman Stanley in The Sweet Smell of Success, "one 's' or two? Item: he dates three-eyed girls." It seems almost blasphemous, crudely debasing, to suggest that what Picasso did when he imaginatively remade the human face was a kind of caricature, with some of the comic energy of a cartoon. But that's what is going on in the Portrait of Gertrude Stein. The face Picasso gives Stein is not unrelated to her real one; it is a heightened graphic game of distortion. She instantly recognised the portrait as authentic.The story of its making is part of modernism's folklore. Stein sat for Picasso again and again, but in the end he set it aside, saying he couldn't get the head right. "I can"t see you any more when I look," he said irritably, she remembered. Everybody went away, the Steins to Italy, he to Spain. What it was he saw there - ancient Iberian art or the desiccated faces of peasants - has been debated, but something changed. Back in Paris, relates Stein, "Picasso sat down and out of his head painted the head in without having seen Gertrude Stein again. And when she saw it he and she were content."As much as anything perhaps it was the distorted, vibrant, violent, grotesque, fantastically modern graphic world of American newspaper comics that helped Picasso break out of every convention of continuity in art, that helped him paint a portrait that is a cartoon, but with gravitas. It was also, surely, a sense that subjectivity, the free flow of perception, mattered more than objective appearances; the stream of consciousness as described by James, a faith in the contingent feel of things. Picasso feels this, remembers this as Stein's face; it is the head in his head after not seeing her for a while, not the objective truth, but the truth as he experiences it.This insistence on the complicatedly personal nature of experience is totally at odds with the western pictorial tradition that begins in the Renaissance with the Florentine idea of single- point perspective.Renaissance painting and the pictorial tradition that followed sees the world as a recessive, objectively real picture, a model of the world that is a useful fiction but absolutely at odds with the flow of experience as it is insisted on by modernism. In the Portrait of Gertrude Stein, the picture breaks in two. Later in that same year of 1906, Picasso develops the caricatural mask in his own Self-Portrait, to be shown in Matisse Picasso at Tate Modern.From these two works, he develops to his sensational sexual phantasmagoria, Les Demoiselles d'Avignon. These paintings inaugurate a new experience of the world, one we still find it difficult to acknowledge because we still simplify things into pictures for our convenience. The richer sense of life embodied in Picasso's art is still subversive, still has something to show us. Cubism is one thing we will never be entirely accustomed to, and that's why, for many of us, it will always be easy to choose between the two greatest artists of the 20th century."Matisse and all the others saw . . . the reality of the 19th century," said Stein. "Picasso was the one in painting who saw the twentieth century . . ."Matisse Picasso is at Tate Modern, London SW1 (020-7887 8008), from May 11 to August 18. Title: Abstract
What does it take to live in the shadow of Pablo Picasso?
Full Article: Full TextTranslateUndo Translation Learn more about TranslateFromSelect language...ArabicChinese (Simplified)Chinese (Traditional)CzechDanishEnglishFinnishFrenchGerman HebrewIndonesianItalianJapaneseKoreanPolishPortugueseRussianSpanishSwedishTurkishTo TranslateTranslation in progress... [[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.CancelOverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation| Jump to first hitTHIS is how it goes, his grandson says. A man falls in love with a woman. He is an artist. She inspires him, becomes his muse. He paints her over and over again.And then the inspiration is used up. He goes seeking another. The relationship is not as important as the paintings. “The man and the artist are one person in the case of Pablo Picasso,” his grandson says. “He put the art first.”It is Wednesday morning in New York. Later today Olivier Widmaier Picasso will fly to Edinburgh for an appearance at the Edinburgh International Book Festival. Yesterday he went and sat in the Museum of Modern Art and watched the people coming to look at one of his grandfather’s most famous paintings, Les Demoiselles d’Avignon, painted more than a century ago but still holding a huge pull for art lovers.Indeed, it is hard to think of another name in modern art that is more resonant than Picasso. Between 2017 and next year there will be 42 exhibitions mounted of his work. And that’s just in Europe. Quite frankly, Picasso is modern art.But what did that mean for those who share his surname? Those who grew up in the shadow of his legend?Widmaier Picasso, a TV producer in his day job, has written a book, Picasso An Intimate Portrait that attempts to answer those questions.In it, he talks about Picasso the artist, his political beliefs and his financialdealings. But at heart it is the story of Picasso and the women he loved and the families (plural) he created. In life as in art Picasso, his grandson suggests, was avant garde.Much of the story is tragic. There were costs to belonging to the tribe of Picasso and some struggled with the legacy.Widmaier Picasso’s grandmother Marie-Therese was one of them. She met Picasso in 1927. He was married to Olga Khokhlova at the time. Marie-Therese became Picasso’s lover and muse. They had a daughter together, Maya, Widmaier Picasso’s mother.And then Picasso met Dora Maar and soon Marie-Therese and Dora were competing for the artist’s attention.Widmaier Picasso says: “Marie-Therese was the sensual inspiration and Dora Maar was the intellectual stimulation.”Growing up, Widmaier Picasso never met his grandfather. His mother never visited because she feared being turned away at the gate of his estate. But over the years his grandson found it impossible to escape the legacy of his grandfather. It was the same for all of those children who inherited the Picasso name.“I would say it’s not easy to live next to Picasso,” he says.“You are just waiting for your cheque or a word or attention. Or you live without Picasso, which is not possible because at some point someone will know that you are the grandson or the granddaughter of someone special.“You have 90 per cent of your life influenced by history, by his legacy, his fame, and 10% you can save as your own life.”And not everyone can live with that. In the end Widmaier Picasso’s own grandmother committed suicide, as didPicasso’s second wife Jacqueline and Widmaier Picasso’s cousin, Pablito.“For my grandmother life after Picasso was not so exciting. She was not in need of anything. She was probably tired. The same for Jacqueline.”His cousin Pablito’s situation was different. He was 24 when he died, shortly after Picasso himself passed away. He drank a bottle of bleach having been turned away at the gate of Picasso’s house in Mougins.Pablito’s death was a result of a “kind of despair,” Widmaier Picasso suggests. “It has been said he was on drugs, that he was depressed,” he points out. But, really, he wonders, if the problem was the fact that his cousin shared the same name as his grandfather.“It was a huge mistake, a huge mistake. You cannot be Pablo Picasso after Pablo Picasso. It is impossible.”Picasso’s life is a story of destruction as much as creation then.“He was not the man he should have been or the grandfather he should have been,” Widmaier Picasso acknowledges. “But he had too much to do outside of the family.“I feel a bit uncomfortable when I say ‘my grandfather.’ I have to share him with the rest of the world.”Olivier Widmaier Picasso appears at the Edinburgh International Book Festival this morning at 11am. His book Picasso An Intimate Portrait is published by Tate Publishing, priced £30.CREDIT: Teddy JamiesonWord count: 745Show lessYou have requested "on-the-fly" machine translation of selected content from our databases.
